Onset Tender Offer
LEAD: The Onset Corporation, an acquisition company formed by the New York investment firms J. H. Whitney &amp; Company and Welsh, Carson, Anderson &amp; Stone, raised its tender offer by 50 cents a share for the Decision Industries Corporation, to $11 a share.
Under its new bid, which was accepted by Decision, Onset said it would defer the merger until April 29; the deal had been scheduled to take place immediately after its tender offer succeeded.


Orders Rise A Weak 0.1% At Factories
LEAD: Orders to the nation's factories edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent in November, the weakest showing in three months, the Commerce Department said today.


Canada Bans Most Seal Kills After Big Protests in Europe
LEAD: Canada has banned all offshore commercial hunting of white-coated baby harp seals and blueback hooded seals after European threats of trade reprisals and reduced demand for seal pelts.


McPherson Tired After Busy Month
LEAD: His performance this season, much like his taste in clothes, has been virtually impeccable.
Recently, however, Don McPherson has shown signs of wear: a loose thread here and there against Boston College, a wrinkled crease against West Virginia, a generally rumpled look since early December, when the Syracuse quarterback became one of the more publicized runners-up in the history of the balloting for the Heisman


Rainier Sells Unit
LEAD: Rainier National Bank, whose $1.2 billion acquisition by the Security Pacific Corporation became final three months ago, said it had agreed to sell its leasing operation to a unit of the First City Trust Company of Vancouver, British Columbia.
Terms were not disclosed.
The operation has assets of $160 million and in the first nine months of 1987 earned $2.2 million.

Shareholders Fight Shoe-Town Plan
LEAD: Shoe-Town Inc., a specialty retail store chain, said certain shareholders had asked Delaware's Court of Chancery to stop its $103 million tender offer to take the company private.
An investment group including Shoe-Town managers began the formal offer to buy shares at $9.75 each on Dec. 21.

Two Ways to Reduce Underage Drinking
LEAD: To the Editor:


300,000 Celebrators Jam Times Square
LEAD: Despite threats of snow and sleet, more than 300,000 New Years revelers jammed Times Square last night to watch the traditional lowering of the ball on 1987.


Court Rules On Monet Ownership
LEAD: A 19th-century French impressionist painting by Monet that vanished from a German castle during World War II belongs to the Manhattan woman who bought it 30 years ago -not the original owner, a Federal appeals court ruled yesterday.


How Goes Ozone War?
LEAD: Friends of the Earth, a Washington-based environmental group, is at it again in its role as guardian of the earth's ozone shield.


A Neikrug Premiere
LEAD: The violinist Shlomo Mintz will be guest soloist with the Cleveland Orchestra in the New York premiere of a violin concerto by Marc Neikrug, Jan. 26 at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall.
The piece was commissioned for Mr.
Mintz by the Houston Symphony, with which he first played it in 1984.
The Cleveland Orchestra will be conducted by Christoph von Dohnanyi.


Stymied Conrail Officer Resigns
LEAD: Stuart M. Reed, Conrail's president and chief operating officer since 1979, resigned yesterday after being passed over as designated successor to the chief executive.
The top job is expected to become vacant at the end of 1988 when L. Stanley Crane retires.


Drug Manufacturer Recalls Cold Syrups, Citing Health Risks
LEAD: Several brands of an over-the-counter cold medicine are being recalled because they may be mislabeled and might contain a potent tranquilizer, the Food and Drug Administration said today.


A Tranquil New Year's Eve in the Capital
LEAD: On a cold, but not-too-cold day (mid 40's) in the nation's capital, seagulls perched on a frozen section of the Tidal Basin, within view of the Jefferson Memorial.
Like this scene, Washingon, too, was quiet. (NYT/Paul Hosefros)

Soviet Attack Is Seen as Move in Afghan Peace Bid
LEAD: A Soviet-backed military drive to lift the guerrilla siege of an Afghan garrison town is intended to strengthen Afghanistan's Communist Government in peace talks, Reagan Administration officials and other analysts say.


A NEW YEAR'S STROLL AMONG THE SIGHTS AND DELIGHTS AT MANHATTAN'S TIP
LEAD: IT was a cold, brisk New Year's morning, and the sun, which had started to warm lower Manhattan on the East River, had not yet surmounted the skyscraper barricade that still shadowed the West Side, where City Stroller gingerly sat on a waterside bench in Battery Park City feeling his teeth chattering like jackhammers tearing up Broadway.

Gordon, the club's patriarch, clearly wasted no time in proposing a return engagement.


Vietnam Children of Americans Reach Thailand on Way to U.S.
LEAD: Sixty-five children and young adults fathered by Americans during the Vietnam War arrived here today with 91 relatives on their way to the United States under a resettlement program stalled for nearly two years.

USX Expects Charge Tied to Oil Price Drop
LEAD: The USX Corporation said today that it expects to take a charge against fourth-quarter earnings to reflect the decline in value of oil inventories at its Marathon Oil Company subsidiary.


Court Won't Bar Return of Boy In Abuse Case to Zimbabwe
LEAD: A New York State appeals panel ruled yesterday that state courts may not block the forcible return to Zimbabwe of a 9-year-old boy whose father, a Zimbabwean official with diplomatic immunity, is accused of brutally beating him at their Queens home.


Truck Carrying Nuclear Wastes Overturns
LEAD: A technician checking containers of low-level nuclear wastes for radiation leaks after a truck carrying them overturned yesterday near the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Washington State.
Officials said the driver, two police officers who responded to the accident and motorists who stopped at the scene were being checked for radiation.


Buckeyes Meet Cooper
LEAD: The official hiring of John Cooper as head football coach at Ohio State yesterday ended six weeks of uncertainty for the Buckeye players.

Sheriff Reconstructs the Murders of 16
LEAD: The man suspected of one of America's worst mass murders probably began slaughtering 16 people by stealthily strangling his sleeping children on Christmas Eve, according to the sheriff investigating the slayings.


Subsidy to Industry
LEAD: To the Editor:


Seagram Bid Is Set Back
LEAD: An offer by Seagram &amp; Company of Canada to acquire a 40.1 percent stake in the French cognac producer Martell &amp; Compagnie from the Martell family failed to follow normal procedures for takeover bids, the Paris Stock Exchange regulatory body said today.


Stock Markups Seen in London
LEAD: The London Stock Exchange said that it was investigating allegations that some market makers marked up share prices on Christmas Eve to win personal bets on the closing level of a stock index.


Hollings Says He Originated Murdoch Curb
LEAD: Senator Ernest F. Hollings, an outspoken critic of consolidation within the communications industry, said yesterday that he originated legislation ''aimed directly'' at barring Rupert Murdoch's continued ownership of The New York Post and The Boston Herald while he owns television stations in those cities.


The Dance: Nikolais's 'Imago'
LEAD: ''IMAGO'' was hailed, on its premiere in 1963, as the last word in the kind of multimedia theater-dance practiced by Alwin Nikolais.
The dance started life as a full-evening work that explored ways movement, light and sound affect each other.
Subtitled ''The City Curious,'' the piece also seemed to allude to the busy and mysterious pace of urban life.


Letter: On Finance; Public Power Is a State Concern
LEAD: To the Editor:


Benefits Disparity Made Issue in Iowa
LEAD: With single-minded persistence, elderly Iowans who describe themselves as victims of a quirk in the Social Security law have emerged as a significant force in the state's Presidential politics.


Raeburn Van Buren; Drew Daily Comic Strip
LEAD: Raeburn Van Buren, a cartoonist and illustrator, died Tuesday at North Shore Community Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., after suffering an injury in a fall.
He was 96 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.


Vito Acconci's Art of Opposition and Provocation
LEAD: VITO ACCONCI may be avant-garde in a rather old-fashioned sense.
He has always made art that is an affront to conventional behavior (esthetic or otherwise), that is not too viable in the commercial sense and that is often all the more off-putting for the way it implicates the viewer in its machinations.

LEAD:  Friday


Rangers' Burst Fells Nordiques
LEAD: It is a night generally remembered for the significant seconds leading up to midnight.
For the Rangers, no matter how extravagant their individual New Year's Eve celebrations, it was going to be hard to top the memorable couple of minutes they enjoyed last night slightly after 9 P.M.


Sounds Around Town
LEAD: Kindred on Saxophone Bob Kindred Quartet, at Red Blazer Too, 349 West 46th Street (262-3112).
The spirit of the great tenor-saxophonist Ben Webster is kept alive in the playing of Bob Kindred, who frequently shows his deep admiration for Webster not by copying him but by building on the emotion and intelligence that Webster brought to his performances.


The 'Uprising' Fires Palestinian Pride
LEAD: ''It's miserable,'' said Asmaa Khroob, summing up life in the Balata refugee district, a grim warren of dirt streets, open sewers and low concrete-block houses.


Harry Green, Lawyer, 94
LEAD: Harry Green, a retired New Jersey lawyer, died of heart failure Monday at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center.
He was 94 years old and lived in Los Angeles, where he moved in 1986.


30 Reported Killed by Tamils in Sri Lanka
LEAD: Ethnic Tamil militants killed at least 30 Moslems in eastern Sri Lanka on Wednesday in revenge for the deaths of six comrades killed by Moslem fundamentalists, two communities said today.


Free Trade by Phone
LEAD: For the signing of their historic free trade agreement tomorrow, President Reagan and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada are planning a little telephone conversation around 4 P.M. and separate ''photo opportunities.''


Football Hero Keeps Warm and Shuns Memories
LEAD: Sunshine pours in a large picture window of the house.
Outside, in a chill breeze that ruffles their gray feathers, two sandhill cranes, visitors from nearby Lake Weohyakapka, stand like frozen sentinels on the lawn.
Their beady eyes beneath a tufted crown of bright red feathers dart back and forth, betraying no secrets.

Pinafore'' tonight at 8, tomorrow at 3 and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street.
Tickets are $15 to $25, with a $5 discount for children and the elderly.
Information: 864-5400.

LEAD: Blasius Industries said that it intends to wage a proxy fight for control of the Atlas Corporation.

Economic Scene; Seeking a Course For the New Year
LEAD: THE year 1987 ended on a downbeat.
The dollar, on the last day of the year, fell to record lows of about 121 yen and 156 West German marks.
In the stock market, by no coincidence, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 11.27 points.
Worries about recession were rife, intensified by the sharpest fall in the leading economic indicators since 1981.

Indoor Lacrosse Starting Up
LEAD: They are being paid $150 a game, but they say that, for the pleasure of competition, they would play for nothing.
There are 25 of them, mostly Long Islanders who learned to love the game at Sewanhaka High or Levittown or Manhasset.


'Junk Dances' Originators Reminisce
LEAD: It was 23 years ago that two youngsters performed together in a new work called ''Junk Dances.'' It was a popular and critical success.
The stars of the piece - Murray Louis and Phyllis Lamhut - soon went on their separate ways to become even more deft comedians and dancers, as well as modern dance choreographers with distinctive gifts.


Haig Leaves Hospital
LEAD: Former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was released from a hospital early today after an overnight stay for treatment of an allergic reaction to drugs he had taken for a tooth problem. ''They gave him a clean bill of health,'' said a spokesman for Fairfax Hospital, Lon Walls.
Mr.
Haig, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, had been treated Wednesday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center for an abscessed tooth.

Prices of Precious Metals Show a Moderate Increase
LEAD: Precious metals futures posted moderate advances yesterday, but analysts said the gains were more subdued than they would have otherwise expected in view of new declines in the slumping dollar.

Correction
LEAD: A picture caption in Sports Pages yesterday with the New Year's Day bowl preview misidentified the Miami player.
He was Melvin Bratton.

LEAD: Pat Robertson's well-heeled Presidential campaign adjusted its financial course again today by agreeing to accept $4.5 million in Federal matching funds.
But it pledged to put the money in escrow while Mr.
Robertson decides whether to keep it or try to give it back.


No Decision By Robins
LEAD: The board of the A. H. Robins Company will meet today to continue its review of three takeover offers, and a company spokesman said a decision to accept one of them was expected early in the day.

LEAD: It seems only yesterday that America celebrated its Bicentennial.
Yet it was 12 whole years ago, and by the same measure the 21st century is tomorrow - just 12 years hence.
Foresighted earthlings will start now to get ready.

LEAD: For the last five seasons, Connecticut has been a sore spot for the image-conscious Big East.
The Huskies were like a blighted part of the city tourists never see or an offbeat relative visitors never meet.

LEAD: Two comedy shows - featuring individual comics and the First Amendment Comedy and Improvisation Company - will be offered this weekend at 2 Bond Street, between Broadway and Lafayette Street.
Tonight at 10:30, there will be appearances by four comedians - Bill Torres, Mike King, Judy Gold and Liz Wolynski.


Prices Paid to Farmers Fell by 3% in December
LEAD: The prices that farmers received for raw products declined 3 percent in December, from the November average, the Agriculture Department said today.


Alexis Smith
LEAD:  The Brooklyn Museum 200 Eastern Parkway Through Jan. 11 Alexis Smith is a California artist who emerged in the mid-1970's as part of the narrative or story-art phenomenon, a more talkative, less hermetic branch of Conceptual art.
Ms.
Smith's metier is a collage-like installation that, using film stills, bits of printed matter, small found objects and quotations from fiction, tells tales in visual terms.


The Law on 'Excludable Aliens': Stay Tuned
LEAD: While the President's signature on a bill usually certifies the end of the legislative process, that was not the case last week when President Reagan signed a bill removing ideology as a ground for excluding foreigners from entry into the United States.


Correction
LEAD: An article yesterday about a dispute between the developer Sam LeFrak and Jersey City officials misidentified his development in Jersey City.
The development is Newport; its shopping mall is Newport Center.


Closings Today
LEAD: Stock and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of New Year's Day.


BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JANUARY 1, 1988
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL  The dollar ended a bleak year on a bleak note, falling to new lows against the yen and the mark.
Trading was very light.
The drop came despite what dealers said was a fourth straight day of buying dollars by the central banks of Japan, West Germany and Switzerland.
For the second consecutive year, the dollar recorded the dubious distinction of falling to its lowest levels of the year on the year's last day.


Rescue the Future, at Birth
LEAD: ''Social dynamite'' is one way to define poor children who lack education and sound parental supervision. ''Overwhelmed'' is a way to define poor mothers who lack education and self-esteem.
How to help the children and the mothers is a question that can overwhelm, too - so much that it may induce paralysis even among the most well meaning.

LEAD: Betty Ford was reported doing well today after unexpected surgery to repair sutures from a heart operation last month, and she was expected to remain hospitalized for about two more days.

Smoking Ban on Jet Stirs Unruly Protest And Police Response
LEAD: Passengers enraged by an airline's smoking ban on a cross-country flight earlier this week lit up anyway and shoved attendants who asked them to stop, and the pilot radioed for the police, the authorities said today.


Parker Hannifin Renews Gull Bid
LEAD: The Parker Hannifin Corporation, which last week dropped its bid for Gull Inc., an aviation equipment maker, said that Gull had agreed to a lower price and the offer would again proceed.
The Cleveland-based Parker Hannifin, which makes fluid power systems, said that under the new agreement each Gull shareholder would receive 0.55 of a Parker Hannifin share.

LEAD: NO sooner is Willie Nelson released from jail after serving 20 years for trying to rob a train, than he gets together that old gang of his and goes off to try to rob a train again.
He knows that an ex-Texas Ranger, Richard Widmark, who stopped him the first time, will be out to get him again, with that old gang of his.


Tighter AIDS Precautions Urged in Labs
LEAD: Scientists and technicians who work with the AIDS virus have been warned in a new report to take more precautions when working with the virus to avoid the chance of infection.


Fines for 70 Players
LEAD: Danny White and Daryle Smith of the Dallas Cowboys and Dexter Manley and Neal Olkewicz of the Washington Redskins were among 70 players from the two teams fined a total of about $30,000 by the National Football League for their part in a brawl late in their game Dec. 13.
The melee started with the four players, but 30 to 35 players from each team ran onto the field and each was fined at least $400 for joining the fight.

The Chancellor Search Goes Haywire
LEAD: New York City's Board of Education appears on the verge of a mistake.
Acting under pressure from borough presidents and the teachers' union, it has decided to consider Dr.
Bernard Gifford, a candidate rejected by the board's own search committee.
Such political intervention inevitably would handicap any chancellor it produces.


SHARP OZONE DROP FOUND WORLDWIDE IN 8-YEAR PERIOD
LEAD: The atmosphere's protective shield of ozone ebbed rapidly from 1979 through 1986, not just over Antarctica, where the depletion has been sharpest, but over nearly the whole globe, researchers said yesterday.


Dow Off 11.27 to End Year at 1,938.83
LEAD: The stock market ended a frustrating but record-filled year with the Dow Jones industrial average giving up 11.27 points yesterday to close at 1,938.83.
That left the Dow down 60.84 points for the week and only 42.88 points, or 2.26 percent, above its 1986 close of 1,895.95.

LEAD: Paul Coffey, the speedy defenseman for the Pittsburgh Penguins, will miss at least two more games with a knee injury he suffered two days before Christmas when he collided with Don Koharski, the referee, during a Penguins-Devils game in Pittsburgh.

LEAD: Rex Chapman scored 13 of Kentucky's final 16 points tonight as the Wildcats rallied to beat Vanderbilt, 81-74, in the Southeastern Conference opener for both teams.


Taiwan Trade Surplus
LEAD: Taiwan will record a 1987 trade surplus of at least $18.7 billion (American), the Board of Foreign Trade said today.
The board's director, Vincent Siew, said that Taiwan's exports were expected to total $53.5 billion and imports $34.8 billion in 1987 compared with exports of $39.8 billion and imports of $24.2 billion in 1986.

Jets for Northwest
LEAD: Northwest Airlines Inc. has agreed to buy three more B-757 aircraft from the Boeing Company for an undisclosed amount.
Northwest, a subsidiary of NWA Inc., also said it had accelerated deliveries of two B-757's ordered previously.
The aircraft are to be delivered in the second half of 1988.
The aircraft will seat 184 passengers each and will expand Northwest's B-757 fleet to 33.

Patricia E. Roberts, Landscape Designer, 77
LEAD: Patricia Easterbrook Roberts, a landscape designer and author, died of cancer Sunday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital.
She was 77 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.


Harcourt Brace Units Are Sold
LEAD: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. completed the sale of its business periodicals, trade-show and school-supply distribution companies to a group of investors for $334.1 million.
The sale was part of Harcourt Brace's restructuring, undertaken to fight a takeover by the British publisher Robert Maxwell.


More Selfless Resolutions
LEAD: Making resolutions for other people last New Year's had mixed results.
I didn't have to worry about keeping my own, which was a relief, but not many of them lived up to the obligation.
Maybe I can do better this time.
Here are some suggestions:


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Circle K Corp., Phoenix, an operator of convenience stores, appointed Larry J. Zine executive vice president of finance and chief financial officer.
He replaces Bill J. Farmer, who resigned to pursue other interests.


Holly Sugar Bid Increased
LEAD: The Holly Sugar Company, which agreed to be acquired by the Imperial Sugar Company on Christmas Eve, said today that Imperial had increased the cash portion of its offer from $105 a share to $108.


Title to Santos
LEAD: When Jose Santos won his third race of the day aboard Jane's Dilemma yesterday in the $90,150 Display Handicap, Aqueduct's year-end feature, he earned a spot in the national money winner's circle for 1987.

LEAD: Jump-off, as the major called it, was at 5 A.M., and the heavily armed policemen in their fatigue uniforms clattered from a dozen jeeps and fanned out through the narrow alleyways of the sleeping slum.

Tales of 1987: Strikers, Dogs And U.F.O.'s
LEAD: The Our Towns reporter pauses to glance back at a few tales from the old year:


Motel Burns; 50 Guests Forced to Leave
LEAD: Firefighters examining the burned remains of a section of the Towne and Campus Motor Lodge in Union, N.J.
Fire started in an adjacent lumberyard.
No injuries were reported among firefighters or the 50 guests. (NYT/John Sotomayor)


Federal Programs Assisting New York City's Housing Needs
LEAD: To the Editor:


Music From A Crossroads Of Cultures
LEAD: A FEW centuries ago, Bukhara was a Central Asian hot spot.
An ancient city on the silk route between China and the West, just north of present-day Iran and Afghanistan, Bukhara developed a cosmopolitan culture of the Near and Far East.
Its traditions drew from Persia, from nomadic Turkic tribes that wandered the steppes, from the bustle of trading cities and the calm of mountain villages; its music was shaped by classical Sufi poets and generations of Jewish court musicians.


DOLLAR SETS LOWS IN SPITE OF BUYING BY CENTRAL BANKS
LEAD: The dollar ended a bleak year on a bleak note yesterday, falling to new lows against the Japanese yen and the West German mark.
Trading was very light.


Federal Workers Get Raises
LEAD: President Reagan, secluded at a private estate for a New Year's celebration, signed an executive order today that grants a 2 percent pay increase to 4.3 million military and civilian Federal workers.

NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JANUARY 1, 1988
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL/2-4


When the Campus Is the Corporation's Servant
LEAD: To the Editor:


A Free Insider Tip
LEAD: After all the hysteria generated by stock market fluctuations during the last three months, my Super Bowl stock theory has triumphed for the 21st consecutive year, indicating that some order still exists in the financial universe.


Colombia Frees Drug Figure, Provoking American Anger
LEAD: A Colombian reputed to be one of the world's leading cocaine smugglers has been freed from a Colombian prison, prompting angry criticism today by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and the State Department.


Leo Steiner, 48, Owner of a Deli; Known for Wit
LEAD: Leo Steiner, co-owner of the Carnegie Deli, who was renowned for his celebrated corned beef as well as his cornball kosher humor, died of complications from a brain tumor yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan.
He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan.


A Brokerage Sues Drexel
LEAD: A lawyer for a Santa Monica, Calif., brokerage firm said today that his client had filed suit against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and its ''junk bond'' expert, Michael Milken, seeking $200 million in damages and contending that 10,000 transactions had been mishandled since 1980.


N.C.A.A. Mark For Long Game
LEAD: When Clarkson defeated Colgate, 7-6, Wednesday night on a goal 9 minutes 28 seconds into the game's fourth overtime, the teams set a National Collegiate Athletic Association record for the longest hockey game.


Auctions
LEAD: Art and antiques collectors will long remember 1987 as a banner year for auctions.
It saw world records toppled with the sales of two van Gogh paintings, a Bugatti automobile, a Mozart manuscript, a Stradivarius, a Gutenberg Old Testament, Charlie Chaplin's hat and cane and Babe Ruth's locker tag.


The Supreme Court and the National Will
LEAD: To the Editor:


A.T.&amp; T. in Rate Cut Today; 3.5% Drop Exceeds Estimate
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it would lower its rates for interstate long-distance calls by an average of 3.5 percent on New Year's Day, a larger reduction than expected.


A First For Irish, Aggies
LEAD: Notre Dame will make its fifth appearance today in the Cotton Bowl (Channel 2, 1:30 P.M.), hoping to salvage a promising season that was all but ruined by Miami.


Tokyo Starts Dollar's Drop
LEAD: In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell to a record low yesterday for the 11th time in 17 trading days, closing down 1.50 yen at 122.00 yen.
Later, in London, the dollar was quoted still lower at 121.25 yen.


Judge, Backing Blacks' Case, Orders Vote in Georgia Town
LEAD: A Federal district judge today ordered officials to conduct Monday's scheduled election in the predominantly black town of Keysville, rejecting a state judge's ruling that the town's boundaries were too indistinct to hold a legal election.


Two in Track Honored
LEAD: The New York Track Writers Association yesterday voted Ben Johnson of Canada and Heike Drechsler of East Germany as the outstanding athletes of the 1987 indoor season.


North Beach Journal; The Nightclub Where It All Began Imposes an End on a Topless Era
LEAD: Most of the topless clubs that lined Broadway Street in the North Beach section are gone, maybe because of competition from X-rated home videos, maybe just because times change and it became no big deal to watch people dance with approximately no clothes on.


Cordero Recovering
LEAD: Angel Cordero Jr., the jockey who is thoroughbred racing's second-leading career money winner with more than $121 million, was transferred from the intensive-care unit to a private room at Arcadia Methodist Hospital in California yesterday.


Rio Journal; As '88 Dawns, Brazil Is Spellbound
LEAD: As evening fell tonight, even amid tropical showers, Copacabana beach came alive with lighted candles as tens of thousands of Brazilians bedecked in white prepared to ask Iemanja, an African goddess of the sea, to guide them safely through the New Year.


Politics of Education; Chancellor Selection Process Reveals Rift on Board and Groups' Influence
LEAD: The decision by the Board of Education to go beyond the recommendations of its own screening panel and consider additional candidates for chancellor of the New York City school system exposes a number of the political undercurrents that have been operating during the selection process.


Restaurants
LEAD: ZARELA MARTINEZ'S stewardship of nearly three years at the whimsical Mexican restaurant Cafe Marimba ended abruptly in September when the owner, David Keh, converted all his restaurants back to Chinese.
The feisty Ms.
Martinez wasted no time gathering her pots, pans and jalapenos and opening her own place, called Zarela, in the former Tastings on Two on Second Avenue.


Philip Weinberg, Ex-G.O.P. Aide
LEAD: Philip H. Weinberg, a lawyer who served as appointments secretary to two governors of New York, died of leukemia Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan.
He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

No Tilt as Yet From New California High Court
LEAD: When a conservative tide forced out Chief Justice Elizabeth Rose Bird and her liberal majority on the California Supreme Court in 1986, liberals feared the new court would mount an assault on defendants' rights and privacy.
Conservatives expected a pronounced rightward tilt.

LEAD: MacGregor Sporting Goods Inc. said it had been notified that Oppenheimer-Palmieri Fund L.P. would not complete the acquisiiton of the assets of MacGregor's Riddell Inc. football equipment unit and the capital stock of its Equilink Licensing Corporation, a licensor of the MacGregor trademark.
The fund said it had been unable to obtain satisfactory financing for the transaction, which was to have been completed by Jan.

LEAD: 'Aria' Coming to U.S.


Diner's Journal
LEAD: TIME AND AGAIN, the American restaurant at 116 East 39th Street, is catering to the early-bird business client with its new breakfast club.
Along with the a la carte breakfast (eggs, cereals, smoked salmon, homemade breads, from $5.50 to $15), diners get complimentary copies of The New York Times or The Wall Street Journal and the use of pads and pens, calculators and, if you ask, cassette tape recorders and cordless telephones.


Bruins' Lemelin Shuts Out Sabres
LEAD: Reggie Lemelin recorded his second shutout of the season over Buffalo as the Boston Bruins beat the Sabres, 2-0, tonight.


Elaborate Creches From Italy
LEAD: The history of European art is filled with odd but intriguing footnotes -including an 18th-century Neapolitan craze for creating and collecting extraordinarily elaborate creches.
One of these sculpted tableaux, known as presepios and rarely exhibited in the United States - can be seen through Jan.


An Investment Bank's Big Shift
LEAD: For years, the financial world considered Stephens Inc. something of an anomaly.
The privately held brokerage firm in Little Rock, Ark., had $500 million in capital - as much as many of the big Wall Street houses - but it was neither a broker that controlled giant pools of money nor an investment banker for scores of major corporations.


Hanover Unit Sale
LEAD: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation has sold 500,000 shares, or 20 percent, of its Banco Manufacturers Hanover (Portugal) S.A. unit at a public auction for $43.4 million.
The sale will result in a pretax gain of about $35.7 million in Manufacturers Hanover's fourth-quarter earnings.
Based on the return on equity, Banco Manufacturers Hanover is the most profitable foreign financial institution in Portugal, the bank said.


Monty Alexander
LEAD: Monty Alexander, a pianist, is to lead his Ivory and Steel Jamboree, featuring Othello Molineau on steel drums, tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260).
Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

LEAD: WHILE debate continues over the future of the New York Coliseum building at the west side of Columbus Circle, another tower has been rising just south of the Coliseum.
It is a 55-story square residential condominium called Central Park Place, and it is replacing the cluster of low-rise buildings that represented the

LEAD: The Ramones are to perform tomorrow night at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800).
Manitoba's Wild Kingdom is to open at 11 P.M., with the Ramones at 12:30 A.M.
Tickets are $13.50 in advance, $14.50 tomorrow.

LEAD: Sheldon Andelson, a leader in the gay community and a fund-raiser for such politicians as Senator Edward M. Kennedy and Walter F. Mondale, died Tuesday of complications from AIDS.
He was 56 years old.
A member of the University of California Board of Regents and the founder of the Bank of Los Angeles, Mr.


Ferry Service From Bay Ridge Coming to End
LEAD: Ferry service between Brooklyn Heights and Wall Street, just seven months old, is scheduled to die next Friday - a victim of sharply lower ridership as temperatures have plunged.


Bonds End Year on Familiar Note
LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices fell as much as a point yesterday, as the dollar's decline to new lows cast a pall over the credit markets.


Missing Woman Is Found Dead In Field on L.I.
LEAD: The body of a 22-year-old woman who disappeared the night of Dec. 24 after leaving her home to take a walk was found last night in a bleak, weed-strewn field here.


More Bar Questions Are the Same But Scores Still Vary State by State
LEAD: For decades, lawyers have been talking about the desirability of a national bar examination, but progress in that direction has been painfully slow.


Texaco Financing Plan Filed
LEAD: Texaco Inc. intends to borrow $3.4 billion and use $2.2 billion of its cash on hand to settle its dispute with the Pennzoil Company, pay off its creditors and emerge from bankruptcy, the company said yesterday in a document it filed with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in White Plains.

LEAD: Harold A. Rousselot, a retired investment banker and commodity trader, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 80 years old.


Wine Makers Divided on How to Fight Curbs
LEAD: As efforts to curb wine consumption gain momentum, American vintners are widely divided about how to combat the movement.


Bridge; Senior Player Is Honored By New York Association
LEAD: The American Contract Bridge League recently began to recognize that a slight majority of its membership is over the age of 55.
It has therefore sanctioned events and even tournaments for these players, many of whom prefer the peace and quiet of their own age group to the hurly-burly engendered by the rising stars of the younger generation.

Horse Racing Notebook; The New Year Brings Instant Birthdays
LEAD: Happy birthday to every race horse in the Northern Hemisphere - technically, that is.
Each Jan. 1, all runners age a year for official purposes, regardless of whether they were born in January or June.

LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus more than doubled in 1987 to a record $6.55 billion, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported today.


Brooklyn Series to Study Black Images in Film
LEAD: Although few black directors worked in Hollywood until the last 30 years, and histories of American movies rarely even mention such pioneering black filmmakers as Oscar Micheaux and Richard Maurice, black American cinema has a rich -albeit largely unknown - history, according to Pearl Bowser, who has organized a series of works by black directors that begins on Sunday at the Brooklyn Museum.

He was 80 years old.

Why All Those People Feel They Never Have Any Time
LEAD: Because she wanted more free time, Sue Alstedt quit her job as a manager at A.T.&amp;T.
Then, to save even more time, she bought equipment to do her banking at home.
But she soon became impatient with the computer because it was not as fast as the one she had used at work. ''I couldn't stand to wait for it, even though it was coming out at the rate of speech,'' she said.


14 Reported Killed by Sikhs
LEAD: Fourteen people were killed in violence attributed to Sikh separatists over the New Year's holiday, the police said today.
Sikh militants reportedly shot dead three people in Beas village today.
In Amritsar the police found the bodies of two suspected extremists possibly killed by rival hardliners.


Japanese Becoming a Force On Exchanges in Chicago
LEAD: Chicago's futures exchanges have long had their eyes on the large financial markets of Japan.
And now the Japanese are returning that interest.


For a Hudson Greenway
LEAD: The extraordinary cultural, historical and environmental values of the Hudson River Valley are under siege.


Syracuse Sidesteps Criticism of Dye
LEAD: Tim Vesling kicked the 38-yard field goal that put Syracuse ahead before Win Lyle's 30-yard field goal with 1 second remaining salvaged a 16-16 tie for Auburn in the Sugar Bowl today.
But now Vesling and five of his Syracuse teammates were being asked in the Superdome's interview area for their reaction to Coach Pat Dye's decision to go for the tie instead of trying for a victory with a last-play pass from the 13-yard line.


Rainier Sells Unit
LEAD: Rainier National Bank, whose $1.2 billion acquisition by the Security Pacific Corporation became final three months ago, said it had agreed to sell its leasing operation to a unit of the First City Trust Company of Vancouver, British Columbia.
Terms were not disclosed.
The operation has assets of $160 million and in the first nine months of 1987 earned $2.2 million.


Erie Lackawanna Files Suit on Taxes
LEAD: The president of Erie Lackawanna Inc. said that he hoped that the filing of a suit in Federal Claims Court this week would speed up a $42.5 million refund the company hopes to obtain from the Internal Revenue Service.
Harry A. Zilli Jr., who is in charge of what is left of the former railroad concern, said company lawyers had been frustrated by a lack of progress through the I.R.S.


13 KILLED IN BLAZE AT BANGKOK HOTEL
LEAD: At least 13 people died and 36 were injured when a fire destroyed a tourist hotel early today.
Some guests received injuries trying to jump from windows or rooftops, according to police and fire officials.


Jazz Fellowship Awarded
LEAD: The National Endowment for the Arts has announced awards to three jazz musicians for contributions to ''jazz in the African-American tradition.''

LEAD: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev exchanged televised New Year's greetings to the Soviet and American peoples today.


CORRECTION
LEAD: A headline yesterday with an article about ferry service in New York City incorrectly described the status of two lines.
Service between Brooklyn Heights and Wall Street is to end next week.
Service between the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn and Wall Street is to begin in late January or early February.


Eagles Set to Fly in Face of Expectations
LEAD: When someone suggested recently that Boston College's basketball program was stuck in a downward spiral, Jim O'Brien, the school's second-year coach, insisted that the Eagles' fortunes could change sooner than people thought.

LEAD: SECOND SIGHT. By Mary Tannen. 259 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.


Grown-Ups' Video Game Is a Mazelike Journey
LEAD: In a darkened room on the third floor of the Kitchen, the experimental arts space on West 19th Street, sits a machine that resembles a futuristic piece of gymnasium equipment but is actually a video game for grown-ups.
Two attached video monitors offer printed instructions to the player and an observer who stands to his left.


Soviet Halts Jamming of Broadcasts to Poland
LEAD: For the first time in six years, the Soviet Union today stopped jamming broadcasts to Poland by the Voice of America and Radio Free Europe, the director of the Voice of America said.

Comparing Apple Juice And Orange Juice
LEAD: To the Editor:


Railroad Tank Car Explodes
LEAD: A railroad tank car exploded Wednesday night, setting off a fireball seen more than 25 miles away, derailing adjacent rail cars and shattering windows of buildings up to six miles away, the authorities said.
At least two people suffered minor injuries. ''The only thing left of the tank car was the wheels it was standing on,'' a police spokesman, Mike Healy, said.


Rehnquist Says Shortage of Judges Threatens to Clog Federal Courts
LEAD: A shortage of trial and appellate judges poses a ''serious dilemma'' for the Federal courts that is not likely to be resolved soon because of budget pressures, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist says.


Warriors of Hate Find No Homeland in Idaho
LEAD: The Rev.
Richard Girnt Butler, head of the neo-Nazi sect based here in northern Idaho, believes white people in the Northwest will rally round him when he is tried on Federal sedition charges.


To Keep Horses Alive and Wild
LEAD: Early in this century two million wild horses roamed the American West.
Human and wild predators reduced them to a mere 17,000 by 1971.
Then the Federal Government stepped in with a law to protect wild horses and burros as vestiges of an older America.
But like crop supports and rent control, this well-intended initiative produced unanticipated side effects.


Court Gives Leader's Money to Black Muslims
LEAD: A $5.7 million bank account of Elijah Muhammad, the Black Muslim leader who died in 1975, belongs to the religious organization he founded and not to his heirs, an Illinois appeals court has decided.


Children's Radio Show Is Canceled
LEAD: ''Kids America,'' an award-winning nationally syndicated children's radio program, went off the air yesterday after nearly four years of live broadcasts that combined ''Sesame Street''-style teaching with the format of talk radio.


The Audience as Obstacle
LEAD: During a recent performance of ''Tamara'' at the Seventh Regiment Armory, on Park Avenue at 66th Street, a woman in the audience could not contain her feelings.
When the character Emilia, a hot-tempered housemaid, kept silent after a proposal from Dante, the good-natured valet, the spectator cried: ''Marry him!


After 2 Years of Struggle, Ann Jillian's Story Is Told
LEAD: Ann Jillian is not the first actress to play herself in a television dramatization of her life.
But in preparing ''The Ann Jillian Story,'' an NBC-TV movie to be broadcast at 9 P.M.
Monday, Ms.
Jillian found herself embroiled in conflicts with her producers - disagreements that grew from her unusual double role as actress and as consultant on the authenticity of the script.


Four Arrests In Taiwan
LEAD: Four officials of a leading stock brokerage house have been arrested in connection with illegal margin loans that led to a default on payment of $750 million (Taiwan), or $26.3 million (United States) by a stock investor, police said.


Overstaying By Patients Cuts Beds
LEAD: Despite a critical shortage of beds in New York City's public and private hospitals, an average of 2,000 beds a day are occupied by patients who are medically ready for discharge and do not belong there, government and health-care officials acknowledge.

COPING: WITH NEGLIGENCE CASES
LEAD: If you slip and sprain your ankle on an icy public sidewalk or a wet floor in a department store, how do you go about getting compensation for your injury and suffering?
What if your car is dented by a parking-lot attendant who won't admit fault?
Or an expensive garment is damaged by a dry cleaner who accepts no liability?


NEW YORK REACHES PACT ON COLISEUM
LEAD: The Koch administration, working to keep viable its disputed plan for developing Columbus Circle, has agreed to a new proposal that includes no reference to the height of the project, reduces its purchase price and bulk, and places a new financial constraint on the developer.


Regulators Oppose Bid By Seagram for Martell
LEAD: The attempt by the Seagram Company of Montreal to acquire a controlling interest in the French cognac producer Martell &amp; Compagnie has run into an obstacle from French regulators, raising the hopes of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. of London, which has made a competing bid.

LEAD: A funny thing happened as the clock at the old Town Hall here struck midnight and ushered in the New Year.
There were people on hand, more than 4,000 of them, to watch.

He played the 6-foot-9 1/2-inch Pat Cummings at center for the rest of the period.


Cold Brings California Gas Cutoff
LEAD: The nation's largest natural gas utility will temporarily cut off shipments, starting Monday, to 800 corporate users in Southern California, hoping to avert a shortage for residential customers.

LEAD: When Clarissa Davis, top-ranked Texas' all-America basketball player, came crashing down onto the court Tuesday night, badly injuring her left knee in the Orange Bowl Classic in Miami, her mother was listening to the game at a park about an hour south of San Antonio, where she and her husband had driven because that's where the reception was best.

LEAD: The stock market opens the New Year under a shadow.
The trauma of October has reintroduced the fear of losing money.

LEAD: Egyptian police with riot sticks charged and beat hundreds of anti-Israeli protesters chanting Islamic fundamentalist slogans today and besieged others at one of Cairo's most eminent mosques, witnesses said.

LEAD: A third convoy carrying supplies arrived today in Khost, the southeastern Afghanistan city where Government troops are besieged by Moslem guerrillas, the Kabul radio said.

SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.
Answers appear on page 16.


Tumultuous Markets
LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average ended a year of turmoil 2.3 percent higher, at 1,938.83.

Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 413 money market mutual funds decreased $3.16 billion, to $258.22 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday.
Assets of the 112 institutional funds were down $2.11 billion, to $70.99 billion.
Assets of the 206 general purpose funds increased $159.8 million, to $79.36 billion.


China's G.N.P. Up 9%
LEAD: China's gross national product will exceed $270 billion this year, up 9 percent from 1986, the official New China News Agency said.
Zheng Jiaheng, deputy director of the State Statistical Bureau, said in an interview earlier this week that industrial output increased 14.5 percent while agricultural output was up 4 percent.

LEAD: A Roman Catholic clergyman says that the South Carolina Republican Party is helping perpetuate a segregated society and that racism should be stamped out on the 125th anniversary of Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation.

LEAD: Firefighters heard faint scratching at a locked door today while they struggled to enter a burning apartment, but they were unable to save a pregnant woman and three children inside, an official said.

End Paper; Minesweeping? Try Mindsweeping
LEAD: ENGLISH COMP is the minesweeper of the educational fleet.
There's absolutely no status in running such a class, or ship.
Yet somehow the whole fleet looks very silly without it.
The minesweeper clears away problems everybody else pretends are not there.
It's time-consuming, hazardous duty.
And if, when I'm done, there are only half as many mines - comma splices, sentence fragments and the like - have I succeeded?

Not least, it seems, the golfer's zany wardrobe, which over the years has encompassed such classical oddities as screaming argyle hose and peaked tartan caps.

LEAD: Gary Hart's sudden decision to re-enter the 1988 Presidential campaign has provoked, at least in public, more wringing of hands than careful calculation, more denunciation than analysis of its impact on the Democratic race.


Embattled Teamsters Fight Government on Several Fronts
LEAD: FEW labor leaders were surprised last month by a spate of reports that Jackie Presser, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, had resigned.
The rumors weren't true, but the fact that they were so widely believed showed how troubled is Mr.
Presser's reign over the 1.7 million-member union, the nation's largest.

CHILDREN'S BOOKS
LEAD:  OWL MOON  By Jane Yolen.
Illustrated by John Schoenherr.
Unpaged.
New York: Philomel Books. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 9) THE very best books for not-quite-reading children must be written to charm and astonish the adults who will read them aloud: thrill that reader, who will communicate those prickles at the nape of the neck, and you'll have created a desire in the young listener to learn how to read books alone.


CHARITABLE DONATIONS STEADY
LEAD: ALTHOUGH charitable organizations had expected deficits in holiday fund-raising this year because of the uncertain economy, most major charities in New Jersey seem to have raised at least as much as they did last year.


OLD AND NOVEL
LEAD: Gary Jennings's article ''Old and Novel'' (On Language, Nov. 29) is devoted to an impassioned plea for the compilation of a dictionary of ''What People Used to Call Things.'' Such a dictionary is, in fact, being edited at the University of Glasgow - it will be called the Historical Thesaurus of English.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article last Sunday about the new state law governing marine fishing licenses misstated the kind of fishermen to whom it would apply.
The $100 annual license fee is required only for commercial fishermen who are state residents.
Under the law, commercial fishermen are defined as those who sell one or more fish a year.

Edited by Stuart Berg Flexner with Leonore Crary Hauck.
Illustrated. 2,478 pp.
New York: Random House. $79.95.
THIS outsize unabridged dictionary, the first in English in 20-odd years, weighs in at 12-plus pounds.
It involved nine years' labor by 340 lexicographers and consultants, and its 2,500 pages contain 50,000 new words; 75,000 fresh definitions; Italian, French, Spanish and German dictionaries; prodigious, encyclopedic information; spankingly updated entries on high-tech jargon, trade names,

Slides vs. Prints
LEAD: ONE of the reasons that color-print films outsell color-slide films is their reproducibility.
Take a picture on slide film of the family gathered together round the Yule log and you get back a slide, period.
Take the same picture on print film and you get back a print and a negative.
With the negative, you can order as many duplicates of the picture as there are family members.

WHEN A PARENT NEEDS A NURSING HOME
LEAD: ''WE take care of our own'' was one of the family mottos I grew up with.
And take care they did.
My father supported his mother, my mother's parents and her two unmarried sisters. ''I married the whole damn family,'' he once said in a rare expression of feeling.
Mother's sister, Bessie, submerged her life in order to care for her parents at home, through Grandma's broken hip and Grandpa's strokes.

A Year of Shame
LEAD: As one scandal after another unfolds, it is clear that President Reagan presides over one of the most corrupt administrations ever.

Precise comparisons to the Grant, Harding and Nixon Administrations aren't possible or necessary.

How Education Came to Be a Campaign Issue
LEAD: CONGRESS created the national Office of Education in 1867 and then, not quite sure of what it was supposed to do, ordered its Commissioner to keep an eye on the Federal reindeer herds in Alaska.
Commissioners have since been relieved of their reindeer-watching duties, but the tradition of turning to education to deal with everything from driver safety to drug abuse lives on.

Intellectual Seduction
LEAD: LISTENING TO MIKHAIL S. Gorbachev's impassioned address in the rococo white-and-gold ballroom of the Soviet Embassy on 16th Street in Washington, on the late afternoon of Dec. 8, in a heterogeneous gathering of some 50 fellow American ''intellectuals'' and ''artists,'' I recalled these cryptic words of Nietzsche's; but wondered if my habitual skepticism, particularly regarding politics in its most public, theatrical mode, might be irrelevant here, unjustified.

LEAD: Fire swept through the cabaret of the seafront Balmoral Hotel in Blackpool this morning, forcing 102 people from the Balmoral and a neighboring hotel, the Craigy Don, to flee.

THE NEW GREED TAKES CENTER STAGE
LEAD: SUDDENLY EVERYBODY IS TALKING about greed.
It may not be a brand-new topic, but after the chastening experience of the stock market fall in October it seems an all too appropriate one.
We virtuously distance ourselves from yesterday's excesses (without necessarily discarding today's); and three works in particular have shown up at just the right time to highlight our concerns - Oliver Stone's movie ''Wall Street,'' Caryl Churchill's play ''Serious Money'' and Tom Wolfe's novel ''The Bonfire of the Vanities.

New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:  ANNA DELANEY'S CHILD, by John Thorndike. (Plume/New American Library, $7.95.) Anna Delaney is grief-stricken by the loss of her son in a car crash; her father, Alex, is depressed over the death of his wife.
This ''lyrically powerful'' first novel ''deftly explores the ethics of memory, dramatizing how Anna and Alex learn to forge bonds with the living without betraying their loving memories of the dead,'' Sherie Posesorski said in The Book Review in 1986.

Streetscapes: The West Side Improvement; On the Lower West Side, Fate Of Old Rail Line Is Undecided
LEAD: IT was hailed in its time, but now the West Side Improvement is to some an awful blight and to others a magnificent opportunity.
The elevated railroad, completed in 1934, snakes around and even through industrial buildings on the Lower West Side of Manhattan.
It will either be demolished or returned to service, depending on the outcome of litigation that began in 1985.

OLD AND NOVEL
LEAD: I believe I can aid Gary Jennings with the ancient word for getting ''bucked'' off a horse.

Dye's Tie Still Ugly In Syracuse's View
LEAD: It was apparent that there had not been any overnight revelations for Dick MacPherson.
The Syracuse coach came to a team breakfast this morning, lacking sleep and a satisfactory explanation for why Auburn chose to play for a tie in the Sugar Bowl game the day before.

Missile Fire Inquiry
LEAD: Investigators looking into an MX missile fire that killed five workers at a Morton Thiokol plant here are examining the possibility that static electricity may have ignited the blaze, a company official said.
A 23-foot MX segment containing 100,000 pounds of solid propellant burst into flames Tuesday after the fuel had been poured into the rocket segment, Thiokol said.

Living Poor in America.
By Eugene Richards. (Consumers Union, Cloth, $32; Paper, $20.) People will be more concerned about poverty in America if they see its face up close.

LEAD: AS HIGH SCHOOL students in California start selecting classes next fall, some will be able to get credit for an unusual language course -American Sign Language.

Comings &amp; Goings
LEAD: THE Olympic 100-meter champion, Evelyn Ashford, who holds the world record of 10.75 seconds in the event as well as indoor bests of 5.74 for 50 yards and 6.54 for 60 yards, will compete in the United States Olympic Invitational meet at Byrne Meadowlands Arena Feb. 13.
The 30-year-old Ashford, who won the United States Olympic Invitational in 1986 after the birth of her daughter but missed most of last year because of an injury, will run in the 55-meter dash against the defending champion, Gwen Torrence, and Merlene Ottey, the bronze medalist in the 100 meters at the 1984 Olympics.

For the Retailers, A So-So Season
LEAD: Retailers' Christmas sales were nothing to brag about, but the modest increases were enough to allay the worst fears of merchants.
Gains were expected to average out to about 3 percent, which is really no gain at all when an inflation rate of more than 4 percent is factored in.
But things could have been a lot worse in a year that saw a dizzying tumble in the stock market, and, in fact, the biggest sales gains came from affluent shoppers.


LITERARY FEMINISM COMES OF AGE
LEAD: In my years of undergraduate and graduate study of literature, I have yet to meet a student or professor who would disagree with the point made in Elizabeth Kolbert's article ''Literary Feminism Comes of Age'' (Dec. 6) that we have a legacy of neglected or forgotten female writers.
However, sexual politics has less to do with who makes the course syllabus than do the practical constraints of the academic year.

It is now possible for a terrible film to resurface in a nice package that bears no memory-jogging information, just an indistinct title and the name of a star or two.

They separate after the first few days and there's usually a divorce within the month.

LITERARY FEMINISM COMES OF AGE
LEAD: Feminist literary studies are a new thing on campuses, but they did not spring full-grown from the heads of the recent polemical feminists.
For generations, well-read women have developed a chain of favorite authors, passed on by word-of-mouth.
My mother was my link to the feminist literary past.
She introduced me to such important and then neglected authors as Olive Schreiner, Elizabeth Gaskell and Maria Edgeworth.

NONFICTION

By Lieut.
Gen.
Ion Mihai Pacepa. (Regnery Gateway/ Kampmann, $19.95.) In 1945, Rumanian intelligence officers provided the nascent United States intelligence organization with copious secret files on the Soviet Union - of value in part because they covered Soviet territory occupied by Rumanian forces during World War II.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH a quadruple jump has never been completed in competition, Brian Boitano, who goes after his fourth straight United States Figure Skating championship this week in Denver, has come close and he says he will be trying to come even closer. ''Whether the jump is successful or not on a particular night will not make that much of a difference in the results,'' said Boitano, who won the 1986 world championships then finished second to Brian Orser of Canada last year.

Krapp's 15 Broadway palaces have been given landmark status.
Meanwhile, the brick exterior of the Boulevard, at 82-28 Northern Boulevard, has been covered with brown tile.

Photos That Capture the Sculptor's Spirit
LEAD: THE PHOTOGRAPHS IN the recently published book ''Alberto Giacometti'' do something rare: they convey a measure of what we feel when we encounter the sculptor's work in the flesh.
The pictures may be missing the sculpture's scale, texture and command of space, but they elicit its essential spirit through the pictorial equivalent of metaphor.

STAR WARS

CORRECTION
LEAD: An article in The Week in Review on Dec. 20 about New York's Congressional delegation incorrectly traced the history of New Yorkers who have served on the Senate Finance Committee.
Daniel Patrick Moynihan is the first Senator from New York to have served on that committee since the 1930's.
Calvin Coolidge was from Massachusetts and never served in Congress.

LEAD: THE GUITAR WAS PRIMARILY A rhythm instrument in jazz until Charlie Christian brought the electric guitar into the jazz mainstream in 1939 when he came out of Oklahoma to join Benny Goodman.

THE REGION: Pro &amp; Con: Tactics of Transit Officers; Police Decoys, Temptation and Crime
LEAD: SINCE the days when burly, bewigged policemen masqueraded as women to catch molesters, police departments around the country have used decoy officers to trap suspected muggers, rapists and other criminals.
The technique works, but it has sometimes been abused.
Officers have been accused of entrapping suspects by dangling money, flaunting jewelry, planting evidence - a practice sometimes called ''flaking,'' though the origin of the term is uncertain - or tricking a target into picking up a valuable item an officer has purposely dropped.

Sick Thinking
LEAD: WAKING AT night, I made my way in the dark to the bathroom without trouble, but when I switched on the light, I was stunned: it wasn't my bathroom at home - or, in fact, any bathroom I'd ever seen.
I supposed I must be in a hotel on a business trip - but what trip?
What hotel?
I had no idea.
Panic such as one feels in certain nightmares swept over me, but this was no nightmare; I was definitely awake.

France Moves to Curb Campaign Funds
LEAD: Officials in the administration of Prime Minister Jacques Chirac said today that they would formally propose legislation later this month that would set limits for the first time on campaign spending and donations.


Banking: Regional Powers Gain As Giants Struggle
LEAD: The shake-up in the nation's banking industry will accelerate this year.
Regional banks will continue to consolidate into bigger and bigger institutions, while the traditional behemoths - based in New York, Chicago and California - will remain locked in their struggle to deal with huge loans to deeply troubled third-world countries.


Buyout Artist Kravis Had a High-Ticket Year
LEAD: For Henry R. Kravis, the man who perfected the art of the leveraged buyout, it is hard to imagine a better year than 1987.

LEAD: Franklin Torch says he was reading the latest West German census, which shows a declining birth rate, when ''it clicked in my mind that they could use surrogate mothers.''


Gay Catholics Resume Protest At St. Patrick's
LEAD: A group of gay Roman Catholics resumed their protests during Mass at St.
Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, one month after 11 of them were arrested at the Cathedral when they refused to be seated during the sermon.

LEAD: Lacrosse at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, an ancient game in a modern setting, mixed marketing and mild mayhem tonight.

LEAD: The only problem at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow night will be finding someone to show you your seat, because all but a few of the ushers will be performing.

LEAD: ''It's a shame we had to pick this week to be terrible.''  - Tony Elliott of the New Orleans Saints.  [ C4:1. ]


Hasidic Jew Killed in Borough Park Is Remembered
LEAD: Some of the hundreds of Hasidic Jews who gathered yesterday at Beth Jacob School in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn at a memorial service for Eli Wald, who was stabbed to death as he returned home from work on Christmas morning.
The gathering was also intended to protest what the participants called increased violence against residents of the predominantly Jewish neighborhood.


Pope Dines With Homeless
LEAD: Pope John Paul II had dinner with about 130 poor and homeless people today, becoming the first Pope in modern history to sit down and eat with the poor inside the Vatican.
Vatican sources said the Pope was greeted with applause as he entered a refectory near St.
Peter's Basilica to share a meal of pasta, meat, fruit and wine with the homeless men and women, many of whom sleep in the streets of Rome throughout the year.


Israeli Army Decides To Deport 9 Arabs In Wake of Rioting
LEAD: The Israeli Army announced today that it would permanently expel nine Palestinian nationalists arrested during the riots of the last three weeks.


Bridge: A Taiwanese Could Qualify For 1987 Apology of the Year
LEAD: The game of bridge surely generates more apologies than any other activity, unless one counts late arrival as an activity.
Millions of them cross the world's card tables every year, and as many again fail to materialize through stubbornness, lack of courtesy or lack of understanding.


Another Low For Dollar
LEAD: The dollar rebounded after opening at a record low against the Japanese yen today, while stocks declined sharply in an abbreviated post-holiday session.


Autos: Detroit's Rosy View Has Some Support
LEAD: America's passion for new transportaton vehicles remains nearly as ardent as ever.
Most industry forecasts call for sales of about 10 million cars and 5 million light trucks - roughly the same as last year but down from 1986, when 16.3 million vehicles were sold.


'ANN JILLIAN STORY,' ON NBC
LEAD: ANN JILLIAN has kept a tight rein on ''The Ann Jillian Story,'' the television movie on NBC at 9 this evening.
A year or more of skirmishing took place before Ms.
Jillian settled on a teleplay by Audrey Davis Levin.
Corey Allen is the director.
And Ms.
Jillian plays herself.
The result is admirable in some ways, puzzling in others.

Byzantine Coins in Egypt
LEAD: Archeologists have unearthed a trove of ancient gold coins while restoring a 1,500-year-old Coptic monastery, the head of Egypt's Antiquities Organization said today.
Ahmed Kadri said at a news conference that the 820 Byzantine coins, dating to the fifth and sixth centuries, were found last month in two clay jars.

LEAD: Chinese organized crime's involvement in extortion, prostitution, loan sharking, gun smuggling and murder is sharply on the rise in the New York area, law-enforcement officials say.

No Need for a New Token War
LEAD: New York City Transit Authority officials are still fuming over Connecticut's unneighborly issuance of 17.5-cent turnpike tokens that also worked in $1 subway turnstiles.
Until the turnstiles were rewired in 1986 to reject slugs, the T.A. lost more than 7,000 full fares a day to the Connecticut coin.

LEAD: The nation's industrial economy expanded briskly in December, significantly outshining November in new orders and production, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report scheduled to be released today.

LEAD: George Steinbrenner has just about everything money can buy, but the one holiday present he has wanted for years still eludes him: a Presidential pardon.

NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JANUARY 4, 1988
LEAD: International A2-11


28 Chilean Exiles Occupy U.N. Offices in Brazil
LEAD: For the last four weeks, 28 Chilean exiles, including 10 children, have been occupying the local offices of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees as part of a campaign to obtain political asylum in a country other than Brazil.


E.P.A. REASSESSES THE CANCER RISKS OF MANY CHEMICALS
LEAD: New evidence of the way chemicals cause cancer is leading the Environmental Protection Agency to reassess the risks of many of the substances it regulates.
It is finding some of them less dangerous than it previously believed.


Entertainment: Bright Prospects At the Box Office
LEAD: Hollywood not only shrugs off economic uncertainty but thrives on it, according to legend.
Despite the ripple effects of the stock market collapse, customers keep pouring into movie theaters, even as ticket prices reached $7 in some areas.


Washington Talk: Briefing; An L-word Acronym
LEAD: There is such a thing as official lust in the Federal Government.
Among the many little-known provisions tucked deep within the $17.6 billion deficit-reduction bill adopted by Congress just before Christmas is a Senate amendment covering the excise taxes that are levied on diesel and certain other motor fuels sold wholesale to dealers.


VIKINGS' 'DIFFERENT' WEAPON
LEAD: IN preparing for the Super Bowl playoffs, coaches often talk about how it's just another football game. ''We haven't approached this game,'' Jim Mora of the Saints said before yesterday's wild-card game, ''any differently than any other game.'' But a playoff game is different.
And the Minnesota Vikings approached it differently.


Semiconductors: Recovery Is Expected To Continue in 1988
LEAD: After two years of heavy losses that turned the plight of the nation's semiconductor industry into an international political issue, chip makers returned to profitability in 1987.
Industry officials and analysts generally expect a continuation of the recovery in 1988.


UNITED STATES
LEAD: Only three weeks into 1987, the year was already shaping up as an historic one on Wall Street.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which had closed out 1986 at 1,895.95, promptly waltzed past 2,000 on Jan. 8 and then 2,100 on Jan. 19.


Philharmonic Radiothon
LEAD: The 11th New York Philharmonic Radiothon, a three-day broadcast of music, interviews and pledges, will take place in February on WQXR (1560 AM and 96.3 FM).
The broadcast, an annual fund-raising event for the orchestra, will begin at noon on Feb. 5 and last until midnight Feb. 7.
Included in the 60-hour broadcast will be taped excerpts of performances.


Workshops in Theater Look at Writing Lyrics
LEAD: Martin Charnin, a Broadway lyricist, is to lead a workshop in lyric writing and directing for the musical theater, during two-hour sessions, Jan. 7, 11, 14 and 21 at 7:30 P.M., at the 92d Street Y School of Music, at 1395 Lexington Avenue.


Joseph Sittler, 83, Dies; Was Lutheran Scholar
LEAD: Joseph Sittler, a Lutheran theologian known for his work on religion and ecology, died of cancer Dec. 28 at his home in Chicago.
He was 83 years old.

LEAD: Everyone hears this is a difficult time in Argentina, but it's also a promising one.
Fashionable Buenos Aires fills its conversation with the troubles.
To discern the positive requires poking beneath the surface of the capital's complex and Italianate political life and venturing into the million-square-mile interior.

LEAD: The 10 inches of snow that fell on Chicago this week snarled the city's airports and roads.
But down at the Civic Opera House, where the Lyric Opera is halfway through its most successful season, the big winter storm seemed barely a flurry.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  Shriver Overcomes Novotna: Top-seeded Pam Shriver of Lutherville, Md., had to struggle for almost two hours yesterday, but she defeated Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia, 7-6, 7-6, in the championship of the Ariadne Classic at the Milton Courts in Brisbane, Australia.
Shriver won $25,000.


Takeovers Revert to the Old Mode
LEAD: The fall of the stock market is rewriting the rules of corporate takeovers.
Gone are the swashbuckling raiders who used junk bonds to plunder the business landscape.
Instead, Wall Street is expecting a return to normalcy: back to the days when corporations merged for strategic business reasons and not for quick financial gain.

LEAD: ''The Dead,'' the work that marked the extraordinary synthesis of a great literary talent with a great cinematic one, was voted the best film of 1987 by the National Society of Film Critics yesterday.

LEAD: An hour before his team was scheduled to face Virginia on Saturday night, Rollie Massimino sat in a deserted locker room at the John E. duPont Pavilion contemplating the Big East season.


Market Place; Potential Gains In Foreign Stocks
LEAD: A FURTHER decline in the value of the dollar against major foreign currencies would be, on balance, bullish for foreign stocks.
However, one risk of investing abroad is that a drop in foreign stock markets could offset the advantage of the currency play.
With that caveat in mind, what are some foreign stocks that appear attractive for 1988?


Miami No. 1 in All Three Rankings
LEAD: Miami was voted the No. 1 college football team in the nation yesterday in both The Associated Press and United Press International polls and also finished on top in The New York Times's computer rankings.
Florida State and Oklahoma were second and third, respectively, in all three rankings.

LEAD: The world of big banking acknowledged reality last year, largely as the result of moves by two men: John S. Reed, chairman of Citicorp, and Lewis T. Preston, chairman of J.P.
Morgan &amp; Company.
In a one-two punch of sorts, the two bankers smashed the myth that such big third-world debtors as Mexico and Brazil would ever fully repay their hundreds of billions of dollars in foreign debt.

LEAD: Payments by the PTL ministry to Jessica Hahn in exchange for her silence about a tryst with Jim Bakker totaled $363,700, nearly $100,000 more than previously reported, according to an Internal Revenue Service report.


MEXICO
LEAD: For the Mexican stock market, 1987 has been a year straight out of Charles Dickens: the best of times, the worst of times.
For the first nine months of the year, the Bolsa de Valores in Mexico City performed more impressively than any other market in the world, rising eightfold in local currency terms.

LEAD: The vise tightens on the $450 billion health-care industry, which runs the gamut from drug and medical-supply houses to hospital chains and nursing homes.
Many costs are soaring, and skilled workers are scarce in the labor-intensive hospitals, where revenues have been cut by insurer-imposed restrictions.

Chambers stands charged with her murder, a jury is expected to begin hearing the full fabric of the tale - and prosecutors and defense lawyers say many widely held assumptions about the case may fall.

GERMANY
LEAD: The West German stock market got off to a bad start in 1987.

The relative stability of the dollar in the spring led to some improvement, but the summer would prove a calm before the storm.

LEAD: In Hong Kong, the stock market underwent a devastating collapse in October that seriously harmed confidence.

Yesterday a large pile of visa papers was spotted at the Soviet consular office in the capital, apparently to permit Ms.

The Past Of a Town Is at Stake
LEAD: When California was known to people in southern China as ''the Golden Mountain'' a century and more ago, Chinese immigrant settlements dotted the rural regions of the state.
Chinese communities, born in the Gold Rush of 1849, thrived in the countryside until job opportunities began swelling the Chinatowns of big cities like San Francisco.


Tourists in London
LEAD: Foreign visitors spent a record $5.7 billion in London in 1987, the London Tourist Board estimated today.
There were 8.9 million visitors, and 23 percent of them were Americans.


China Is Reported to Execute 17
LEAD: At a mass rally, 17 people were tried and convicted last month of crimes including murder, rape and robbery, then immediately shot in one of the largest reported group executions in recent years, according to a radio report.


AIDS Research On New Drugs Bypasses Addicts And Women
LEAD: AIDS experts are growing more concerned that results from many trials of experimental drugs against the disease may not be valid for key segments of the population that the epidemic is increasingly hitting: drug users, nonwhites and women.


FILIPINO TESTIFIES ON AQUINO'S KILLER
LEAD: After four years of silence, an airport worker testified today that he saw a soldier shoot and kill Benigno S. Aquino Jr. as the opposition leader stepped off a plane to end years of exile.

LEAD: In a matter of seconds last Tuesday evening, 11 shots from two police revolvers rang out on a Queens street.
Moments later a man who the police say had lunged at an officer with a five-inch knife lay dying, struck by at least six bullets.

Oil Rig Count Declines
LEAD: The number of oil and gas drilling rigs working in the United States fell by 24 last week, to 1,121, Baker Hughes said today.
A year ago the total was 962.

LEAD: A coalition of legal and church groups here is trying to prevent the deportation of a handful of Cuban women, detained around the country, so they will not be separated from the children to whom they gave birth in this country.

Primerica-De Luxe
LEAD: The Primerica Corporation said the sale of its direct marketing subsidiary, Looart Press Inc., to De Luxe Check Printers Inc. had been completed, resulting in an after-tax gain of about $35 million for the fourth quarter of 1987.
The proceeds from the previously announced sale of Looart and its operating subsidiary, Current Inc., totaled about $180 million, or about $150 million after taxes, Primerica said.


Building Outlays Up
LEAD: Construction spending shot up 2.2 percent in November, the biggest increase in nine months, as the building industry benefited from widespread gains in both residential and nonresidential construction, the Government reported today.


Steel Production Grows
LEAD: Steel production rose to 1.75 million tons last week, up 3.7 percent from the previous week's 1.68 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

CRAVING FOR PAINKILLERS IS RECALLED BY JACKSON
LEAD: Jesse Jackson told patients at a drug-rehabilitation center he was briefly dependent on a painkiller more than 25 years ago, but he said in an interview today that the episode lasted less than a day.


VW's Price Rise
LEAD: Volkswagen United States, a subsidiary of Volkswagen A.G., said it had raised suggested retail base prices by an average of 5.6 percent, or $377, on its Fox models, effective immediately.
The base price of Volkswagen's Fox two-door model will increase to $6,290, from $5,990; its four-door GL model to $7,280, from $6,890, and its wagon to $7,380, from $6,990.

LEAD: Sikh militants in Punjab state killed 10 people, one a senior member of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party, in attacks over a 24-hour period Sunday and today, the police and news organizations said.

LEAD: Wayne J. Stemmer was snowed in yesterday at his home in Westport, Conn., and he had a cold to boot.
But he also had a deal wrapped up to give him some cheer - the $150 million acquisition of the Lincoln Savings Bank.

LEAD: About 130 people were arrested in disturbances during and after a concert by the pop singer Tina Turner in an Argentine soccer stadium, the police said.

LEAD: A 53-year-old unemployed actor shot himself to death last night after having held his former girlfriend hostage for seven hours earlier in the day in her West Side apartment, the police said.

LEAD: Yvonne Constant, a French singer and actress, will offer cabaret songs in French and English at Jan Wallman's, 49 West 44th Street, tonight, Saturday and Jan. 16.
Miss Constant first performed in New York in the revue ''La Plume de Ma Tante,'' and later was featured in ''No Strings.'' She has appeared on television on ''Tonight'' and recently in the CBS miniseries ''Sins.


Ski-Lift Death in Italy
LEAD: A cable car loaded with about 50 skiers here started up accidentally with its door open and without its conductor today, and one teen-age skier fell 50 feet to his death, the police said.
Two other teen-agers were injured when they also fell to the parking lot below the valley station.

Plum Resumes Bidding for Holly
LEAD: The New York investor group Plum Associates, which appeared to have lost a takeover bid for the Holly Sugar Corporation to the Imperial Sugar Company, re-emerged as a suitor.
In its third proposal in two weeks, Plum Associates, a group headed by Peter R. Harvey of Illinois, is now offering to acquire 60 percent of the company's stock at $92.50 a share, or $61.5 million, instead of the previous cash price of $85 a share, or $56.5 million.


MENTAL PATIENTS IN SOVIET TO GET NEW LEGAL RIGHTS
LEAD: The Soviet Union has adopted a new set of legal rights for mental patients, the official press agency Tass reported tonight.
It was the first fundamental revision of the Soviet regulations governing psychiatry in 27 years.

Korean Trade Outlook
LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus in 1988 is expected to exceed $4 billion, down from last year's $6.55 billion, the Trade and Industry Ministry said today.
It predicted that exports would grow by 8 to 13 percent, to about $52 billion, despite the rise of the won against the dollar.

There is even a drive-through pawn shop for those who do not want to leave their cars and expose their hard luck to the world.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: N.H.L.
Oilers 2, Bruins 2: Charlie Huddy scored an unassisted goal on a long shot apparently deflected by a Bruin player with 2 minutes 17 seconds left in the third period, giving Edmonton a tie last night.
Huddy's 60-foot shot apparently hit Boston's Ken Linseman and spun past the goalie.
Edmonton played without the injured Wayne Gretzky.

LEAD: A NEW song cycle by David MacBride was the main feature of Sunday evening's concert by the Prism Chamber Orchestra at Merkin Concert Hall. LEAD: Mieczyslaw Rakowski has been at the leading edge for reform among Polish Communists for over a generation.
He never quit the party, as so many did, and his fortunes waxed and waned according to the climate.
Along the way he accumulated enemies among party officials who thought him too soft and critics of the party who thought he lacked the courage of his conclusions.
