LEAD: Armed with pickaxes and jackhammers, a contingent of 40 stagehands worked furiously yesterday to tear apart the set of ''The Mahabharata'' at the Majestic Theater in Brooklyn, barely 10 hours after the last performance of Peter Brook's epic production.

Cyclosporine and Kidneys
LEAD: About one in 10 people receiving cyclosporine to prevent rejection of transplanted organs develops kidney problems, including fatal kidney failure.
Now a group at the Albany Medical Center has found experimental evidence that the reason those people develop kidney trouble is that the drug breaks down into poisonous fragments in their bodies.

LEAD: Dana Goode-Veistrup with her 78-year-old, $14,000 Rodolfo Fredi violin.
It was stolen last September and returned on Sunday after a young man bought it from a man in the street for $10, and gave it to the police.
She now faces a problem because she bought a replacement last month for nearly the same price.


OFF BROADWAY'S BIGGEST GAMBLE
LEAD: ''The Chosen,'' which opens Thursday at the Second Avenue Theater, is the biggest gamble in Off Broadway history.
Its $2.5 million capitalization is more than the combined cost of all Off Broadway productions last season, according to Paul Libin, head of the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers, a trade group.


Chess: American Open Tournament Is Won by Yasser Seirawan
LEAD: Yasser Seirawan won the $10,000 first prize in the 23d annual American Open Tournament at the Los Angeles International Airport Marriott Hotel.
The 27-year-old Seattle grandmaster scored the winning, 7-1, in the eight-round Swiss-System competition sponsored by Software Toolworks and organized by the Santa Monica Bay Chess Club.

LEAD: In Eastern Europe, where for four decades the Soviet leader has represented to millions the main source of their discontent, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has wrought an astonishing transformation.

LEAD: Angel Cordero Jr., thoroughbred racing's No. 2 career money-winning jockey behind Bill Shoemaker, with more than $121 million in purses earned, will be sidelined for at least three weeks because of injuries he sustained in a spill last Wednesday at Santa Anita Park in Arcadia, Calif.

LEAD: A West German diplomat was shot and killed here early today, and there were hints and denials that a Kurdish group was responsible.


Reagan With Scissor
LEAD: President Reagan will cut the ribbon Friday morning when the Army-Navy Club, a 102-year-old institution, rededicates its clubhouse on Farragut Square after almost four years of remodeling and reconstruction.
The light-yellow brick building was dedicated by President Taft in 1912 after a move from a building across the street that President Harrison had dedicated in 1892.


Salah Hindawy, Egyptian Diplomat, 48
LEAD: Salah Hindawy, a senior Egyptian diplomat who took part in efforts to resolve a border dispute with Israel, died of a heart attack Sunday in Kuwait.
He was 48 years old.


The Goose Factor
LEAD: In the early 1950's, a flock of migrating geese made an alarming appearance on the nation's Distant Early Warning radar screens.
Steadily advancing across the DEW line, their formation resembled that of an enemy bomber squadron.
Fortunately, the error was discovered and nuclear scenarists lived to think again.

LEAD: Representatives of Jay A. Pritzker met with union leaders of Pan American World Airways Inc. in an effort to revive his attempt to take over the airline, sources close to the talks said yesterday.

LEAD: Margaret Thatcher has become Britain's longest-serving Prime Minister of the century, and the main effect of her new historical status seems to be a broadening of the debate about authoritarianism and the concentration of power in her third term.

LEAD: The Brooklyn Lyric Opera's professional workshop, the Opera Stage, is to perform Bizet's ''Carmen'' on Thursday at 8 P.M., Sunday at 3 P.M., Jan. 14 at 8 P.M. and Jan. 17 at 3 P.M. in Hirsch Hall at Temple Ansche Chesed, 251 West 100th Street.

Ruins Yield Tales of Ancient Wars and Spies
LEAD: WRITTEN in the clay, a sunbaked tablet from the 18th century B.C., was a message from one ruler of a city-state of upper Mesopotamia to another.
We have released your spies, the ruler said, so where is the money you promised as ransom?


Nora Kaye Honored In Memorial Tribute By Artist Colleagues
LEAD: Members of the dance and theater worlds gathered yesterday afternoon at the City Center to honor Nora Kaye, the American ballerina who died last year.
Known for her dramatic power, Ms.
Kaye, who was born in New York City in 1920, was a member of American Ballet Theater from its inception in 1940 until 1951, and again from 1954 to 1959.

LEAD: Traces of a muscle-paralyzing drug have been found in the body of one patient suspected of dying from unauthorized injections given by a West Islip nurse, a Suffolk County prosecutor said today.

LEAD: Continental Airlines struck a blow at the concept of first-class service yesterday, announcing that passengers who belong to its frequent-flier program and pay the full coach fare could get first-class seats on most flights by making reservations on a first-come, first-serve basis.

LEAD: As usual, the behemoth spending bill that Congress passed just before adjourning in December contains tucked-away provisions serving special interests of individual legislators.
But, surprisingly, some Capitol Hill analysts suggest that, in a reflection of general budget constraint, the bill may have fewer pork-barrel items than in the past.

LEAD: The Philadelphia 76ers suspended Andrew Toney yesterday after the guard failed to complete the team's West Coast tour while complaining of chronic foot problems.
Toney, who has appeared in only nine games this season, started and played 29 minutes at Portland Friday, tying his season-high of 13 points and handing out a season-high nine assists.

LEAD: At a tumultuous public meeting, the Board of Education voted tonight to draw up insubordination charges against the principal of Eastside High School, Joe Clark, because of his suspension of 60 students last month.


5-Year Term in Check Fraud
LEAD: A man who was convicted of stealing more than $428,000 from his employer was sentenced today by Judge Gerard Goettel of Federal District Court to five years in prison and ordered to return the money.
The man, Charles Bates, 41 years old, had pleaded guilty to defrauding the company, Equitable Relocation Management Corporation, during a 10-month period in 1986.

LEAD: FOR a while last Friday night I rooted for the University of Miami to be No. 2 because I thought it was a dirtier team than Oklahoma.
Why else were so many of its players wearing towels on their belts?

LEAD: Tyson Kobus sat under an oak tree here the other day and vented his disgust.
Mr.
Kobus is black and works as a $65-a-week driver for a local engineering company.

Electrical Gremlins
LEAD: SURGE suppressors are devices that stand between a computer and its power source, guarding the machine's delicate circuitry against surges and other electrical fluctuations that are normal along AC power lines but potentially disastrous in a computer.
I like to think of them as gremlin guards.

LEAD: A 61-year-old union organizer, reputed to be an organized-crime figure, was found shot dead yesterday afternoon in his automobile parked in front of his home in Brooklyn, the police said.


Viking Problems Left Behind
LEAD: Now, it is on to San Francisco, where the Minnesota Vikings fully expect to be regarded as an appetizer on the 49ers' playoff menu.
Their one-sided victory Sunday against New Orleans probably will end the talk that they did not deserve to be in the playoffs, but ultimately, the Vikings figure the National Conference wild-card game will be remembered as the day the Saints reverted to their losing ways.


Westinghouse Growth Projection
LEAD: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said that sales for the industrial and broadcasting company are expected to grow 8.5 percent this year.
John C. Marous, the company's new chairman and chief executive officer, and Paul E. Lego, president and chief operating officer, who both took office today, said acquisitions and new business generated internally would account for three percentage points of the revenue growth.


Bridge: A Computer Takes 5 Weeks To Digest a 10-Day Tourney
LEAD: At the end of a decathlon the track-and-field computer can normally digest the results of 10 events and produce final standings within five minutes or so.
The American Contract Bridge League's computer in Memphis, however, took more than five weeks to digest the results of 10 days of national play, admittedly involving much more data.

LEAD: Just before Christmas, Congress gave Nevada an expensive present - the Federal repository for highly radioactive waste, now to be tunneled out of Nevada's Yucca Mountain.
The gift comes with a special evergreen greeting: $20 million, every year.
Yet the Governor of Nevada, Richard Bryan, does not sound grateful.

Troubled Waters: The Concern Grows
LEAD: On the beaches of southern New Jersey, children hunting for seashells came upon broken hypodermic needles and other hospital debris.
Off the craggy coast of Connecticut, lobstermen found their catch already dead because of the paucity of oxygen in the water.
Biologists in New York, performing autopsies on sea turtles that had washed ashore, discovered plastic shopping bags in their stomachs.

LEAD: Having never finished with a winning record in 13 years as a National Hockey League franchise, the Devils are not accustomed to playing in games they are supposed to win.

LEAD: WHY does CBS keep conveying the distinct impression that, all things being equal, it would prefer not to have ''Cagney and Lacey'' on its schedule?
You may remember that the series was officially canceled a few years ago and then brought back, thanks largely to viewer protests.
Since then the show had been doing reasonably well in the ratings on Monday nights, although rumors of its permanent cancellation continued to circulate each year at renewal time.

The Basic Speech: Paul Simon; An Appeal to Seek Out 'a Better, Brighter Future'
LEAD: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns.
Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way.
But more often the candidate uses a basic speech.
It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.


Palestinians Admit Terror Guilt in Pakistan
LEAD: Five Palestinians today admitted involvement in the hijacking of a New York-bound Pan Am jumbo jet in 1986.
But they blamed Pakistani commandos for the deaths of 21 hostages killed by gunfire and grenades.


Film: 'The Horse Thief'
LEAD: THE Chinese film ''The Horse Thief'' is best watched as pure spectacle, since it unfolds almost entirely without benefit of dialogue.
What little talk there is tends to be plain and to the point (''If only we had stew'').
However, from the scenic and ethnographic standpoints the film is often quite arresting.


Inquiry on Nestle Unit
LEAD: Peru has started an investigation of a subsidiary of Nestle S.A. here, accusing it of stockpiling three million cans of evaporated milk. ''This is serious because it involves a foreign company and we have to intervene to safeguard the economy,'' Peru's President, Alan Garcia, told reporters Monday as he announced the investigation into the company, called Perulac.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''For the past two days the central banks have been like a basketball team that uses fast breaks to keep the opposition off balance.
For the past two days they have been buying dollars as the currency has risen in value, an action that has pushed the dollar even higher.
For the last year or so they always bought dollars as the currency was sinking.

LEAD: WHINING chief executives of agencies and magazines, in search of publicity, are fond of saying, ''We are the best-kept secret in the business.'' Few, however, back up that cliche with proof.

LEAD: By early February, the Securities and Exchange Commission staff is expected to complete its study of the October stock market collapse, the commission's chairman, David S. Ruder, said today.

LEAD: The Suffolk County Medical Examiner has issued a ruling of homicide in the death of a patient at Good Samaritan Hospital who was treated by a nurse suspected of injecting lethal drugs into patients, a law-enforcement official said today.

LEAD: ''Three Men and a Baby'' remained the top film at the box office for the first weekend of 1988, earning nearly twice as much as the second-place movie.

LEAD: Congress, attaching special significance to the financial plight of black colleges and universities, has increased the amount of Federal aid for those schools by about 50 percent this year, to $73.1 million.

LEAD: Postmaster General Preston R. Tisch announced today that he would leave office to return to private business in the next few months.

LEAD: Bond prices rose modestly yesterday for the second consecutive day, following the lead set by the foreign exchange market, where the dollar continued to strengthen.

LEAD: Herbert G. Kawahara, a longtime executive of E. F. Hutton &amp; Company, has been named president of the Pacific Stock Exchange.


Swimmer Dies After Sting
LEAD: A swimmer has died after being stung by a Portuguese man-of-war, a bubble-like relative of the jellyfish.
Emily H. Small, 67 years old, screamed and lost consciousness when she was bitten about 30 feet from shore, friends who were with her said.
She was in a coma for five days before she died Friday.

A Computer's Penmanship Problem
LEAD: Computers are dumb beasts that do exactly what they are told.
When told to do something perfectly, they do it perfectly.
Inscribe, a Cambridge, Mass., company marketing computerized calligraphy , is finding that the computer is . . . well, not human enough.
It doesn't make mistakes.

LEAD: Investigators are considering the possibility that the shooting death of a West German Embassy employee was related to a private matter and not terrorism, an Interior Ministry spokesman said today.

LEAD: Manufacturers of drugs given to animals that are used for food will be required to develop new tests for residues, in order to meet a stricter safety standard proposed by the Food and Drug Administration, officials announced Monday.

LEAD: Travel Fox sneakers, which created quite a stir last year by running an ad featuring a male and female clad only in sweat socks and the product, have been switched to another agency.

THEY CALLED HIM PISTOL
LEAD: THE first thing you noticed were the eyes, sad eyes, moist eyes, unfulfilled eyes.
Bil Keane has made a career of painting sad-eyed clowns, waifs who have seen too much, but Pete Maravich was not merely a Keane painting, he was a man trying to go straight.

LEAD: Myerson &amp; Kuhn is making its debut in New York City this week, arising from what was recently the nation's fourth-largest law firm.

LEAD: Robert F. Wagner Jr., his authority as president of New York City's Board of Education imperiled, resolved a sensitive political stalemate over the choice of a new schools chancellor last week with a threat to resign, city and education officials said yesterday.

13,000 Deaths a Year Indicated By Science Academy Radon Study
LEAD: Exposure to radon, the odorless radioactive gas that seeps into buildings from underground rocks, appears to be responsible for about 13,000 lung cancer deaths annually, according to new data compiled by the National Academy of Sciences.


Alysheba Is Top 3-Year-Old
LEAD: Alysheba lost to Java Gold the only time they met on the race track last year, but scored a resounding victory yesterday in the Eclipse Award balloting for the champion 3-year-old of 1987.


Stuart Perlman, 60, Co-Founder Of Caesars World With Brother
LEAD: Stuart Z. Perlman, who with his brother founded Caesars World Inc., a chain of opulent gambling casinos and hotels, and then severed ties with it amid charges of ties to suspected organized-crime figures, died of a heart attack Monday at the North Miami Medical Center in North Miami Beach, Fla.
He was 60 years old.


U.S.-Mexico Export Pact
LEAD: Textile and apparel exports from Mexico to the United States would grow by 6 percent annually in the next four years, compared with a 50 percent increase in 1987 imports, under a pact between the two countries announced today by the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter.

McGwire Leaving Iowa
LEAD: Saying he didn't get a fair shake at Iowa, Dan McGwire, who dropped from starting quarterback for the Hawkeyes in the preseason to No. 3 by the end of the year, said he plans to transfer to San Diego State. ''Very unhappy.
Very unhappy.
You can underline that,'' McGwire said. ''They built me up to be real big and they didn't give me a chance.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation showed off its technological visions of the future yesterday, even though some of its high-tech efforts have been less than wildly popular with consumers.

LEAD: Mayor Koch, seeking to dissuade the State Legislature from approving increases in municipal pensions, said yesterday that New York City would hire 1,548 fewer police officers and sanitation workers over the next two months than had been anticipated.

Brockway Stock Posts a Decline
LEAD: Brockway Inc.'s stock dropped yesterday amid signs the Federal Trade Commission would seek to block its proposed $750 million takeover by Owens-Illinois Inc., a fellow glass-container maker.
Owens-Illinois said it expected that the F.T.C. would try to stop the deal after talks with the agency ended on Monday.


Life in the 30's
LEAD: I HAVE been married almost 10 years to the same person.
Sometimes it's hard for me to believe.
Neither of us was sure that any human being could be expected to live over the long haul with anyone as stubborn, opinionated and difficult as the other.
Somehow it has worked, and it is not a gross exaggeration to say that this is partly because I am a much better cook than he is, and he tells much better jokes than I do.

LEAD: Stephen King's ''Tommyknockers,'' a nightmarish tale set in a Maine village, was the best-selling hard-cover book in the United States in 1987, according to a survey by The New York Times.
Even though it went on sale only in October, there are already 1,345,000 copies in print.

LEAD: The Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden has been given eight major works of modern art from the estates of Gustave Ring, a leading builder in the Washington area, and his wife, Marion.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Skiing  Schneider Wins Giant Slalom: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland won a women's World Cup giant slalom yesterday at Tignes, France, holding off challenges from Catherine Quittet and Carole Merle, both of France.
Schneider was timed in 2 minutes 33.68 seconds for the two runs.
Quittet, who led after the first heat, came in second at 2:33.83.

LEAD: President Jose Napoleon Duarte asserted today that Salvadoran leftist guerrillas were responsible for killing a leading human rights official here three months ago.

Saday Courville, Fiddler, 82
LEAD: Saday Courville, who played second fiddle on the first known Cajun record in 1928 and was one of the last links with the ''pure'' sounds of the Acadian heritage, died of heart failure Sunday.
He was 82 years old.


NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 6, 1988
LEAD: International A2-12


Eating Well
LEAD: MILLIONS of adults brought up on breakfast grains that were colored, sugared, flavored and shaped like little O's or chocolate-chip cookies are continuing their lifelong cereal habit.
But as they have grown older their tastes have changed.
Today, they want something a little less sweet, a lot more sophisticated, with emphasis on nutrition.


A Vital Shadow Society: East Bloc Breadwinner
LEAD: Across Eastern Europe a shadow society has sprung up outside of the control of the ruling Communist parties, tolerated because the authorities have neither the money nor the ability to fulfill Marxism-Leninism's promise to build a better life for working people.


Soviet Bloc Proposes Talks Toward Battlefield Nuclear Missile Ban
LEAD: The Warsaw Pact has proposed negotiations that could lead to the elimination of the battlefield nuclear missiles deployed in Central Europe and along the border between the Germanys.

What Could Be Colder Than Yesterday? Today!
LEAD: It wasn't modesty that caused walkers in midtown to cover their faces yesterday.
Chilly winds made it feel decidedly colder than the 23-degree high temperature that was recorded.
But if you think that was bad, wait until tonight, when the temperature is expected to drop as low as 8 degrees below zero.


Brushing Up
LEAD: A small girl with a big brush taking part in an annual New Year's calligraphy contest yesterday in Tokyo.
Some 7,400 youngsters demonstrated their skill in producing characters. (AP)


John Hancock Unit Hires Ex-Prescott, Ball Chief
LEAD: John H. Goldsmith, who lost his job as chief executive of a Midwestern brokerage firm in a dispute with the firm's parent, has landed on his feet with a new post in the regional brokerage industry.


Monopoly By Shuberts Is Charged
LEAD: Three ticket agents charged yesterday that Broadway's largest theater owner has a monopoly on theater-party sales of tickets to the musical ''Phantom of the Opera,'' in violation of antitrust law.


LESSONS
LEAD: Here in Texas by the Colorado River is a man from Oregon whose story begins in Chicago.
He is a mountain man, a lover of Douglas firs, the self-appointed watchman who keeps a summer vigil high on a Pacific peak.
It seems strange to encounter him on a cold, leaden day among cinder block and steel.
And yet, this is an apt place.


VNU Sets Acquisition Of Media Records
LEAD: VNU, the United States subsidiary of a Dutch publishing company, has acquired Media Records, a company that keeps track of the advertising content of newspapers, and will add it to its Marketing Services division.
Since the division already operates Leading National Advertisers, a major media-measuring service, it means a more complete service for the industry.


GLADLY, THE JAPANESE IMPORT AN AMERICAN CAMPUS
LEAD: Shinya Watanabe was amused at the unlikely sight of his fellow students panicking over a term paper that was almost due.
Nearby, students sitting in study carrels with their heads bent over Western classics occasionally looked longingly out the window.


Savings Deposits Grow
LEAD: Net new deposits at savings and loan institutions rose by $2.7 billion in November, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.
It was the second consecutive monthly gain: Deposits rose by $6.1 billion in October as stock market investors shifted money to savings accounts.

LEAD: Chris Columbus says that it is a privilege to live in New York City and that he ''wanted to give something back to the city I love so much.''

But not invariably, as the diagramed deal from the Blue Ribbon Pairs at the recent Fall Nationals in Anaheim, Calif., demonstrates.

Citicorp Rates Off
LEAD: Interest rates fell for the third consecutive week at Citicorp's regular commercial paper auctions yesterday.
The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.908 percent, down from 7.3946 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 7.0184 percent, down from 7.2978 percent.

LEAD: A second flaw in the redesigned shuttle booster rocket has been discovered by engineers from the space agency and Morton Thiokol Inc.
Their further examination of last month's test firing showed that hot gases reached an O ring seal in a critical rocket joint.

LEAD: Pete Maravich, the leading career and single-season scorer in major college basketball history, died yesterday in Pasadena, Calif., after suffering an apparent heart attack while playing in a pickup game.
He was 40 years old.

LEAD: Nobody was gratified by the 3-3 tie that followed three plodding periods and the blizzard of offense both clubs appeared to save for the five-minute overtime.
Still, the Islanders and the Minnesota North Stars admitted to feeling a sense of relief about at least being able to emerge unbeaten from a lengthy game whose difficulty grew as it neared its conclusion.


Prison Revolt Ends in Brazil As Police Wound Ringleader
LEAD: Police sharpshooters wounded the leader of a prison revolt today, ending a 30-hour uprising that left four inmates and guards dead and eight wounded, officials said.


Marmie Named Coach
LEAD: Arizona State named defensive coordinator Larry Marmie as its new head football coach last night, just five days after John Cooper resigned to take the job at Ohio State.
Although Marmie, who is 45 years old, has no previous head-coaching experience, he had Cooper's support as his successor plus the unanimous approval of the Sun Angel Foundation - the school's main booster group.

LEAD: After more than 60 years as a Left Bank landmark, the restaurant La Coupole has been sold to a French restaurant chain for about $10 million, the buyer said today.

LEAD: Bernard King scored 15 of his 27 points in the fourth quarter, and Moses Malone scored 26 points as Washington snapped a five-game losing streak by defeating the Nets, 101-97, tonight.
It was Wes Unseld's debut as the Bullets' head coach.


Stage: 'Song of Refuge,' Environmentalist Show
LEAD: THE most vivid images in ''Song of Refuge,'' a kind of environmentalist Punch and Judy show, suggest a high-minded, low-budget theatrical offshoot of the movie ''Robocop.'' Following scenes in which the unpolluted natural environment is depicted in shadow puppetry underscored by ethereal chanting, actors clad in outfits made entirely from metal cans battle one another clumsily in a sequence of clanking duels.

Eating Right? Not In America
LEAD: Sugary snacks, soft drinks and french fries are still high on the list of America's favored foods, a nationwide New York Times telephone survey has found.
Despite recommendations to decrease sodium, sugar and cholesterol in the diet, and despite greater consumer awareness, the diets of Americans of all age groups are not significantly more nutritious.

LEAD: The New York Observer, a four-month-old weekly serving Manhattan, cut its news staff by 25 percent yesterday to try to reduce costs, said Arthur L. Carter, the owner and publisher.

It was Credit Suisse First Boston, which shared the top spot with First Boston.

60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: FRIENDS are often surprised when I tell them that one of the favorite foods of my childhood in Burgundy was macaroni and cheese taken bubbling from the oven of the wood-burning stove.
Their response is conditioned by the thought that macaroni and cheese is as solidly American as Boston baked beans and clam chowder.

Vote Puts Small-Town Blacks on Top
LEAD: The small, impoverished town of Keysville, 120 miles east of here, on Monday re-established a local government that had been dormant for 54 years.
The election, seen by many as a symbol of efforts by rural blacks to gain political power, marked a victory for blacks seeking more municipal services over whites who fear higher taxes.

LEAD: The public schools here will be the focus of a national research center on education being established with the goal of restructuring American education and making the country's work force more competitive with foreign workers.


U.S. Crude Output Off
LEAD: United States crude oil production declined 4.1 percent, to 3.03 billion barrels, in 1987, a year when the oil industry was thought to be showing signs of recovery from its nose dive in the early 1980's, Petroleum Information reported on Monday.
Meanwhile, natural gas production, bolstered by increased production from the Gulf of Mexico, increased by 1.7 percent above 1986 to an estimated total of 18.2 trillion cubic feet, according to the Denver-based reporting service for the oil industry.

At the U.N., the Security Council, in a unanimous vote, called on Israel to drop deportation orders.

LEAD: The Broadway production of ''Chess,'' which for the last year has been scheduled, threatened with cancellation and, only last week, postponed indefinitely, is now scheduled to open in April, the producers announced yesterday.

LEAD: Britain's foreign currency reserves rose by $3.74 billion in December, which was more than expected, the Government said today.

LEAD: Too much New Year's food and drink killed 10 people in Belgrade, the newspaper Vecernje Novosti reported today.

Navy Awards Pact
LEAD: The Navy has awarded a $644 million contract to the General Dynamics Corporation to build the 15th Trident missile submarine.
The submarine will be built by General Dynamics' Electric Boat division in Groton, Conn., and is scheduled to be completed in July 1994, the Navy said.
The submarines will each carry 24 of the Navy's updated Trident 2 missiles, or D-5, which is undergoing flight tests.

Real Estate; Flushing's Main Street Is Thriving
LEAD: MAIN STREET, the downtown of Flushing, was weakened but never felt the sharp decline that hit other Queens commercial centers when regional shopping malls began opening in the borough in the 1960's.
Since the early 1980's Main Street has evolved from a struggling retail street into a thriving shopping center where retailers have squeezed into almost every square inch of space and where the vacancy rate is less than 1 percent.

A decade ago only 5 percent of the third world's children were vaccinated.

Letting The Service Come to You. . . At Home
LEAD: IT is the stuff of fantasy.
A woman is delayed at work and arrives home with only an hour to dress for a party.
Her daughter needs help with her homework; so much for bath time.
She jumps in and out of the shower and wraps her hair in a towel.
Thirty minutes to go.
Is she frantic?
No.
A personal shopper has made sure she has the right earrings, stockings and shoes to go with her dress.

For Gardeners, Snow Is Welcome News
LEAD: January brings on the snow.
But gardeners can take heart.
Snow is nature's blanket, the best thing that can happen to plants, at least when it is light and fluffy.
Plants snuggle underneath, bulbs and shrubs push their roots down deeply and grass is safe from harm.


Chile's Inflation Rate
LEAD: Chile's cost of living rose by three-tenths of 1 percent in December, bringing the increase for the year to 21.5 percent, the Government reported on Tuesday.

LEAD: As diesel fuel from last week's spill flowed down the Ohio River, the water crisis here eased somewhat today and attention turned to why a storage tank burst.


Europe Alters Steel Quotas
LEAD: The European Community formally approved a change in steel output quotas today.
Less than 50 percent of the trade bloc's steel will be produced under the quotas, compared with almost 85 percent at the end of 1985.

GROUP LIVING FOR THE ELDERLY
LEAD: THEY were once alone: elderly people who had retired from jobs or housekeeping.
Their children were busy, and sometimes far away.
Perhaps they had trouble seeing, or were just frail.
The old neighborhood was changing and it was hard to find an affordable apartment.
They were a little fearful, anyway, of being on their own.

Korean Car Output Up
LEAD: The South Korean automobile industry produced 957,394 vehicles in 1987, up 63.3 percent from the previous year, according to a report issued today.
Nearly a third of the vehicles were exported.
Yonhap, the South Korean press agency, quoted unidentified industry sources as saying that auto exports totaled 304,471 vehicles, up 78.3 percent from 1986 levels.

LEAD: ELEMENTS that made the Chaim Potok novel ''The Chosen'' popular help to turn the new musical adaptation into a ponderous evening. ''The Chosen'' - the movie as well as the book - is a dense, atmospheric study of a rigorous religious and generational conflict among Orthodox Jews in Brooklyn in the 1940's.

LEAD: Citicorp said yesterday that it would eliminate 400 of the 2,500 jobs at its North American investment bank within two months.
The decision follows an announcement in November that about 1,000 jobs would be cut by the end of 1988 in its retail banking operations because of a centralization process.

HERS
LEAD: ''SEE that squirrel?'' my friend said, pointing.
To me the squirrel looked like any other, except for its tail, which was not a curve but a right angle. ''So?'' I said.  ''If your farm were any closer to this park,'' my friend continued, ''that squirrel would have found you.''

LEAD: Bruce Avery carrying a scuba suit and coat yesterday in New London, Conn., that he wore when a boat he was aboard capsized Monday night in Long Island Sound.
Mr.
Avery and two other divers were salvaging gear from a sunken barge off Fishers Island.
They spent 16 hours clinging to capsized boat before being picked up by Coast Guard.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. I am using a veneered hardwood plywood to panel a wall.
My problem is covering up the nail holes after I nail the panels in place.
No matter what kind of filler or putty I use, the holes are still noticeable.
Can you suggest an easy solution?
A.
An old cabinetmaker's trick should work.


HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: EVEN among professionals, rollers replaced brushes long ago for painting the major portions of interior walls and ceilings.
But a brush is still necessary to reach areas where a roller will not fit.
Knowing how to use a paintbrush skillfully makes working with one much easier and less messy, and it gives better-looking results.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions of Business Day yesterday about the new law firm of Myerson &amp; Kuhn incorrectly described the financial status of Booth, Marcus &amp; Pierce, a law firm whose partners joined the new firm.
Booth, Marcus &amp; Pierce specialized in bankruptcy law; it was not bankrupt.


Judge Blocks Owens's Acquisition of Brockway
LEAD: A Federal judge in Washington yesterday temporarily blocked the $750 million proposed acquisition of Brockway Inc. by Owens-Illinois Inc., as the Federal Trade Commission had requested.


Farm Credit Unit Cancels Offering
LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation has canceled an offering of intermediate-term bonds that was expected later this month, it announced yesterday.


Despite Bitter Cold, Many of Homeless Shun Shelters
LEAD: As temperatures plunged to 8 degrees yesterday morning, New York City officials proclaimed that there was shelter for all.
But hundreds of homeless people preferred to brave the bitter weather on their own, saying they were safer, and in some cases more welcome, on the streets and in subway and bus stations.

S.E.C. Sets Canada Pact
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission and Canadian securities regulators plan to sign a joint agreement Thursday that will expand the cooperation between the two countries in securities fraud cases, the S.E.C. announced today.


Jail Term in Mummy Case
LEAD: An amateur archaeologist has been sentenced to 60 days in jail and three years' probation for trying to sell a 1,350-year-old mummy of an Indian infant to an undercover Federal agent for $35,000.
The 54-year-old archaeologist, Ralph L. Cortiana, was sentenced Monday in Maricopa County Superior Court after being convicted by a jury on felony charges of trafficking in archeological resources and possession of stolen property taken from Federal land.


HAITI'S NEIGHBORS OPPOSE SANCTIONS
LEAD: Leaders of seven Caribbean nations accused Haiti's military-led junta today of violating democratic principles, but after a day of talks they refused to impose diplomatic or economic sanctions.

LEAD: AMERICANS have been called the world's most generous people, but few charitable events enable people to combine a favorite sport with a donation to a worthy cause.
Skiing for charity, a growing phenomenon over the past few years, has changed that.

MOSCOW DECLARES ITS AIM IS TO LEAVE AFGHANISTAN IN '88
LEAD: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said today in Afghanistan that the Soviet Union hoped to remove its troops from Afghanistan by the end of the year, and indicated that the withdrawal would not depend on creation of an acceptable transition government.


Mark J. Rozance, Transit Official
LEAD: Mark J. Rozance, deputy director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, died of leukemia Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center in Manhattan.
He was 36 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Nestle Unit Under Watch
LEAD: The Peruvian Government today took over supervision of a local milk processing operation owned by the Swiss-based food company Nestle S.A., which has been accused of speculative hoarding of evaporated milk.


Yanks Sign Clark, Shaking Up Free-Agent Market
LEAD: The Yankees shattered the two-year calm in baseball's free-agent market yesterday when they signed Jack Clark, the power-hitting first baseman for the St.
Louis Cardinals and one of the premier sluggers in the big leagues.

LEAD: TONIGHT at Carnegie Hall, the American Symphony Orchestra will perform music by William Thomas McKinley, who teaches at the New England Conservatory.
On Tuesday, however, Mr.
McKinley was at the piano leading the Tom McKinley Group, a quartet with Richard Stoltzman on clarinet, opening a two-night stand playing jazz at Fat Tuesday's.

LEAD: The Hunt brothers announced a major victory after a recent order by a Federal judge reduced their potential liability against a Peruvian company's contentions that the Hunts had manipulated the silver market in 1980.


U.S. to Increase Inspections Of Travelers From Colombia
LEAD: The State Department, retaliating for Colombia's release of a reputed cocaine smuggler. said today that all travelers from Colombia are now subject to closer inspection on arrival in the United States.

LEAD: Nonprofit cultural activities contributed $500 million to the Boston economy in 1986, and the arts industry was the third-largest private employer in the city, according to a study.

LEAD: In an unusual move, a small Philadelphia agency has announced that it has published a price list of its services.
Harris-Edward Communications is 12 years old, bills about $11.5 million and serves both business-to-business and consumer accounts.


Copters in Ulster Receiving Anti-Missile Gear
LEAD: In response to warnings of stepped-up violence by the Irish Republican Army, British military helicopters in Northern Ireland are being equipped with machine guns and with infrared systems designed to protect aircraft against surface-to-air missiles, military authorities say.


Fixing Antique Clocks
LEAD: WHEN he was a child in Pittsburgh, Joe Fanelli had no intention of going into the clock-repair business.
But to keep him out of trouble, his father made him work after school twice a week with a local clockmaker.
As he got older, he repaired friends' clocks for fun.

LEAD: The word of the year in 1987 was probably Nimby, biting shorthand for Not In My Back Yard.

That condemns 48 homeless families to lives of continued squalor in the Mayfair


Human Gene in Mice Producing Blood Substance
LEAD: Scientists have transplanted a human gene into mice so that the animals produced a key human blood substance, an advance that may hasten the day when gene transplantation can be used to cure serious human blood diseases.


Ahold Purchase
LEAD: Ahold N.V., a leading Dutch food retailer, said it had bought an 80 percent stake in First National Supermarkets, a chain of 122 supermarkets across the United States, for an undisclosed amount of cash.
The Dutch company, which also owns the BI-LO and Giant Food Store chains in the United States, said the present management would continue to direct First National, which is based in Cleveland.


No. 1 Supporter Is Key to Hart's Bid
LEAD: Her husband calls her ''babe'' and often puts his arm around her.
At a drugstore here he helped her put some batteries in the small travel alarm clock he bought her for Christmas.
They are always side by side, tall and smiling, framed in the dozens of camera lenses that follow everywhere.

LEAD: THE two architectural figures may seem safely captive within the large atrium of the Great Hall at the University of the Arts in Philadelphia, at Broad and Pine Streets, where they will stand through Jan. 14.
But if you walk down the stairs to the bottom level, the 27-foot-tall structures take on a menacing aspect.

LEAD: Henri Filion, the harness driver accused by a colleague of trying to fix a November race at Yonkers Raceway, denied the charge yesterday and said he had never exchanged more than casual greetings with his accuser.

On-Time Performance of Airlines Fell in November
LEAD: The on-time performance of domestic airlines in the United States declined markedly in November, the Department of Transportation said today, and the airline industry attributed the poor showing to unexpectedly bad weather.


Advertising; Heineken to Go To Warwick
LEAD: After April 1 Heineken Beer, as well as Amstel Light Bier and Grizzly Canadian Lager, will have their advertising done by Warwick Advertising.


Dell'Olio's Swimsuits: No Camouflage
LEAD: WINTER, particularly when snow is on the ground, is the best time to appreciate swimsuits.
They conjure memories of warm pools and sunny beaches, and are a sign that benign temperatures will eventually return.
So there was a disposition, earlier this week in numbing weather, to applaud Louis Dell'Olio's showing of his first collection of swimsuit fashions.


Britain's Woman of the Century
LEAD: Cliches flock around Margaret Thatcher as thickly as sparrows in London's East End.
She is indeed forceful, divisive, gritty, a quick study, thinks fast on her feet.
So are other politicians, yet none in modern Britain have equaled Mrs.
Thatcher's longevity.
She has served longer than any previous Prime Minister in this century - 3,167 days as of last weekend - and has a fair chance of winning a fourth straight election.


Senator Defends Plan to Aid Jews in France
LEAD: Senator Daniel K. Inouye has defended his role in persuading Congress to approve $8 million to build schools in France for Jews who emigrated from North Africa.


HEALTHPersonal Health
LEAD: The holidays are finally over.
You're exhausted, relieved and wondering whether it was worth all the time, energy and money you put into the event, which each year seems to be longer, more complicated, more stressful and less satisfying.


Air Controllers Blamed For a Midair Collision
LEAD: Errors by air traffic controllers were to blame for the collision of a skywriting plane and another small aircraft near Orlando, Fla., last May in which all four people aboard the planes were killed, Federal investigators said Tuesday.

LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about a speech by Vice President Bush at the National Press Club in Washington misidentified the club president.
He is Andy Mollison.

LEAD: WILLIAM KOPELK and Olga Hirshhorn both live alone in triplexes that measure about 500 square feet. ''To live in a space this small,'' Mrs.
Hirshhorn said, ''you have to think as you would on a boat.''

LEAD: In a switch from its original 4-to-3 vote, the New York City Board of Education yesterday formally and unanimously named Dr.

LEAD: Visitors to the snow-covered grounds of the Washington Monument were bundled against the cold yesterday despite the brilliant sunshine and blue skies.

LEAD: The Phoenix Suns said they would activate Armon Gilliam from the injured list and make him available to play tonight in a home game against the Dallas Mavericks.
The 6-foot-9-inch, 248-pound rookie forward from Nevada-Las Vegas, who was the second choice in the college draft after David Robinson of Navy, suffered a broken bone in his left big toe in the season-opener at Portland.


Masada Mentality

Cabaret: Helen Schneider
LEAD: HELEN SCHNEIDER'S appearances in New York cabarets, which have been widely spaced over the past dozen years, have shown her in constantly changing lights.
She has been a blues singer drawing on Muddy Waters and Willie Dixon, a jazz singer leaning on Billie Holiday and Ella Fitzgerald, a singer of rock nostalgia and - after an absence of nine years during which she became a rock star in West Germany and an actress in films and theater - she returned to New York almost two years ago singing pop songs of the 20's in a one-woman revue, ''A Flapper's Folly,'' at the


Patrick Dolan Is Dead; Retired Ad Executive
LEAD: Patrick Dolan, a retired international advertising executive, died Dec. 31 as a result of a stroke at St.
Joseph's Hospital in Baltimore, Md.
He was 76 years old and had residences in Manhattan and Much Hadham, England.


Bridge: 1930 Article Gives a Writer A Good Claim to Seniority
LEAD: It seems improbable that anyone now alive wrote about bridge in any newspaper in the 1920's.
Seniority in this area probably belongs to George Copeland, who wrote about the game in The New York Times in 1930.
He received varying answers when he asked the experts, for a Times article, whether married couples who played bridge as partners were excessively likely to have fights and, consequently, divorces.

A LITTLE SHOP OF CRAFTS
LEAD: FOUR months ago the American Craft Museum quietly opened a small shop on the upper level of its galleries at 40 West 53d Street.
And for a very small store, it has a surprisingly high concentration of things you didn't know you needed.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about regulations on mass transit for the disabled misstated the provision turned down by a Federal judge.
The provision was that a mass transit agency could comply with the regulations by spending 3 percent of its budget on transportation for the disabled, but it did not prohibit an agency from spending more.

LEAD: Moderation, which he had lost along with his composure two days before, returned to Doug Carpenter's voice.

LEAD: Doctors here have transplanted tissue from a spontaneously aborted fetus into the brains of two patients suffering from Parkinson's disease, the leader of the group that performed the operations said today.

LEAD: Israel expressed ''regret and disappointment'' today that the United States had voted for a United Nations Security Council resolution urging Israel not to deport Palestinians from the occupied territories.


Debt
LEAD:  Columbus Southern Power Co. filed a shelf offering of up to $200 million of first mortgage bonds.
First Executive Corp. announced a private placement of $235 milllion in short-term notes, with proceeds to be mainly invested in its Executive Life Insurance Company.
Merrill Lynch Realty signed a $330 million credit agreement with 12 international banks led by the New York branch of Algemene Bank Nederland.


Korean Opposition Chief Gets Party Backing
LEAD: Kim Young Sam, the South Korean opposition leader, won an overwhelming vote of confidence from his party today after saying he would step down to take responsibility for his defeat in last month's presidential election.


Suit Challenges Auditing Plan
LEAD: A group of small and mid-sized accounting firms filed suit jointly in New York State Supreme Court yesterday seeking to block the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants from counting the votes on a member referendum that would introduce sweeping changes in the accounting profession.
The judge postponed a ruling until Jan.


Illinois Imposes a Tax on Illegal Drug Dealers
LEAD: Illinois has imposed a tax on marijuana, cocaine and other illegal drugs but expects most of the revenue from the new law to come from stamp collectors.


CBS News Employees Give to Neediest
LEAD: A group of CBS News employees has joined forces and sent a donation of more than $1,200 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
The contribution came from more than 200 employees, including maintenance workers, security guards and mailroom employees, as well as newsroom personnel.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Talking of Eloquence
LEAD: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., traveling in Europe, has conferred this week with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany and President Francois Mitterand of France.
He is scheduled to meet Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in London next week.
His main subject: The United States-Soviet treaty banning intermediate missiles in Europe.


NATIONS' WARNINGS LIFT DOLLAR MORE
LEAD: Central bankers, who acted dramatically to bolster the dollar's value earlier this week, backed up those deeds with strong words yesterday, and nervous currency traders responded by pushing the dollar higher for the fourth straight day.


New York City Needs A Volunteers Exchange
LEAD: To the Editor:


Surprise Teams Hope to Take Another Super Step
LEAD: Three largely unheralded teams remain alive in the National Football League playoffs this weekend.
But if the Minnesota Vikings, the Indianapolis Colts and the Houston Oilers are the underdogs, the Chicago Bears, the San Francisco 49ers, the Washington Redskins, the Denver Broncos and the Cleveland Browns are recognizable big names.


McFarlane Lawyers Dispute Iran Allegations
LEAD: Lawyers for Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, have sharply disputed allegations of wrongdoing leveled against their client in the Congressional Iran-contra report.


Oil Slick From Tank Collapse Reaches City in West Virginia
LEAD: A 20-mile oil slick caused by the collapse of a huge oil tank in Pennsylvania on Saturday reached this city on the Ohio River at midnight, prompting officials to start the process of closing the city's water treatment plant.


Woman Killed By Gunman In IRT Station
LEAD: A woman was shot and killed, and her sister was seriously wounded, when the dead woman's ex-boyfriend approached them on a crowded platform at the Grand Central subway station in the rush hour last night and fired a shotgun before disappearing into the crowd, the police said.


WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD:  FRIDAY  FOCUS ON A PRODUCER


Boitano Closes In on National Title
LEAD: Brian Boitano performing his short program last night at the United States Figure Skating Championships in Denver.
He earned eigh perfect marks of 6.0 for composition and style, virtually assuring himself of a fourth straight national title.
Page B13. (NYT/Jose R. Lopez)


Gaetti Signs
LEAD: Yesterday, less than 24 hours after Gary Gaetti had said that there was ''a real good chance'' he would reject a contract offer from Minnesota and seek a better deal, and slightly more than 24 hours before he would lose the chance to return to the Twins until May 1, the free-agent third baseman signed a three-year Twins contract worth $4.3 million.


A Path to Modernism: Mondrian at the Janis
LEAD: FOR those deeply attracted to modern and contemporary art, the greatest story ever told remains the invention, early in this century, of abstraction.
A heroic epic played out on many fronts, both esthetic and geographic, its countless chapters seem to sustain endless scrutiny.
As with much of the past, these chapters are in perpetual motion, being continually revised and elaborated upon by succeeding generations of art historians, critics, curators and, in their own way, artists.


Early-Music Ensemble
LEAD: Vineyardmusik, an early music ensemble, is to present ''Gulliver's Travels'' set to music by Telemann and performed on 18th-century instruments tomorrow at 10 A.M. and noon at the Vineyard Theater, 309 East 26th Street.
The performances are intended for children.
Tickets are $6.
Information: 683-0696.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.H.L.
Flyers 6, Blues 4: Rich Tocchet and Brian Propp each scored two goals last night as Philadelphia defeated visiting St.
Louis, extending its unbeaten streak against the Blues to 34 games at the Spectrum.
The Flyers are 31-0-3 at the Spectrum since Jan. 6, 1972, when the Blues won, 3-2, for their last victory in Philadelphia.


Refugee Report Burned Over Data on Germany
LEAD: All 138,000 copies of a United Nations report on refugees were ordered burned by the United Nations High Commissioner because he thought it unfairly represented West Germany's policy toward asylum-seekers.


Topics of The Times; Mixed Message for Whistle Blowers
LEAD: The Koch administration says it's serious about protecting New York City workers who blow the whistle on waste, fraud and corruption.
But consider the case of Samuel Adams, formerly a $263-a-week Health Department janitor.
After a month on the job, Mr.
Adams reported to the department's Inspector General that his supervisor was turning back the time clock to protect tardy co-workers.


81% Found to Support U.S. On Backing AIDS Research
LEAD: Three of four adult Americans now know that the AIDS virus can be transmitted through sexual contact, and 81 percent support federally financed research to find a cure for the deadly disease, a new poll shows.
In 1986 this fact about transmission of the disease was known by 61 percent.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 413 money market mutual funds increased $5.64 billion, to $263.88 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 112 institutional funds increased $4.32 billion, to $75.31 billion.
Assets of the 206 general purpose funds were down $117.0 million, to $79.27 billion.


Second Graders Jump Rope To Raise Money for Neediest
LEAD: A group of second graders at Public School 54 on Staten Island held a Jump-a-Thon the other day to raise money for the homeless of New York City.


Ex-Contra Looks Back, Finding Much to Regret
LEAD: The seaside condominium where Arturo Cruz now lives in exile is set in a gentle landscape of marinas and country clubs quite unlike his native Nicaragua.
But the comfort that surrounds him has done nothing to ease his regrets.


Comedy: Dennis Miller
LEAD: DENNIS MILLER is one of the youngest and brightest standup comedians to belong to the tradition of urbane scattershot commentary that extends from Bob Hope to Johnny Carson to Chevy Chase.
Mr.
Miller, who maintains an air of sarcastic deadpan geniality in his role of anchorman for the ''Weekend Update'' segments on ''Saturday Night Live,'' is more vivacious and irreverent in his club act than on television.


Moynihan Says He'll Offer Law To Help Murdoch Keep The Post
LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said yesterday that he would propose legislation that might allow Rupert Murdoch to continue to own both The New York Post and a New York City television station, at least temporarily.


Jersey Passes Bill Banning Sale of Irradiated Foods
LEAD: A bill banning the sale and distribution of irradiated foods was passed by the Assembly today by a 62-to-3 vote and sent to Governor Kean.


The Law; A Tenure Dispute at CUNY
LEAD: The law school of the City University of New York, a much-lauded experiment in devising a nontraditional curriculum and in preparing law graduates for public service careers, is embroiled in a dispute over tenure.


Moscow Speeds Plans for Afghan Pullout Even if it Risks Collapse of Kabul Regime
LEAD: Having failed to find a safe exit from Afghanistan, the Soviet Union may now be bracing itself to settle for a quick exit - even one that leaves the possibility of continued civil warfare on this country's southern border.


49ers Fined
LEAD: The San Francisco 49ers will not appeal the National Football League's $50,000 fine for offering playoff bonuses to their players, Coach Bill Walsh said yesterday.
Commissioner Pete Rozelle notified the team yesterday that, although he would not rescind the bonuses promised by the 49ers' owner, Edward J.


Anti-Smoking Rules Get Koch's Signature
LEAD: Mayor Koch signed into law yesterday a bill that will greatly restrict smoking in public places in New York City.


U.S. Accuses Airline in Buffalo Of Operating After Losing License
LEAD: A Buffalo charter airline formed by a Continental Airlines pilot was charged by Federal authorities yesterday with operating illegally for seven months after its airline license had been revoked.


Consumer Credit Increase Slowed to 4.4% in November
LEAD: Americans took out about $2.22 billion more in installment credit than they paid off in November, as the growth in consumer borrowing slowed in the first full month after the October stock market plunge, the Government said today.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Saints and Presidents
LEAD: The renewed Presidential campaign of Gary Hart has received thousands of small contributions from adiring supporters.
Some checks were accompanied by notes to Mr.
Hart's wife, Lee, praising her for standing by her husband after disclosures about the weekend he spent with a Miami model.


Drug Group to Offer Free Needles To Combat AIDS in New York City
LEAD: In an attempt to force the issue of giving addicts clean needles to help prevent AIDS infection, a private drug abuse agency has decided to defy New York State law by distributing free needles and syringes in New York City.


S.E.C. Details Canada Accord
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission and its Canadian counterparts today set up a framework for close cooperation in an effort to stem a broad range of cross-border violations of securities laws.


Economic Scene; Policy on Dollar: A Puzzle to Solve
LEAD: WITH the financial markets pursuing the dollar down, up and sideways, the big question remains: What is United States policy on the dollar?


A Witness Tells Of Finding Body In Park Slaying
LEAD: The first witness in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. described yesterday finding the body of Jennifer Levin, almost nude and sprawled with her arms and legs askew in Central Park, and seeing a tall man in khaki pants lingering under the trees in the background.


Beacon Theater Organ
LEAD: A program of show tunes, soul, jazz and gospel music is to be played on Sunday on the vintage organ at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street.
James Paulin, who was the organist at Radio City Music Hall during the early 1970's, is to play the theater's 1928 Wurlitzer.
The concert is sponsored by the New York Theater Organ Society.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: The Islanders have assigned the 27-year-old defenseman Ken Leiter to Springfield of the American Hockey League for conditioning.
Leiter, who has played in only 18 of the team's 38 games because of chronic abdominal and groin strain, had missed seven of the team's last eight games. 26. . . .
Dick MacPherson of Syracuse was honored last night in Atlanta by the 5,500 members of the American Football Coaches Association as this season's major-college coach of the year.


Wedtech Prosecutor Said to Scan Some Meese Stock Dealing
LEAD: The Justice Department has sent additional information about investments by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to the independent prosecutor investigating Mr.
Meese in connection with the financially troubled Wedtech Corporation.


Market Place; Funds Outpace S.&amp;P. in Quarter
LEAD: THE stock market's October tumble dealt a harsh blow to general equity mutual funds, but an odd thing happened along the way.
In the final quarter, these funds managed to outperform the Standard &amp; Poor's 500-stock index for the first time since the second quarter of 1983.


New U.S. Investigation Looks at Esposito
LEAD: Meade H. Esposito, the 81-year-old former Brooklyn Democratic leader who was convicted last September of giving an illegal gratuity to Representative Mario Biaggi, is under investigation again by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn.


Lehman Joins Paine Webber
LEAD: Paine Webber Inc. announced yesterday that John F. Lehman Jr., the former Secretary of the Navy, had joined its investment banking division as a managing director.


Selling Out Tibet
LEAD: Traveling about India, or suddenly during conversations here in the capital, I find my mind wandering off to a street in a distant town in the Himalayas.

LEAD: *
Adelphia Communications Corp., Coudersport, Pa., said it had entered into an agreement with Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. to acquire Ultracom Inc. for $78 million.


Hit or Miss to Mullen
LEAD: Hit or Miss Shops of Stoughton, Mass., a division of the Zayre Corporation, has assigned its advertising account to Mullen Advertising of Wenham, Mass.
The budget is $4 million.
Hit or Miss operates more than 450 off-price women's apparel shops.


Bridge: The Right Defensive Signals Can Thwart Declarer's Plan
LEAD: Facing a partner who is knowledgeable and skillful is just as important in defensive signaling as it is in bidding.
It is frustrating to send signals that your partner does not read, or look for signals that are not sent.


Life Magazine to Lift Circulation Base Again
LEAD: Life magazine, which raised its circulation rate base by 100,000, to 1.6 million, with its November issue, is now going to increase it another 100,000 with the March issue, Elizabeth P. Valk, its publisher for the last year, has announced.


Foster Care Can Be Found for AIDS Infants
LEAD: To the Editor:


Rates Drop on Mortgages
LEAD: Interest rates on fixed- and adjustable-rate home mortgages fell for the second consecutive month, and although rates on fixed-rate mortgages declined at a faster pace, the share of adjustables continued to rise, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.


Hart's Rivals Soften Attacks on Him
LEAD: At first they excoriated him, but now the other contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination have stifled their attacks on Gary Hart because they found they were only hurting themselves and helping his resurrected campaign.


Gunnar Engellau, Headed Volvo
LEAD: Gunnar Engellau, the Swedish industrialist who built the Volvo company into a major international automobile maker, died Tuesday in a nursing home in Goteborg, where he lived.
He was 80 years old.


Spacecraft Flaw Seen as Less Serious
LEAD: An investigation of the nozzle failure on the space shuttle booster rocket has determined that a key component probably did not fall off in the test firing but immediately after, and so the problem is not considered to be as serious as first thought, industry and space agency officials said yesterday.


A Jumbo Pick-Six for the Price of Five at Hialeah
LEAD: A betting frenzy surrounding the largest Pick-Six pool in Florida racing history made for a memorable closing afternoon at Hialeah Park today.


Fledgling Plays Take First Flight, Ready or Not
LEAD: WHEN most theater-, concert- or museumgoers come in contact with a creative work, they expect the play, composition or painting to be a finished, polished product.
They may pause to reflect on the arduous and perhaps mysterious process that led from the first spark of an idea, through many creative twists and turns, to a completed work with which the artist presumably was more or less satisfied.


Mack Lobell Horse of Year
LEAD: Mack Lobell, winner of 13 of 16 starts last year, was a landslide choice for Horse of the Year and top trotter of 1987 in balloting conducted by the United States Trotting Association and the United States Harness Writers Association.


Court Permits Effort to Send Boy, 49, Back to Zimbabwe
LEAD: A Federal appeals court issued a brief order yesterday allowing the State Department to resume efforts to return a diplomat's 9-year-old son to Zimbabwe in a dispute growing out of accusations that the boy had been beaten by his father.

LEAD: Bernard Krauss, former president of Esquire Inc., an educational and music publisher, died of cancer Jan. 4 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan.
He was 58 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

LEAD: While the Big East season began a month ago, the bitter battles that distinguish conference play began when Georgetown and Pittsburgh squared off Wednesday night in the season's first true heavyweight bout.


PILLSBURY RESTAURANT CUTBACKS SET
LEAD: The Pillsbury Company said yesterday that it planned to sell or close about 103 of its fast-food and full-service restaurants to improve sagging corporate profits.

LEAD: ONE of the pleasures of frequent ballet-going is the chance it gives to see dancers step into new roles.
On Wednesday, the New York City Ballet offered such an opportunity in a performance at the New York State Theater that boasted four role debuts in Jerome Robbins's ''Piano Pieces.''

LEAD: When the wind howls and the Hudson freezes and the clouds hang heavy in the sky, a funny thing happens to New York.
It turns into Fat City.


Robertson Battles Image of TV Minister
LEAD: Pat Robertson, seeking to broaden his support, stumped through western New Hampshire earlier this week, urging voters to judge him on the issues and not on his personal religious beliefs.

LEAD: WITH support from one TV commercial for men, one TV commercial for women and one radio commercial that is sexually ambiguous, Fairchild Publications on Monday will be offering its new weekly consumer publication Travel Today to the East Coast reading public.


Arizona Gets Rolling Again
LEAD: Sean Elliott scored 23 points, and Tom Tolbert had 20 as third-ranked Arizona, which held California to 12 first-half points, cruised to an 80-51 Pacific-10 Conference victory tonight.


A. Hawley Peterson, Stockbroker, 83
LEAD: A. Hawley Peterson, a retired New York investment counselor and stockbroker, died Monday at his home in Naples, Fla.
He was 83 years old.


Trio to Perform
LEAD: As part of the Washington Square Contemporary Music Series, a trio -Rolf Schulte, violinist, William Purvis, french hornist and Alan Feinberg, pianist - is to perform works by George Edwards, Robert Helps, Babbitt and Stockhausen on Sunday at 3 P.M. in Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street).
Tickets are $8.


British Car Sales Record
LEAD: New-car sales in Britain last year exceeded two million for the first time, the industry said today.
The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said that December sales of 91,000 vehicles, the best since 1971, raised the year's total to 2,013,693.
The group's provisional figures show that British plants made just under 1.2 million cars last year, up from about a million in 1986.

LEAD: The International Olympic Committee said today that a record 143 countries have signed for the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea.

LEAD: Treasury bond prices rose modestly yesterday, as many market participants waited for the dollar to stop gyrating and for more economic data to provide clues on interest rates.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that an agreement on Afghanistan should include not only a withdrawal of Soviet troops and a halt in American arms to Afghan rebels, but also an end to Soviet military aid to the Afghan Army.

LEAD: Syria has begun a diplomatic offensive, proposing to be host for a meeting of the Arab countries of the Persian Gulf and Iran, with which they are at odds.

LEAD: The A. H. Robins Company, which has operated under a bankruptcy court's protection since August 1985, yesterday began an uphill battle to win support for a plan to clear its debts and reorganize itself as a subsidiary of Sanofi, a big French drug company.

LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk intends to negotiate a political settlement with the Vietnamese-backed Government in Cambodia with or without the backing of his coalition partners or foreign allies, the Prince's son and spokesman said today.

He was sledding at Pelton Field at about 5 P.M.

LEAD: William C. Brennan, a former advertising executive, died of cancer of the colon and liver Tuesday at Fairview Hospital in Great Barrington, Mass.
He was 75 years old and lived in Great Barrington.


Bout for Duran
LEAD: Roberto Duran, the 36-year-old former champion, will challenge the Continental Americas middleweight champion, Ricky Stackhouse, Feb. 5 as part of a pay-per-view cable-television tripleheader in Atlantic City.
The other bouts, previously announced, include a title defense by Marlon Starling, the World Boxing Association welterweight champion, against Fujio Ozaki, and a welterwieght fight matching Mark Breland and Juan Alonzo Villa.


Will TV's and Stereos Cost More?
LEAD: Consumers long accustomed to a deluge of sophisticated electronic products that have continually declined in price might be in for a rude awakening this year.
For the first time in years, prices of televisions, stereos, compact disk players and video cassette recorders appear to be going up.


90 Jobs Cut By C.B.O.E.
LEAD: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said today that it would cut 90 jobs, or nearly 10 percent of its work force, in response to the steep decline in trading volume since the October market collapse.

LEAD: Robert Streetman, a high school dropout who murdered a woman in a $1 burglary, was put to death by injection early today.
The execution was delayed three hours by confused state officials.

LEAD: Kansas City Southern Industries said today that it would continue to press its bid for the Southern Pacific Transportation Company despite an agreement by the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation to sell the railroad to another line.
Santa Fe said last week that it would sell Southern Pacific to Rio Grande Industries for $1.8 billion, including the assumption of $800 million in Southern Pacific debt.

FMC Turkish Deal
LEAD: The FMC Corporation's Defense Systems Group and a Turkish partner, Nurol Defense Industry, will receive a $1 billion contract from the Turkish Government to build armored combat vehicles, it was announced today.
A spokesman for the FMC Defense Systems Group, which is based here and has a manufacturing plant in nearby San Jose, said the deal called for about 1,700 armored vehicles to be made over the next eight years.


Will Soviet 'Psychiatry' Go Straight?
LEAD: Under Stalin, much as in czarist times, a dissenter in the Soviet Union might have been shot in the back of the neck.
Under Yuri Andropov's tenure at the K.G.B., the dissenter might instead have been confined to a psychiatric hospital and tortured with psychotropic drugs.


Frankenmuth Journal; Christmas Shopping, All Year Round
LEAD: For many Americans who are just now storing their holiday decorations, plastic angels and stocking stuffers may not be at the top of their shopping list.
But on a 45-acre site in this community of 3,000 some 80 miles north of Detroit, the selling of seasonal cheer is a year-round business.


Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of the snow, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today.
Other regulations remain in effect.

LEAD: While political specialists continue discussing how many debates are too many debates, the second round of the prolonged 1988 Presidential debating competition will start Friday in Des Moines.


Corrections
LEAD: Articles about the publisher Rupert Murdoch yesterday and on Jan. 1 misstated the circulation of The Boston Herald.
It had an average daily circulation of 355,000 and Sunday circulation of 265,000 in the six-month period ended Sept. 30, 1987.

Jackson Says No
LEAD: Bo Jackson, already a professional baseball and football player, has rejected an opportunity from pro basketball.
Offered a chance to sign a contract with the Orange County (Calif.) Crush of the new International Basketball Association for players 6 feet 4 inches or shorter, the former Heisman Trophy winner from Auburn said no thanks yesterday and went home to Bessemer, Ala., to pursue hunting, a sport for which he receives no pay.


Stage: 'Searching Satyrs,' Sophocles at Nat Horne

That should give us a reprieve until 2060, but here it is, as if early confirmation were required that Aristophanes was Greece's great comic poet.

LEAD: December sales at the nation's top retailers were generally, in some cases surprisingly, improved over the figures from December 1986.

LEAD: Citing an uncertain investment climate and a soft market for office space in the financial district, the New York Mercantile Exchange announced yesterday that it was withdrawing from a project that would have created the world's largest commodity exchange.
The withdrawal appeared to doom the project.

BOOKS: Recalling Papa
LEAD:  THE TRUE GEN: An Intimate Portrait of Hemingway by Those Who Knew Him.
By Denis Brian. 356 pages.
Illustrated.
Grove Press. $19.95.


Cooper Stake Up
LEAD: A New York family that increased its stake to 7.6 percent of the Cooper Companies' 23 million shares outstanding said it might seek representation on the board of the eye-care concern, based in Palo Alto, Calif.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Bruce, Howard and Wayne Sturman of Mount Vernon said they might present a restructuring proposal to Cooper management that ''could include the sale or disposition of one or more of the company's principal business segments and a restructuring or liquidation of the company.





SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
LEAD:  Philly Connection


Cold Sends Oil Contracts Up Despite Late Profit Taking
LEAD: Severe winter weather over much of the nation bolstered heating and crude oil futures yesterday.
Despite a late burst of profit taking, the spot February heating oil contract closed up 0.31 cent a gallon, at 53.79 cents, after soaring to an intraday high of 54.40 cents.


Trevor Howard, Actor in Over 70 Films, Dies at 71
LEAD: Trevor Howard, the gravelly-voiced actor who made a career of playing English officers and gentlemen in his more than 70 motion pictures, died yesterday.
He was 71 years old.


TEXACO HOLDERS SEEK TO STOP 'POISON PILL'
LEAD: A committee of shareholders of Texaco Inc. pressed the company's chairman yesterday to change the board's proposed bankruptcy reorganization to remove bylaws that make unfriendly takeovers difficult.


Chrysler's Sales Fell 8.1% in 1987
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said it had sold 2,012,950 cars and light trucks in the United States in 1987, down 8.1 percent from its own 1986 sales plus those of the American Motors Corporation, which it acquired last year.
Its car sales were down 20.9 percent, to 1,096,385, and its truck sales were up 14.1 percent, to 916,565.


Ford Talks Ended by Bank Board
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had ended its efforts to arrange a sale of the troubled Financial Corporation of America to the Ford Motor Company.


Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL


JULES-FRANCOIS CRAHAY, DESIGNER
LEAD: Jules-Francois Crahay, a Belgian designer who began working as a couturier in Paris in the early 1950's, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Monte Carlo.
He was 70 years old.
Mr.
Crahay retired in 1984 from the House of Lanvin, where he had worked for 20 years.
Before that, he worked for Nina Ricci from 1952 to 1963.


L.I. Housing Problem Forces SUNY at Stony Brook to Create New Program
LEAD: The housing problems of Long Island came home to Jeff Casey last summer when the 29-year-old assistant business professor moved his family from Boston to take a job at the State University of New York management school.


Views of U.S Public Sought Over Relations With Moscow WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -
LEAD: Americans in four cities will have a chance to voice their concerns on the future of American-Soviet relations this month as part of a project designed to let Presidential candidates know how Americans feel about the Russians.


East German Leader Visits France
LEAD: Erich Honecker, left, with President Francois Mitterrand yesterday after arriving at Orly Airport.
Mr.
Honecker is the first East German leader to visit any of the three Western powers that have occupied West Berlin since World War II.
French officials say there are no plans for signing agreements, but the talks are seen as a step toward overcoming what Mr.


Evidence to Be Retested In Chicago Rape Case
LEAD: A judge today approved an agreement that will allow new tests of evidence that helped convict Gary Dotson of rape and send him to prison for six years.


Boitano Near-Perfect in Short Program
LEAD: With a stunning performance in his short skating program, earning perfect marks of 6.0 for composition and style from eight of the nine judges, Brian Boitano tonight virtually assured himself of his fourth consecutive national title.


French Music Series Turning to Debussy
LEAD: The Year of French Music, a series of performances sponsored by the New York University Chamber Music Society, continues today at 8 P.M. with a concert of piano music by Debussy at the New York University Theater, 35 West Fourth Street.
Gregory Haimovsky is the pianist for the concert, which is a benefit for the society.


Soviet Bonds Are Success
LEAD: The Soviet Union's first venture into Western bond markets was a resounding success and other issues could follow, according to the West German bank that arranged the trail-blazing deal.


Islanders Caught In Crowded Race To Gain First Place
LEAD: The Islanders, the unanticipated proprietors of first place in their division for the bulk of the season, aren't sure whether they ought to be pleased with themselves or worried.


Courtroom Sketches
LEAD: More than 15 courtroom sketches of those involved in recent trials will be on view through January at the library of the New York Law School, Queens College, Long Island Expressway and Kissena Boulevard.
Subjects of the sketches, done by a variety of artists, include David Berkowitz, Mary Beth Whitehead, Cheryl Pierson, Marla Hanson and Eddie Murphy.
