LEAD: Eight string quartets that are now taking part in the Juilliard String Quartet Seminar Week are to give two free concerts at the school's Michael C. Paul Recital Hall today at 4 and 8 P.M.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''The argument that this is going to encourage drug abuse is ridiculous.
We're one of only 11 states restricting needles, yet we have the highest rate of drug abuse in the world anyway.
And we're not giving needles to anyone who doesn't already have them.''  - Yolanda Serrano, head of a private drug-abuse agency in


Jordan Is Wary of P.L.O.'s Influence
LEAD: Jordan is watching the events in the Israeli-occupied West Bank to see if they might lead to a reopening of Middle East peace talks, but it is wary of a possible resurgence of the Palestine Liberation Organization's influence.


RESTAURANTS
LEAD: LE REGENCE, the opulent, Old World French restaurant in the Hotel Plaza Athenee, has in a sense been a victim of its own success.


Storm Drops a Foot of Snow on Much of the South
LEAD: Snow and strong winds idled much of the South yesterday, stranding travelers and closing schools.
More than a foot of snow fell in parts of Georgia, Tennessee and Mississippi.


Brooklyn Man Seized in Attempted Robbery
LEAD: An 18-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged in an attempted robbery Wednesday that left a police officer wounded and another suspect dead outside a Brooklyn house, the police said.


Poll Shows Discontent on Reagan Helps Dole Outpace Bush in Iowa
LEAD: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas has capitalized on disaffection with President Reagan among Iowa Republicans to build a substantial lead there over Vice President Bush, a New York Times/ CBS News Poll has found.


Corrections
LEAD: An obituary of Harold Matson on Wednesday gave an incorrect date for his death.
Mr.
Matson, a literary agent, died Monday.


U.S. Is Suing Con Edison Over Asbestos
LEAD: The Federal Government filed a lawsuit yesterday charging that the Consolidated Edison Company had removed asbestos from its plants without properly protecting its workers or the public.
Asbestos, when dispersed in the air, can cause cancer or other diseases.


TASK FORCE URGES A MAJOR OVERHAUL OF STOCK TRADING
LEAD: A task force appointed by President Reagan to study the stock market crash will call for radical changes in the way stocks, bonds and other financial instruments are traded.


The Stage: 'Man and Superman'
LEAD: George Bernard Shaw subtitled ''Man and Superman'' ''a comedy and a philosophy.'' Shorn of its third act, ''Don Juan in Hell,'' and without the appended ''Revolutionist's Handbook,'' the play accents the comedy rather than the philosophy - a cascade, sometimes a surfeit, of wit and impertinence at the expense of marriage, morality, wealth and social position.


The Law; The Rise and Fall of the Class-Action Lawsuit
LEAD: The class-action lawsuit, which has its roots in medieval English law, achieved what many consider its finest hour in 1954 when Brown v.
Topeka Board of Education desegregated the nation's schools.
Then, in the 1970's, class actions became the rage of the legal profession.
Now they appear to be dying.


Singer Advisers In Bilzerian Talks
LEAD: The Singer Company said its advisers, Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company and the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher &amp; Flom, had entered into talks with representatives of Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor, about his $50-a-share bid for Singer.


Top Specialist Gives Up Role in Morgan Stock
LEAD: In the first of what is expected to be a series of sanctions resulting from the stock market crash, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that the largest specialist firm on the exchange was giving up its right to make a market in an important stock, that of J.P.
Morgan &amp; Company.


For Melodies From Weill To Webb, Come To the Cabaret
LEAD: Cabaret, an ever-fragile world perpetually on the verge of flickering out, seems to thrive at the coldest time of the year, its intimacy a buffer against the blast of winter.


After Storms, Help Pours Into Town
LEAD: In a modest frame cottage built on a concrete slab, Willie Mae Porter and Marlin Gingerich looked down at her carpet, ruined by water. ''Tear it out,'' Ms.
Porter said.
Mr.
Gingerich bent to do so.


Pan Am Pilots to Cut Wage $58 Million for Equity Stake
LEAD: The pilots' union at the Pan Am Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the company's board on $58 million in wage concessions in exchange for an equity share in Pan Am.


Rent Control Is Target of Reagan Budget
LEAD: President Reagan's draft budget for the next fiscal year calls for a new policy that would prevent cities with rent control laws from receiving Federal grants for the repair of rental housing, according to confidential budget documents.

South African Reports 4 More Blacks Killed
LEAD: The police said today that four blacks had been killed in separate incidents in Pietermaritzburg, where fighting between black political groups has killed 31 people this year.


Study of AIDS And Insects
LEAD: A study of the rapid spread of AIDS in a small Florida town found no evidence that the AIDS virus can be transmitted by mosquitoes, as had been feared by local officials, a research team reported today.


Cards Contact Horner
LEAD: The St.
Louis Cardinals, starting an immediate search for power after the loss of Jack Clark, have held preliminary discussions with Bob Horner. ''At this point, we're talking,'' Horner said last night from his home near Dallas. ''Obviously, there's a fit there.'' Clark signed a free-agent contract with the Yankees Wednesday, leaving the Cardinals without their only proven power hitter.

LEAD: Bob Eddy, a former editor and publisher of The Hartford Courant, died Monday at his home in Glastonbury, Conn.
He was 70 years old.


2 Fish Dissected in Hunt For Evolutionary Clues
LEAD: Scientists wielding million-dollar medical instruments completed a weeklong operation yesterday, the main feature of which was the carefully choreographed dissection of two dead fish.

LEAD: By halting the purchase of plastic foam cups, plates and other products by New York City agencies, Mayor Koch sets a welcome example.

Taiwan Trade Record
LEAD: Taiwan had a record trade surplus of $19 billion in 1987, up 22 percent from 1986, the Government reported today.
Exports were $53.5 billion; imports were $34.5 billion.
Taiwan's surplus in trade with the United States grew 18.5 percent, to $16 billion.


Washington Talk: Labor Union Consultants; Big Winner in Teamsters' Return
LEAD: The high-ceilinged corridor of the Fontainebleau Hotel in Miami Beach was crowded with labor leaders, most of whom had suddenly become publicity shy.


Driver Denies Charge
LEAD: One of the seven drivers charged with trying to fix a race at Yonkers Raceway in November said yesterday that he did all he could to win the race but that his horse was outclassed.


Blame for All in Gaza
LEAD: Sanctimony and hypocrisy attend the great tragedy being played out now over the Palestinians of the Gaza Strip.
Any fair look at Gaza, and the West Bank, shows guilt on all sides - Israel, Arab leaders, the United States and the United Nations.
They have all stood by while Palestinians have been stripped of any legitimate political voice, and few have worked to rekindle hope through renewed Arab-Israeli negotiations.


Demand Rising for Insurance That Covers Long-Term Care
LEAD: Thousands of Americans have begun buying a new form of health insurance that pays for nursing homes or care in their own homes for chronic illnesses.


Art: 'Realism Today,' At National Academy
LEAD: ''REALISM TODAY,'' an exhibition at the National Academy of Design, pulls together drawings that can be grouped only in the loosest way under the same artistic banner.
American artists whose pictures incorporate recognizable images of the world, whether or not these were generated by observations of nature, have been allowed to share the academy's walls.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture on Dec. 31 with an article about Sam LeFrak's Newport development in Jersey City was published in error.
The photo - showing waterfront strollers - was made at Pier 17 of the South Street Seaport in Manhattan.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that after a nationwide search, it had selected a new chief accountant from its own ranks, naming Edmund Coulson to the important financial post.

Gen.
William F. Burns as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, the White House announced today.

LEAD: Nine paintings found in France in the custody of Adnan M. Khashoggi, the Saudi arms dealer, may actually belong to former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and have been turned over to the Justice Department by the French Government, Federal law-enforcement officials said today.

LEAD: Vice President Bush said today that he knew ''a lot'' about the President Reagan's secret initiative to ship arms to Iran.

LEAD: GAGE &amp; TOLLNER, the 99-year-old Brooklyn landmark restaurant, may be sold soon, and its future as a business is uncertain, the owners say.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II is likely to meet President Kurt Waldheim as many as three times during a papal visit to Austria this June in keeping with protocol, Roman Catholic officials said today.

LEAD: Bruce Springsteen will begin a United States tour of about 20 cities for his latest album, ''Tunnel of Love,'' in late February, according to Columbia Records.

LEAD: Donald G. Russell, who has spent much of his career bouncing sound waves beneath the ground as a petroleum engineer for the Shell Oil Company, was named this week to head a small exploration and production company trying to rebuild.

LEAD: A senior Defense Department official made a secret trip to Panama last week to urge the country's military leader, Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, to withdraw from politics and allow an elected civilian government to take power, State Department and senior Latin American diplomats said Thursday night.

LEAD: New Yorkers, however outraged they may be by $7 movie tickets, like to think they are beyond street shock.
Nothing is so unusual or outrageous, they imagine, that they haven't seen or heard it already.
But a New Yorker visiting Chicago recently found something about which to be surprised.


Art: The Silver of San Gennaro, From Naples
LEAD: WITH the Nancy Graves sculpture retrospective and the display of Rodin bronzes, the third installation on the fifth floor of the Brooklyn Museum is easy to overlook.
It doesn't help that its title, ''The Treasure of San Gennaro: Baroque Silver From Naples,'' suggests luxury items, religious relics and little else.

LEAD: A Government offer to buy back stock in the British Petroleum Company closed this week with most investors apparently hanging on to their shares, according to official figures released today.

LEAD: Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga of Jamaica said today that the pledge by the army-dominated Government of Haiti to hand over power after a presidential election scheduled for Jan. 17 ''seems to be on course.''

Nelson A. Rockefeller Empire State Plaza in Albany.

That piece makes its way onto New York stages every so often, but the work from which it may have drawn inspiration has so far not been staged in New York

LEAD: Almost half the tests for the AIDS virus given at a major United States medical center over a 15-month period were administered without a sound medical reason or the patients' consent, researchers reported today.

Escaped Rapist Is Captured
LEAD: An inmate who escaped last April from a Virginia state prison where he was serving a 135-year term for rape and sodomy was captured here Thursday night, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.
The inmate, Rafael Rogel Acosta, was four years into his sentence when he walked out of the prison dressed as a corrections officer.

Carlsson, 27 years old, is being recalled for the third time this season.

LEAD: Harald Norvik, an economist in private industry since 1981 and a Socialist Government official for 10 years before that, will be the next managing director of Statoil, the state-owned company announced Thursday.

The Ice Hockey Follies, With Qaddafi Starring
LEAD: Striding languidly into the large, brightly colored Bedouin tent with his flowing brown cape swept over his arm, Col.
Muammar el-Qaddafi declared to the two dozen West German sportswriters that he had watched an ice hockey game on videotape and approved of it.
It is not a violent game, he declared, but a mass sport that people like.

LEAD: The police have issued a warrant for the arrest of Dino Ciccarelli, the Minnesota North Star right wing, on a charge of assault from a stick-swinging incident during a game here last Wednesday, officials said today.


ISRAEL JAILS ARABS WITHOUT A TRIAL
LEAD: Israeli officials said today that dozens of Palestinians had been jailed in the last few days under a procedure allowing them to be held without trial for up to six months.


Jazz: Clifford Jordan, On the Tenor Saxophone
LEAD: For the last decade, Clifford Jordan has quietly and consistently been making brilliant music with his tenor saxophone.
At 56, with 30-odd years of professional experience behind him, Mr.
Jordan's profound mastery allows him to wrap each note of his solos in its own texture.
In the midst of his unhurried improvisations, he'll convert a low note into a crying moan, slide it up through a silky blue haze to a new pitch and end the phrase with a gently swaying vibrato.

LEAD: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said today that it was studying a wide range of changes in its operations and regulatory role in response to the October market collapse.

LEAD: One of three polyps removed from Gov.
William A. O'Neill's colon this week contained a cluster of cancer cells, his doctors said today.

LEAD: The Canadian Government has denounced a major United States report that concluded acid rain caused little if any damage to American crops, forests and lakes and was unlikely to do so.


Duties Ended On Potash
LEAD: The Commerce Department has withdrawn temporary duties on Canadian potash after Canada agreed to stop selling the fertilizer in the United States for less than cost, the Canadian Embassy said today.

The timing is no coincidence, according to direct-mail marketers, who say they get the best response at this time of year.

LEAD: Olivier Messiaen's ''Turangalila'' Symphony is only 40 years old, but it belongs to an age other than ours.
Its vastness contradicts modern science's assertions that man is small and the universe infinite.
Extravagance such as this bespeaks a confidence in our powers ultimately to control the world around us.

Hijacker Kills Himself
LEAD: A man arrested for hijacking an Aeromexico jet with 119 people aboard hanged himself today, the federal Attorney General's office said.
The man, Marcos Ganem, a 37-year-old Mexican, committed suicide in the hospital of the Monterrey federal prison, a spokeswoman said.
He was arrested Tuesday in Monterrey, where the DC-9 had landed for refueling.


Kidnapped Baby of Murdered Couple Found in Delaware
LEAD: Joyce L. Lynch and her husband, Richard, in the custody of state police officers in Hazletville after they were arrested in connection with the Christmas Eve murder of a Delaware couple and the abduction of their nine-day-old son.
Joseph and Beverly Gibson were found shot to death early Christmas Day in their home near Wyoming, Del.; their two older children were unhurt, having slept through the shooting.


Citibank Acquires 95.1% of Vickers
LEAD: Citibank, a subsidiary of Citicorp, has acquired the 95.1 percent of the brokerage house Vickers Da Costa Securities Holdings Inc. that it did not already own for undisclosed terms, a Citicorp spokesman said.
Citicorp had acquired 4.9 percent of the New York stock brokerage of Vickers Da Costa Securities in 1984 at the same time that it bought a 29.9 percent stake in Vickers's London operation and a controlling interest in the firm's Tokyo unit.

LEAD: ONE of the fastest-growing ''investment'' products available is single-premium whole life insurance.
Its appeal comes primarily from the tax advantages it retained after the Tax Reform Act of 1986 took effect last Jan. 1.

LEAD: The Cuomo administration plans to propose major changes in housing regulations, including making leases permanent in rent-stabilized apartments and ending the need for their renewals.
It would also eliminate rent surcharges for fuel costs and stiffen some penalties against landlords who do not properly maintain apartments.

Taiwan Investment Up
LEAD: Foreign investment in Taiwan soared 84.4 percent, to a record $1.42 billion in 1987, from $770 million in 1986, the Investment Commission said today.
Investment in other countries by Taiwan businesses surged 80.8 percent, to a record $103 million, from $57 million.
Investment in Taiwan from the United States totaled $414 million in 1987; from Japan, $399 million; from Europe, $224 million, and from Hong Kong, $181 million.


Canada Jobless Rate Off
LEAD: Canada's unemployment rate fell to 8.1 percent in December, the lowest level in more than six years, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today.
The November rate had been 8.2 percent.
The average unemployment rate for 1987 was 8.9 percent, down from 9.4 percent in the previous year.


THE BASIC SPEECH: Albert Gore Jr.; Southerner Stresses Strong Military
LEAD: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns.
Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way.
But more often the candidate uses a ''basic speech.'' It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.

LEAD: Texaco Inc. will take charges of $4.9 billion against its fourth-quarter after-tax earnings in order to finance its bankruptcy reorganization, the company said yesterday.
The charges are among the largest ever taken by an American company.

LEAD: A man described as one of the city's major drug dealers was convicted yesterday on charges that will put him in jail at least 15 years, officials said.
A jury that deliberated more than A jury that deliberated more than two days found Lorenzo (Fat Cat) Nichols, 29 years old, guilty of three counts of criminal possession of a controlled substance, criminal possession of marijuana, criminal use of drug paraphernalia and six counts of criminal possession of a weapon.

LEAD: Bill Rodgers, the 40-year-old world-class marathoner who had earlier announced he would not compete in the Phoenix City Marathon today because of a mild Achilles' tendon injury to his right foot, has changed his mind and plans to attempt to break Barry Brown's American Masters marathon record of 2 hours 15 minutes 15 seconds.

LEAD: This year's National Conference for Conductors will interrupt classes and meetings at Columbia University today to give its Theodore Thomas Award to Max Rudolf, a man whose Central European training and professionalism has had a strong influence on American symphonic life over the last half-century.

LEAD: Pat Robertson has lost a bid to postpone the trial of his libel suit against a former Congressman who questioned the Republican Presidential candidate's Korean War record.


Kuwait-B.P. Link
LEAD: Kuwait has told Britain that it does not plan to use its big stake in the British Petroleum Company to control the oil giant.
In a short statement, the British Treasury said, ''The Kuwaiti authorities have assured us that they have no ambitions to control British Petroleum, nor any interest in any management role, and that the Kuwait Investment Office holding in the company is intended as a long-term investment.


Nissan Recalls 75,000 Cars
LEAD: The Nissan Motor Corporation is recalling 75,000 four-wheel-drive vehicles for repairs to pollution-control devices and fuel lines.
The fuel line problem, involving the potential for leaks, is limited to 1987 and 1988 Pulsar NX models.
Nissan said in a statement that it had received no reports of engine fires.


Unemployment in New York Area Falls to Lowest Level Since 70's
LEAD: Unemployment in the New York region fell last year to its lowest level since the early 1970's, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday, attributing the decline to an economy that expanded through most of the year.


BITTERSWEET HOLIDAY JOURNEY PROMPTS GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST
LEAD: ''Sorry I am late,'' Sophie Gluck of Brooklyn wrote in a note, along with her gift of $15 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
She requested that her contribution go to a needy older person.


Auto Sales Climb in Italy
LEAD: Sales of new cars in Italy rose 8.3 percent last year, to a a record 1,976,541, the Italian Association of Auto Makers reported today.
Fiat accounted for 43.7 percent of the total.


Mexico's Inflation Rate
LEAD: Consumer prices in Mexico soared by a record 159.2 percent last year, the Bank of Mexico announced.
The bank said on Thursday that consumer prices rose by 14.8 percent in December alone, the highest one-month increase since the Government began collecting such statistics in 1968.
Consumer prices rose 105.7 percent in 1986, which had been the previous record level.


TOKYO'S PRICE LIMITATIONS
LEAD: Prices fell less on the Tokyo Stock Exchange than in other major markets of the world when stocks collapsed in October.
Some analysts, trying to explain why, have cited Tokyo's curbs on price movements.

Joseph's Hospital in Savannah, Ga.
He was 69 years old and lived in Hilton Head, S.C.

LEAD: Anna Sokolow's Players' Project offered two suites of choreographic images and a little sketch of a dance on Thursday night in Buttenwieser Hall of the 92d Street Y. Because of the fragmentary nature of the proceedings, watching Ms.

LEAD: David R. Waters, president of the specialty store operations of General Mills Inc., resigned yesterday after the company announced on Thursday that it would seek to sell its Talbots and Eddie Bauer retail chains.

Mentally Disabled May Gain Thousands in Back Benefits
LEAD: Mental health and social workers are looking for thousands of mentally disabled people in New York City, many of them homeless, who may be due Social Security benefits that were cut off several years ago in what the courts said was an illegal policy.
Some people may get tens of thousands of dollars.


Celtics Sign Gilmore
LEAD: The Boston Celtics answered their need for a backup center yesterday by signing the 7-foot-2-inch Artis Gilmore, a 17-year veteran who was released by the Chicago Bulls last month at the age of 38.
Gilmore, who averaged at least 11 points and seven rebounds a game in each of his pro seasons, averaged 15.5 minutes, 4.2 points and 2.6 rebounds with the Bulls this season.

Choosing Batteries
LEAD: If you're thinking about winter travel, it's time to check batteries for the appliances you may need.
Manufacturers usually specify the size, from AAA to D, but there are different types to choose from.
Zinc carbon batteries: Least expensive; most cost effective when used in gadgets that require little power.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Cooper Lasersonics
LEAD: Cooper Lasersonics Inc. said that because of the difficulty it had encountered in turning around its laser business, it was no longer considering a spinoff of the business.
Cooper had said in June that it would spin off the business as a separate public company by this month.
The company said it was considering other divestitures to maximize shareholder values.


One for Mother
LEAD: Diego Maradona, the Argentine soccer star who has played in Naples since 1984, said yesterday in an television interview in Milan that when his contract with Napoli (which he recently extended by four years) expires in 1993, he will return to Argentina. ''After nine years in Naples, I will return home and join Boca Juniors to fulfill my mother's dream that I and my brothers, Hugo and Lalo, would play together for at least one year,'' he said.


Fears of a Freeze in Florida Bolster Orange Juice Prices
LEAD: Orange juice futures soared the limit for daily trading on the Cotton Exchange in New York yesterday as fears of a freeze in the Florida citrus region spurred a buying binge.

LEAD: While economists debate whether another bout of inflation is on the way, Louis R. Cooper, the manager and part owner of Cooper Plumbing and Heating in Ottsville, Pa., thinks it has already arrived.


Geese, Sheep and Chemists Vie to Keep Us Warm
LEAD: Is there warmth without down?
After years as the unrivaled cold weather insulator, down is facing growing competition from dozens of new synthetic insulators.


Alfred J. Barabas, Star Halfback In Columbia's Rose Bowl Victory
LEAD: Al Barabas, the Columbia halfback who scored the game's only touchdown in the famous 7-0 upset of Stanford in the 1934 Rose Bowl, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Rockville, Md.
He was 77 years old.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera's revival of ''Macbeth,'' which opened Thursday evening, has already been in the news as an example of the problems an opera house faces when star singers cancel.
The baritone Renato Bruson pulled out without giving a reason (the falling value of the dollar, Met insiders say); the scheduled participation of the conductor Giuseppe Sinopoli and the soprano Eva Marton then fell like dominoes in response, and the performance was headed instead by Frederick Burchinal and Elizabeth Connell on stage and Kazimierz


German Jobless Rate Up
LEAD: West Germany's unemployment rate rose to 9.2 percent in December from 8.5 percent in November as the number of jobless grew by 175,200, to more than 2 million, the Government reported today.

Community Seeks End To Redevelopment Ban
LEAD: The Clinton community board has unanimously approved a zoning change to end a ban on redevelopment of local apartment buildings in which tenants have been harassed by landlords.


HOW TO INSTALL A LOCK ON A DOOR
LEAD: THE term ''lockset'' is used to describe collectively all door hardware (except hinges) that permit the door to be opened, closed and locked.
Usually a lockset consists of a lock with keys, a latch bolt, doorknobs and a strike plate, which is installed in the door jamb to receive the end of the latch bolt and hold the door shut.

The Knicks need a scoring forward like a viper needs fangs.

NEW INVENTIONS FROM THE CORNFIELD
LEAD: OF all the Christmas gifts exchanged on Capitol Hill last month, few attracted more interest than the biodegradable plastic bags Senator Tom Harkin included in the baskets of Iowa farm products that he delivered to colleagues.
The bags, which are designed to decompose after a year or two, are at the head of a growing list of industrial products made with corn, the nation's largest and most important crop.

2 Die in Plane Crash
LEAD: A jet carrying 1,500 pounds of packages for Federal Express crashed before dawn Friday on its approach to an airport here, apparently killing both pilots.
One pilot's body was found, and divers searched the Ouachita River for the other, a spokesman for the local sheriff said.
The names of the pilots were not immediately released.


ECLECTIC FOOD, DRAMATIC SETTING
LEAD: YOUR PLACE . . .
OR MINE, in Williston Park, is not a yuppie watering hole where the gang can go for buffalo wings.
Nor is it a dark roadhouse rendezvous with dewy-eyed couples holding hands in the corners.
It's a startlingly attractive restaurant serving well-prepared, eclectic food.

The Portman Formula in Miniature
LEAD: JOHN PORTMAN is perhaps the best-known hotel architect in the world.
His Hyatt Regency in Atlanta, completed in 1967, was the first postwar hotel with a central atrium, and it changed the nature of hotels everywhere, replacing the banal boxes of the Hiltons and Sheratons with the Portman trademarks of vast atrium spaces, fountains and glass-enclosed elevators.

LEAD: IN January, corporations traditionally add the final sweetening to employee compensation packages, signing off on year-end bonuses and incentive awards.

Texas

Opera: By John Blow, 'Venus and Adonis'
LEAD: ''VENUS AND ADONIS,'' a ''masque for the entertainment of the King'' by John Blow, is an endearing trifle, but the beginnings of English opera were so sparse and tentative that it can plausibly be called a landmark among them.
The king was Charles II; we do not know precisely when he was entertained by this brief retelling, with dance and diversions, of the Greek tale.

The Accuracy Keeps Improving
LEAD: IT is no secret that forecasts of the economy are fallible.
As a nonexperimental social science, economics cannot achieve the degree of precision that physicists attain in measuring the speed of light or even the lower degree achieved by meteorologists in predicting tomorrow's precipitation.
It is less widely understood that, despite several notable mistakes, economic forecasters have been able to predict some, though not all, important economic variables better than simple rules of thumb and that their accuracy seems to have increased over time.


'UNCLE FLOYD' TAKES NEW TACK
LEAD: FOR Floyd Vivino, laughter makes the world go round, and although he has not taken the career leaps that other New Jersey comedians have, his followers have kept his zany humor alive.


FICTION
LEAD:  THE PIOUS DANCE: The Adventure Story of a Young Man.
By Klaus Mann.
Translated by Laurence Senelick. (PAJ Publications, $15.95.) In this 1925 novel, written when its author (Thomas Mann's son) was 19 years old, everything - carnivals, despair, erotic love, bug bites - is experienced with the solemn rhapsodic intensity of romantic youth, a mood reminiscent of Rimbaud that is skillfully captured in Laurence Senelick's translation.

BRONX IS THE SUBJECT THROUGH EYE OF A RESIDENT REALIST
LEAD: IT is not easy being a Realist these days.
Something - the massive art-education program of the last 30 years, the long shadow that Abstract Expressionism still casts, end-of-the-century blues - has made it very difficult for artists to tackle observable reality without a game plan or without seeming to put their efforts in quotes.

More Good Things About the Midwest
LEAD: To the Editor:


On Language; Dam That Tinker
LEAD: WHEN GENERAL Secretary Mikhail Gorbachev brushed off charges of human-rights violations in the Soviet Union with the question, ''What about the wetbacks?'', Americans cringed - not at the crude attempt of moral equivalency, but at the use of a term now regarded as a slur.
A wetback - from the condition of a Mexican swimming across the Rio Grande to enter the United States - later become known as an illegal alien, and when that became onerous, the name was changed to undocumented person, now applied to persons of any nationality who enter the country without a visa.


Egypt Says It Arrested Iranian in Terror Plot
LEAD: Egypt said today that it had arrested an Iranian agent who was setting up a sabotage group and attempting to recruit adherents from among Moslem fundamentalists.
The announcement came a few days after Bahrain reported the arrests of members of what it called a terrorist network directed by Iran.

ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. I am finishing my attic to add a workroom, so I want to add insulation to the roof (it is now on the attic floor).
I have been told to allow for ventilation above the insulation - between the insulation and the roof sheathing - but am not sure how to do this.
Can you tell me if this is really necessary, and if so where vents should be located?

The Kingdom And the Power At Cambridge
LEAD: ''I'M a fellow in English here at Cambridge,'' the young man presiding over our class told us, ''and I shall be the literature half of your course on Tudor kingship.
My history colleague will handle the historical material and we hope our different approaches, intellectual prejudices and convictions will crossfertilize the subject and give you the chance to explore it in considerable depth.


PACKS OF WOLVES? THIS IS RIDICULOUS
LEAD: Martin Brech wrote in the Dec. 13 Westchester letters section that wolves and coyotes might be a solution to the deer problem in Westchester.
This is ridiculous.
Whereas I have never heard of a wolf attack on human, the coyotes have been noted in California for taking a small child in a suburban neighborhood encroaching in the Sierras.

LEAD: THE reviewers agree that Tom Wolfe's ''Bonfire of the Vanities'' is the New York City novel -but not much has been said about what kind of New York City Mr.
Wolfe offers us.
He is generally considered to be a brilliant reporter - yet no one seems to be reading past his headlines, past the scandal.


Texas
LEAD: To the Editor: In his interesting article about Austin, Tex. (Travel, Nov. 8), Peter H. Lewis says that often in the morning the Hill Country is covered with a purple haze.
Those two words, like magic, immediately called to mind pleasant but hitherto long-dormant memories from my teen-age years when I first read one of the many exciting Western novels by Zane Grey, namely, ''Riders of the Purple Sage,'' with the cowboy mystery man, Lassiter, dressed in black.

Mountains
LEAD: To the Editor: Not to diminish Lesley Hazelton's fine endorsement of mountain ascents, ''Because It's There'' (Travel, Nov. 29), a slight correction is in order.
Mount Monadnock is such an approachable and adoptable peak precisely because it is not above the tree line.
Its summit is artificially bare, devastated by fire.

Three months ago, the stock market crash put upstart companies at risk, those fragile new movie makers dependent on stock sales and one hit movie.

FICTION
LEAD:  BROWNSTONE FACADE.
By Catherine M. Rae. (Joan Kahn/St. Martin's, $13.95.) Catherine M. Rae has concocted a leisurely mystery-romance in her first novel that fairly cries out for a long train ride during which to read it.
She presents New York City in the winter of 1920 through a frame of more recent years: In 1981, a middle-aged man comes upon a disturbing memoir purportedly penned by his late aunt two decades before.


SRI LANKA: A NATION DISINTEGRATES
LEAD: The picture of Tamil fighters looking over the bodies of Indian soldiers vividly portrays the tragedy of conflicts inspired by mistaken ethnic pride (''Sri Lanka: A Nation Disintegrates,'' by Steven R. Weisman, Dec. 13).
The young Tamils stare in disbelief at what they have done.
There is neither joy nor celebration of victory; just plain shock and a pall of gloom descending on the blood bath.

A Transient Art Form With Staying Power
LEAD: WITH THE SPEED AND glitz of the art world, the need for the installation as a self-contained work of art, in which visitors can be totally immersed, is not likely to diminish.
Installations are made for a particular place and time.
After their run, they are dismantled.
Most are never reassembled.
At best, they are at the same time immediate and slow.

Taking On Mount Kilimanjaro
LEAD: IT is two and a half hours after midnight, Tanzanian time.
In the light of the full moon lighting our climb, we can look down on the lofty peaks of Kenya's mountains poking up through layered clouds in the far distance.
We are more than three miles into the sky, almost as high as jet liners cruise, and higher at that moment than any of the millions of people on the African continent.


THE PALESTINIANS
LEAD: Israeli soldier facing Palestinians at a refugee camp in the Gaza Strip (Sygma/Derek Hudson)


Bookshelf
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:


NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Wilmington, Del.; A Revival By the River
LEAD: TRAIN passengers to Wilmington used to arrive at a rundown railroad station in an equally shabby neighborhood.
Now the station has changed and so has the neighborhood.


Rival Guerrillas in Lebanon Seeking Unity Against Israel
LEAD: Palestinian and Lebanese guerrilla groups, which have been fighting among themselves for years, are showing new solidarity in their common war against Israel.


LONG ISLAND NEEDS A SENSE OF COMMUNITY
LEAD: Dispersed and fragmented Long Island needs more than leaders who take a hand in community affairs, as John Racanelli urged recently  [ ''Countering the Hysteria on Economic Growth,'' Opinion Page  ] .
Gaining ground on Long Island's future requires a mixture of public leadership with wider vision.


ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. I am finishing my attic to add a workroom, so I want to add insulation to the roof (it is now on the attic floor).
I have been told to allow for ventilation above the insulation - between the insulation and the roof sheathing - but am not sure how to do this.
Can you tell me if this is really necessary, and if so where vents should be located?


ROSENTHAL APPOINTED EDITOR AT G.P. PUTNAM
LEAD: A. M. Rosenthal, a columnist and former executive editor of The New York Times, has been named editor at large at G. P. Putnam, the publishing house announced yesterday.


INDUSTRY WEATHERING THE FINANCIAL STORM
LEAD: THE New York National Boat Show, coming at the onset of a new year, is viewed by the marine industry as the bellwether for its coming season.
In 1988, eyes are peeled for a glitch in the boating market that might be traced to the stock market's Black Monday in October.
But few really expect such a ripple.


Israeli Troops Kill Gaza Protester In Clashes During General Strike
LEAD: Israeli troops clashed with Palestinians in the occupied Gaza Strip today during a general strike, killing a demonstrator and wounding five others, the army command said.


A Look Beyond Stravinsky's Style
LEAD: MUSICAL FASHION IDENTI-fies itself primarily with style, and only when time has sepaand only when time has separated the two (so that the style in which a work was composed merely becomes one of several attributes by which it can be judged, rather than the test of its timeliness) is it possible to attempt accurate comparative assessments of contemporaneous works.

LEAD: The engagement of Juliet Jean Pennington to James Jude Matte, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
George Matte of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Gloria Pennington of Hastings-on-Hudson and Bruce Pennington of New York.
Miss Pennington, a reporter for The Sun Chronicle in Attleboro, Mass., and her fiance, a copy editor at The Boston Herald, plan to marry in May.

OFF BROADWAY'S UNLIKELY HITS
LEAD: QUIETLY, WITHOUT FAN-fare, there has been a resurgence of Off Broadway, with plays as well as musicals developing into long-run successes.
This theatrical arena has once again become a healthy commercial territory at the same time that it is providing the theater with new and rewarding work.
The plays include Alfred Uhry's ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' Terrence McNally's ''Frankie and Johnny in the Claire de Lune,'' Robert Harling's ''Steel Magnolias,'' Barbara Lebow's ''Shayna Maidel'' and Tom Griffin's ''Boys Next Door.


OILERS TROUNCE ISLANDERS
LEAD: Craig Simpson scored twice as the Oilers routed the Islanders, 5-1, tonight, giving Simpson 16 goals in 22 games since being acquired from Pittsburgh in the trade that sent Paul Coffey to the Penguins on Nov. 24.


Question Of the Week; Should The Knicks Trade for Mullin?
LEAD: Chris Mullin is Bill Bradley reincarnate: a team player in constant motion who has a very good shot when he is open.
Just like Trent Tucker.
Based on Pitino's pitiful progress in getting his players to set picks and screens for Tucker, Mullin would fare no better.
KEN ROSENBERG  New York


Statues of Caligula Clan On Display in Florence
LEAD: Several life-size statues, thought to have been smashed nearly 2,000 years ago to eradicate traces of the Roman Emperor Caligula's family, have been restored and put on display.

LEAD: The TV View column in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday, about the public TV series ''Inside Television'' misidentified an NBC News vice president.
He is Joseph Angotti.

A STAY-HOME MOTHER WITHOUT CHILDREN
LEAD: AFTER 16 years, I am at last a stay-home mother.
The only thing is, the children are no longer there.
I timed my transition from corporate executive to budding author to coincide (was it coincidental?) with the high school graduation and departure for college of my younger daughter, Sarah.

They rallied to protest the plan, the new 49th Precinct stationhouse was built on Eastchester

PREDICTING THE PULSE OF THE ECONOMY
LEAD: WHAT everyone in business needs is a good crystal ball.
But to be of value, forecasts must be accurate, and a Chappaqua consulting group, Levy Economic Forecasts, has compiled one of the best records in the country for predicting turning points of the business cycle in the United States for the last 40 years.

HOW TO INSTALL A LOCK ON A DOOR
LEAD: THE term ''lockset'' is used to describe collectively all door hardware (except hinges) that permit the door to be opened, closed and locked.
Usually a lockset consists of a lock with keys, a latch bolt, doorknobs and a strike plate, which is installed in the door jamb to receive the end of the latch bolt and hold the door shut.


By Freighter
LEAD: To the Editor: It was delightful to read ''Marquesas by Freighter'' by Robert Gordon (Travel, Dec. 6).
My friend and I took that trip last March and the best part of it was that there are no age limitations on the passengers.
She and I are both 80, and while it's true that one must be in good health since there's no doctor on board, we found no difficulty in making all the shore excursions and being tossed by muscular sailors into and out of the whaleboats on to the shore or back at the ship for the ascent up the ladder.


India Replaces a Top General in Sri Lanka
LEAD: India has replaced a senior military commander in northern Sri Lanka after months of speculation that New Delhi had been dissatified about his handling of the Indian peacekeeping force there.


ARTS AND CRAFTS FOR THE COLLECTORS
LEAD: RECENT stamp issues can be used to form a collection within a collection.
Pottery, fine jewelry and native crafts can be gathered for an international arts and crafts fair within the confines of a stamp album.

TEMPERED TAN
LEAD: BY NOW, EVERYONE KNOWS THAT A HEALTHY TAN IS A contradiction in terms.
The gap between knowledge and behavior, however, is big enough to hold all the cocoa butter in Florida.
People like the all-over toasted look.
Accordingly, tanning parlors, born in the early 1970's, now dot street corners across the country, holding out the promise of the impossible: a safe tan.


Knicks Stun Celtics As Jackson Stars
LEAD: Mark Jackson, the Knicks' rookie playmaker, has had so many outstanding games, it is difficult to pinpoint his best one.


SRI LANKA: A NATION DISINTEGRATES
LEAD: It was surprising that Steven Weisman's article made no mention of an interesting and important personality in the recent history of Ceylon/Sri Lanka, Sirimavo Bandaranaike, who became the world's first female prime minister, in 1960.
Her husband, Solomon West Ridgeway Dias Bandaranaike, had been assassinated the year before, and she was persuaded to take over the reins of his party, which won the general election the following year.

LEAD: The dollar got strong support from central bankers in both words and deeds.
When the week's trading began in Tokyo the dollar resumed its slide to record lows, but central banks of several countries, including the United States, moved vigorously to prop it up, buying billions of dollars in the currency markets.

In Stamford, Sweetening The Deals Makes a Difference
LEAD: FROM the time Stonegate opened in the summer of 1986 until last Oct. 19, 53 houses were sold.

LEAD: TEEN-AGERS, too often linked with alcohol and drugs through the devastation of family life, are seldom thought of in the same category as the compulsive under- or over-eater, whose pattern on examination is remarkably similar.

LEAD: DURING last year's tumultuous legislative session, traditional party alliances often seemed to break down into personality conflicts, with the new Speaker of the Democratic-controlled State Assembly, Mel Miller, more at odds with the state's Democratic Governor than with the majority leader of the Republican-controlled State Senate.


HAVE AN URGE FOR A GOOD BOWL OF SOUP?
LEAD: IN winter I could eat soup every day.
For lunch, I like nothing better than a bowl of hot soup and a sandwich.
I also like seasonal winter soups for dinner, thick vegetable soups that are almost like stews, with additions of lentils, beans, pasta, rice or potatoes.
I like to serve them in large deep bowls, along with some fresh French bread, with cheese and salad to follow.


HAZARD: ALL TOO FAMILIAR: In Coal Mining, A Call for Strict Standards
LEAD: In fulfillment of President Reagan's campaign pledges, the Mine Safety and Health Administration, known to coal men by the awkward acronym ''EM-sha,'' joined many other regulatory agencies in emphasizing cooperation with industry, rather than being its adversary.
Republicans and Democrats in Congress, the United Mine Workers union and now a number of the agency's top career safety engineers have accused it of going too far - of calculated laxity in enforcing safety standards in what has long been the most hazardous of all industrial workplaces.

WATSON AIMS AT '88 RETURN TO TOP OF LEADERS' PACK
LEAD: Two shots in 1987 will go down among the most memorable in golf history -Larry Mize's chip into the second extra hole to beat Greg Norman for the Masters title and Lee Trevino's hole-in-one at the Skins Game in November.
Those who saw them on television or in person should remember them - they probably won't be repeated any time soon.


Food; DINING LIGHT
LEAD: WHEN I SEE CALORIE counts listed on a menu, I cringe.
Although the threat of extra pounds is constant, the idea of being reminded of this when I'm out to enjoy myself is no fun at all.
Paying dearly for diet food is only further insult.


Carnegie Hall Names A Music Administrator
LEAD: Carnegie Hall has appointed Catherine Gevers to the newly created post of music administrator, Judith Arron, general manager of the hall, announced.
Miss Gevers, who will assume her responsibilities Feb. 15, will be in charge of engaging artists and developing programs for the main hall.
Summer programming is to be expanded and planning begun for the hall's centennial celebrations in the 1990-91 season.

But many professionals who deal with such incest cases warn that had the teen-age victim turned to Suffolk County for help, she might have been frustrated and might even have ended up dead herself.

UBIQUITOUS PESTS
LEAD: CATALOGUES are arriving; before tossing out the old ones, check them to be sure garden notes and plans are not discarded.
Use calcium chloride on icy steps and walks; keep it dry so it does not cake.
Start petunias, snapdragons and other long-season seed indoors.

Salving Market-Battered Managers
LEAD: WHEN the stock market falls, the flight to safety begins. ''Companies are looking at different vehicles that give people an equity position, but protect them from volatility,'' said Ms.
Meyer of Handy Associates.


Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a front-page article last Sunday about the new immigration law incorrectly described the number of aliens whose applications have been approved for lawful status.
About 1.2 million aliens have applied so far, and fewer than a quarter of their applications have been fully reviewed.


Real Runaway
LEAD: To the Editor:


Wall Hangings From Oaxaca
LEAD: THE cacti, dwarf trees and small farm plots that dot the vast plateau of the Mexican state of Oaxaca create subtle harmonies of green and ocher right up to the jagged gray profile of the Sierra Madre.
As the Pan American Highway traces an unswerving black line across this alto plano, or high plane, a blue signpost overhead indicates, by a pattern of white lines symbolizing interwoven threads, the turnoff for Teotitlan del Valle.

Early Early Music: Still a Fight
LEAD: A FEW DECADES AGO, THE term ''early music'' carried the implication of quaintness, oddity and distance, and described a vast literature that ran from medieval troubador songs to the dawn of the Classical symphony.
As musicologists supplied theories about ancient performing practices, established a hierarchy among medieval, Renaissance and Baroque composers, and fleshed out the lists of those composers' works, ensembles specializing in subdivisions within the genre flourished.

LEAD: On their painted, icy field, the Cleveland Browns disposed of one bad memory and one real obstacle today by beating the Indianapolis Colts in their American Conference semifinal playoff game.

LEAD: Iran resumed artillery attacks on Iraq's second-largest city and the two sides fought a naval battle in the northern Persian Gulf, reports from Baghdad and Teheran said today.


A PRIVATE OWNER FOR PUBLIC HOUSING
LEAD: A 40-YEAR-OLD public housing project in New Rochelle, still solid but now shabby, graffiti-marked and in need of major repairs, is being sold to a private corporation that will renovate it at a cost of $7 million and continue renting it to 180 low-income families.

Local Foes Hamper New York's Bid for Collider
LEAD: When New York was selected last month as one of eight finalists in the national competition to become home state for the superconducting supercollider - the biggest and costliest tool for science research ever built - state officials expressed satisfaction.

THE ROAD TO SELF-RELIANCE
LEAD: I hope the irony of the Nyack Boys School is not lost on Michael Norman.
The place where boys learned that the fundamental lesson of manhood is the ''lesson of separation'' and where ''the road to independence and self-reliance . . . insured forever the loneliness'' - that place became a therapeutic center for children with behavioral and emotional problems.

Big Talents vs. the Big Screen
LEAD: FOR ONE REASON AND AN-other, some great performers don't fit easily onto the motion picture screen.
The camera wasn't kind to the Lunts in ''The Guardsman'' (1931), their first (and last) co-starring screen appearance.
Somewhere between the movie set and the movie theater, the grace and elegant humor that were evident in all of their theatrical performances evaporated.

LEAD: THE MEN WHO LIVE ON MY ONE-BLOCK street are a banker, a lawyer, a television ad writer, an obstetrician, a librarian, a retired ophthalmologist and another college prof like me.
On mornings after a big snow, three or four of us will be out there at more or less the same time, shoveling the stuff out of our driveways and off our walks.

Wider Testing For Radiation Urged in Study
LEAD: A major study of the monitoring of radiation at nuclear power plants has concluded that better equipment and procedures are needed in the plants and in nearby areas to achieve safe operations and inspire public confidence.

Matthew's Episcopal Church in Pacific Palisades, Calif.
The Rev.
Peter Kreitler performed the ceremony.


Correction
LEAD: A Sunday television highlight listing and a front-page picture caption today in The Guide, section 2A, misstate Mike Nichols's connection with the ABC comedy series ''The Thorns.'' He is the executive producer.


FANS HAVE LITTLE SYMPATHY FOR SYRACUSE
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Special Gift Of Concerto Conducting
LEAD: LAST FALL, JORGE BOLET PLAYED A lovely run of performances of the Grieg Piano Concerto with the New York Philharmonic.
But what made them lovely was not just the pianist's own brand of commanding, diffident elegance.
It was also the orchestral accompaniment - forthright on its own; properly subservient yet never self-effacing in partnership with the pianist.


Arias: Whom Can He Trust?
LEAD: IT WAS MIDDAY AND THE President of Costa Rica was hungry.
Pausing just long enough to invite a visitor along, he hopped in his blue Honda Accord and drove to a nearby corner restaurant.
The President brought along his sunglasses but left his bodyguards behind.


Maybe the Party Will Thank Hart
LEAD: Contrary to some speculation, Gary Hart's latest caper may turn out to be a valuable gift to the Democratic Party.
He may turn out to be his party's deliverer in the coming electoral season.


Honors for Excellence
LEAD: THE RECOGNITION OF excellence is not a sure thing.
The maker of the better mousetrap may be in real trouble if the other fellow has the bigger ad budget.
They didn't know this back in the days when proverbs were coined.


PAMELA REYNOLDS, PHYSICIAN, IS WED
LEAD: At the Duke University Chapel in Durham, N.C., Dr.
Pamela Preston Reynolds, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs.
Charles W. Reynolds of Akron, Ohio, was married yesterday to Dr.
John Robert Ball, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
John C. Ball Jr. of Auburn, Ala.
The Rev.
Noel Calhoun, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.


How Far Will the New Travel Magazines Go?
LEAD: ITS publisher, Ronald A. Galotti, contends that Conde Nast's Traveler, which made its debut in September, is unique among travel magazines.
Several advertisers agree - which is why they withdrew their ads.


Hogmanay
LEAD: To the Editor: In his piece on the Scots' hogmanay (Travel, Nov. 29), Israel Shenker has resurrected an impressive list of folklore and folk customs about welcoming the New Year in Scotland.
Much of that applied, if it ever did, only to previous generations.

Fat Bear, Thin Bear and the U.S.; Is Soviet Growth Worth Betting On? Yes, a Little.
LEAD: The Soviet economy stagnates and it's clear that Mikhail Gorbachev is willing to undo a half-century of Stalinist central planning to get it moving again.
What's not clear is whether a successful fix would serve American interests.

LEAD: The letter to the editor from the Long Island Association  [ Dec. 13 ]  concerning the projected work on the interchange between the Meadowbrook and Northern State Parkways and the widening of the Northern State between the Wantagh and the Meadowbrook requires an answer.

Boy's Return to Africa Barred
LEAD: Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the United States Supreme Court barred the State Department yesterday from returning a 9-year-old Zimbawean boy to his country until the court reviews the Government's arguments against legal attempts to block the boy's return.

LEMON LAW BEARS FRUIT FOR CAR OWNER
LEAD: I would like to urge every car owner who qualifies to seek redress under the New York State Lemon Law and not through Autocap or the Better Business Bureau  [ ''Car Buyers Get a Referee in Disputes With Dealers,'' Dec. 13 ] .


Terrorism Stalks A Drama
LEAD: AIR FORCE COMMANDOS SNATCH A TERRORIST in Lebanon and bring him to the United States for trial.
The Justice Department is involved; the American Civil Liberties Union is involved.
Sy Resnik (played by Ron Liebman), the well-known defense attorney who also teaches law at the University of Pennsylvania, becomes involved, although not because he really wants to.


THE HIGH PRICE OF GARBAGE
LEAD: The sooner we face the undeniable fact that disposing of garbage costs a lot of money, the quicker we'll be able to solve our environmental difficulties.
I had hoped that the plight of the garbage barge would have raised our waste consciousness.
After all, it probably cost over $1,000 per ton to transport, inspect, incinerate and finally dispose of the garbage back on Long Island.


Sunday Observer; High-Flying Confusion
LEAD: AMERICANS ARE cruel to their journalists.
They say we would rather take cyanide than confess error.
Nonsense.
I am no different from the next journalist, and I am always eager to retract and apologize if I make an error.

New Indian Educator
LEAD: The Education Department said Thursday that John L. Sam had been named director of its $66 million Indian education programs.
Mr.
Sam, a 43-year-old member of the Cherokee Tribe, has been a Federal education official for the past decade and formerly taught in the Sand Springs, Okla., public schools.


HAVE AN URGE FOR A GOOD BOWL OF SOUP?
LEAD: IN winter I could eat soup every day.
For lunch, I like nothing better than a bowl of hot soup and a sandwich.
I also like seasonal winter soups for dinner, thick vegetable soups that are almost like stews, with additions of lentils, beans, pasta, rice or potatoes.
I like to serve them in large deep bowls, along with some fresh

Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a Nov. 29 article from Concord, Mass., about efforts to ban swimming in Walden Pond in Concord, Mass., misstated the status of a concrete pier.
The pier was removed in 1983.


HOW TO INSTALL A LOCK ON A DOOR
LEAD: THE term ''lockset'' is used to describe collectively all door hardware (except hinges) that permit the door to be opened, closed and locked.
Usually a lockset consists of a lock with keys, a latch bolt, doorknobs and a strike plate, which is installed in the door jamb to receive the end of the latch bolt and hold the door shut.


MEASURING SUCCESS WITH A SCALE OF IMPS
LEAD: A small demon has long appeared in this column in enlarged form: the ''international match point,'' which will in future be described as an ''Imp'' and so conform to the practice of most bridge books and magazines.


Marion B. Reith Dead; Taught Aliens English
LEAD: Marion B. Reith, who founded the English in Action program, died of pneumonia Dec. 21 at Pomona (Calif.) Valley Community Hospital.
She was 91 years old and lived in Claremont, Calif.


SOMETHING FOR EVERYONE IN STORRS
LEAD: JACK COHAN, the director of the Jorgensen Auditorium at the University of Connecticut, faces the challenge each season of assembling a schedule that ''contains something for everyone.'' This time, he said, ''I think we've succeeded.''


Israeli Police Challenged on Palestinian Death
LEAD: An Israeli magazine asserts that the police investigating the sudden death of a Palestinian prisoner have rewritten their opinion ''to make it possible to close the file.''


POSTINGS: Leasing a Suite; Boesky's Space
LEAD: Last year, Ivan F. Boesky paid a record $100 million civil penalty for insider trading.
In March, he will begin serving a three-year prison sentence for conspiracy.
Clearly, he needs less office space.


New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:  PERU, by Gordon Lish. (Scribners, $8.95.) A violent television newscast from Peru and a bump on the head jar a 50-year-old man into a remorseless recollection of a murder he committed as a child.
Told in an obsessively circular manner, the novel ''increases speed to a kind of frenzy,'' Stephen Dobyns said in The Book Review in 1986.


HART'S 1984 DEBTS MAKE THE 1988 CAMPAIGNS NERVOUS
LEAD: ON a national television program last week, a caller from Connecticut told Gary Hart that she was ''sick of hearing about your sleeping habits.''


Zaire Mission's Debts in New York Prompt Concern at U.N.
LEAD: Zaire's Permanent Mission to the United Nations owes landlords and companies in the New York region more than $150,000 in rent and other bills, with many of those debts outstanding for more than half a year, according to complaints filed with various official United States bodies by Zaire's creditors.

LEAD: THE rract of making a choice and all its implications have begun to take on a new meaning for me.
Most people, whether they make the right or wrong choice, usually have that option.
The degree varies, of course; should I remain at this job or look for another, should I stay with my husband or leave him, will


THE RIGHT GIFTS TO TAKE ABROAD
LEAD: A DELFT TILE of a blue sailing ship, a gift from a Dutch friend, hangs over our kitchen sink filling the blank space with sea voyages and adventure.
A miniature Puerto Rican ''coqui,'' decorates a shelf in my office, reminding me how the little green frog sings through the tropic nights.
It accompanied a birthday gift of local rum from a Puerto Rican friend.

Henry M. Eisenberg of Hewlett Bay Park, L.I., was married last evening to Daniel B. Kula, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Herman Kula of Jericho, L.I.
Rabbi Saul I. Teplitz and Cantor Lazar Wax officiated.
Mrs.
Kula, a graduate of George Washington University, is an account executive for Parfums Stern in Miami.


Gore Is Openly Challenging Jackson For Black Voters in Southern States
LEAD: Senator Albert Gore Jr. is openly challenging the Rev.
Jesse Jackson for a share of the black vote in the 14 Southern and border states that on March 8 will choose delegates to the Democratic National Convention.


With Hope, Money Goes To Neediest
LEAD: ''Sorry I am late,'' Sophie Gluck of Brooklyn wrote in a note, along with her gift of $15 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
She requested that her contribution go to a needy older person.


Royal Cousin Weds Scholar
LEAD: The Earl of St.
Andrews married a Canadian scholar, Sylvana Tomaselli, today and became the first member of the royal family to wed in a civil ceremony in Britain.
Lord St.
Andrews, 25 years old, is the son of the Duke of Kent, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II.
The bride, 30, a Roman Catholic and divorced, is a history research fellow at Cambridge University, where she met the Earl.

Sidney Jacobs, the Registrar for the British Virgin Islands, performed the ceremony.

He has the intellect that can help solidify the defense and a jump shot that would rock the Garden.
BOB LEE  Roslyn Heights, L.I.

THE ARABS: A COLLISION OF CRISES UPSETS THE NEW AGENDA
LEAD: THE protest in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip has forced the issue of Israel and the Palestinians back to the top of the Arab world's agenda.
It has done so, however, at a time when the Arabs, increasingly focused on the hazards in the Persian Gulf war and the rivalries among themselves because of it, seem least prepared - or willing - to respond to the unrest.

The Power Of Boards Challenged
LEAD: AS the elected directors of a co-op corporation, board members have long had the right to make management decisions without disclosing their reasons to the shareholders.


THE MYTHS OF HUNTING
LEAD: In explaining why he chooses not to hunt, gentle Hervie Haufler  [ ''Three-Generation Perspective of Hunting and Killing,'' Opinion page, Dec. 13 ]  shows he has bought two of the most powerful myths, both promoted by game agencies, that perpetuate the notions that hunting is necessary to reduce deer overpopulation and that the legendary conservationist John James Audubon is the prototype for combining kindness and killing No data support the overpopulation contention.


SPECIAL UNITS AIMING TO HASTEN DRUG CASES
LEAD: FIVE special prosecuting units for drug cases are being created in Connecticut this month, working with local police departments to insure that investigations withstand court tests and to target cases for speedy prosecution.
The units will be part of what state officials call Connecticut's most ambitious effort to step up drug enforcement.

LEAD: It was just about a year ago when Elaine Mittelgluck, the young people's librarian of the Hastings-on-Hudson Public Library, decided that she had read just a bit too much about Westchester's burgeoning homeless population.

Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

New Snow, Old Ice - and Old Excuses
LEAD: The big weekend snow that covered the Northeast would have caused mighty traffic problems all by itself.
But in many residential sections of New York City, it came on top of the thick ice still left from last Sunday night's fall.
With cars now swathed in snow and cemented in ice, some streets may not be cleared till the forsythia blossoms.


The Weather
LEAD: To the Editor: The Nov. 1 Q &amp; A column provided information about weather conditions for travelers.
Since March of last year, American Express has provided Accu-Weather forecasts to card members through our Global Assist Hotline.
The forecasts, updated twice daily, are available for 220 cities in the United States and throughout the world.


Unbidden, Confessions In a Dining Car
LEAD: IN my life, the two points between which I must routinely travel are Union Station in Washington, D.C., and Penn Station in Manhattan.
If I am feeling rushed, I pay a bit more for the Metroliner, which gets me back and forth a little faster.
Otherwise I take the regular train that stops for more pilgrims in its progress along the way.


Ortega: Can He Be Trusted?
LEAD: EARLY ON A HUMID MORNING in November, Daniel Ortega Saavedra boarded a jet in Managua and flew off to fight contras.
He was headed not for Nicaragua's rugged mountains or lush tropical rain forests, where combatants stalk one another, but for Washington, where he believes the contra war will ultimately be won or lost.

FANS HAVE LITTLE SYMPATHY FOR SYRACUSE
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Frank Pace Jr., Former Secretary Of the Army and Executive, Dies
LEAD: Frank Pace Jr., a former Secretary of the Army and the first chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, died of a heart attack Friday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital.
He was 75 years old and lived in Greenwich.


THE ROAD TO SELF-RELIANCE
LEAD: Ralph Waldo Emerson warns us, in his essay ''Self-Reliance,'' not to drag about ''the corpse of memory.'' But Michael Norman drags his memory of childhood loneliness through all the phases of his maturation, calling it the road to self-reliance.
Romanticizing is dangerous.
All the current psychobabble -being your own person, not needing anyone, doing your own thing - boils down to being lonely.


Randolph K. Byers; Pediatrician and Neurologist, 91
LEAD: Dr.
Randolph K. Byers, a Milton, Mass., pediatrician and child neurologist, died of cardiac arrest Tuesday.
He was 91 years old.


A MASTER OF THE MINI-SERIES
LEAD: AMERICAN ACTORS ARE AS good as ours.
American technicians are as good as ours.
American executives are much more cowardly and will not risk their jobs.
Ours will.''


'PUBLIC OPINION IS QUITE VOLATILE'
LEAD: SHELDON R. GAWISER, 38 years old, owns a consulting concern in Westport that specializes in helping businesses collect and manage information.
He is also a recognized expert on polls, which the public will be seeing a lot of in the coming months of the Presidential campaign.


Shopping for Study Programs
LEAD: IT'S the time of year when teen-age students and their families discuss summer school, summer travel or a semester overseas.


New York Is to Buy Acreage on Hudson For Recreation Use
LEAD: New York State has announced an agreement in which it is to pay $13.3 million to buy a scenic peninsula in the Hudson River for conversion to a recreational area.


Miami-Florida St. May Go to Sept. 3
LEAD: Next season's game between the national champion, Miami, and second-ranked Florida State may be moved to Sept. 3 for prime-time national television, according to Wayne Hogan, a Florida State spokesman.


AFFORDABLE THAI FARE IN Westport
LEAD: THE Thai restaurant wave that seems to be flowing throughout the United States is rippling into Fairfield County.
First there was Bangkok in Danbury.
Now we have a new entry, Siam-o-cha, in Westport.
Tucked away in the largely unchanged upstairs premises formerly occupied by Chez Bach, Siam-o-cha (whose name means delicious Siam), is a happy addition to Westport's expanding ethnic dining scene.


The Big-Stakes Battleground of Shareholder Suits
LEAD: FOUR days after Black Monday, CJI Industries, a maker of coin and currency handling products, announced plans to merge with Triangle Industries, the nation's biggest packaging manufacturer and a company whose stock had been battered in the Oct. 19 market plunge.


WESTCHESTER GUIDE
LEAD:  GUN AND KNIFE SHOW  One of two Winchester model 21 three barrel shotguns known to be in existence will be for sale at $50,000 in the Great Westchester Gun and Knife Show, in progress from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. today at the County Center in White Plains.
The weapon is owned by Dave Bichrest, a collector from Gray, Me.

He was 63 years old and lived in Norwalk, Conn.

LEAD: The article about the Performing Arts Center of the State University of New York at Purchase  [ ''Performing Arts Center: Reviewing a Decade,'' Nov. 29 ]  speaks not only to local usage of a quasi-public facility and to programming but to larger issues of interaction between public institutions and private-sector giving.


WHY SHOULD NOBEL LAUREATES FORFEIT THE MONEY?
LEAD: ALTHOUGH the American Nobel Committee has no official connection with the Nobel Institutes in Norway and Sweden, we reflect the interests of some 100 American Nobel Laureates.
There are more Nobelists in the United States than the rest of the world combined.


CHAMBERS JURY TO TEST THE MEANING OF MOTIVE
LEAD: SINCE at least the 14th century, when English common law called it ''malice a prepense,'' judges and juries have struggled with the concept and the consequences of trying to gauge a killer's state of mind at the moment of killing.


NONFICTION
LEAD:  THUMBS UP: The Life and Courageous Comeback of White House Press Secretary Jim Brady.
By Mollie Dickenson. (Morrow, $19.95.) Most of us are familiar with the tragic and heroic story of Jim Brady, the White House press secretary; now, Mollie Dickenson, a journalist, has given us a more complete portrait of the man.


Street Fashion; In Mink, Longer Is Better
LEAD: SKIRT lengths may be all over the lot these days, but coat lengths - especially fur-coat lengths - remain decidedly long.
And who can argue the logic?
Furs are supposed to keep one warm (in much of the nation recently one has needed all the warmth one can get), and fur coats can't serve that function adequately if they're cut off at the knees.


Salaries Inch Up - Sometimes
LEAD: JOHN H. GUTFREUND, the chief executive of Salomon, Inc., took a $2 million voluntary pay cut in 1987.
Merrill Lynch &amp; Company is cutting brokers' compensation by 6 percent, and analysts say other brokerages mayfollow that lead.


U.P.I. News Service to Cut Its Local Coverage
LEAD: United Press International is planning to reduce its coverage of local news and instead concentrate on major news events in an effort to put the company back on a solid financial footing, a U.P.I. spokesman said today.


4 Former and Suspended Officers Are Accused in 2d Stun Gun Trial
LEAD: Two former New York City police officers and two suspended officers went on trial last week in the latest case stemming from accusations that suspects were tortured with an electronic stun gun at a Queens station house.


RAPPERS KEEP THEIR MUSIC'S CONTENT FRESH
LEAD: RAP IS HEALTHIER THAN IT'S ever been, although its death has been repeatedly forecast since it was born in the Bronx in the late 1970's.
In a typical week, half a dozen rap albums sit securely in the Top 40 of Billboard's black-albums chart, while the 12-inch single market flourishes with the diversity of an Arab bazaar.


2 Hurt in Shootings by Police
LEAD: Two men were shot by the police in Brooklyn and the South Bronx - 20 minutes apart - early yesterday, and one of them remained in critical condition last night, the police reported.


THE PRIVATE PAIN OF INFERTILITY
LEAD: Gwen Davis's article brought back all of the grievous memories of my five years of infertility treatments.
Her depiction of an in vitro fertilization cycle - in which couples gamble $5,000 and all of their hopes on a 10 percent long shot - is accurate.

Salomon Brothers' John Gutfreund
LEAD: LAST MONTH, JOHN H. GUTFREUND, the chairman and chief executive of Salomon Brothers, Wall Street's largest investment banking house, completed the grueling task of fixing the annual bonuses for his senior managers.
There was a lot of bad news to be passed around, including that of his own compensation.


Estate Planning for Disabled Children
LEAD: WHEN parents of a disabled child draw up an estate plan, they face a concern that other parents do not.
While other adult children may be fully independent and in no need of a legacy, a disabled child may be left more vulnerable than ever by a parent's death.

A Hong Kong Satellite Looks Ahead to 1997
LEAD: TEN years ago Shatin was a quiet patch of farmland in Hong Kong's New Territories, with water buffalo pulling plows through geometric acres of rice paddies and fishermen's cottages along the Shing Mun River.
It was an evocation of rural China, even though it was only 10 miles north of the teeming city of Kowloon, separated from Hong Kong's busiest district by the steep Lion Rock

HOW TO INSTALL A LOCK ON A DOOR
LEAD: THE term ''lockset'' is used to describe collectively all door hardware (except hinges) that permit the door to be opened, closed and locked.
Usually a lockset consists of a lock with keys, a latch bolt, doorknobs and a strike plate, which is installed in the door jamb to receive the end of the latch bolt and hold the door shut.

Body and Mind; The Drink-a-Day Lore
LEAD: MY FATHER, A soft-spoken, hard-working, heavy-smoking, meat-and-potatoes alcoholic, died the classic death of the mid-1950's.
Shortly after his 48th birthday, complaining of pain in his stomach, he spent a day in bed.
By afternoon, his heart, not his stomach, had stopped working.
The doctor explained that his coronary arteries had become ''filled with crud'' and so he had a fatal heart attack.

That's no longer so urgent a national concern.

LEAD: WHEN the government of the nation's second-largest state and three highly respected health insurers are burned as New York State and Metropolitan Life, Blue Cross and Equitable have been in recent months by losses in the state's Empire health insurance plan, a lot of people start asking questions.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption on Saturday about the installation of Harold T. Shapiro as president of Princeton University misidentified the man at the center, in light-color robes.
He was John V. Fleming, a professor of English, who acted as mace bearer.


U.S. and Canada Close Extradition Gap
LEAD: Officials of Canada and the United States signed an amendment to an extradition treaty today in an effort to close loopholes that allowed some people wanted for crimes in one country to find haven in the other.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''I am exhilarated by the Court's decision and relieved that this nightmare seems finally to be ending.''  - Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, on the Supreme Court's  refusal to reinstate a murder conviction.  [ B8:1. ]


East Side Water Main Break Disrupts Utilities and Traffic
LEAD: Two aging water mains broke yesterday at Madison Avenue and 72d Street, cutting off water, electricity, heat and phones and leaving a gaping hole that will take about three days to repair.
Page B1. (NYT/John Sotomayer)


Scherer Purchase
LEAD: The R. P. Scherer Corporation, a Troy, Mich., manufacturer of pharmaceutical products, said it had agreed to pay $15.25 a share in cash, or about $59 million, for the Paco Pharmaceutical Services Inc. of Lakewood, N.J.
A Scherer subsidiary is to be merged into Paco as soon as Scherer obtains a majority of Paco's 39 million shares outstanding.


Science Watch; Test Tube Chickens
LEAD: THE question of which came first, the chicken or the egg, may be losing some of its meaning.
A scientist has learned how to produce the chick without its own egg shell.


S.M.U. Wooing Gregg
LEAD: Forrest Gregg of the Green Bay Packers said last night he has received permission to talk with Southern Methodist University officials about the vacant coach's job at his alma mater. ''We will talk,'' Gregg said. ''I'm sure they are interested in what I have to say and I'm interested in what they have to say.


Dollar Finishes With Gains After Central Banks Step In
LEAD: The dollar finished slightly higher in relation to most other major currencies yesterday after central banks intervened to stem its fall.


Pollution Is Blamed for Killing Whales in St. Lawrence
LEAD: Pollution from industrial activity along the St.
Lawrence River and its tributaries, including the Great Lakes, is causing disease, premature death and a declining birth rate among the white beluga whales in the river, according to Canadian researchers.


Roth and Rhodes Books Get Critics Circle Awards
LEAD: ''The Counterlife'' by Philip Roth was named the best novel of 1987 by the National Book Critics Circle yesterday, beating out ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' by Tom Wolfe after what a participant described as a ''passionate and heated discussion.''


Dialing QuantumLink
LEAD: IF you own a Commodore 64 or 128 and a modem, QuantumLink is definitely worth a trial flight.


Plea in Concealing of Death
LEAD: The father of a boy whose body was found in a ditch two years ago pleaded guilty today to misdemeanor charges of abandoning a body and concealing a death.
The man, Eli Stutzman, was sentenced to 18 months in prison after he entered the pleas in Thayer County Court.
Mr.
Stutzman testified that he and his 9-year-old son, Danny, were driving from Wyoming to Ohio on Route 81 in December 1985 when the boy died.


GERMAN IS SEIZED IN DISCO BOMBING
LEAD: The police announced today that they had arrested a West German woman suspected of planting the bomb in a West Berlin disco that killed two American servicemen and a Turkish woman, wounded 229 and prompted the American air attack on Libya in April 1986.

Shuttle to Be Delayed At Least Until July 15
LEAD: Problems with the space shuttle's booster rockets will delay the resumption of flights at least until July 15, space agency officials said today.
But they said they would launch the craft as soon as it was ready, countering speculation that they might delay the flight until after November's Presidential election for political reasons.


For Soviet Alternative Press, Used Computer Is New Tool
LEAD: In the living room of his southwest Moscow apartment, Lev M. Timofeyev has a Toshiba 1000 personal computer and a Kodak Diconix printer.


Boy, 13, Saves 4 Neighbors
LEAD: Matt Snyder, a 13-year-old boy who stayed up late doing homework, has been credited with saving four neighbors when their home caught fire.
He was translating Latin sentences about 12:30 A.M.
Sunday when he heard a crackling noise.
After alerting his parents to call the fire department, he ran next door and banged on the front door until Mike Oklevitch answered and got his family out.


Night of College Upsets
LEAD: Villanova's Mark Plansky shooting over Rony Seikaly of Syracuse in a Big East game last night in Philadelphia.
Villanova scored an 80-78 upset.
Oklahoma and Indiana were also upset.

'Pappy' Boyington Is Dead at 75; Hero of the Black Sheep Squadron
LEAD: Gregory (Pappy) Boyington, the Marine flying ace of World War II who commanded the famous Black Sheep Squadron, shot down 28 Japanese planes and won the Medal of Honor, died here this morning at a hospice for cancer patients.
He was 75 years old.

LEAD: The historic vessels and unusual older buildings at New York City's South Street Seaport Museum were saved with funds generated by selling unused air rights over the old buildings to a consortium of banks.

He was 89 years old.
