NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JANUARY 12, 1988
LEAD:  International A3-10


Dance: 'Einszweidrei'
LEAD: JODY OBERFELDER-RIEHM'S ''Einszweidrei'' ought to be bottled and sold as instant good cheer.
It is that rare genuinely funny dance that manages both to make its points wittily and to give its dancers a chance to let loose and yet be themselves on stage.
There was a good deal more to their performances on Friday evening, in a program of four dances presented by the Jody Oberfelder-Riehm Dance Company at the Dia Art Foundation theater.


Superconductivity Moves From the Laboratory to the Classroom
LEAD: THE discovery in 1986 of a new class of substances called high-temperature superconductors has galvanized research in chemistry and physics, spurred a global race for industrial and military applications and led two scientists to a Nobel Prize.
Now, less than two years after the landmark discovery, even high school students can demonstrate high-temperature superconductivity for less than $50.


Ex-Worker Sues Hutton
LEAD: A former executive with the E. F. Hutton Group filed a $30 million class action lawsuit yesterday, contending that he and other Hutton employees were denied shares in the brokerage house they had been promised when it was acquired by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.


Tears for Kelly: An Elderly Man Freezes to Death
LEAD: Last Thursday, on the day workers from a cleaning service arrived, along with a city social worker carrying a bag full of shirts, Joseph Stiletto was found frozen to death in his second-floor apartment at 16 Abingdon Square in Greenwich Village.
He was 79 years old.


A PLEA FOR MARKET COORDINATION
LEAD: The Presidential panel's report on the stock market crash has run into a cool reception from some in the White House and heavy criticism from some in Congress and on Wall Street for its proposed reforms of the financial system.
Already there have been predictions that the proposals will never be enacted.


'Cabaret' to Switch Theaters
LEAD: The revival of ''Cabaret,'' starring Joel Grey, is to move from the Imperial Theater to the Minskoff to make way for the musical ''Chess,'' Fred Nathan, a spokesman for the show, said yesterday.
The show, which must move no later than March 20, may move earlier, he said. ''Chess'' is to begin performances at the Imperial on April 4.

Vice Chairman Named At Continental Illinois
LEAD: The Continental Illinois Corporation said yesterday that S. Waite Rawls 3d, a managing director of Chemical Bank, would join it on Feb. 1 as vice chairman.


Mecham Seems Contrite in a Speech
LEAD: The troubled Governor of Arizona, Evan Mecham, opened the state's legislative session today by acknowledging ''I have made mistakes'' and extending a conciliatory hand to legislators he had largely ignored in his first year in office.


Kirin Buys Bottler
LEAD: Japan's leading brewer said its United States subsidiary had acquired the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Northern New England.
KW Inc., a Bedford, N.H., subsidiary of the Kirin Brewery Company, bought the remaining 75 percent of the bottling company's stock for $46.5 million earlier this month, Kirin said.


'Slippery Water': Mystery Seems Finally Solved
LEAD: A VISION of long, silken molecules coiling and uncoiling like millions of invisible yo-yos appears to have explained one of the most perplexing phenomena of fluid flow.


Corrections
LEAD: An obituary on Dec. 24 about Hob Broun, a writer, included an incorrect account from his publisher, Alfred A. Knopf, about his illness and death.


U.S. Services Agency to Hire An Outside Firm on Auditing
LEAD: The General Services Administration said today that for the first time it would hire an outside accounting firm to audit its books.

The occasion is the return of ''Side by Side by Sondheim,'' the revue or concert or party that was brought to Broadway by the British in 1977.

Prison Riots Provoke Debate Among Cuban Exiles
LEAD: The consequences of the recent prison riots by Cuban alien inmates in Atlanta and Oakdale, La., are still reverberating here in a divisive debate about the image of the Cuban-American community, After the riots late last year there was a consensus here that the image of Miami Cubans, who account for more than 700,000 of the area's population of l.9 million, had been tarnished.

LEAD: The elimination of athletic scholarships would help return college sports to ''the amateur student-athlete model'' that most college presidents desire, the head of the American Council on Education told the National Collegiate Athletic Association today.

Sterling Sues Hoffmann-La Roche
LEAD: Sterling Drug Inc., the object of a $4.2 billion takeover offer from F. Hoffmann-La Roche &amp; Company, filed suit yesterday against the big Swiss drug producer, accusing it of falsifying dealings to hide profits and avoid income taxes, buying stock on inside information and failing to disclose details about who owns the company.


Winning Hole-in-One
LEAD: Dan Pohl posted a hole-in-one yesterday, although his ace on the 181-yard third hole at LaCosta Country Club in Carlsbad, Calif., won't go into the official record book.
The eagle 1 proved to be the margin of victory as Pohl won the annual nine-hole Epson shootout by two strokes over Ben Crenshaw, Paul Azinger and John McComish.


Seagram Raises Its Bid For Martell Cognac
LEAD: Faced with objections from the French Government over its earlier offer, the Seagram Company said today that it would raise its bid for the cognac maker Martell &amp; Compagnie to 2,975 francs a share, thus topping a bid made by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.


DECOY UNIT ON BIAS CASES IS READIED
LEAD: Moving to deter the rising number of bias-related crimes reported in New York City, the Police Department announced yesterday that beginning today it would deploy at least six decoy teams ''to identify and arrest those who victimize others because of race, religion or ethnicity.''

U.N. Lowers '88 Estimates
LEAD: The United Nations said today that it had revised downward its forecast for worldwide economic growth in 1988.

LEAD: Eight Latin American countries are threatening to block the appointment of a new president of an international lending agency unless the United States backs off from a demand for virtual veto power over new loans.

Foreign Edge in Takeovers
LEAD: Companies in Britain, West Germany and Japan have an advantage in acquiring American companies because of how laws regarding good will payments are handled by their countries, a Congressional report says.

Driver Denies Charge
LEAD: Michel LaChance, one of seven harness drivers suspended by the State Racing and Wagering Board in connection with a Nov. 14 race at Yonkers Raceway, told the board yesterday that ''I tried everything I knew to win.''


Former Agent Indicted
LEAD: A grand jury in Opelika, Ala., yesterday indicted Jim Abernethy, a former Atlanta sports agent who has said he paid performance bonuses to the Auburn defensive back, Kevin Porter.
Don Siegelman, the Alabama attorney general, said that the panel returned misdemeanor counts of tampering with a sports event, violating the deceptive practices act and commercial bribery.

Campaign Finance Folly

Each contribution would be matched by city tax dollars.

Napa Journal; Custom Caves for Vintners' Tastes
LEAD: Give Alf Burtleson a mountain, and he'll give you a cave.
In California's Napa Valley, about 45 miles north of San Francisco, no one is more in demand these days than Mr.
Burtleson, who calls himself a cave man.
He digs caves.
But not ordinary caves.
Burrowing into hillsides, he creates spacious and elegant caverns in the earth that wine makers fill with barrels and bottles of aging wine.

Furs: Now It's a Buyer's Market
LEAD: The deep freeze of the last week has set many cloth-coat wearers to thinking about furs.
And now is the time to buy.
Between fears about the economy and concern over hemlines, fewer coats were sold earlier in the season than furriers had anticipated.
As a result, fur salons, stores and manufacturers are marking down furs anywhere from 20 to 50 percent.

Sikorsky Contract
LEAD: The Sikorsky Aircraft division of the United Technologies Corporation. has been awarded a $983.2 million contract to build 252 UH-60 Blackhawk helicopters, the Army said.
The contract is for four years.
The Army said Sikorsky had been given $243.5 million as a first-year increment toward work on the helicopters, which will be built in Stratford, Conn.

The hearings, to be held by the investigations subcommittee of the Energy and Commerce Committee, are expected to last six to eight days and focus on leveraged buyouts, corporate takeovers and insider trading.

Prize Reporting
LEAD: The Gerald R. Ford Foundation has established two $5,000 journalism prizes, one for coverage of the Presidency and the other for national defense.
The 1988 awards, to be presented in Washington in June, will recognize ''lifetime journalistic achievement'' in the field; subsequent prizes will honor ''consistent, judicious, sensitive and noteworthy coverage'' during the previous calendar year.


Dance: John Carrafa
LEAD: JOHN CARRAFA, Donald Fleming and Vicky Shick are all very good dancers.
They move interestingly and have strong techniques.
They also have intelligent, clearly defined stage presences.
And the dances they presented on Saturday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, in a program produced by Dance Chance, were as sophisticated and well-crafted as one might have expected.


2 Water Mains Burst on Upper East Side
LEAD: Two aging water mains burst early yesterday morning on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, flooding basements, knocking out utilities and making the rush hour treacherous for commuters as water turned to ice in the subfreezing weather.


Global Climate Project Is Summit Bonus
LEAD: To the Editor:


Austria Glances Back
LEAD: Austria is preparing nervously for the 50th anniversary of its absorption into Hitler's Third Reich, on March 11.
As Chancellor Franz Vranitzky says, it wiped the country off the map in 1938, but also led to ''its rebirth as a nation'' after the war.

LEAD: West Germany, under international pressure to buy more foreign goods and sell fewer abroad, reported a record trade surplus last year, according to early official figures published today.

LEAD: The Security Pacific Corporation said today that it had set aside a reserve to cover more than half of its $1.8 billion portfolio of loans to developing countries, making it the largest bank to declare more than half of the portfolio in jeopardy.

LEAD: The chief economist for Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company predicted yesterday that sales of general merchandise would increase 5.8 percent in 1988, compared with a 5.2 percent rise last year.

LEAD: New language inserted in last month's omnibus Federal spending bill appears to have insured that a tax benefit originally intended for a farm-equipment manufacturer will also apply to the Big Three auto makers, Congressional and industry sources said today.

LEAD: In a move to close down several major distributors of pornography, the Justice Department plans to seek a series of racketeering indictments this year designed to seize tens of millions of dollars from the distribution and sale of sexually explicit material.

LEAD: KN Energy Inc. said it had rejected as inadequate an $18-a-share buyout offer from Mesa Limited Partnership.
J.
Robert Wilson, KN Energy's chairman and chief executive, said in a letter to Mesa, of Amarillo, Tex., that the KN board believed the company's continued independence was in its shareholders' best interests.

LEAD: New York City still seeks to limit the dangerous excesses of bicycle messengers by banning all bikes from congested midtown blocks.
A comment period on the ban proposal expires today.
The ban does not make nearly as much sense as another city proposal to license the messenger business.

Cecil Cooper Waived
LEAD: Cecil Cooper, the Milwaukee Brewers' career leader in batting and runs batted in who did not play after the All-Star break last season, was waived yesterday for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release.
Cooper, 38 years old, played 11 of his 14 major-league seasons with the Brewers.
The five-time All-Star had one year remaining on a contract that called for a reported $700,000 in 1988, not including a deferred payment of $840,000.

Grass-Roots Reform In Miami Experiment
LEAD: Jim Griffin's sixth-grade classroom at the North Miami Elementary School is home to 36 children, a boa constrictor named Clyde, a cockateel named Keiko, Columbus the turtle, salamanders and a colony of gerbels whose population depends on when you last counted.
Along the back wall is a ''mini-lab'' where students peer into a microscope to examine amoebas or use a computer to calculate wind velocities.

LEAD: A 6-month-old Brooklyn girl drowned in the bathtub of her parent's Cobble Hill apartment last night while being bathed by a baby sitter, the police said.

New Sprint Service
LEAD: The U S Sprint Communications Company is offering digital, private-line service for large business customers.
Private lines are used for intracompany communications where high volumes of voice traffic or data are transmitted between sites.
U S Sprint, the third-largest long-distance telephone company, said that the new service, to be called Clearline 1-dot-5, was intended for such large telecommunication users as stockbrokers, airline reservation centers and hotel chains.


Moore to Seek Fourth Term
LEAD: Gov.
Arch Moore, the silver-haired patriarch of West Virginia's Republican Party, has announced that he will seek a fourth four-year term.
The announcement Monday by the 74-year-old Governor ended months of speculation that he would run for the United States Senate.Mr.
Moore won his first of two consecutive terms in 1968, then stepped down.


Harried Lawmakers Find Congress 'Too Chaotic'
LEAD: A study of 114 members of Congress has found that nearly 95 percent complained that the legislative process was ''too chaotic.'' Among other criticisms, most lawmakers said that an ineffectual budget process was increasingly dominating policy considerations.

LEAD: A proposed national championship football playoff was overwhelmingly rejected today by the nation's major football schools.


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: IT is amusing to think that when French chefs were passing out names for dishes in the days of Escoffier, they often named the simplest of dishes ''a l'anglaise,'' meaning in the English style.
The term was used for foods that were simply boiled in water or stock, like mutton or chicken or potatoes.

THEATER: ''MIDSUMMER NIGHT''
LEAD: AS festively staged by A. J. Antoon, ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' is the perfect show to inaugurate Joseph Papp's marathon presentation of the entire Shakespeare canon -not by any means because it's perfect Shakespeare, but because it's quintessential Joseph Papp.
The cast is an urban populist's utopian ideal, as diverse in show-biz experience (and inexperience) as it is in ethnic mix.

LEAD: Mario Lemieux, a center, and Paul Coffey, a defenseman for the Pittsburgh Penguins, were chosen yesterday as starters on the Wales Conference All-Star Team.
The 39th National Hockey League All-Star Game will be played Feb. 9 in St.
Louis.
Lemieux, with 315,699 votes, was the leading vote-getter in the conference and outdistanced his nearest rival, Peter Stastny of the Quebec Nordiques, by nearly 200,000 votes.

Dublin Backs Disputed Road
LEAD: The City Council has agreed to build a four-lane highway that will pass within yards of the Irish capital's Anglican St.
Patrick's Cathedral, despite furious protests from environmentalists.
The council voted on Monday to go ahead with a $3 million highway through the Liberties, the city's most ancient part.


Plain Old Vanilla Isn't All That Plain Anymore
LEAD: DINNER included salad with vanilla vinaigrette, vanilla-glazed beef kebabs and vanilla cream seltzer.
For professional reasons, the diners dutifully consumed eight vanilla custards, or at least took a thoughtful taste; each was made with a different vanilla extract or bean.
Organizers of this unusual vanilla dinner, a gathering of the San Francisco Professional Food Society, had hoped to decide which vanilla was best.

LEAD: American Airlines has filed a com-plaint with the Department of Trans-portation seeking sanction against British Airways P.L.C. for maintain-ing ''a virtual monopoly'' on its flight schedule system in Great Britian.
The complaints has asked the Govern-ment to ''eliminate several unfair air-line computerized reservation sys-tem practices of British Airways.

LEAD: More than a century ago, struggling immigrant families, mostly from Ireland and Italy, pulled together to erect a church that matched their own gritty determination and soaring hopes.


Apply U.S. Pressure To Delay Haiti's Vote
LEAD: It is not too late to help Haiti.
Washington should use what influence it still has there to persuade Lieut.
Gen.
Henri Namphy's ruling junta to postpone the presidential elections scheduled for Sunday.
By gaining more time, the Reagan Administration could help assure that all candidates could take part in a fair election.

LEAD: ARCO, Los Angeles, has raised its holdings in British-based Britoil P.L.C. to 23.04 percent from 21.91 percent.

LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission moved today to penalize a television station in Kansas City, Mo., saying it appeared to have violated rules against broadcasting indecent programming at a time when children were likely to be in the viewing audience.

LEAD: The dollar dipped in light trading yesterday as currency dealers warily awaited Friday's report on the American trade deficit.

Failed Engine Part Cited in Crash
LEAD: An Air Force fighter jet that crashed into an Indianapolis hotel last October lost power because of the failure of a part that connects the plane's jet turbine to its driveshaft, according to an Air Force report issued yesterday.

LEAD: Taiwan is planning ''large scale'' investments in hotels, theaters and other cultural establishments in Hong Kong, according to a Cabinet statement issued Monday.


Lemieux Forces A Tie
LEAD: For too long, neither the Islanders nor the Penguins have felt the comfort that comes with victory, so they have been playing without confidence and with uninspiring results.
Nothing changed tonight and the division rivals emerged with a 5-5 tie.


New Orleans Symphony Cancels Rest of Season
LEAD: Struggling with a large debt and low attendance, the New Orleans Symphony has decided to cancel the rest of its season.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration is prepared to tell Japan during its Prime Minister's visit here this week that the United States intends to proceed with a nuclear cooperation agreement despite Congressional objections, Administration officials said today.


Ashton-Tate Seen In Microsoft Pact
LEAD: The Ashton-Tate Company, a leading producer of software for personal computers, is expected to announce a major agreement with the Microsoft Corporation, industry officials said.
The terms of the agreement were not available.
Ashton-Tate, based in Torrance, Calif., and Microsoft, of Redmond, Wash., declined to comment.

LEAD: Leslie Koerner was having his cheeseburger with a slice of onion and a Dr.
Brown's black cherry soda at Big Nick's on Broadway when his beeper went off and he leaped out the door to find a pay phone.
He was just saying, ''a lot of times people are antagonistic because of the price - they feel they're being ripped off even if they're not,'' when he was summoned.

LEAD: It is too early to tell if the $1.6 million study on future American military strategy delivered to the President today by a distinguished group of former Government officials and retired military men will suffer the fate of most other such studies.
But it is highly likely.


LIFE IN THE 30'S
LEAD: ONE of the first terms of art you learn in the newspaper business is that there is something called the silly season, which used to occur around August.
That was the time of the year when news had ground to a dead halt, when the Mayor was at the beach, the kids were out of school and public relations people called up promoting things like the Madonna look-alike contest.

Hart's Campaign Igniting Emotions
LEAD: When Gilbert Fuchsberg, a Harvard student, asked Gary Hart whether he had ever used marijuana or any other illegal drug, he expected that the Democratic Presidential candidate would not like the question.


U.S. Prosecutor Is Resigning
LEAD: The head of the nation's largest Federal prosecutor's office announced his resignation today after leading investigations ranging from espionage to corruption in the administration of Mayor Marion Barry Jr. of Washington.


122 New Yorkers Are Chosen In a Science Talent Search
LEAD: In an improved performance over last year, students at New York City public high schools have won more than one-third of the semifinal places in the national Westinghouse Science Talent Search.


European Jobless Up
LEAD: The number of unemployed in the 12-nation European Community rose to 15.9 million in November from 15.8 million in the previous month, Eurostat, the statistical service, reported today.
Eurostat said the unemployment rate was unchanged at 10.8 percent in nine community nations, excluding Greece, Spain and Portugal.


Curb on News Copters Urged
LEAD: The National Transportation Safety Board is calling for tighter curbs on the use of helicopters by the news media at accident scenes, saying that they often interfere with rescue or cleanup operations.


USX and Bethlehem Lift Sheet Steel Prices
LEAD: Two leading steel companies said yesterday that they had raised prices by 4 percent to 8 percent on their sheet steel products, which are used heavily in the automobile and appliance industries.


New Job for Williams
LEAD: The Chicago Cubs announced yesterday that Billy Williams, a former star outfielder for the team, would join the front office as a special player consultant for the 1988 season.
Williams, 49 years old and a member of the Hall of Fame, will be primarily involved with scouting and evaluating players in the major and minor league.

Commuter Train Kills a Man
LEAD: A 79-year-old man was struck and killed by a Metro-North Commuter Railroad train early today, the police said.
The victim, Eleuterio Giacovelli of Harrison, was hit by the New York-bound train at about 6:30 A.M. just south of the Harrison station, the police said.The train involved was the 6 A.M. from Stamford, due in Grand Central Terminal at 7 A.M.


EDUCATION: Lessons
LEAD: In auditoriums and conference rooms across the country, local school boards are preparing their budgets.
Yet it is unlikely that the process, which involves billions of dollars, is monitored by more than a handful of citizens.
And this lack of interest is perplexing.


MUSIC: 55TH ANNIVERSARY OF COMPOSERS GROUP
LEAD: TO mark the 55th anniversary of its founding, the National Association of Composers, U.S.A., sponsored a program of six works at Weill Recital Hall on Monday evening.
Three of the pieces were given their local premieres and, as it happened, they were the program's least memorable selections.

LEAD: In a state where growth has been one of the most divisive issues, Gov.
Madeleine M. Kunin today outlined a set of sweeping proposals that could shape Vermont for years to come.


Hanover Staff Cuts
LEAD: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation will begin cutting its staff this week to reduce its payroll by 9 percent, the company's chairman, John F. McGillicuddy, said.
Mr.
McGillicuddy said the reductions among the New York-based banking group's 30,134 employees would affect some units more than others.


Neediest Cases Fund Tops Last Year's Record
LEAD: Contributions to the 76th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have set a record, passing the $3 million mark for the second year in a row.


3 N.B.A. Stars In Dunk Contest
LEAD: Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls will defend his title in the slam-dunk competition during the National Basketball Association All-Star weekend against two former winners, Dominique Wilkins and Spud Webb of the Atlanta Hawks.


At Adolfo, the Antic Mood Moderates
LEAD: BETWEEN periods of turbulence, fashion often simmers down.
Despite the prevalence of lace boleros, fluffy skirts paved in ruched ruffles and the glitter of gold-colored metal, the Adolfo collection for spring and summer actually reflects a moderate mood.
It contrasts with the boisterousness of his last collection, giving women as well as the designer a chance to catch a breath.

LEAD: Michael Ephraim skating in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.
Today, temperatures are expected to plunge as winds bring arctic air into the area. (NYT/Barton Silverman)

Concert: From Babbitt, 'Joy of More Sextets'
LEAD: THE title of ''The Joy of More Sextets'' - a recent violin and piano work by Milton Babbitt that had its first local performance Sunday afternoon at Merkin Concert Hall - refers to a work of 20 years ago entitled simply ''Sextets.'' Neither involves a sextet in the conventional sense of six instruments; the term refers to numerical groupings that govern the pitches and other events in the 20-minute work.


New TV System Offers Descriptions for Blind
LEAD: When public television broadcasts a three-part performance of Eugene O'Neill's ''Strange Interlude'' next week, blind and vision-impaired people in nine areas may be able to enjoy the show more than in the past, since an oral description of the visual portions will be broadcast at the same time.


Toyota's Exports
LEAD: The Toyota Motor Corporation expects its exports will be down for the third con-secutive year, its president, Shoichiro Toyoda, said.
A higher Japanese yen and changes in the American tax sys-tem can be blamed for sluggish ex-ports, he said.
Toyota's exports num-bered 1.77 million cars in 1987, down 6 percent from 1.88 million in 1986.


U.S. Would Put Off Sending Child Home Pending Counseling
LEAD: The Reagan Administration, while urging the Supreme Court to lift an interim order barring the return of a 9-year-old boy to Zimbabwe, indicated today that it might allow a brief wait for psychological reasons before returning the boy, who the Administration says was badly abused by his diplomat father.

First Titan 4 Is at Canaveral
LEAD: The first Air Force Titan 4, the United States' most powerful unmanned space rocket, arrived here today to be prepared for a launching with a military payload in October.
The 204-foot booster was brought here by a C5A cargo plane from a plant near Denver.
In addition to the Air Force's plans to launch two of the rockets annually from here, the space agency is considering using the Titan 4 for scientific payloads, and its manufacturer, Martin Marietta, wants to market it for commercial customers.


Jane S. Nickerson, 87, Writer and Historian
LEAD: Jane Soames Nickerson, a writer and historian, died Sunday at her home in Locust Valley, L.I.
She was 87 years old.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, the articles on daily trading in the stock market yesterday and on Saturday incorrectly ranked Friday's 140.58-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average.
The decline was No. 13 in percentage terms and No. 3 in points.


EATING WELL
LEAD: IN the New York Times survey of American eating habits published last week, 25 percent of the respondents said they watched their cholesterol intake at every meal.
But when these people were asked what they had eaten the day before, they described meals high in fat and cholesterol.
Like so many of us, the respondents probably were not really sure what to look for when watching the cholesterol in their meals.


What New Tiles?
LEAD: Senators returning from recess later this month might not notice the new tile floor that is being installed in one of the main lobbies on the first floor of the Senate wing of the Capitol.
Their oversight would be understandable, because the new floor looks exactly like the old tile floor that has been in place since it was installed in the 1850's.


Real Estate; Vertical Plan Cuts Costs of Retail Space
LEAD: SHUNNED by retailers and office tenants, the cheapest space in most commercial buildings is to be found in the basement or on the second floor.


Study Finds Antibodies for AIDS In 1 in 61 Babies in New York City
LEAD: One of every 61 babies born in New York City last month carried antibodies to the AIDS virus, indicating that their mothers were infected and that many of the babies were carriers of the deadly virus.


Advertising; Franchising World Now Available to Public
LEAD: Franchising World, the year-old publication of the Washington-based International Franchise Association, is making itself available to the public on a limited number of newsstands and bookstores beginning with its January-February issue.


Australian With U.N. Force Is Killed by Mine in Lebanon
LEAD: An Australian Army captain serving with a United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon was killed today when his car ran over a land mine, a United Nations spokesman said.


U.S. Study of Airline Accidents Finds Sharp Increase in 1987
LEAD: The major airlines in the United States had their highest number of accidents in 13 years last year and the most deaths in five years, the National Transportation Safety Board reported today.


What's the Hot Item in Town? Depends on the Town
LEAD: GRANTED, some local favorites make sense: grits in New Orleans, rice in Charleston, S.C., and cranberry juice in Boston.
But why do people in Dallas eat more canned spinach than anyone else in the United States?
And why is New York City, supposedly a center of sophisticated tastes, the Wonder bread capital of the country?

Dr.

Grand Union Plan
LEAD: The Grand Union Company, a unit of Generale Occidentale of Paris, said that a management group, led by its chairman, Floyd Hall, had organized a leveraged buyout for all the assets of the supermarket company, based in Elmwood Park, N.J.
Terms were not disclosed.
The transaction is scheduled to close March 1.

At the Lincoln Center station he boarded a downtown IRT train.
Some stops later a well-dressed woman laden with shopping bags and assorted parcels got on board.

LEAD: Three days before President Reagan declared that there was ''no way'' a Soviet pilot could have shot down a Korean Air Lines jet in 1983 by mistake, American intelligence had concluded that a mistake was the likely explanation, according to declassified documents released today.

Kicking About Discrimination
LEAD: Managers of the Radio City Rockettes may pat themselves on the back for finally hiring a black dancer to perform with their world famous New York City chorus line.
Others wonder what took them so long.


John Williams, Ex-Senator, Dies; Represented Delaware for 4 Terms
LEAD: John J. Williams, a Republican Senator from Delaware for 24 years, died of heart and respiratory failure Monday night in a hospital in Lewes, Del.
He was 83 years old and had been in poor health for some time.


Korea Export Rise Seen
LEAD: South Korea's merchandise exports in the first quarter are expected to reach $12.1 billion, up 28.8 percent from the corresponding period last year, the Korea Foreign Trade Association said today.
The association also forecast that the nation's imports in the January-March period would remain at $10.4 billion, creating a trade surplus of $1.7 billion.


The Open-Pit Barbecue: A Texas Tradition in Good Hands
LEAD: THE owner is a 74-year-old Hawaiian-born woman of Japanese descent, the manager is a classically trained British chef, the cooks are originally from Mexico and the waitress is a hillbilly from southern Missouri.
They keep the secret of one of Texas' dearest and most fragile treasures: the traditional open-pit barbecue.


Accidental Shootings of Children Raising Concern
LEAD: Sensational shootings often draw more attention, but to many people here there is something deeply troubling in the numbing frequency of incidents like the one Monday that left 14-year-old Aaron Fultz critically wounded.

LEAD: Ray Bauduc, a jazz drummer and composer in the era of the big bands, died Jan. 8.
He was 81 years old.

LEAD: The American Express Bank said yesterday that it had written off all its loans to Latin America's private sector and added $350 million to its reserves for loan losses.

Is Austin the Next Silicon Valley?
LEAD: IF it were simply a matter of 800 new jobs by 1990, the arrival here of a much sought after experimental research consortium, Sematech, probably would not mean that much for Austin and its growth-conscious city fathers.
After all, the state government payroll alone grew by 2,000 in the Texas capital last year.


Waiting for Christmas
LEAD: Perhaps it had something to do with the uncertainty of United States funding for the anti-Sandinista rebels known as contras: Christmas cards sent to Washington from Miami by the contras' political umbrella group, the Nicaraguan Resistence, were postmarked Jan. 8.


Icahn Objecting to Part Of Texaco-Pennzoil Plan
LEAD: Carl C. Icahn, the financier who holds a 12.3 percent stake in Texaco Inc., filed a motion in Federal Bankruptcy Court yesterday to overturn an accord between Texaco and the Pennzoil Company in which they promise to support Texaco's $5.5 billion reorganization plan.

LEAD: SOME artists work with oils, some in watercolors.
But Sylvia Weinstock and Colette Peters prefer butter cream, a moist, tender cake and icing.
Although the two women work independently they share the same idea of what a cake should be: an edible extravaganza.

Pluto Reported to Share Atmosphere With Moon
LEAD: Observations of Pluto and its moon Charon, which can now be seen eclipsing each other every few days, are providing astronomers evidence that the two may be the oddest couple in the solar system: a double planet apparently enveloped in a single atmosphere.


U.S.-SOVIET ACCORD ON SCIENCE SIGNED
LEAD: The broadest Soviet-American accord on scientific cooperation in almost a decade was signed here today by the heads of the two countries' top scientific academies, paving the way for greater joint efforts in fields ranging from AIDS research to nuclear reactor safety.


Colombia Says U.S. Reprisals Weaken Support for Drug Fight
LEAD: Colombia has warned that the United States is indirectly aiding powerful cocaine traffickers by carrying out reprisals against Colombians over the release from prison of a reputed cocaine smuggler here in late December.

The program is aimed at reaching the 4.5 million businesses that have fewer than 5,000 employees.

John H. Johnson Dies; Executive in Baseball
LEAD: John H. Johnson, who presided over the nation's 176 minor-league teams as president of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, died of chest cancer yesterday at his home in St.
Petersburg, Fla.
He was 66 years old.


Quintuplets Artificially Conceived Are Born
LEAD: The first birth of quintuplets conceived outside the womb in the United States occurred Monday, officials of the William Beaumont Hospital said today.


Dyncorp Board Sets Bid Deadline
LEAD: The board of Dyncorp said that it would terminate an agreement to be acquired by an investor group led by its chairman, Jorge E. Carnicero, unless the group increases its $216 million takeover offer within five days.
Dyncorp has received a second takeover offer from DME Holdings Inc., a group that includes several Dyncorp managers.


U.S. Legislators Warn Sandinistas on Peace Talks
LEAD: Members of a Congressional delegation visiting Nicaragua said today that they warned the Government here that Congress may approve more aid for rebels if the Sandinistas do not reverse their position and agree to begin direct cease-fire talks with the contras.

LEAD: ''If we take fright and stop the processes we have begun, it would have the most serious consequences, because we simply could not raise our people to such a massive task a second time.''  - Mikhail S. Gorbachev, on revitalizing the Soviet Union.  [ A1:5. ]


Beyond New Jersey's Boom
LEAD: With an unemployment rate down to 3.6 percent and jobs increasing by 100,000 a year, New Jersey appears on an economic upswing.
But Governor Kean, in his State of the State Message yesterday, wisely spent less time crowing about the boom than assessing how to prolong it.
He's concerned with those it leaves behind, particularly the homeless.


A Coming Filipino Vote Divides Aquino Family
LEAD: Trucks stacked high with newly harvested sugar cane on the plantation of President Corazon C. Aquino have been flying tiny banners supporting the gubernatorial candidacy of her family's choice, Candido Guiam.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Lakers Win 15th Straight: Byron Scott had 30 points for Los Angeles, which scored 10 of its last 14 points on free throws last night in a 117-113 victory against the Golden State Warriors that extended the Lakers' winning streak to 15 games.


Dorsett to Be Traded
LEAD: Coach Tom Landry ruled out getting a first-round draft pick for Tony Dorsett but said yesterday he hopes the Dallas Cowboys can get a solid, journeyman player when they put their 33-year-old running back on the trading block soon.
Landry told Dorsett on Monday he will try to work out a trade for the 11-year veteran who lost his starting tailback job to Herschel Walker this season.


Little Change in Treasury Prices
LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices were unchanged to slightly lower yesterday in aimless trading that reflected a widespread lack of conviction about the future course of interest rates.


Estimate Board May Face Limit In Making Deals
LEAD: Mayor Koch called yesterday for a curb on the deal-making powers of the Board of Estimate, of which he is a member, by limiting the board to a simple yes or no vote on land-use issues before it.


Savings Mergers Assailed
LEAD: House Speaker Jim Wright said in an interview published today that he was opposed to steps taken by regulators to merge small, ailing savings and loan institutions into larger institutions.

A Civilian President Named in Suriname To End Army Rule
LEAD: The National Assembly elected a civilian President today, paving the way for a return to democracy after seven years of military rule.


Gullickson Signs
LEAD: Bill Gullickson, who spurned a Yankee offer last week, signed a one-year contract today with the Yomiuri Giants.
Gullickson will receive $1.1 million for 1988 plus a contract signing bonus of $400,000 and at least $150,000 in expenses. ''I will try my best for the Giants as I did in the major leagues,'' Gullickson said at a news conference in Tokyo.


Judge Rules for Bush's Side In Michigan G.O.P. Dispute
LEAD: A Federal distjrict judge today dismissed a consi-tutional challenge to seven state laws, giving supporters of Vice President Bush a new legal victory over a coali-tion that controls the Michigan Repub-lican Party.


Energy Contracts Decline In Rumor-Driven Session
LEAD: Energy futures prices closed moderately lower yesterday after being whipsawed by rumors throughout the trading session.


Chase Appoints Citicorp Official
LEAD: Richard L. Huber, formerly an executive in Citicorp's investment bank, has joined the Chase Manhattan Corporation as sector executive for capital markets and foreign exchange.


Lendl, Navratilova Advance
LEAD: Ivan Lendl, seeking his first Australian Open singles title, and Martina Navratilova, going after her fourth, made quick work of second-round foes today.

LEAD: Mark Saxton, an author and editor, died, apparently of a heart attack, last Thursday in his home in New York City.
He was 73 years old.

LEAD: Pakistan's two senior leaders have concluded that some members of the pro-Moscow Government in Afghanistan must be allowed to take part in a successor government as a condition for the withdrawal of Soviet troops.

LEAD: Abraham D. Sofaer, the State Department legal adviser, says that closing the Palestine Liberation Organization observer mission to the United Nations, as Congress has mandated, would violate international law.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Gerry Letourneau, Executive, 52
LEAD: Gerry Letourneau, president of Airstream Inc., a leading manufacturer of motor homes, died in a snowmobile accident Saturday.
He was 52 years old.


Rare Funerary Mask at the American Museum
LEAD: The solid gold ''Hoover Disk'' after it was installed in its case yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History's new Hall of the South American Peoples.
The face-size disk, from the Tiwanaku culture, A.D. 400 to 1000, is on loan from the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace at Stanford University.


GORBACHEV SEES CRUCIAL PERIOD FOR HIS CHANGES
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said in an interview made public today that his domestic initiatives offer the current generation of Russians the last chance to reshape their country.


Donald S. Curtis, Investment Analyst, 78
LEAD: Donald S. Curtis, a financial analyst who retired as vice president in the investment research department of Marine Midland Bank in 1974, died Jan. 3 at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital after a long illness.
He was 78 years old and lived in Old Greenwich.

LEAD: IF one had to name the two great pioneering folk dance ensembles from the Soviet Union that became the model for all other professional folk companies in the world, they would have to be the companies founded separately by two choreographers, Igor Moiseyev and Pavel Virsky.


Portfolio Insurers Reject Blame
LEAD: Facing renewed criticism that they were to blame for the October market collapse, money managers offering portfolio insurance are instead pointing the finger at other market players.

LEAD: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., meeting Neil Kinnock for the first time, today presented the Labor Party leader with a bound copy of the Senator's speeches and told reporters: ''I told him he was welcome to use them whenever he liked, with or without attribution.''

LEAD: Gladys Vaughan, the first woman to direct a New York Shakespeare Festival production, died Dec. 30 in her home in Manhattan.
She was 64 years old.

LEAD:  International

LEAD: Mark Price scored 9 of his career-high 29 points in the final four minutes tonight to help the Cleveland Cavaliers defeat the Knicks, 119-111.


2 Fire Doors Were Wedged Open In Building Where Smoke Killed 4
LEAD: The smoke that killed four residents of an apartment building on the East Side of Manhattan Monday night spread through the structure because two lobby-level fire doors had been wedged open in violation of the fire code, the authorities said yesterday.


Citicorp Unit Cuts 85 Jobs in London
LEAD: Citicorp Investment Bank Ltd. said it would cut 85 jobs in its London securities division, or just under 4 percent of its staff.
The investment bank has 2,200 employees.
Citicorp, based in New York, has a total work force of 4,500 in Britain.


Thriving on Currency Tumult
LEAD: For months, betting against the dollar seemed a sure thing to the global army of traders who ply the $200 billion-a-day currency market.
Going into the new year, most foreign-exchange traders expected the United States currency to fall even more.

Rated A-2 by Moody's and A+ by S.&amp;P., the three-year notes yield about 67-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

LEAD: EVERY year, cardiologists estimate, tens of thousands of Americans with heart disease are potential candidates for a heart transplant or an artificial device to assist the heart.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A report in the Business People column yesterday characterized the Continental Illinois Corporation's business strategy incorrectly.
The bank is emphasizing investment banking and leaving retail banking, but it will continue other aspects of commercial banking, including trust services, lending and providing personal banking services for wealthy customers.

LEAD: The British are coming.


Citicorp Auction
LEAD: Interest rates were mixed at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of commercial paper.
The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.8845 percent, down from 6.908 percent last week.
Another $50 million of 182-day paper sold at an average rate of 7.073 percent, up from 7.0184 percent.


Robins Gets New Offer From American Home
LEAD: With the support of a committee representing shareholders in the A. H. Robins Company's bankruptcy proceedings, the American Home Products Corporation yesterday sweetened its takeover bid for the Richmond-based drug company.


World Military Spending Up By $50 Billion, Study Finds
LEAD: The nations of the world spent about $930 billion on their military forces last year, an increase of $50 billion over 1986, and the United States ranked first in such spending, a military and social researcher reported nan annual study made public this week.

LEAD: Katherine Guy Fenimore Cooper, a horticulturist and member of the boards of many charitable groups, died Friday at her home in Cooperstown, N.Y.
She was 92 years old.


Report Criticizes 2 Relatives In Child's Fall in Texas Well
LEAD: Jessica McClure fell into an abandoned well as a result of inadequate supervision by her mother and an aunt, a state official says in a letter.


Resorts Bid Withdrawn By Trump
LEAD: The developer Donald J. Trump withdrew his offer to buy control of Resorts International Inc. today and said he would probably be forced to halt construction of the huge Taj Mahal casino hotel.


Bridge: First Big Regional Tourney For 1988 Is Opening Today
LEAD: The first major tournament of 1988 for players in the New York metropolitan area, the Tri-State Regional, begins today at the Rye Town Hilton in Port Chester, N.Y.
This is the schedule: Today - Men's pairs and women's pairs, 1:30 and 8 P.M.


A Scholar Guides China's Food Policy
LEAD: WANG QING was 17 years old in 1967, when Red Guards surrounded her home here and placed her entire family under house arrest.


F.B.I. Study Hints Some Lied To Hide Ginsburg Drug Use
LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation will forward information to the Justice Department indicating that associates of Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg lied to investigators when they denied knowledge of the judge's past marijuana use, law-enforcement officials said today.


Brazil Pays Creditor Banks
LEAD: Brazil's creditor banks said yesterday that they had received a $360 million payment of overdue 1987 interest.
With another interest payment on Dec. 31, the latest remittance brings to $1.46 billion the amount of 1987 interest that Brazil has paid so far.


Robert F. Kennon, 85; A Louisiana Governor
LEAD: Robert F. Kennon, who was Governor of Louisiana from 1952 to 1956, died Monday.
He was 85 years old.


Con O'Neill, Diplomat, 75
LEAD: Sir Con O'Neill, who led the intricate negotiations that took Britain into the European Economic Community, died Monday, his family said.
He was 75 years old.

LEAD: Vice President Bush retreated today from the recent verbal barbs at Senator Bob Dole, saying the sharp public sparring had been a ''mistake.''


Korean Oil Imports
LEAD: South Korea's crude oil imports this year are expected to drop 6.6 percent from last year, to 215 million barrels, the Energy and Resources Ministry said today.

LEAD: PATRICK EWING has a problem with aerodynamics, primarily and most deleteriously on defense.
He is often seen flying through the air when his wheels should be firmly on the floor.


Advertising; Over All, '88 Forecasts Are Bullish
LEAD: AMONG the upper echelons of Madison Avenue there is more optimism about the immediate future than you're likely to find among the mighty of Wall Street.


Aged Twins Slain in Illinois
LEAD: Elderly twin brothers who lived as recluses in a house filled with trash were beaten to death and the house set afire, the authorities said today. ''The fire was used to cover the crime,'' said Fire Chief Tom Anderson. ''The motive at this time is unknown.'' The bodies of the victims, Roy and Irl McNutt, 79 years old, were found Saturday in their living room.


G.M. Weighing Venezuela Sale
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it was negotiating the possible sale of a stake in its Venezuelian operations to the Mendoza Group, a local conglomerate.


U.N. Envoy Rebuffed in the Gaza Strip
LEAD: Palestinian women in Gaza City pleading with Marrack Goulding, in car, a United Nations Under Secretary General, to intercede for relatives.
Mr.
Goulding was turned away from one refugee district by Israeli troops and from another by protesting Palestinians.
The army has imposed round-the-clock curfews in some areas.


Judge Orders Readjustment Of Allowances for Housing
LEAD: A New York State judge yesterday ordered a temporary halt to the eviction of all New York City families on welfare whose monthly rent is higher than the shelter allowance provided by the state.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about pedestrians walking on a plank bridge over a Manhattan street flooded by a water main break misidentified the location.
It was Park Avenue at 73d Street.

LEAD:  International A2-13


Home Loan Banks
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Banks offered one-year and three-year bonds totaling $1.8 billion through various securities dealers yesterday.
For $690 million of bonds due on Jan. 25, 1989, the yield is 7.40 percent, while a $1.12 billion issue due on Jan. 25, 1991, yields 8.30 percent.
Both issues were offered at a price of 100.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo and Wayne Diesel, the budget director, at right, as they reviewed the state budget in the Governor's office Monday night in Albany.
Below, in a light moment, the Governor took a scissors to the document and ceremonially stomped on it.
Mr.
Cuomo will present the budget to the Legislature today.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: Ogden Phipps resigned as an active member of the New York Racing Association's board of trustees and was named a director emeritus.
Phipps, 79 years old, had served on the board since its inception in 1959.
Arthur F. Long, a member of the Jockey Club since 1981 and an owner of thoroughbreds for 23 years, has been nominated to replace Phipps on the board.

Louis on Feb. 9 could just as well be called the Edmonton Oilers and a couple of friends.

Currents; The Cans and Caps of Furniture Art
LEAD: CREATING furniture and decorative objects from recycled materials has been an American tradition since the 1870's, when itinerant artists used discarded cigar, fruit and vegetable boxes to make things like lamps, picture frames and tables.
These carved pieces, known as tramp art, are widely sought today, and are often found at country fairs and flea markets.

To Freshmen, a Big Goal Is Wealth
LEAD: A record proportion of more than three-quarters of college freshmen surveyed around the country feel that being financially well off is an ''essential'' or ''very important'' goal.
At the same time, the lowest proportion of freshmen in 20 years, only 39 percent, put great emphasis on developing a meaningful philosophy of life.

LEAD: British spending on takeovers of United States companies more than doubled last year, according to a study published today.

LEAD: August T. Baden, a drugstore owner who founded cinnamon-flavored Baden's Hot Toothpicks almost 40 years ago, died Sunday.

Other regulations remain in effect.

Rebirth of 1866 Manhattan Frame House
LEAD: FIFTEEN years ago, on her first day in New York, Karen Marcus - then 21 years old and fresh from West Virginia - explored her new East 50's neighborhood with a friend and spotted a narrow, four-story, clapboard town house.
With its wood frame, plain facade and simple mansard roof, it was as modest as it was rare.

LEAD: NBC placed seven comedies and the movie ''The Ann Jillian Story'' in the top 10 last week to register the network's highest weekly rating this season, according to figures by the A. C. Nielsen company.

Paterson Principal: A Man of Extremes
LEAD: Getting a measure of Eastside High School, the inner-city school whose principal, Joe Clark, patrols hallways with bullhorn and baseball bat in hand, isn't easy.
Last year a state monitoring team tried, and barely got in the door.


INTEREST RATE CUT PLEDGED BY JAPAN
LEAD: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita told President Reagan today that Japan would work to reduce its interest rates, and both countries agreed to intensify efforts to halt the dollar's decline.


European Farm Income
LEAD: The average income of European farmers dropped by 5 percent last year and by 25 percent since the mid-1970's, the European Farmers Organization said today.
By comparison, the income in all other sectors of the European economy had increased by 1.5 percent, the group said.
The figures are based on early estimates from the statistical office of the European Community, the organization said.


Bush Recalls No Strong Dissent on Arms to Iran
LEAD: Vice President Bush said tonight that he had not heard strong objections voiced in meetings on the shipment of arms to Iran, even though he attended at least one session in early 1986 where such concerns might have been aired.


Lighthearted Classics Evoke Epochs Ancient and Archetypal
LEAD: LAST week, a visitor to Jerrystyle, a newly expanded East Village emporium that specializes in verdigris and well-patinated copper home furnishings, seemed disappointed. ''I must have that really old look,'' she said to Jeff Brown, who works there.
He responded: ''If you don't see anything here, bring in something and we'll oxidize it for you.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about increases in steel prices incorrectly described the types of steel affected.


WASHINGTON TALK: WORKING PROFILE: Theodore S. Greenberg; Prosecutor Who Knows How to Keep a Secret
LEAD: Last month, to the surprise of some Justice Department officials, a Manila businessman pleaded guilty to the charges of defrauding the Pentagon on a Philippine military contract.
Before a Federal judge in Alexandria, Va., he paid the United States $1 million in fines.


Corrections
LEAD: A table in Business Day yesterday with a London dispatch about currency trading reversed the figures for the pretax foreign-exchange income of Chase Manhattan and Chemical Bank.
The correct figures for Chemical were $55.5 million in 1982, $103.2 million in 1986 and $104 million in the first three quarters of 1987.


More Contra Aid, More Suffering
LEAD: The Government and people of Nicaragua want peace.
There have already been more than 50,000 Nicaraguan casualties in the war financed by the United States.
This includes 25,527 dead, the majority of whom are women, children and poor farmers.
For a small country with 3.5 million people, this is a staggering figure.

LEAD: This is shaping up as a season of troubles for Rod Strickland, the high-scoring DePaul guard.

LEAD: George Rogers, despite an uneven season, will start at running back for the Washington Redskins in the National Football Conference championship game Sunday against the Minnesota Vikings.

LEAD: Fathers of 5-year-olds do better in two key measures of their skills as parents if their jobs are involving and satisfying, a new study suggests.

LEAD: Angie McClellan, leading scorer and rebounder for the University of Illinois's women's basketball team, said she has nobody to blame but herself for being bounced off the team.
She was dismissed Tuesday for altering the date on a school medical form so she would have an excuse for missing a class on a day when an absence could have lowered her grade.

LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 3 today that public school officials have broad power to censor school newspapers, plays and other ''school-sponsored expressive activities.''


Price Limits On Futures
LEAD: The Chicago Board of Trade set permanent daily price limits on its stock index futures today, becoming the first futures market to attempt to reduce the trading volatility that some experts have blamed for worsening the October market collapse.

Labor Groups Assail E.P.A.'s Proposed Rules on Pesticide Use
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency is preparing to revise its rules governing the exposure of farm workers to pesticides, but its draft proposal is already under fire from labor groups.


Copiers by Kodak
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company, in a move to enter the growing color copier market, introduced two models.
The company said its Coloredge copier duplicator would produce color copies from color originals at speeds of 23 copies a minute, about four times as fast as any copier on the market.
The company said its Coloredge AC copier duplicator would make color copies from black and white originals at speeds of 23 to 70 copies a minute.


Pakistan Tied to Atom Shipping Plot
LEAD: The State Department was reported today to have sent a memorandum to President Reagan concluding that the Pakistani Government was probably involved in a plot by a Pakistani-born businessman to smuggle material for nuclear weapons out of the United States.


Piano: Angela Cheng
LEAD: THE opening phrases of Mozart's D major sonata, K. 576, are not especially difficult, but the poise and clarity with which Angela Cheng played them at the beginning of her Alice Tully Hall recital Monday evening immediately left the impression that nothing was going to be especially difficult for her.

LEAD: China has set up its first domestic securities firm, the official China News Service said.
It is in the Shenzhen special economic zone.
The agency, monitored in Hong Kong today, said the firm, in the Shenzhen special economic zone, would trade stocks and bonds and help underwrite shares issued by Chinese companies.

LEAD: Paul A. Cohen, the former senior partner of Herzfeld &amp; Stern, a New York stock brokerage firm now owned by Gruntal &amp; Company, died of Alzheimer's disease yesterday at New York Hospital.
He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Comex Chief Will Give Up Chairman Post
LEAD: Alan J. Brody, the chairman of the Commodity Exchange, the nation's largest precious metals futures exchange, will give up the post on March 16, the Comex announced last night.


Reagan Checkup on Friday
LEAD: President Reagan said he felt ''pretty good'' today after being up much of the night with an upset stomach and nausea.
In what was called a coincidence, he will enter the hospital Friday for a six-month checkup to guard against a recurrence of colon cancer.


Washington Talk: Briefing; A Gore Advantage
LEAD: Senator Albert Gore Jr. has a peculiar advantage in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
His state, Tennessee, borders on eight other states, all of which hold their primaries on March 8, the day politicians call Super Tuesday.
Day after day, Senator Gore has told neighboring state audiences how happy he was to be in a state that borders on his own and remarked on how much the neighboring states have in common.

Ice Causes Major Traffic Delays
LEAD: In Union, N.J., traffic on Interstate 78 waited as a truck spread salt after cars skidded on icy pavement.
At Newark International Airport, runways were closed when ''poor braking'' was reported.
Dozens of accidents were reported on the New Jersey Turnpike.
Today is expected to be windy and cold, with highs between 11 and 17 degrees.


Music: Woodwind Quintet
LEAD: THE opening number on the New York Woodwind Quintet's program Tuesday at Merkin Concert Hall predicted an evening of tense music-making.
Variety and richness emerged instead; perhaps the Mozart quintet (K. 452) simply found the guest pianist, Gilbert Kalish, out of his element.
He lacked the singing legato tone it wants, and there was some rhythmic unevenness in the ensemble.


Scientist Identifies Ancestor to All Life Forms
LEAD: An analysis of genetic material from many species has indicated that all of today's living things may have evolved from single-cell organisms that consumed sulfur and lived in near-boiling water, perhaps in hot sulfur springs.


Chambers Jury Hears of Flaws In Key Evidence
LEAD: A New York City detective conceded yesterday that an area in Central Park where several key pieces of evidence about Jennifer Levin's death were discovered was initially ignored by investigators and used as a parking lot on the morning of her death.


Innovative Illinois Bonds Benefit Savers for College
LEAD: To encourage saving for college education, officials in Illinois have turned to the tax-exempt bond market, where they attracted individual investors to an innovative issue that raised more than $90 million for the state.


Theater: 'The River'
LEAD: PETER LINK'S new musical, ''The River,'' is a collage of rock, rap and pop gospel, extolling water in spiritual and metaphorical terms.
In Mr.
Link's lyrics water falls, tumbles, rains and rushes in streams, rivers and oceans.
By the end of the show, which opened last night at the Promenade Theater, one has been inundated by images of liquidity.


New Families Are Barred From Hotel
LEAD: New York City officials have been barred from placing new people in a Chelsea welfare hotel.
State officials said the hotel failed to meet minimum living conditions.


Primark Plans Spinoff Of Its Michigan Utility
LEAD: The Primark Corporation of McLean, Va., said today that its board had recommended that its Michigan utility, which provided $1.4 billion of its $1.5 billion revenues in 1986, be spun off to shareholders.

Prime Raises Bid for Its Rival
LEAD: Prime Computer Inc. sweetened its offer yesterday to acquire its rival the Computervision Corporation, to $15 a share, or a total of $433.5 million.
The company, which previously offered $13.50 a share for Computervision, said that it would not increase its offer again.


Steel Shelves Go Home
LEAD: HEAVY-DUTY industrial steel shelving is selling well at the New York Store Fixture Company.
William Cherkin, the store's president, said the shelves adapt easily to home use.


FEARS FOR TAIWAN: A NEW INSTABILITY
LEAD: Chinese and American specialists on Taiwan expressed concern yesterday about the future of the island after the death of President Chiang Ching-kuo, in their view the most significant political event there since 1949.


Japan Ruling on Death Opens Way for Transplants
LEAD: After years of painstaking study, the Japan Medical Association has decided to accept brain death as a valid definition of death, clearing the way for heart and other organ transplants that are now effectively banned.


Split in N.C.A.A. On Grade Standard
LEAD: Just a few hours after approving legislation that demands better grades from college athletes, Division I schools reversed themselves today and decided not to impose uniform standards.


4 Palestinians Linked to Protests Are Expelled to Lebanon by Israel
LEAD: Israel expelled four West Bank Palestinians today, taking them by helicopter to a lonely mountain road in southern Lebanon.


Japan Tourism Abroad
LEAD: The number of Japanese tourists going overseas rose by 23.3 percent, to 6.8 million, in 1987, mainly because of the strength of the yen, Japan Travel Bureau Inc., a leading Japanese travel agency, said today.


Beth Campbell Short, Truman White House Aide, 79
LEAD: Beth Campbell Short, who covered Eleanor Roosevelt for The Associated Press and held a top White House job in Harry S. Truman's Presidency, died of cancer Monday.
She was 79 years old.


China's Money Supply
LEAD: China's central bank announced plans today to reduce the money supply to help curb inflation, which rose above 7 percent last year.

LEAD: The Philadelphia 76ers showed the Nets tonight how to play just hard enough to win.
But it was something New Jersey could not relate to.
On nights like tonight, the Nets play their hardest and still can't win.

LEAD: SWEET and sour ballets by Jerome Robbins were offered by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater.

LEAD: A grand jury has indicted a former nurse, Richard J. Angelo, on murder charges, District Attorney Patrick Henry said today.
Mr.
Angelo, 25 years old, is charged with injecting a patient at Good Samaritan Hospital with a muscle-paralyzing drug, killing him.

LEAD: The nation's oil production dropped 4.5 percent last year to the lowest level since 1977, the American Petroleum Institute reported today.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Digital Net Up by 22%
LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation reported late yesterday that earnings in its second fiscal quarter, which ended Dec. 26, rose 22 percent and revenues increased 22.5 percent.


Totem Poles for Traffic
LEAD: It's hard enough to find a parking space in New York City; often it's harder still to figure out if the space is legal.
The confusion encourages parking violations.
The city's Transportation Department, aware of the problem, has responded, though slowly, on some cross streets.
But it remains mystifyingly paralyzed about Manhattan avenues.

LEAD: Welcome to the big time.
Within 12 hours of their arrival here, the Minnesota Vikings checked into two hotels, waited for a Mack Truck convention to leave their primary hotel and then, after team meetings and lunch, the offense walked through some plays on a dirt lot near several parked cars, a pickup truck and a bulldozer clearing debris.

A Variety of Plants to Suit Any Climate
LEAD: COMPLAINT plays an important part in almost every gardener's life.
We complain about problems we can solve with a little work, like chickweed or crabgrass in the flower beds.
We also complain about matters beyond our control, mainly the weather.
Chief among these meteorological complaints are those concerning the plants we cannot grow because we live in a climate they find too taxing or unfriendly.

Big Navy Contract
LEAD: The Navy awarded a $4.38 billion contract to the General Dynamics Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to develop its new Advanced Tactical Aircraft for delivery in the 1990's.
The joint program, one of the largest ever undertaken by the Navy, is expected to produce 450 attack aircraft, at an eventual cost of $45 billion, to replace the service's current A-6 attack planes.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Blank Ballots By Writers Burn Bunning
LEAD: IN slamming the doors of Cooperstown on Jim Bunning's fingers, nine Baseball Hall of Fame voters each signed and mailed a blank ballot in this year's election.
Had those voters chosen simply not to return a ballot, Bunning would be in the Hall of Fame with the slugger Willie Stargell.
But the 224-game winner, one of the few pitchers with more than 100 victories in each league, remains on the outside looking in.

HEALTH: Personal Health
LEAD: A decade ago a 9-year-old girl I loved like a daughter developed rapidly progressive leukemia.
When potent drugs and radiation failed to control the cancer, there was only one possibility: a bone marrow transplant to replace her diseased blood-forming cells.
Unfortunately, no one in her immediate family was a good enough ''match'' to be a donor, and she died.

Mr.
Robertson also edited ''Shaft'' and was associate editor of ''The Miracle Worker'' and ''Lilith.'' He directed ''Melinda,'' a 1972 melodrama, and produced and directed ''Bim,'' a 1976 film on colonial Trinidad.

LEAD: Paul A. Volcker is concerned about the decline in the quality of the Federal bureaucracy, and he plans to do something about it.


Editors' Note
LEAD: A brief article on Monday reported that A. M. Rosenthal, columnist and former executive editor of The New York Times, would serve as an editor at large for G. P. Putnam, book publishers.

Dole Sees Spending Freeze As Centerpiece of Campaign
LEAD: Senator Bob Dole said today that if he was elected President he would propose a one-year spending freeze that would save $150 billion over three years and slash the Federal budget deficit.


Film: 'For Keeps,' on Teen-Age Pregnancy
LEAD: THERE was a time when unwanted teen-age pregnancy meant missing the senior prom, to say the very least.
It was more of an inconvenience than it is in the thoroughly modern ''For Keeps,'' which stars Molly Ringwald as a bright young mother-to-be.
The problems created by adolescent pregnancy and early marriage are indeed set forth here, sometimes with the appearance of great candor.


Old Masters Sale Produces Mixed Results at Sotheby's
LEAD: The Old Master paintings owned by Linda and Gerald Guterman, described as the most valuable such selection ever auctioned in New York, brought mixed results in a record-breaking sale yesterday morning at Sotheby's.


Regan Supports Bush Assertion on Concern Over Iran Arms Sales
LEAD: Donald T. Regan, the former White House chief of staff, said through a spokesman today that Vice President Bush had voiced reservations on ''several occasions'' about aspects of the arms shipment to Iran.
The concerns were raised in the presence of President Reagan, the spokesman said.


A Waldbaum Trader Fined
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged Joseph Sierchio, a 36-year-old lawyer from Sea Cliff, L.I., with illegally buying shares of Waldbaum Inc., while possessing non-public information about an impending takeover of the food chain by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company in November 1986.


Diner's Journal
LEAD: PARRILLADA is the Spanish term for mixed grill, which in the Argentine tradition ususally means a mini-charcoal barbecue presented at the table and heaped with T-bone steak, marinated skirt steak, morcilla (blood sausage), sweetbreads, kidneys, calf's liver and sausage.
At La Fusta, a popular neighborhood Argentine restaurant in Elmhurst, Queens, the lusty and well-cooked parrillada (sans kidneys and liver) comes with a jar of chimichurri, a piquant sauce made with garlic, parsley and olive oil.


City Ballet: 'Chaconne' With Maria Calegari
LEAD: MUSIC was the controlling impulse behind George Balanchine's choreography and two of his works at the New York City Ballet Wednesday night typified how wide-ranging that specific focus could be.


Our Towns; Getting the Truth About the Ways Of Streetwalkers
LEAD: How much to believe of what you hear on Broad Street?
Police Sgt.
Charles Whitner can't say.
The prostitutes tell him they make $300 a night on the street, but he always sees them in the same clothes, with the same holes in the same jackets - jackets too thin for the winter's cold.


Treasury Prices Increase Slightly
LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices rose slightly yesterday, after trading in a relatively narrow range before the barrage of economic statistics to be announced today.


An Artists' Agent Who Left by Night
LEAD: Most of the photographers and fashion stylists whom Xavier Moreau represented had already quit his agency.
There had been lawsuits against his company, with more threatened.
And months ago, he had suddenly moved out of his Sutton Place town house.

U.N. Council Again Asks Israelis To Stop Deporting Palestinians
LEAD: With the United States abstaining, the Security Council adopted a second resolution today calling on Israel to cancel plans to deport Palestinians from the occupied territories and allow those already deported to return home.
All 14 other Council members voted in favor of the resolution.

University Given $20 Million By Perot for Medical Studies
LEAD: The University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center at Dallas, one of the most respected medical schools in the nation, said today that it was receiving a $20 million gift from H. Ross Perot, the Texas businessman, to support its Nobel Prize-winning cholesterol research and to train medical scientists.


Drug Term for an Ex-Mayor
LEAD: Former Mayor Mike Roark, who admitted last year that he had possessed cocaine six times, was sentenced today to 179 days in prison, fined $5,000 and given a three-year suspended sentence.


Market Place; Why Hoffmann Wants Sterling
LEAD: SOME analysts say there was a lot of ego behind the decision of F. Hoffmann-La Roche &amp; Company to offer $72 a share, or $4.2 billion, to buy Sterling Drug Inc.


Mullin Works Out and Then Speaks Out
LEAD: In the early stages of the rest of his life as a recovering alcoholic, Chris Mullin today discussed what he had learned about himself in the past month.

LEAD: THE European American Bank, which was doing its own advertising, felt that its name didn't go with the image it wanted.
It doesn't really sound like Long Island's leading bank.

Riding the Black Market to Development
LEAD: The black market, long thought the enemy of third world economies, may instead indicate their surest path to development.
So argues Hernando de Soto, an iconoclastic Peruvian economist whose ideas have begun to attract interest in Latin America and beyond.


2 Events at Met Museum
LEAD: Elaborate historical analogies that elucidate the past while referring to the present have been a popular pastime of historians and pundits for centuries.
One of the best-loved epochs for such scholarly musings has been that of the Roman Empire, from the time of its greatest grandeur 2,000 years ago to its subsequent decline.


STOCK EXCHANGE SETS TEST TO CURB PROGRAM TRADING
LEAD: Reacting to criticism that computerized program trading was a major factor behind October's stock market collapse, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday announced a six-day experiment to curb the practice.

LEAD: Two reigning world champions added to their large collection of titles when the tournament year began Wednesday in Port Chester, N.Y.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Job for Bullhorn and Bat
LEAD: If the Board of Education in Paterson, N.J., is unhappy with Joe Clark, the school principal who maintains order with a bullhorn and a baseball bat, there could be a place for him in the Reagan White House.
Gary Bauer, Assistant to the President for Policy Development, has invited him to Washington to see if he wants a job.

NATO May Meet Before Reagan Soviet Trip
LEAD: Western officials are considering plans for a rare meeting of NATO leaders to review Western policy toward the Soviet Union and to demonstrate the alliance's solidarity before President Reagan visits Moscow this spring.

Television Research, died of histoplasmosis last Dec. 30, according to the executor of his estate, Edward J. Kissko.
Mr.
Brown was 35 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Raphael L. Elias, Lawyer, 82
LEAD: Raphael L. Elias, a lawyer who specialized in probate cases and estate planning, died of cancer Tuesday at New York Hospital.
He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Judge Quits Myerson Case In a Dispute
LEAD: A Federal judge withdrew yesterday from the pending trial of Bess Myerson because of a bitter dispute with the United States Attorney in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani.

Vincent's Hospital.

Hanover Bank Sets Big Charge
LEAD: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would drop by almost 70 percent because of costs related to efforts to make itself a more efficient competitor.

Town Accepts Plan to Shelter The Homeless
LEAD: The Town of Greenburgh, which embraces several villages in central Westchester County, agreed today to the construction of 108 units of housing for the homeless in a wooded area between a country club and a community college.


Walkouts Disrupt Republican Caucuses in Michigan
LEAD: Michigan's Republican caucuses, the first of the 1988 Presidential campaign, were disrupted tonight by delegate walkouts, and the campaign of Vice President Bush charged that followers of Pat Robertson tried to confuse the process to deny Mr.
Bush a victory.


Strike and Boycott Are Urged in Haiti
LEAD: Four leading Haitian politicians called today for a national strike on Saturday and repeated their appeal for a boycott of the election that the army-dominated Government has scheduled for Sunday.

LEAD: When Congress approved a Federal holiday to honor the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr., many who had fought for passage of the bill privately feared it might produce no more than another three-day weekend.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''As a sitting judge on a very busy court, I cannot devote the time and energy I wish to public discourse.''  - Judge Robert H. Bork, resigning from the bench.  [ A1:4. ]


Chip Industry Enjoys Surge
LEAD: The United States semiconductor industry closed out the year with a surge as product orders for December reached the highest level in more than three years, industry officials said.


Bid for USG Stalls
LEAD: Two wealthy Texas oilmen, Cyril Wagner Jr. and Jack E. Brown, said they had been unable to obtain financing for a hostile takeover of the USG Corporation.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the men's investor group, called Desert Partners, said that it had been advised by an unidentified investment banking firm that subordinated debt financing for a hostile bid of USG was impossible ''under current market conditions.


Investor, 23, Charged in $10 Million Fraud
LEAD: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan yesterday charged a 23-year-old, self-styled money manager with mail fraud, saying he took $10 million from 100 friends and associates to invest in stocks and instead bought himself an art collection, two homes and expensive cars.


Jes Grew Orchestra
LEAD: Jemeel Moondoc, a saxophonist, is to lead his Jes Grew Orchestra tonight at 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M. at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street, at Mulberry Street (219-3055).
Admission is $6.


Art: 'Media Post Media,' A Show of 19 Women
LEAD: ''MEDIA POST MEDIA'' is the latest exhibition organized by the independent curators Tricia Collins and Richard Milazzo.
Their exhibitions, of which this is at least the eighth in a New York gallery, are well known in the art world as barometers of a sort, or of several sorts.
The duo's shows usually manage to indicate important directions in new art while remaining somewhat inconsistent and presenting a number of artists whose prominence will probably not exceed the proverbial 15 minutes.


Horse Racing Notebook; Odds Shift for Florida Tracks
LEAD: From all the fuss here Tuesday, one would think that the Fountain of Youth had been rediscovered, or at least that an extraterrestrial had arrived.


West End Jazz
LEAD: Harold Ousley, a saxophonist, is to lead a group tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (570-7037).
Sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight, plus a 1:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.


AUCTIONS
LEAD: The Americana auctions at Sotheby's and Christie's every January are traditionally the largest and most important such sales of the year, and 1988 looks like it will be no exception, with Christie's presenting more than 400 works and Sotheby's about 2,000.


2 Students in New York Wounded by Gunfire
LEAD: Two New York City students were injured, one critically, by gunfire yesterday in incidents at the schools, the police said.


Man Held in Jet Crash Hoax
LEAD: A man was arraigned Wednesday on charges that he falsely reported a plane crash that led to a search by 100 people in a snowstorm.
The 28-year-old Laconia man, Mark Blair, pleaded not guilty in Laconia District Court on a misdemeanor charge of false public alarm.
He was ordered held on $1,000 bail, and a hearing was set for Feb.


Miller Brewing Fills Position of President
LEAD: Leonard J. Goldstein, senior vice president for sales at the Miller Brewing Company, has been named president and chief executive, succeeding William K. Howell, who took early retirement effective yesterday.
