LEAD: Henri Filion's claims of innocence about having any knowledge about tampering involving a race at Yonkers Raceway last Nov. 14 were challenged yesterday in the final day of hearings before the State Racing and Wagering Board.


No Straight A's for the Law Schools
LEAD: Sometime before the turn of the century, a million lawyers will be practicing in this country. ''To some, that is an awesome thought,'' said Haywood Burns, dean of the City University of New York Law School at Queens College. ''To some, that is an awful thought.''


Beijing Extols Taiwan's Chief On His Death
LEAD: Zhao Ziyang, the head of the Chinese Communist Party, delivered a remarkable tribute today to Chiang Ching-kuo, the President of Taiwan and a fervent anti-Communist, who died Wednesday in Taipei.

Clara Mae Taylor-Olson, Professor, 89
LEAD: Dr.
Clara Mae Taylor-Olson, professor emeritus of nutrition at Teachers College, Columbia University, and a leading figure in the field of nutrition education, died after a long illness Jan. 6 in a Pittsburgh hospital.
Dr.
Taylor-Olson was 89 years old and lived in Pittsburgh.


A Rival for the Space Palace
LEAD: The space station NASA wants to build is a luxury sky hotel with a sky-high price tag, now at $32 billion.
Congress has at last decreed that the agency should also consider supporting a much smaller, privately operated space station that costs a mere $700 million and can do many of the same things.


AT THE BAR
LEAD: It's no longer a big deal when a key partner at a mojor New York law firm changes jobs.
But as the fate of Kenneth J. Bialkin unfolded this week, a profession that has almost entirely lost its capacity for suprise or indignation was jolted to attention.


Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of the weather, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today.
Other regulations remain in effect.


Citadel Makes Bid
LEAD: The Citadel Holding Corporation said it had made a $18.50-a-share, or $107.3 million, offer to buy Valley Federal Savings and Loan Association, the first hostile takeover attempt in California's thrift industry.
Valley Federal, based in Van Nuys, Calif., has $3.1 billion in assets and 47 offices.
Valley Federal, trying to avert a takeover by Citadel, is talking with other potential merger partners.

LEAD: A woman suspected by South Korea of destroying a South Korean airliner with 115 people aboard in November said on television today that she was a North Korean agent and that she and an accomplice had planted a bomb on the plane.


Bonn Inquiry Hints Pakistan And Libya Got Atom Material
LEAD: The West German Environment Minister said today that a widening investigation into illegal cross-border transportation of nuclear wastes by a West German company has raised the possibility that nuclear materials may have found their way to Pakistan and Libya.

Preston Grover, War Correspondent, 87
LEAD: Preston Grover, who covered World War II in Germany, the Mediterranean and North Africa as a correspondent for The Associated Press, died Monday.
He was 87 years old.
In a 38-year-career with The A.P., he headed bureaus in New Delhi, Moscow and Paris.


European Urges U.S. Rate Rise
LEAD: Despite Japanese-American progress in steadying the dollar, higher United States interest rates are needed ''to make the dollar an attractive currency,'' a high-level representative of the International Monetary Fund said today.


The Monthly Announcement That Makes Wall St. Sweat
LEAD: At 8:30 A.M.
Friday, or a split second later, a number representing the deficit in the nation's trade for November will flash across news-service terminals from Wall Street to Tokyo.
While other Government statistics have had their heyday, the trade figure is clearly the number to watch these days.


Memorials to Dr. King In an Array of Activities

Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday is less a day for celebration than one for reflection on both the achievements and the goals yet to be realized in this country's generations-long struggle for social justice.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Sniffing Out Terrorists
LEAD: The State Department has found a new tool to combat terrorists: a dishwasher-size explosives detector called the EGIS Mark II that will be installed in all United States embassies next fall.

LEAD: The principal of Park West High School, a school in the Clinton section of Manhattan where there has been an unusual amount of violence among students, has asked to be reassigned, according to the Board of Education.

LEAD: RON DAUGHERTY is planning a party for Sunday afternoon -his ''football cronies'' crowding into his Chicago apartment, and purple pompons everywhere.


Japanese Scientist Will Head World Health Organization

Hiroshi Nakajima, was elected today to be Director General of the World Health Organization.


Chamber Music Society
LEAD: The Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society will perform the premiere of Peter Lieberson's ''Ziji'' tomorrow at 6 P.M. at the Paula Cooper Gallery (155 Wooster Street) and Sunday at 5 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall.
The program also includes works by Mozart and Brahms.
Tickets are $8 for tomorrow's performance, $18 for the Sunday concert.


First Amendment Lessons
LEAD: The Supreme Court has upheld in broadest terms the power of public school authorities to control the content of high school newspapers.
Now just about any educational reason will justify heavy editing and outright exclusion of student articles.
The Court reaffirms its 1969 decision that students may not be punished for non-disruptive political expression, like wearing black armbands in school to protest the Vietnam War.

LEAD:  A Tribute for Montand


Sports People; Hall List Gets Shorter
LEAD: Mike Ditka, Al Davis and Bob Griese were among the survivors yesterday when the list of 1988 Pro Football Hall of Fame candidates was cut to 15.
Davis, the Los Angeles Raiders' managing general partner, was nominated as a contributor.
Other former players nominated were Fred Biletnikoff, Buck Buchanan, Jack Ham, Lee Roy Jordan, Leroy Kelly, Tom Mack, Alan Page, Lou Rymkus, Art Shell and Lynn Swann.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: Cellular Communications Inc. said it would begin a tender offer for up to 4.5 milion shares of common stock of American Cellular Network Corp. at a price of $15.50 a share, representing about 51 percent of the outstanding shares on a fully diluted basis.


Texaco Is Urging Approval Of an 'Anti-Greenmail' Plan
LEAD: Apparently fearing a takeover threat, Texaco's president and chief executive is recommending that shareholders approve an ''anti-greenmail'' provision in the company's charter.

LEAD: After a lively, standing-room-only hearing at City Hall, the Board of Estimate yesterday voted 8 to 3 to uphold a lower city agency's decision to approve a plan by the Guggenheim Museum to build a 10-story addition to its building at Fifth Avenue and 89th Street.

Emergency Rooms: The New Wards
LEAD: On a recent evening at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx, a woman who had undergone heart bypass surgery and had been readmitted with chest pain asked her doctor how long she must remain in the hospital's emergency room. ''Awhile,'' he answered. ''What you call awhile?'' she shot back.  ''Awhile,'' it turned out, might mean five days, depending on how quickly beds became available in the hospital's intensive care or cardiac units.


Tunesmith's '50 Years' Of Music
LEAD: ANYONE who has seen the movie ''Broadcast News'' is not likely to forget a nutty cameo featuring a pair of eager-beaver jingle writers auditioning their John Williams-ish ''evening news'' theme for a major network news department.
Amid office chaos, the unflappable duo, waving their arms and la-la-la-ing, present their theme song like the set piece from a comic operetta.


Stage: By A. R. Gurney, 'Another Antigone'
LEAD: SOMEWHERE - even if it's only Hollywood - there must be a school where all the teachers are as inspiring as Mr.
Chips, Miss Brooks, Miss Jean Brodie, Professor Kingsley and those other lovable fictional educators who lecture so often on screen or stage but somehow always seem to be on sabbatical in real life.

LEAD: Coach Bob Wade and the Maryland Terrapins were reintroduced to the realities of the Atlantic Coast Conference tonight.
Riding high after two conference victories and a noticeable recovery from a disastrous 1986-87 season, the Terrapins were brought back to earth by North Carolina.

Honda said the expansion would add 100 jobs by 1989.

Corrections
LEAD: A chart in Sports Pages on Jan. 13 with an article about the N.F.L. playoffs misidentified the Denver Broncos' backup quarterback.
He is Gary Kubiak.


San Francisco Journal; The Rush These Days Is Hardly for Gold
LEAD: San Francisco can boast of beautiful scenery, crusty sourdough bread and flaky white Dungeness crab, which is now bountiful and in season.
But when San Franciscans get together these days, the prime topic of discussion is the difficulty of simply finding a parking space.

Correct.

Film: 'Couch Trip,' With Aykroyd and Matthau
LEAD: IN ''The Couch Trip,'' Michael Ritchie's new farce about radio sex therapists and assorted southern California con artists, Walter Matthau plays a comparatively small role, but in the way he looks and behaves he defines the movie's laid-back, ramshackle charm.


Paine Webber Is Charged
LEAD: The E. F. Hutton Group Inc. and Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. have begun criminal proceedings in Switzerland against Paine Webber Inc. and four of its employees on charges that include stealing client records and brokerage business from Hutton, the investment firms said yesterday.


Israelis Detain 10 Palestinians Termed Moderates
LEAD: The Israeli authorities detained 10 Palestinians, most regarded as members of the moderate Arab establishment, in a continuing crackdown today as scattered disturbances continued in the occupied territories.

Film: Testing Poses in 'Patti Rocks'
LEAD: BILLY REGIS (Chris Mulkey) is a ladies' man who likes to boast about his exploits, and Eddie (John Jenkins) is the friend who has heard it all.
So when the two of them embark on an all-night drive to visit a girlfriend of Billy's in ''Patti Rocks,'' it's a very long journey indeed.
Billy describes his sexual adventures in rude, graphic detail; meanwhile, the more sensitive Eddie laments the breakup of his marriage.


Oreo Thief Gets 3-Year Term
LEAD: A transient has been sentenced to three years in prison after pleading guilty to breaking into a church nursery school and eating Oreo cookies and drinking Kool-Aid, officials said.
David Deskin, 25 years old, drew the sentence Tuesday because he was already on probation for another burglary.

LEAD: The Stop and Shop Companies said that a partnership controlled by Herbert Haft, the chairman of Dart Group, planned to buy more than $15 million of Stop and Shop stock.
Stop and Shop, which operates 171 Bradlees discount stores in addition to 114 Stop and Shop supermarkets, said it had received a letter from Mr.


Sports People; Guerrero Back at Wheel
LEAD: Only four months after a crash nearly ended his life, Roberto Guerrero was back in a race car yesterday, feeling ''100 percent.'' The 29-year-old driver from Colombia suffered critical head injuries in a crash last Sept. 10 during a test of tires at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.
He spent more than two weeks in a coma after the accident.


In Bullish Britain, One Big Worry
LEAD: THE British are feeling good about their economy.
The latest official forecast of the Treasury, prepared soon after the October stock market collapse, put the growth rate for the national economy in 1988 at 2.5 percent.
Inflation is expected to remain low.
And unemployment, still at the high level of 9.4 percent, has come down from 13 percent and is still declining.


Paul E. McKeever, Theologian, 64
LEAD: The Rev.
Paul E. McKeever, professor of moral theology at St.
John's University and a former editor of The Long Island Catholic, died of cardiac arrest Sunday at the Seminary of the Immaculate Conception in Huntington, L.I., where he lived.
He was 64 years old.


Chemical Net Climbs in Quarter
LEAD: The Chemical New York Corporation, the corporate parent of the Chemical Bank, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income more than doubled.
Much of the increase, however, resulted from special, one-time factors rather than the company's main operations.

LEAD: Forrest Gregg left his head coaching job with the Green Bay Packers today, returned to Southern Methodist University with a $200,000 cut in pay and vowed to rebuild his alma mater's scandal-rocked football program.

Retail Sales Climbed 0.7% In December
LEAD: The nation's retail sales rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in December over the November level, the best performance in four months, spurred in great part by higher auto sales, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

Film: Lahti in 'Stacking'
LEAD: ''STACKING,'' opening today at the Public Theater, is somewhat better than its title, which evokes nothing before one has seen the movie and not much more after.
It refers to the operation by which bales of hay are collected and stacked together in one part of the field with the use of a large, tractorlike vehicle equipped with a forked scoop.


Kidder, Peabody Is V.A.'s Adviser
LEAD: Kidder, Peabody &amp; Company has been named financial adviser to the Veterans Administration, which plans to sell an undisclosed amount of home mortgage loans from its portfolio this year.


Sports People; Floyd Fined, Suspended
LEAD: Eric (Sleepy) Floyd of the Houston Rockets was suspended for one game and fined $5,000 for his part in a fight Wednesday night with Jeff Hornacek of the Phoenix Suns, the league announced last night.
Floyd sat out Houston's 103-98 victory over Portland as part of his punishment.
Floyd's suspension and fine was issued by Rod Thorn, the leauge's vice president of operations.


New Polish Voting Laws Bar Candidates From Opposition
LEAD: The Polish Communist Party today categorically ruled out a role for opposition candidates under new voting laws that the party has vaunted as part of its design for broader democratization of Polish political life.


U.S. TO WITHDRAW 72 JET FIGHTERS FROM SPANISH BASE
LEAD: The United States, after months of negotiations with Spain, has decided to accede to Spanish demands and withdraw 72 F-16 jet fighters based there, Defense and State Department officials said today.


BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JANUARY 15, 1988
LEAD:  MARKETS  The New York Stock Exchange will curb program trading in a six-day experiment.
Reacting to criticism that the enormous computerized trades were a major factor in October's stock market collapse, the exchange asked the firms that engage in it to refrain from using the exchange's computer system on any day when the Dow Jones industrial average climbs or falls by 75 points or more.

LEAD: Harold J. Kennedy, a jack-of-all-theatrical-trades and for nearly half a century a champion of the summer theater circuit, died of cardiac arrest on Sunday at Doctors Hospital.

Sports People; Comings and Goings
LEAD: Reggie Jackson said yesterday that he was considering an offer to play baseball in Japan.
Jackson, currently on the Oakland Athletics roster, indicated last season that he was playing for the last time, but never formally announced his retirement. . . .
Jerry Rice of the San Francisco 49ers, the wide receiver who set National Football League records of 22 touchdown receptions and at least one in 13 straight games this season, has been voted the Maxwell Football Club's Bert Bell Award as pro player of the year.


Brooklyn Fire Kills One; 27 Families Are Displaced
LEAD: One woman was killed, six people were injured and 27 families were forced to leave their homes when a four-alarm fire blazed through a city-owned building yesterday at 583 Franklin Street in Prospect Heights.
The building was ''believed to be a crack house,'' a police officer said.
The cause of the fire was termed suspicious.


Beethoven Society
LEAD: The Beethoven Society will present a program of familiar Beethoven sonatas performed by five pianists -Jacob Lateiner, Ursula Oppens, Seymour Lipkin, Ralph Votapek and Lee Luvisi - tomorrow at 3 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall.
Tickets are $17.50.
Information: 874-6770.


Big Board Expanding
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange will expand its floor space more than 20 percent next Monday by opening a new area, it announced yesterday.
The $20 million project, begun in 1985, will add 7,000 square feet to the Big Board's present 30,000 square feet.

LEAD: Michel Bergeron, the coach of the Rangers, will remain at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y., at least until today, the team said yesterday.
Bergeron entered the hospital Tuesday night complaining of abdominal pains.
A statement said Bergeron had undergone extensive testing in the last two days but the results were inconclusive.

Mr.
Keh, the indefatigable Manhattan restaurateur, has apparently never felt comfortable with Western food, which is why it came as no surprise when he pulled the plug on his two experiments in Occidental cuisine - the California-style Safari Grill and the Mexican restaurant Cafe Marimba - and turned them back into

LEAD: CAN it really be a quarter of a century since a 16-year-old pianist named Andre Watts made his spectacular debut with the New York Philharmonic as the substitute for an ailing Glenn Gould?
Evidently so, for there was Mr.
Watts striding onto the stage of Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night to mark the silver anniversary of that celebrated event.

Administration Calls Law on Aliens Effective
LEAD: The Reagan Administration says the new immigration law is working, as shown by a drop in apprehensions of aliens at the border, by a steady rise in applications for legal status and in broad employer compliance.


Then Turned Into Now But 60's Music Lives On
LEAD: TWO decades after the fact, the 1960's really have a hold on us.
We're surrounded by its images and echoes, in a wash of revisionism and nostalgia.
Historians and film makers try to sort out the Vietnam War; academics defend or disparage 60's ideas.
Television characters sling 60's references to prove they're fun-loving folks; fashion plates wear tie-dye and mini-skirts.

Fund Rise Barred For Use of TPA
LEAD: A Government advisory panel has decided not to recommend a special increase in Medicare reimbursements to hospitals that treat heart attack victims with tissue plasminogen activator, the new drug from Genentech Inc.
The decision could discourage some hospitals from using TPA.
Under Medicare rules, hospitals receive a set payment for a particular disease.

George Balanchine did, too.

LEAD: An Army instructor at a major weapon-testing center was arrested today on espionage charges and accused of attempting to sell military documents to the Soviet Union, Federal law-enforcement officials said.

LEAD: There is little dispute here that Taiwan's new President, Lee Teng-hui, is a man of sincerity and scholarship, a soft-edged man who associates say virtually exudes moral rectitude.
But there is a question about whether those exemplary attributes will be enough to keep him in office for long.


Consider Demilitarized Palestinian Democracies; Holy Places
LEAD: To the Editor:


Key Dole Aide Leaves to Calm Queries on Fund
LEAD: The national finance chairman of Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign stepped aside today as Mr.
Dole sought to distance himself from the growing political controversy over the aide's financial dealings with his wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole.


Miller Fires Eagle
LEAD: Johnny Miller scored the first eagle of the 1988 PGA Tour today with a shot that brought back memories of his deadly iron play during his winning days in the 1970's.
His 8-iron effort of 140 yards at the par-4 13th hole took one short bounce into the hole for a deuce.


Urban League Says Blacks Suffered Loss Over Decade
LEAD: The economic and social status of most black Americans did not significantly improve in the last decade and may actually have worsened, the president of the National Urban League said today.


B.P. Bids for Britoil, But Offer Is Rejected
LEAD: Despite major obstacles, the British Petroleum Company formally offered $:2.27 billion in cash today for Britoil P.L.C., which quickly rejected the bid.

LEAD: Pay attention.
This gets complicated. ''Pulaski: The TV Detective'' is an eight-episode BBC series that starts tonight at 10 o'clock on the Arts &amp; Entertainment Network.
It is about a character named Larry Summers, an American actor who plays the title role in a British action series called ''Pulaski.


Ron and Noboru: A Good Start
LEAD: The first meeting of President Reagan and Prime Minister Takeshita of Japan showed promise - a friendly spirit at the top of what is otherwise a difficult economic relationship.
With Japan's power swelling steadily, and American supremacy no longer unchallenged, relations still will be poisoned by stand-offs over trade and finance.


BROKEN WATER MAIN FLOODS BUILDINGS AND KNOCKS OUT UTILITIES ON UPPER WEST SIDE
LEAD: A 90-year-old water main broke underneath Broadway between West 84th and 85th Streets in Manhattan early yesterday, sending a cascade of water flowing westward in the frigid darkness into basements of apartment houses and stores.


Alfred Easton Poor, Architect, 88
LEAD: Alfred Easton Poor, a New York architect who designed many government buildings, banks and institutional headquarters, and who was part of a group that designed the restoration and extension of the East Front of the United States Capitol in the early 1960's, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''The figures are unambiguous on the improvement in exports.


Reagan Waiver for Pakistan
LEAD: President Reagan invoked a waiver today to assure continued aid to Pakistan despite American concerns that Pakistan may have been involved in smuggling nuclear-weapons materials from the United States.
The waiver was invoked on a law that requires a cutoff of aid to any nation believed to be exporting restricted materials from the United States that can be used to make nuclear weapons.


Sports of The Times; The Heart of Pistol Pete
LEAD: TOO many times, said Atlanta Hawks Coach Richie Guerin in 1970, Pete Maravich gets himself ''stuck up there in the air.'' It's a great trait for a moon, but not necessarily for a basketball player.


POP: HOT CLUB RE-CREATES REINHARDT-GRAPPELLI SOUND
LEAD: Few sounds in modern pop are more archetypally jazzy than the lilting string-band music of Django Reinhardt, the Belgian gypsy guitarist, and his Hot Club of France.
Led by the guitarist, who died in 1953, and Stephane Grappelli, the violinist, who will turn 80 this year, the group refined a propulsive, accelerated dance music that, savored in the context of today's electronic jazz-fusion, seems quintessentially pure and simple.


Concert: Marc-Andre Hamelin Plays Ives
LEAD: The ''Concord'' Sonata by Charles Ives is one of those pieces that rarely makes its way onto piano recital programs but invariably steals the show when it does.
It appeared as the welcome entry on the first half of Marc-Andre Hamelin's concert in Carnegie Hall Wednesday evening.
Mr.
Hamelin won first prize in the Carnegie Hall International American Music


Your Money; Franchises Offer Profits and Risks
LEAD: JAMES Goodman, executive vice president of the Morehouse School of Medicine in Atlanta, recently decided to leave his position and go into franchising.
So he bought the Seattle-area rights to open franchises of Jiffy Lube International Inc., a fast oil-change and lubrication system for automobiles.


Pyongyang as Outlaw
LEAD: North Korea, a political and economic failure, hates and envies successful South Korea.
Recently that envy has grown as Seoul reaches for new prestige by playing host to the 1988 Summer Olympics.
Now it appears that despite the new and positive foreign policy signals Pyongyang has been emitting in recent months, its policy still comes down to nastiness, terror and murder.


Plenty for Jews and Catholics to Discuss
LEAD: To the Editor:


NAKED IGNORANCE
LEAD: Happy 100th birthday to the National Geographic Society.


Output in 1987 Up 5.2%, Biggest Gain Since 1984
LEAD: The nation's industrial output climbed 5.2 percent in 1987, almost five times the previous year's gain and the best showing for American industry since 1984, the Government reported today.


Levin Friend Testifies Of Drinks and Diet Pills
LEAD: Jennifer Levin was not intoxicated when she left an Upper East Side bar with Robert E. Chambers Jr. just after 4 o'clock on the morning of her death, a witness at Mr.
Chambers's murder trial testified yesterday.

More Glasnost Needed on Soviet Prison Camp
LEAD: To the Editor:


Little Federal Office Has Big Role in Art Tours
LEAD: Last year, an art exhibition in the United States commemorating the 750th anniversary of the City of Berlin was postponed, not because of the usual artistic or political problems but because Federal officials declined to provide a form of insurance to protect the lenders against possible loss.


Judgment Stage for Central American Peace Accord
LEAD: Leaders of the participating Central American countries at the opening ceremony of a conference yesterday in San Jose, Costa Rica, to judge the results of the regional peace treaty.
From the left were Presidents Jose Azcona Hoyo of Honduras, Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador, Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica, Vinicio Cerezo of Guatemala and Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua.

LEAD:  The Economy


Bank Board Plan Near On Texas Savings Units
LEAD: Federal regulators are expected to adopt soon a plan to close or merge by year-end 104 savings institutions in Texas and 42 in neighboring states, the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, M. Danny Wall, said today.

U.S. and Spain Announce a Limited Military Accord
LEAD: The United States and Spain announced new military arrangements today that would sharply curtail the American presence here and terminate American aid to Spain under the existing 35-year-old treaty between the two countries.


Knicks Fall to 1-15 on Road
LEAD: The Knicks suffered a second-half collapse tonight on the way to their 10th consecutive loss on the road, a 119-104 decision against the Philadelphia 76ers.
New York had played an outstanding first half at the Spectrum, leading by as many as 13 points, and holding a 58-50 lead at the half.
Then came the third period.

Mother and 2 Children Die in Jersey House Fire
LEAD: Firefighters working early yesterday at a home in the Browns Mills section of Pemberton Township.
Coralie Diane Rahner; her 13-year-old daughter, Elizabeth Anne, and son Eugene Jr., 6, were killed in the blaze.
Mrs.
Rahner's husband, Eugene, was listed in critical condition at a hospital.
Their son James, 14, was treated and released.

New York City Has Record Rise In Assessments
LEAD: The taxable value of property in New York City is now $65.7 billion, reflecting a $6.4 billion increase that is the largest annual rise in the city's history, tentative city figures showed yesterday.


Conner Is Still Fuming
LEAD: Dennis Conner took an opportunity yesterday to lash out at Michael Fay, the New Zealand merchant banker and yachtsman, charging that Fay's unorthodox challenge for the America's Cup amounts to a ''legalized ambush'' of the 137-year-old trophy.


Strike Disrupts Ports in Northwest
LEAD: A 38-hour work stoppage by 3,800 longshoremen that shut down docks in all ports of the Pacific Northwest ended today, but labor leaders hinted of further disruptions in the coming weeks.


Bergeron Released
LEAD: Three days after he checked himself into a New York hospital complaining of stomach pains, Coach Michel Bergeron of the Rangers was released yesterday after undergoing a final examination.
Bergeron promptly flew to join the team in Montreal and planned on coaching when the Rangers play the Canadiens at the Forum tonight.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Celtics 122, Kings 86: Kevin McHale and Larry Bird led Boston in a 14-0 surge to take a 34-11 lead after one quarter and rolled to a victory last night over visiting Sacramento.
The Kings were never in the game after the midpoint of the opening period.
The closest they came in the last three quarters was 63-44 with 10 minutes 3 seconds left in the third quarter.


Stage: Ping Chong's View Of History in 'Maraya'
LEAD: In theater, Ping Chong discovers the same kind of freedom of abstraction that others utilize in dance, music and the visual arts, all of which are inextricably intertwined in his innovative work.
His new performance piece, ''Maraya - Acts of Nature in Geological Time'' (at the Apple Corp Theater), is a mysterious investigation of world history, as studied on Mr.


Broncos Lose Johnson
LEAD: Vance Johnson, the Broncos' leading wide receiver and an extraordinary playoff performer, will miss the American Conference championship game on Sunday against the Browns.

Joe Albany, 63, Dies; Master of Jazz Piano
LEAD: Joe Albany, a jazz pianist who first emerged in the be-bop era, died of upper respiratory failure and cardiac arrest on Tuesday in the Roosevelt Hospital Division of St.
Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.
He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.


NBC Rules Out TBS Stake As Talks With Turner Fail
LEAD: NBC and Turner Broadcasting System Inc. have halted negotiations that would have given NBC a minority interest in Ted Turner's cash-hungry television enterprise, officials of the two companies said yesterday.

Raimondo Manzini, Editor, 86
LEAD: Raimondo Manzini, editor of the Vatican daily L'Osservatore Romano for 18 years and a former member of parliament, died Thursday.
He was 86 years old.


Trio With Trombone
LEAD: Ray Anderson, a trombonist, is to lead a trio Sunday at Visiones, 125 Macdougal Street (673-5576).
Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M.; there is a $3 cover and a two-drink minimum.


Newark Bill on Testing Of Prostitutes Is Vetoed
LEAD: Mayor Sharpe James today vetoed a city ordinance that would have required convicted prostitutes and their customers to be tested for AIDS, saying it was unconstitutional.

LEAD: Office vacancy rates in Manhattan rose in the fourth quarter of 1987, to 11.5 percent in the downtown area and 10.2 percent in midtown, according to a study by a leading real estate concern.

Frederic Karoly, 95, Abstract Painter, Dies
LEAD: Frederic Karoly, a painter whose abstract oils are in the collection of the Metropolitan, the Guggenheim and the Whitney museums, died on Dec. 15 at the Inter-Continental Hotel in Manhattan, where he had made his home for many years.
He was 95 years old.


Abercrombie Chain Bought
LEAD: The Limited Inc., the diversified chain of women's apparel stores, and Oshman's Sporting Goods said yesterday that the Limited had agreed to buy the Abercrombie &amp; Fitch division of Oshman's for $47 million in cash.

Some Doubts About New Cosmetics for Tanning
LEAD: Tan accelerators, the newest cosmetics for sunning, are intended to provide the maximum tan with minimum exposure.
For winter travelers who are planning short vacations in the sun, the products sound ideal.
But some dermatologists are dubious.


Muller Scores 3 Goals Again
LEAD: Kirk Muller drew the penalties and capitalized during the manpower advantages tonight in leading the Devils with three goals to a 7-3 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in Byrne Meadowlands Arena.


Deaver on the Block: Auction Helps Pay Legal Fee
LEAD: Shortly after the doors opened, the hand-painted Chinese screen from Michael K. Deaver's lucrative lobbying business was sold this morning for the asking price of $3,500.


Teen-Age Girl Killed in Nevada Storm
LEAD: A house in Reno, Nev., was left without a roof Thursday as a storm with winds gusting up to 87 miles an hour swept through the city, knocking down power lines.
Officials said that an automobile accident in which a teen-age girl was killed was caused by the storm. (AP)


Texaco to Ease Takeover Defenses
LEAD: Concerned that their bankruptcy reorganization plan might be rejected by shareholders, executives of Texaco Inc. agreed in principle yesterday to demands by a shareholders' committee to ease restrictions on an unfriendly takeover.

Better Ways to Clean New York's Dirty Streets
LEAD: To the Editor:


Met Opera: Debussy's 'Pelleas,' With Von Stade
LEAD: Debussy's ''Pelleas et Melisande'' is less an opera than an anti-opera.
His setting of the Maeterlinck play rarely raises its voice above a somber hush but can draw the susceptible listener deep into a world of gauze and shadow where hazily defined characters move as if in a trance and where almost everything important is left unsaid.


At Latin Parley, Charges of Bad Faith
LEAD: The leaders of five Central American countries opened a final stage of peace negotiations here today amid accusations of bad faith and strongly differing interpretations of the regional treaty they signed five months ago.


Schools Should Teach Us of Other Cultures
LEAD: To the Editor:


Leader of Army Revolt Escapes in Argentina
LEAD: The leader of an army revolt last April that threatened Argentina's democratic Government escaped from house arrest today, shortly before he was to be taken to jail, officials said.


Arizona Governor May Be Impeached
LEAD: A special counsel retained by the Arizona House of Representatives to investigate Gov.
Evan Mecham asserted today that the Governor had violated numerous state laws and suggested that there were grounds for impeachment.


2 Officers Suspended In Separate Incidents
LEAD: Two New York City police officers were suspended yesterday after they were arrested in separate incidents.
One was arrested during a raid on a Manhattan social club and the other was charged with buying crack on Long Island, the police said.


FOR SANDINISTA, A STRONG LITERARY ESCORT
LEAD: The five Central American presidents who met today in Costa Rica were accompanied by aides and advisers, but the delegation traveling with President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua carried the greatest literary weight.


Hyundai Price Rise
LEAD: Hyundai Motor America said it had raised the base prices of Excel car models by $200, with the exception of the three-door hatchback, whose price rises $100, to $5,395.
The company attributed the increase to the depreciation of the dollar against other currencies and to other business costs.


CORRECTION
LEAD: An article last Saturday about the annual Ascap Musical Theater Workshop identified the sponsoring organization incompletely.
It is the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, the musical licensing organization.

NO CANCER IS FOUND IN TEST ON REAGAN
LEAD: Doctors who examined President Reagan today found ''no recurrence of cancer'' in his colon and none of the nonmalignant growths that have been discovered on the four other checkups he has had over the past two years, the White House said.


Three Laboratories Are Chosen to Determine Age of Shroud of Turin
LEAD: Three laboratories have been chosen by the Roman Catholic Cardinal of Turin to test fragments of the shroud of Turin in an effort to determine its age.


Bridge; Four Groups Capture Titles In Tri-State Regional Event
LEAD: Four championships were decided Thursday, on the second day of play in the Tri-State Regional Championships in Port Chester, N.Y.
The winners of titles were: Men's teams - Miles Storfer of Jamaica, Queens, Irving Ingwer of Brooklyn, Dave Greenwald of Manhattan, and Gene Prosnitz of Brooklyn.


Faldo Shoots 7 Birdies In a Row
LEAD: Nick Faldo of England, winner of last year's British Open, posted seven consecutive birdies today to fall just one short of the American PGA Tour record of eight birdies in a row.

Coping: With Self-Help Books
LEAD: For every New Year's resolution, there now seems to be a companion book.
Feeling blue? ''Letting Go'' promises, on its jacket, to help readers ''erase painful memories'' within three months.
Shy? ''Stand Up!
Speak Out!
Talk Back!'' has, the jacket states, ''liberated thousands from anger, guilt and self-denial.


CORRECTION
LEAD: The Sports of The Times column on Thursday omitted identities for five of the nine members of the Baseball Writers Association of America who returned blank ballots in the Hall of Fame election.
They were Michael Martinez of The New York Times, Fred Down and Fred Lief of United Press International, Bob Oates of The Los Angeles Times and Ken Nigro, a former baseball writer who works for the Baltimore Orioles.


Security Tightened in Haiti as Election Nears
LEAD: A driver being searched in Port-au-Prince.
Soldiers tied up traffic for miles as security was increased for the Government-run national election tomorrow.
In violence that accompanied aborted vote Nov. 29, at least 34 people were killed.
Opposition leaders claim that the Government is attempting to force participation in the voting.


Thatcher Uses Muscle to Retain Secrets Law
LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher used personal lobbying and parliamentary tactics today to defeat the latest effort to rewrite Britain's Official Secrets Act.

Leon Seltzer, 69, Dies; Led a University Press
LEAD: Leon E. Seltzer, a national figure in university press publishing and a lawyer, died of cardio-respiratory arrest Monday at Stanford University Hospital.
He was 69 years old and lived on the Stanford University campus in Stanford, Calif.


Student Discipline, Principal Discipline
LEAD: Can Joe Clark, the two-fisted school principal in Paterson, N.J., survive the conflict with his Board of Education?
The White House says it wants him for a full-time position, but he has agreed only to an unpaid consultancy.
Whatever games are being played on that front, Mr.
Clark need not lose his job as principal unless he forces the board to dismiss him.


Broader Waste Cleanup Seen
LEAD: The nation may have to spend an estimated $22.7 billion cleaning up hazardous waste sites that were supposedly operating under strict environmental regulation, a Congressional study says.


Moves to End Digital Tape Dispute
LEAD: Record companies and consumer electronics manufacturers have begun moving toward resolving a dispute that has kept a new tape recording technology - digital audio tape - out of the hands of American consumers, industry and Government officials say.


Battling the Radar Busters
LEAD: When Geico decided to deny automobile insurance to drivers who said they owned radar detectors, it expected no controversy. ''It made sense,'' said August P. Alegi, vice president and deputy general counsel for the company. ''People own detectors for one reason only: to avoid speed limits.
That makes them unacceptable risks.

LEAD: Vice President Bush said today that he had answered all questions on his role in the Iran-contra affair and that he believed the issue was closed.

'Crazy Horse' Author Is Upheld in Libel Case
LEAD: A Federal District Court in Minnesota has dismissed a four-year-old libel suit brought against Peter Matthiessen, author of ''In the Spirit of Crazy Horse,'' and his publisher, Viking Penguin.
The ruling, which is subject to appeal, upholds the right of an author ''to publish an entirely one-sided view of people and events.

O'Sullivan Won't Retire
LEAD: One week after a lopsided defeat for the vacant North American Boxing Federation welterweight title, Shawn O'Sullivan ended speculation that he might end his boxing career by announcing yesterday that he would continue with a new sense of commitment. ''There's no debate in my mind, I will not retire,'' O'Sullivan said at a news conference in Toronto.


Agent Surrenders
LEAD: Jim Abernethy, a former Atlanta sports agent, turned himself in to Alabama authorities Thursday on misdemeanor charges stemming from his admitted payments to an Auburn defensive back, Kevin Porter.
Abernethy was released on a $1,000 cash bond after he was booked at the Lee County Jail in Opelika, Ala.


Sterling Drug's Stock Up Sharply
LEAD: Shares of the Sterling Drug Company, target of a hostile takeover bid from Switzerland's Hoffmann-La Roche &amp; Company, rose sharply yesterday as investors bet that Sterling would find a friendly partner to outbid the European pharmaceutical giant.
Sterling rose $2 a share on the New York Stock Exchange to close at $74.125.


Congress and Critics Eye Army-Mormon Rift
LEAD: Congress says the Army is not providing adequate religious facilities for workers at a remote weapon-testing facility in Utah where Mormon Church officials were denied land to build a church.

LEAD: Rich Bond, Vice President Bush's deputy national campaign manager, stood in the street outside Elmer's Steak Pit Thursday night, bundled against the arctic cold in a blue loden coat, his face creased in anger, and shouted at the bolted door in front of him, ''Let our people in!''

LEAD: Kerry Ketchem may have won the biggest one-game prize in the history of television's ''Super Password,'' but it paled in comparison with a string of illegal jackpots he has scored in recent years, authorities across the country said today.

Guidepost
LEAD: Borrowing Costs  After months of see-sawing interest rates, American consumers enter the new year facing moderately higher borrowing costs than in January 1987.
The uncertainty has led people to postpone purchases, and indeed the outlook remains clouded as the Federal Reserve adjusts for changing economic conditions.

CORRECTION
LEAD: An article yesterday about observances for the birthday of the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr. misattributed a quotation about the level of participation by white Americans.
The statement was by Lloyd Davis, executive director of the King Federal Holiday Commission, not by Alan Jackson, its deputy director.


CONERT: GUARNERI QUARTET
LEAD: Erich Wolfgang Korngold was the center of interest when the Guarneri String Quartet played at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night.
Korngold, who began as a Viennese child prodigy and ended his days in Hollywood, endured the first half of the 20th century without ever finding a comfortable place in it.


Nofziger Jury Chosen
LEAD: A jury of seven men and five women was selected today for the conflict-of-interest trial of Lyn C. Nofziger, a former aide to President Reagan.
The jury was selected from a panel of 60 prospective jurors that had been screened in questioning that began Monday.
Mr.
Nofziger, 63 years old, is charged with improperly lobbying former White House colleagues after he resigned from the President's staff in early 1982.

Pop: Culture, Rockers Reggae Band
LEAD: The raw-edged lead vocals of Joseph Hill, melodies like pop hymns and lyrics that meld current observations with biblical prophecies made Culture one of the most important Jamaican reggae bands of the late 1970's.
Its first LP, ''Two Sevens Clash'' from 1976, is a landmark reggae album that helped shape steadfast, mid-tempo ''rockers'' reggae.


A New System for Nasdaq
LEAD: The Nasdaq over-the-counter market began using a new automatic trading system today for large stock orders.
The change is intended to reduce reliance on telephone lines, which became clogged during the October market turbulence.


Mr. Cuomo Promotes Housing Crisis
LEAD: New York needs desperately to encourage housing production, especially housing for rent.
What a disappointment, therefore, that Governor Cuomo's first 1988 bill will discourage any sane builder from creating it.

Treasury Prices Advance Sharply
LEAD: Treasury bond and note prices rose sharply yesterday after the Government reported an unexpectedly sharp drop in the nation's trade deficit for November.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose by more than two and a half points, its biggest one-day increase since October.

Sean MacBride of Ireland Is Dead at 83
LEAD: Sean MacBride, an Irish revolutionary who went on to win the Nobel and Lenin peace prizes, died after a short illness yesterday at his home in Dublin.
He was 83 years old.
In a 70-year career that took him from street battles with the British in Dublin to the international award-ceremony podium in Oslo, Mr.


E.P.A. Considers Sanctions Against Oil Company in River Spill
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency, after inspecting the site of a huge oil spill from an Ashland Oil Company storage facility in Pennsylvania, is considering legal action against the company for violations of the Clean Water Act, agency officials said today.


Apple in Pact With Digital
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. and the Digital Equipment Corporation, as expected, formally announced a joint development effort aimed at developing products to connect Apple Macintosh machines and Digital VAX computers.


Harvard Stops Columbia, 64-57
LEAD: Ralph James scored 20 points and triggered a second-half surge last night that helped Harvard beat Columbia, 64-57, in an Ivy League game.

Another Judge Selected to Preside In Federal Case Against Myerson
LEAD: A new Federal judge was selected yesterday to conduct the trial of Bess Myerson, the former New York City Cultural Affairs Commissioner, on charges that include obstruction of justice.


Traffic Cameras Installed
LEAD: New York City placed the first of three cameras on traffic lights yesterday as part of an experiment to capture people who go through red lights.
The first light was installed at 86th Street and Third Avenue and will be in operation for three months.
Set on poles, the cameras would be tripped after a car ran a red light.


Wells Fargo to Buy Barclays in California
LEAD: Wells Fargo &amp; Company said today that it had agreed to acquire Barclays Bank of California for about $125 million in cash.
A subsidiary of the London-based Barclays Bank P.L.C., Barclays Bank of California is the 17th-largest bank in the state, with 1987 year-end assets of about $1.3 billion.


AVAir Halts
LEAD: AVAir Inc., which operates the American Eagle commuter airline service, has suspended operations indefinitely, officials said.
American Eagle, which serves airports in North Carolina, Virginia and Washington, D.C., is owned by Dallas-based American Airlines.
AVAir is a franchisee, with headquarters in Raleigh, N.C.


U.S. May Return Boy, 9, To Africa, Court Rules
LEAD: The United States Supreme Court today cleared the way for the State Department to return to Zimbabwe a 9-year-old boy who was taken from his father, a diplomat, last month amid accusations that he beat the boy.


Hong Kong Charges May Grow
LEAD: Ronald Li, the former chairman of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange who was charged Thursday with accepting $352,000 from a Japanese company in return for listing it on the exchange, could face further charges as the colony's Government continues its investigation, a prosecutor said today.


James Marcus, Ex-Water Chief
LEAD: James Lewis Marcus, a former New York City Water Commissioner who pleaded guilty to Federal charges in a kickback conspiracy involving a city reservoir contract, died of leukemia yesterday at Maricopa County Medical Center in Phoenix.
He was 57 years old and had moved to Arizona from Manhattan last year.


INSIDE
LEAD:  Cuba Says No to Olympics


Decision for Sears in Sex Bias Suit is Upheld
LEAD: A Federal appeals court in Chicago this week upheld a ruling against the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in its nine-year-old sex discrimination suit against Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company.


Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of the weather, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today.
Other regulations remain in effect.


N.H.L. Suspends Two
LEAD: Calling one incident ''potentially very dangerous'' and another ''totally irresponsible,'' Brian O'Neil, the executive vice president of the National Hockey League, issued suspensions yesterday totaling 12 games to Steve Konroyd, the Islanders' steadiest defenseman this season, and Randy Cunneyworth, the Pittsburgh Penguins' free-swinging left wing.


Grand Met Makes Final Martell Bid
LEAD: The British liquor and hotels giant Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. today made what it said was its last raise in the bidding against the Seagram Company for the cognac house Martell.


Mexico City Journal; Season of Smog in 'Makesicko City'
LEAD: To a large extent, the 20 million people in the world's largest metropolis have reluctantly adapted to living with the pollution that fouls the air here.

CORRECTION
LEAD: A chronology from The Associated Press on Dec. 30 about recent mass killings in the United States misstated the number of people slain by a gunman July 18, 1984, at a McDonald's restaurant in San Ysidro, Calif.


6 Freeze to Death in New York
LEAD: At least six people, three of them homeless, have frozen to death in New York City in the last week and a half of bitter winter cold, city officials said yesterday.


Political Marketing; Cable TV Is Becoming an Integral Player in Advertising Strategies for 1988
LEAD: Political operatives are making cable television an integral part of their advertising strategy for the first time in a Presidential race.
They are buying spots on cable for their candidates and exploring other ways of using the nation's 5,000 cable television systems.


New York Area Store Sales Up
LEAD: Sales at several of New York City's largest department stores rose by an average of 8.8 percent in December from the period a year ago, according to a monthly spot-check.
The stores posted average sales gains of 7.3 percent in the metropolitan area.


No Headline
LEAD: The cargo ship American Maine being moved by tugboats up the Hudson River to Pier 92 yesterday as chunks of ice from upstream headed for the ocean.
The ship, which was moved from Maher Terminal at Port Newark where it underwent repairs, is one of 12 cargo ships of the bankrupt United States Lines that are docked at various berths in New York Harbor.


Racial Remarks Cause Furor
LEAD: Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder, the longtime CBS Sports commentator, provoked a controversy yesterday when he told a local television interviewer in Washington that blacks make better athletes than whites because they were ''bred to be that way.''

Concert: Philharmonic Plays Reich
LEAD: Commissioned by the San Francisco Symphony, Steve Reich's latest orchestral score, ''The Four Sections,'' was first performed by that orchestra in October.
Kent Nagano led the New York premiere with the Brooklyn Philharmonic the following month, and now Zubin Mehta is conducting the score for the current round of New York Philharmonic subscription concerts at Avery Fisher Hall.


David Bromberg, 61; Served on Judicial Unit
LEAD: David Bromberg, a lawyer who was a member of the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct, an agency that investigates complaints against judges, died of a heart attack Thursday in Grand Central Terminal after a day of hearings at the commission.
He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

California and Connecticut Seek Funds for AIDS Tests
LEAD: Health officials in California and Connecticut are seeking Federal funds for testing newborns for antibodies to the AIDS virus as part of their efforts to track the spread of the infection.


SHULTZ IS CHIDING RUSSIANS OVER IRAN
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz complained today that the Soviet Union was not moving quickly enough toward a Security Council resolution imposing an arms embargo on Iran.


Another Water Main Break
LEAD: Consolidated Edison workers on Broadway between West 84th and 85th Streets after a 90-year-old, 36-inch water main ruptured early yesterday.
Basements were flooded, electricity and telephone service was disrupted and traffic and subways were re-routed.
It was the second major break this week.

ARCO's Britoil Stake
LEAD: Los Angeles-based ARCO, competing with the British Petroleum Company for shares in Britoil P.L.C., said today that it had increased its stake in the North Sea producer to 23.83 percent, from 23.73 percent.
ARCO has said it was seeking to acquire a 49.9 percent holding in Britoil.
On Thursday, Britoil rejected B.P.


Collegiate Swan Song
LEAD: For many of the college stars in the East-Shrine game today in Palo Alto, Calif., their next football game will be in the National Football League.
For Lorenzo White, that's a long way off. ''I've been on the road for the last month,'' said White, the running back who starred for Michigan State in the Rose Bowl victory over Southern California and then went to Japan for an all-star game.

Divestment's Success
LEAD: To the Editor:


Australia Marks Settlement
LEAD: A fleet of tall ships re-enacting the 1788 settlement voyage by convicts from England made landfall today, and celebrations went ahead despite fears of a huge protest by aborigines.
The police said that they had expected about 2,000 aborigines to protest what militants call a celebration of invasion but that only a handful had turned up.


CORRECTION
LEAD: An article on Monday about Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, and his views on political corruption included an incomplete quotation.
Asked whether political corruption was pervasive, he said, '' No, I don't think so,'' and then added: ''I think that where political power remains in somebody's hands for a very long period of time, it's the rare individual who doesn't become personally corrupt.


Producer Prices Post 0.3% Drop
LEAD: Prices at the producer level declined three-tenths of 1 percent in December, reflecting new rounds of automobile rebates and lower oil prices, the Labor Department said today.


Post Office Hours to Be Cut in Austerity Move
LEAD: The United States Postal Service said tonight that post offices around the country would begin to close a half-day a week to absorb budget cuts.

LEAD: The store's unofficial motto is: ''If you're going to Loehmann's, you better not go with someone your size.'' Famous for offering designer women's clothing - sans label - at discount prices and infamous for provoking fights among aggressive bargain hunters, the 80-store chain, a division of May Department Store Companies, plans to open a new outlet in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx in March.

Arthur Greenspan of Beaumont, Tex.

LEAD: IT is not the easiest thing in the world to balance words and movement in a dance character study.

STRIKE PARALYZES THE HAITI CAPITAL ON EVE OF ELECTION
LEAD: On the eve of Haiti's second attempt at presidential elections in seven weeks, a general strike brought the usually teeming capital to a virtual standstill today.


Walking Made Easy With Snowshoes
LEAD: THEY are not numerous, but they are out there, traveling along woodland trails, across meadows and beaches, up and down hillsides and around backyards.
They are the people who fasten frames of ash or aluminum to their feet and go snowshoeing.


Are They Statistics or Guesswork?
LEAD: I DON'T know about anyone else, but I'm very impressed with all the information we get from the Government in Washington.
I'm especially impressed with statistics about the Gross National Product, the percentage of unemployment, the trade deficit, personal income and the like.
Just think about the amount of work it takes to compile those figures and the number of people who must be involved.

LEAD: PETER constantly reminds me that I'm the first line of defense against the forest.
It's been that way since we moved here.

Cuba's Decision to Stay Home Could Be Costly
LEAD: Cuba's decision not to attend the 1988 Seoul Olympics could result in its loss of the 1991 Pan American Games, which were awarded to Havana two years ago.

LEAD: BAGPIPES, ballads and poetry will be in the spotlight Thursday as the South Congregational Church in Hartford celebrates Robert Burns Night.


Zero-Coupon Bonds and the 'Kiddie' Tax
LEAD: Below are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column.


AUGUST WEDDING FOR CAROLE BALIN
LEAD: The engagement of Carole Beth Balin to Michael Eric Gertzman, a son of Dr.
Gloria B. Gertzman and Arthur A. Gertzman of Bridgewater, N.J., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs.
Theodore G. Balin of Andover, Mass.
An August wedding is planned.
Ms.
Balin is a second-year rabbinical student at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion in New York.


GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
LEAD:  HONORS FOR DR. KING


Plea From Nurses: Wages, Wages
LEAD: A NURSE at Waterbury Hospital, Barbara Chavez, said there were three answers to solving the nursing shortage: ''wages, wages and wages.''


Borderline 'Village': Condos
LEAD: The Federal-style apartment building fills the sharply angled southeast corner of Hudson Street and Ninth Avenue.
It is in the West Village, but just barely: Chelsea is across the street.
Still, the building's developer, Alan B. Friedberg, chose to emphasize the geographic distinction and named the 49-unit condominium Village Pointe.


ELIZA WEBB IS AFFIANCED
LEAD: Eliza Ordway Webb and Craig Robert Faulks, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
James L. Faulks of Rocky River, Ohio, plan to marry in May, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs.
William J. Gaynor Webb of New Canaan, Conn., have announced.


A Real Sign of a Bargain Says, 'Made in America'
LEAD: Akami Ueno, who lives near Tokyo, flew across the Pacific and bought a camera with a familiar label: Made in Japan.

MY SIX YEARS ON THE COUCH
LEAD: With regard to Dan Wakefield's article, I am enclosing a poem I wrote some time ago, which I think you will find appropriate.
I told him my anxieties,  Confessed some improprieties,  Revealed a dozen vices too  (Well, at these prices, wouldn't you?)  I thought that he'd have prodded me,  He didn't even nod at me,  He never showed a mild concern,  Yet meekly, weekly, I'd return.


Going to Pieces
LEAD: FINDING SOLUTIONS TO PROBLEMS may be difficult enough these days without someone like Steve Richardson, whose active trade is obfuscation.
He's the owner of Stave Puzzles in Norwich, Vt., an enterprise dedicated to state-of-the-art vexatiousness.
Stave's hand-painted and custom-cut wooden jigsaw puzzles go beyond the ruses that other puzzlemakers have long employed as tools of confusion - monochromatic designs, say, or pieces painted back and front.

NOT THE SAME OLD SHEARLING
LEAD: Shearling coats, which have seen their wearers through some cold times, are getting the chance to do so again this frigid winter.
Simple, honest, rugged - these are the words that come to mind in describing the sturdy and functional shearling.
They still apply to this hardy perrennial, but now some new descriptions can be added to the shearling coat lexicon, such as sophisticated and fashionable.

LEAD: Fred C. Ikle, the Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, said today that he was resigning from the top-level Pentagon post, essentially completing a realignment of senior military officials under the new Secretary of Defense, Frank C. Carlucci.

Men's Style; UNDER COVER
LEAD: EVEN THEIR WIVES DON'T ALWAYS KNOW for sure.
So while some men talk breezily about coloring their hair, most stop short of candor.
One case in point concerns an investment banker, who asked not to be identified.
A man in his 30's, he admits he touched up his gray just before his marriage because, as he put it, ''I didn't want to look like an old fogy in my wedding pictures.

The Real Revelation In Pollock's Floor
LEAD: I fail to see how the uncovering of Jackson Pollock's studio floor reveals evidence of his working process  [ ''Studio Floor Yields a New Look at Polock's Art,'' Dec. 20 ] .
The real revelation coming from Pollock's studio floor is the fact that he was a very messy painter who liked to walk around in wet paint.


Mayor of Newark Proposing 12% Increase in Property Tax
LEAD: Residents face an average property-tax increase of 12 percent this year, most of it attributable to sharply higher costs for garbage disposal, Mayor Sharpe James announced this week.


THE WORLD: With India and Pakistan; U.S. INTEREST IN SOUTH ASIA IS DEEPENING, CAUTIOUSLY
LEAD: A NEW wariness has crept into the relationship between the United States and each of the two South Asian rivals, India and Pakistan, but there is also opportunity for Washington to extend its authority.
Both the wariness and the opportunity are a result of deepening American involvement in an area that often receives less attention than the neighboring Persian Gulf but may be no less critical to Washington's interests.

LEAD: THE WASHINGTON Post was bewailing the reluctance of candidates to mention the dread word taxes. ''They've been Mondaled,'' the editorialist wrote, making a verb out of the name of the last candidate to suggest that a rise in taxes was inevitable, ''you say the T-word and you die.''

LEAD: WHEN RICHARD L. ARMITAGE, an Assistant Secretary of Defense, embarked on a secret mission to Panama two weeks ago, he carried a harsh message.
In a lengthy meeting, he told Gen.
Antonio Manuel Noriega, the de facto leader of the military-controlled regime, to get out of politics within three months so that the country could have a cushion of civilian rule before elections next year.


Photography
LEAD: It sometimes seems that there are two competing schools of contemporary photography.
One, usually called street photography, aspires to capture the textures of life itself.
The other, generally known as art photography, is less literal and more experimental, emphasizing the expressive potentials of the medium.

AIDS ANTIBODIES IN NEW YORK INFANTS
LEAD: EVEN in an epidemic in which grim statistics have become numbingly commonplace, a New York state study on AIDS and newborn infants was shocking: one of every 61 babies born in New York City last month carried antibodies to the virus, indicating that their mothers were infected and that many of the babies were also carriers.

CONNECTICUT GUIDE
LEAD:  'MACBETH'' IN STAMFORD


The Many Visions of Shakespeare's 'Dream'
LEAD: More than most Shakespearean plays, ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' freely lends itself to reinterpretation and transplantation, or - to use the word applied to Bottom - to ''translation.'' Although the play takes place in Athens and the forest beyond, it is an Athens of the mind, and the fairies can be relocated to almost any fictive environment - in contrast to the histories, which, by definition, are so rooted in specificity.


The Grand Canyon's Winter Face
LEAD: I FIRST saw the Grand Canyon by the light of a winter moon.
A handful of the canyon's snow-topped buttes shimmered under its gaze; ethereal and serene, they seemed to float above the darkened canyon floor.
Under a blanket of snow, the Grand Canyon lay mysteriously, almost terrifyingly, still.

LEAD: WALKING THROUGH MILFORD, A NEW England town turned small city turned New York suburb, I think of my parishioners and can't help but feel a little envy.

ETTORE SCOLA SCANS HISTORY THROUGH 'THE FAMILY'
LEAD: IN ''THE FAMILY,'' WHICH opened on Friday at the Cinema Studio, Ettore Scola offers up a two-hour crash course in 80 years of European history, without ever leaving the rambling apartment which is both haven and prison for five generations of a comfortable Roman clan.
Just outside the family's field of vision - and the audience's - World War I rages, Mussolini waxes and wanes, threadbare liberation is followed by a burgeoning postwar boom, post-'68 malaise segues into the uneasy reconciliations of the 1980's.

Civil Rights Demonstrators March in Georgia
LEAD: Hosea Williams, with bullhorn, an Atlanta City Councilman, leading a march yesterday near Atlanta.

Mr.
Williams led the march last year and another a week later with more than 20,000 demonstrators.

Jazz and Fiction
LEAD: To the Editor:


Bringing the Office Home
LEAD: IF there was one hot catch-phrase at this year's show, it was the ''home office.'' By one estimate, there are 13 million proprietors running businesses from their homes, and many of these people have high incomes, making them attractive targets for vendors.


Crash Comparison
LEAD: To the Editor: I have followed with interest the graph you printed each week comparing the crashes of 1929 and 1989.
But to put the post-crash periods in proper perspective, I think it mandatory that you graph the 50 or so trading days before the crashes.
Doing that will allow readers to see longer-term similarities and differences between the two events, and thus help us to evaluate the post-crash period.


MY SIX YEARS ON THE COUCH
LEAD: Let no reader of Dan Wakefield's troubling article be misled into thinking that the decline of ''orthodox'' Freudian analysis has made the couch a safer place.

How One Company Clamped Down on Doctor Bills
LEAD: FOR Jeanne Kardos, director of employee benefits at the Southern New England Telecommunications Company, the numbers were alarming.
Last year, she estimated, her company spent almost $40 million on medical expenses for its employees, up 14 percent in one year and more than double its spending five years ago.

LEAD: It would be unfortunate if Dan Wakefield's experience of ''strict Freudian psychoanalysis'' in the 1950's were considered representative of psychoanalysis today (''My Six Years on the Couch,'' Dec. 20).
That he was not helped despite considerable expenditure of time and money, and that he felt traumatized is obvious from his bitter account.

LEAD: Todd Witsken, the only American remaining in the men's competition of the Australian Open, advanced today to the quarterfinals of the Grand Slam event.

LEAD: A crowd stood on a corner at West 84th Street and Broadway yesterday, gawking at the enormous hole left by an aged water main that broke and spewed thousands of gallons of water onto the streets early Friday morning.

Bogeys Haunt Pate, But He Holds Lead
LEAD: After playing 42 holes over three days with 15 birdies, 27 pars and no bogeys, Steve Pate took a double bogey on his 43d hole, his seventh hole in today's round.
He then took three bogeys on the back nine of LaCosta Country Club's course.
But he also had seven birdies for the round, and that helped him keep the lead he has held from the first day of the 36th annual MONY Tournament of Champions.

NICARAGUA AGREES TO TALK DIRECTLY WITH THE CONTRAS
LEAD: In a last-minute concession after two days of difficult bargaining, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua agreed today to open direct talks with rebel leaders and to suspend a state of emergency in Nicaragua.


THE 'BLACK HOLE' OF MONEY
LEAD: The foreign trade deficit may have shrunk by more than $4 billion in November, as the Commerce Department reported, but statisticians know that raw monthly totals can be off by as much as $2 billion.
They will eventually refine the figures.
For overall world trade statistics, however, a much larger error defies refinement.

LEAD: Like a general marking his victories, Francis T. Vaughan pointed to the map of New York State hanging on the wall of his office in downtown Tokyo.
It was covered with red dots - several clustered on Long Island, two near Elmira, others scattered throughout the state.

LEAD: A 69-year-old woman was killed yesterday evening when fire broke out in her room at the Martha Washington Hotel on the East Side of Manhattan, fire officials said.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.


Stocking Up for the Winter War
LEAD: WHEN I was a little girl, my mother used to tell me about the ration cards she jealously guarded during World War II.
She always stressed how difficult it was to obtain items like nylon stockings and gasoline; that even keeping your larder stocked with butter and sugar presented a formidable challenge.


Why New Issues Usually Disappoint
LEAD: FEW investors who bought new stock offerings from companies in 1987 will look back with pleasure.
The frothy pre-October market enabled Wall Street's underwriters to sell a record volume of initial public offerings - $24.2 billion worth, up 8 percent from a year earlier, according to Going Public, a service that tracks the new-issue market.

LEAD: IT was just a year ago that Yonkers officials were saying they hoped the city's new Kawasaki rail car plant, which was making subway cars for New York and New Jersey, would someday be manufacturing them for railroad and subway systems around the world.


Martha's Vineyard Land Pact Leaves Some Indians Bitter
LEAD: A bitter legal dispute between Indian tribal leaders and the Martha's Vineyard town of Gay Head ended this week with the signing of a final piece of legislation needed under a settlement that allows the tribe to buy some of the land it has long wanted.
But few of the Indians are rejoicing.


117 Secret U.S. Atomic Tests Are Indicated in Seismic Data
LEAD: The United States has concealed at least 117 nuclear explosions at its underground test site in the Nevada desert over the past quarter-century, a group of private scientists reported yesterday.


Packaging an Estate: Seacroft For Sale
LEAD: W. James Oelsner, the mayor of Centre Island from 1975 to 1977, is selling Harbour Point, the Oelsner family's Centre Island estate since 1946.
The 25.4-acre tract, which faces Cold Spring Harbor on the north shore of Long Island, is composed of 12 land parcels assembled over the years around Seacroft, the family's Mediterranean-style mansion.

LEAD: IN the tinkle of Las Vegas slot machines nearly two decades ago, Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder was hurrying out of the Stardust lobby toward double glass doors.
But instead of moving through the door that opened outward, he found himself stumbling against the door that opened inward.


Remembering the Big One of 1888
LEAD: THE mood on Wall Street was glum.
Just 2,000 shares changed hands that Tuesday.
Retail sales took a beating.
The B. Altman store had only one customer all day.
Food prices soared.
Milk went from 2 cents to more than 10 cents a quart within three days.

Of Men and Mice: Witty Toys on View
LEAD: THE MOST COMPREHEN-sive collection of comic-character toys ever exhibited - Mickey Mouse, Popeye, Donald Duck, Little Orphan Annie, Felix the Cat and Betty Boop - will be on view through Saturday at the Alexander Gallery, 996 Madison Avenue (at 77th Street).
The 400 outrageously colorful and boldly graphic windup, push-pull, squeezeable and noisemaking toys were produced mostly between 1920 and 1940.


Q&amp;A
LEAD: Stefan Batory  Question: I understand the Polish Ocean Lines' Stefan Batory is to be retired.
Is there to be a replacement for this wonderful ship, which my family has enjoyed the past three summers? - W. B. R., New Paltz, N.Y.
Answer: Polish Ocean Lines is seeking a more modern ship to replace the Stefan Batory, which is to be taken out of service in March.


He Furnishes Objects To Fit a World Gone Awry
LEAD: RICHARD ARTSCHWAGER'S IS A strange sculptural world, like an ordinary home whose furnishings - the tables and chairs, the windows, the floorboards, the medicine chest, everything - have all gone slightly mad.
His work called ''Handle,'' for instance, is a handsomely crafted piece of polished oak that resembles a length of bannister, but it hangs on the wall and is not a handle to anything.


Oysters From Northern California
LEAD: PREHISTORIC garbage heaps testify that humans have enjoyed oysters for hundreds of thousands of years.
In modern times, Californians had little chance, until relatively recently, to consume local oysters because the Olympia oyster - the only one native to the West Coast - didn't grow large enough to be commercially viable.

LEAD: The six Republican candidates for President clashed sharply in a debate here today over economic policy, taxes and each other's records.


Music: 'Verein Revisited,' By Chamber Ensemble
LEAD: THE New York Chamber Ensemble has undertaken an appealing four-concert series this season at Alice Tully Hall.
Entitled ''Music of the Verein Revisited,'' it offers music once heard on the programs of Arnold Schoenberg's Society for Private Musical Performances in Vienna between 1917 and 1921.


AIDS Panel Recommends No Change in Bias Law
LEAD: A PANEL studying discrimination against AIDS patients has decided against recommending any changes in the law that guards against bias in housing, employment or other fields.


Knicks Roll Past Sixers
LEAD: Rick Pitino, searching for a new way to win, revived an old concept last night: starting Patrick Ewing and Bill Cartwright together on the front line.
It was only the second time this season that the Knick coach had started his two 7-footers together in hopes of controlling the boards and the tempo of the game.

Jesse Jackson holding 8-year old Nick Aldrich on his lap on a visit yesterday to the farm of Terry Hoy, right, in Adel, about 20 miles west of Des Moines.

Outdoors; Books on Fly Fishing Are Flourishing
LEAD: BOOKS dealing with fly fishing have long outnumbered those devoted to any other angling technique.
This tradition shows no sign of weakening even though fly fishermen represent only a small fraction of the angling public.


HIP GRAPHICS
LEAD: Your essay on ''Hip Graphics'' (Works in Progress, Dec. 13), with the images in sequential rotation of the human hip, recalls a similar revolutionary image of the human body 76 years ago -Marcel Duchamp's ''Nude Descending a Staircase, No. 2.'' The painting caused quite a stir at the Armory Show of 1913 in New York, owing to the liberties it took with the human form.


A Wellspring From Poulenc's Song Legacy
LEAD: FOR A DECADE NOW, THE GREAT point of reference for the songs of Francis Poulenc has been the rich edition integrale, lovingly and carefully produced for EMI with Dalton Baldwin (who early in his career was close to Poulenc's artistic circle) at the piano.
The singers are Elly Ameling, Nicolai Gedda, Michel Senechal, William Parker and Gerard Souzay: important talents all.


Classics Won't Just Disappear
LEAD: OUT OF FRUSTRATION WITH A HISTORICAL clock that insists on moving at its own measured pace, some dedicated propagandists for new music come to sound like the generals who insisted that the only way to save Vietnamese villages was to bomb them out of existence.
Only by ruthlessly dismantling the repertory built up over previous centuries, it is suggested, can room be made for the 20th century's own candidates for survival.

Sherwin attempts to show how the world lost its chance to avoid the arms race by bringing nuclear weapons under international control.

A Crew Leader
LEAD: WHILE Horace Davenport was growing up in not very prosperous circumstances in Brooklyn in the 1920's, he went to Columbia, where he went out for sports teams - football, swimming and crew -so he could eat.
In that era, the training table for the athletes featured steaks and was a standard accoutrement of intercollegiate athletics.

LEAD: OPPONENTS of a proposed natural gas pipeline are hailing the elimination of a 42-mile east-west spur that would have cut through 10 towns in Connecticut.

First Town Houses: Strangers In Town
LEAD: The first town-house development in Palisades Park, N.J., is under construction at the corner of Grand Avenue and Roosevelt Place.
Upon completion next fall, the six buildings of the 26-unit complex will join the area's mostly one-family homes and garden apartments.
The $4 million project's first building, with three units, will be ready for occupancy next month, said the developer, Alfred Haber.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. We recently installed a brass-framed glass door over the opening to our brick fireplace.
Because the brass frame is very straight and the brick against which it fits is rough and bumpy, there are gaps where smoke seeps out into the room.
We stuffed small strips of fiberglass insulation into these cracks, but some smoke still gets through and bits of fiberglass keep falling out.


Correction
LEAD: An article by The Associated Press last Sunday about United Press International misstated the number of people dismissed from U.P.I. in the last two months.
Christopher Smith, a U.P.I. spokesman, said that while as many as 100 employees had left the news agency in the period, only 33 were laid off.


Teams Find It's Better to Receive
LEAD: FOR three seasons, Anthony Carter felt more like a status symbol than an integral part of the Minnesota Vikings' offense.
He was the family heirloom that the Vikings were reluctant to remove from its display case.
Whether a wide receiver relies on speed or moves, or both, he must be elusive.
And here was Carter, sensing constraints, as if he were running his pass patterns in a ball and chain.

LEAD: Drug trafficking is again emerging as a source of tension between the United States and Mexico, after an interlude of nearly a year in which both sides played down their differences on what each should be doing to combat it.

TAMARA AND TAMARA AND TAMARA . . .
LEAD: In ''Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead,'' Tom Stoppard gave audiences a chance to see the tragedy of ''Hamlet'' through the eyes of its bewildered bit players.
In ''Tamara,'' the playwright John Krizanc makes bit players of the members of the audience, who trail after 10 characters through action set in the sprawling estate of the Italian poet Gabriele d'Annunzio.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. We recently installed a brass-framed glass door over the opening to our brick fireplace.
Because the brass frame is very straight and the brick against which it fits is rough and bumpy, there are gaps where smoke seeps out into the room.
We stuffed small strips of fiberglass insulation into these cracks, but some smoke still gets through and bits of fiberglass keep falling out.

Corrections
LEAD: A Travel Advisory report on Dec. 27 about Hertz rental cars omitted mention of some national car-rental companies that hold renters responsible not only for collision damage but also for vandalism, theft and other loss of the car.
Besides Value Rent-a-Car and Hertz, they are Alamo and Thrifty.
In some copies, the headline characterized Hertz's new policy inaccurately.

Clipper Sinks at Boston Pier
LEAD: A 144-foot clipper believed to the nation's last working square rigger of her size sank Thursday night while docked for maintenance work, officials said Friday.
The 80-year-old Regina Maris was undergoing routine maintenance at the Boston Marine Works when she sank in about 30 feet of water, said Dusty Rhodes, a spokeswoman for Quincy's Marina Bay, where the vessel was usually docked.


Sunday Observer; Polls Apart
LEAD: THOUSANDS OF POLL fans, learning of my retirement, beg me to publish my memoirs of the early days of polling.


LOOKING BACK AT 'LOOKING BACKWARD': WE HAVE SEEN THE FUTURE AND IT DIDN'T WORK
LEAD: NEAR the end of the last century Edward Bellamy wrote ''Looking Backward'' - a ''fanciful romance,'' as he called it - in which he risked daring predictions about life at the end of our own century.
We are still reading his durable classic, but time has revealed to us what it hid from him: the appalling implications of his prophecies.


Paris
LEAD: To the Editor: Having recently returned from a week in Paris, we have been telling friends about our tour of the catacombs, which was not unlike that described in Frederick Turner's article ''The Worlds Beneath Paris'' (Travel, Oct. 25).
