After 20 Years of Infighting, the Democrats Grow Closer
LEAD: BEFORE the Democratic candidates for President gathered in debate here last week, people figured they knew what would be said about the deficit and arms control and welfare reform.
What people were wondering was, would any one in the pack go after Gary Hart on the character issue?


IN TV AT THE MOMENT, 'DIGITAL' MAY NOT ADD UP
LEAD: WHAT SNAKE OIL was to folk medicine in the last century, the word ''digital'' is to home electronics in our era.
Like the reptilian elixir, or traditional incantations of ''abracadabra,'' that word is deemed to possess miraculous powers.
Anything to which the term digital can be attached is supposed to be either perfect already or getting there fast.


Corrosion of Bridge's Cable Is Called Limited
LEAD: Engineers and transportation officials, seeking to determine the future of the aging Williamsburg Bridge, uncovered the bridge's most corroded cable yesterday and pronounced it not as badly damaged as they had feared.

LEAD: IT WOULDN'T BE SURPRISING if future pop historians, looking back on 1987, expressed more interest in the accelerating popularity of George Gershwin than in Michael Jackson's changing physiognomy or Bruce Springsteen's romantic maturation.


U.N. Aide in Middle as Israelis Shoot
LEAD: A senior United Nations official, sent to investigate conditions in Palestinian refugee districts, was caught up in a hail of rubber bullets and tear gas today as the Israeli Army chased youthful protesters.

The Buck Stops
LEAD: Over the last two years a 23-year-old New York investor named David Bloom collected $10 million from 100 friends and associates to play the stock market.
But last week authorities charged that Mr.
Bloom's favorite investment was himself.
They said he spent most of the money on such things as an art collection, a beach house, a condo, an Aston Martin and contributions to Duke University, his alma mater.


Army Is Trying to Save Half Of Plan for New Helicopters
LEAD: The Army has asked Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci to authorize continued development of a new tactical helicopter in exchange for delaying similar work on a model for transporting troops, Pentagon sources say.


Taxes and Outlays: Scenario in Works
LEAD: GOVERNOR KEAN touched nearly all the bases in his State of the State address last week, but omitted tax and spending reforms, probably because the working script for those items is being written by others.


Fire at Russian Palace
LEAD: A fire broke out in the 18th century Yekaterinsky Palace on Friday night, slightly damaging its gilded throne hall, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today.
The palace in the town of Pushkin, near Leningrad, is considered one of the finest examples of Russian Baroque architecture.

LEAD: ''EACH man has his own design for wedded bliss.'' So says Arnolphe, a would-be husband determined not to be duped, in ''The School for Wives'' at the Whole Theatre.

LEAD: BY next weekend, the concert calendar will have returned to its busy preholiday pace, and choices will have to be made from among orchestral concerts, chamber recitals or folk music.

Fashion; SUIT SEARCHING
LEAD: IT'S THE JACKET THAT MAKES THE SALE.
THE moment a woman slips into the top half of a suit, she sees herself taking on a new shape.
This season, her shoulders are still jaunty, though more rounded than squared.
The seaming makes her look at once thinner and curvier.
The elongated lapels or lower openings suggest that her neck is admirably longer.


Taiwan Imprisons 2 Backing Independence
LEAD: A Taiwanese court today imposed long prison terms on two dissidents who were convicted of sedition for advocating Taiwan's independence from China.


Nurse and Teacher Licensing Under Fire
LEAD: THE rush to fill vacant nursing and teaching positions is resulting in what critics contend are policies and proposals that will lower the licensing standards for people entering the fields.


Lakshmi Jha, Indian Economist And Former Envoy, Is Dead at 74
LEAD: Lakshmi Kant Jha, one of India's most distinguished economists and an architect of the country's recent economic liberalization, died of kidney failure today.
He was 74 years old.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. We recently installed a brass-framed glass door over the opening to our brick fireplace.
Because the brass frame is very straight and the brick against which it fits is rough and bumpy, there are gaps where smoke seeps out into the room.
We stuffed small strips of fiberglass insulation into these cracks, but some smoke still gets through and bits of fiberglass keep falling out.

David Cruz of Great Neck, L.I.

A FEW OF THE SEASONAL PROJECTS
LEAD: STUDY seed and nursery catalogues and place orders promptly to be sure of getting first choices.
Stock bird feeders daily.
Bring in a pot of hardy bulbs from the coldframe, water gradually and place in sunlight to force flowers.
Study pruning manuals to brush up on methods for trimming back grapevines, fruit trees and other dormant plants, weather permitting.

Canadian Team Wins
LEAD: The United States Olympic hockey team, testing itself against tougher competition after an idyllic schedule in which it routed collegiate squads, today lost its second consecutive game to Canada's Olympic team.
Sean Burke of Canada made 50 saves in a 5-1 Canadian victory at the Joe Louis Arena.


Census Count: 42 Eagles
LEAD: The annual census of bald and golden eagles has counted 36 birds in the Quabbin Reservoir so far and at least six others elsewhere in the state, according to Massachusetts wildlife officials.
Bird counters said this week that this year's total was slightly below those of the past two winters, when more than 50 birds were counted.

LEAD: The revenues of the Atlantic City casino industry continued to grow about 10 percent last year, despite the addition of a 12th casino to a market limited by a lack of scheduled air service.

429 THOUGHTS ON WHAT CAN FILL THE SPACE OF WESTWAY
LEAD: THE New York real estate market, perhaps even more than nature, abhors a vacuum, and one of the biggest vacuums in the city is the 4.2-mile stretch of Hudson River waterfront between 44th Street and Battery Park City.
Though last August Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch announced their support of a roadway and esplanade, which will succeed the Westway proposal defeated in 1985, no comprehensive plan exists for the adjoining ragged edge of water, piers and land amassed during the Westway years.

What Is a Wife? A Mix of Peccadilloes and Passions
LEAD: JUST beyond the senior prom and the soft-spoken words ''I will'' is a wonderful creature called a wife.
Joke all you want about them, wives are the best things that happen to men.
They come in all heights and weights, with straight or wavy hair, with green or blue or brown eyes, with freckles and without, but somehow the one you have is the nicest combination of all.

A Tax Worry Adds To Texaco's Burdens
LEAD: Texaco might face a $6.5 billion bill for back taxes relating to the pricing of Saudi Arabian oil from 1979 to 1981.
The Internal Revenue Service would not comment, but Texaco said it was possible such a claim would be filed in the company's bankruptcy proceedings.
Texaco's effort to get out of bankruptcy was already facing enormous expenses, principally a $3 billion payment to Pennzoil to settle their celebrated legal dispute.

Dance
LEAD: The poetic and the rowdy will be celebrated at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street) this week when Jazzdance: The Danny Buraczeski Dance Company performs in a program of new and recent work.
Over the past decade, Mr.
Buraczeski has set himself the task of exploring and mining jazz dance, and he has stretched the boundaries of that seemingly limited form of dance with contagious wonder and good cheer.


Mondrian on the Path to the Abstract
LEAD: IT IS UNUSUAL FOR A DEALER TO put together an exhibition on a modern master that seems indispensable.
Yet Sidney Janis has done just that.
The 44 paintings, drawings and gouaches at the Sidney Janis gallery through Feb. 13 focus on the early figurative work and the ideas and feelings that Piet Mondrian wanted to distill and synthesize in his abstraction.

80's Movies Take the Easy Route
LEAD: LIKE SO MANY FILMS OF THE 1980'S, THE GOLDIE Hawn comedy ''Overboard'' offers something for everyone.
To begin with, it presents the amusing spectacle of Miss Hawn impersonating a viciously bad-tempered heiress, striking terror into everyone she meets.
After this satirical high-life phase, the film moves into its low-rent period, with an amnesiac Miss Hawn trapped in the squalid home of a carpenter (played by Kurt Russell), who intends to teach her a lesson.

Harry, the hapless customer, walks up to the counter and asks for a roll of film. ''What kind?'' the clerk queries. ''I dunno, the kind that makes color prints,'' Harry replies, acting as if he's on an errand for his wife.


A Widow Reflects on Her Difficult Adjustment to a New Life
LEAD: TWO years have gone by since my husband died, and I have just realized that I no longer wince when I refer to myself as a widow.
Looking back now, I see there have been other changes in my feelings during my difficult adjustment to a new life.
I've experienced shock, anger, grief, depression, guilt, doubt, pain, regrets and loneliness.

ITALY DEBATES ITS 45 YEARS OF AVERSION TO FASCISM
LEAD: SINCE Mussolini's fall in 1943, anti-Fascism has been a national creed in Italy, extolled, institutionalized and politically manipulated.
Only recently has anyone argued that it is obsolete.
The debate has raged since Italy's most prominent historian of the Fascist period, Prof.
Renzo De Felice, said in a newspaper interview last month that ''the great alternative'' between Fascism and anti-Fascism ''no longer makes any sense either in the public conscience or in the reality of everyday political struggles.

FOREIGN MONEY, U.S. FEARS
LEAD: Isn't progress wonderful (''Foreign Money, U.S. Fears,'' by Martin and Susan Tolchin, Dec. 13)?
In just a little over 200 years we have progressed from being a colony whose economic and political life was governed from across the ocean, to an expanding free nation, to the world's greatest political and economic power and the world's largest creditor nation, and, in the last six Reagan years, to being the world's largest debtor nation, with an economy increasingly owned and controlled by foreign investors from across two oceans.

Tornado Toll at 59 in 1987
LEAD: Tornado deaths rose to 59 in the United States last year, nearly quadruple the toll of a year earlier, the National Weather Service says.
While tornado-related deaths rebounded from the record low of 15 posted in 1986, last year's total still fell short of the long-term average of 90 fatalities, the agency said Thursday.

LEAD: Martha Graham, the 93-year-old modern-dance choreographer, is in the hospital to undergo tests, according to Ron Protas, associate director of the Martha Graham Dance Company.
Mr.
Protas said last night that Miss Graham had experienced dizziness in the afternoon and that they had made the decision together for her to enter the hospital.

LEAD: Steve Pate became the winner of the 36th MONY Tournament of Champions today when a Pacific storm with 40-mile-an-hour winds and heavy rains washed out the final round of the year's first PGA Tour event.

LEAD: It is cold, very cold and the pond is frozen solid.
The neighborhood children push aside the snow, someone builds a fire and soon the ice is covered with skaters gliding to and fro, their faces reddened from the cold and exertion.

Water System: The Marvelous Monster
LEAD: It is a vast subterranean network, a whooshing, gurgling 6,000-mile iron snake under the streets of New York City, and it is unseen and largely ignored until it erupts like a monster, flooding basements, streets, subways and utility lines as it did twice last week.


TV Reviews; DRAMA OF COLLEGE FOOTBALL, ON ABC
LEAD: ''WHAT PRICE VICTORY'' has no question mark; it has no story, either.
Mostly it has cliches: big-time college football has no soul; it chews up and spits out good old country boys.
Actually, this makes the two-hour movie, on ABC at 9 o'clock tonight, sound more interesting than it is.
Cliches can work fine, but in this movie they are particularly barren.


Pacific Gas Ends Offer
LEAD: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company said it was withdrawing its proposal to consolidate its gas service in the Sacramento, Calif., area with the electricity operations of the Sacramento Municipal Utility District.
P.G.&amp;E., which had proposed in September to take over the struggling utility and scrap its nonfunctioning nuclear power plant, said it was dropping the offer because of the Sacramento utility's failure to give it serious consideration.


City Ballet to Honor American Composers
LEAD: The New York City Ballet will celebrate the music of American composers with its American Music Festival at the New York State Theater.
The festival, which features such guest artists as Ray Charles, begins April 26 with a gala opening of the company's spring season, and continues through May 15.
Over 35 ballets are scheduled, 19 of them world premieres.


When a Tie Vote Means Death
LEAD: While the Supreme Court awaits a ninth justice,tie votes of 4-to-4 have blocked decisions in some instances.
But not when the Court grinds out orders that send condemned prisoners to the executioner.
An anomaly in the Court's rules, coupled with the determination of four justices to get on with executions, is producing death decrees from a deadlocked tribunal.

LEAD: Browsers crowding a table yesterday at an outdoor flea market at the Avenue of the Americas and 26th Street as the temperature soared to 44 degrees.
Today should be even warmer, with a high of about 46, but periods of rain are expected. (NYT/Dith Pran)

Rock: Big Dipper, Dumptruck and Subtle Plague
LEAD: BIG DIPPER and Dumptruck, two big attactions on the college rock circuit, brought a near-overdose level of earnestness to CBGB Saturday night.
Both groups are from the Boston area, and they both present rock as anti-spectacle.
Band members wear the same T-shirts and jeans offstage as they do on, both groups stand there, calmly delivering their songs with the idea that the words take priority over entertainment - rock as literature.


Israeli Inflation Eases
LEAD: Israel's consumer price index rose 16.1 percent in 1987, the lowest annual inflation rate in 15 years, the Central Bureau of Statistics announced Friday.
The improvement reflected a sweeping austerity program begun in July 1985.
It included a freeze on prices and wages and helped to reduce inflation from a record 444.9 percent in 1984 to 19.7 percent in 1986.

LEAD: MODESTY and lack of assumption are virtues that seem increasingly rare in the theater these days.

Ms.
De Vito, a noted Manhattan jazz-dance teacher, seemed to be aiming for simplicity, freshness and an entertaining and even inventive evening of jazz dance performed by a well-rehearsed company of strong and personable dancers.

Subtle Steps to a Better Grip on the Game
LEAD: THE names of the basic tennis strokes, forehand and backhand, should tell you something about the role of your hands in shot-making.
The adage is that the racquet should feel like an extension of your hand.
You should meet the ball on the forehand side as if you were striking it with your open palm, and on the backhand side as if you were hitting it with the back of your hand.

Wife to two great kings, mother of Richard the Lionhearted, possessor of enormous political and cultural influence in both France and England, she accompanied the French King Louis on the 12th century's Second Crusade and survived 16 years of imprisonment to become the power behind the throne of her legendary son and


Ms. Goldberg, Writer, Is Wed to Stuart Lewis
LEAD: The marriage of Judith Goldberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Ralph Goldberg of New York, to Stuart Lewis, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Philip Lewis of Blauvelt, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Hotel Inter-Continental in New York.
Rabbi Martin Zion officiated.


Ballet Stars Join in Brussels AIDS Benefit
LEAD: Twenty-five international ballet stars, including current Soviet dancers and an expatriate, joined here today in an AIDS gala benefit.

Market Place; The Strategies Of Top Managers
LEAD: THE nation's top-ranking investment advisers of 1987 began raising cash well before the stock market collapsed on Oct. 19.
But, unlike many other money managers, they also had the fortitude to jump back into the market on the heels of the record 508-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average.


'St. Elsewhere,' on NBC, to Cease Production
LEAD: ''St.
Elsewhere,'' NBC's award-winning medical drama, is to cease production in March and its crew is to move to a new series, although NBC is still discussing ways to keep the show alive, officials said today.


Building on a Legacy in Taiwan
LEAD: A dynasty ended in Taiwan when President Chiang Ching-kuo died last week, but change had already begun.
While faithful to the myths of Chiang Kai-shek's rule, the generalissimo's son was a realist who had recently set course toward liberalization and democracy.
The challenge to Taiwan's new president is to keep that course, tackle economic problems and yet not upset the delicate balance that maintains calm in the Formosa


Nets and 76ers Analyze Trade
LEAD: With 4 minutes 17 seconds remaining in Saturday night's game against the Boston Celtics at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, Mike Gminski hit a 13-foot jumper over Dennis Johnson that tied the score at 91-91 - it was to be the 6-foot-11-inch center's last basket as a Net.


DEALS PROPEL SPACE STATION MAKER
LEAD: If any company has positioned itself well for the commercialization of space, it is Space Industries.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about Morris Giloni, a stockbroker and board member of the Jewish National Fund of America, described the fund incorrectly.
It represents not only the Herut Zionists but other Jewish groups as well.


Frank V. Schwinn, 67, Bicycle Company Chief
LEAD: Frank V. Schwinn, who developed the independent dealership network for his family's bicycle company, died unexpectedly at home last Tuesday.
He was 67 years old.


Games Banks Play With Home Equity Loans
LEAD: To the Editor:


Church Attack Leads to a Dissident's House
LEAD: An explosion ripped through a Mormon church Saturday.
Hours later law-enforcement officers surrounded the house of a woman whose husband had feuded with the Mormon leadership before he was shot to death by the police nine years ago.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Choice for Ambassador
LEAD: The next American Ambassador to East Germany will be Richard C. Barkley, according to State Department insiders.


Council Leaders Draft a Compromise Bill on Campaign Financing
LEAD: After weeks of negotiations, the leadership of the New York City Council has crafted a compromise bill on the Koch administration's proposal for public financing of municipal election campaigns and says it has the votes to pass the measure.


City Ballet's 'Matinee'
LEAD: The New York City Ballet will present its annual ''Family Matinee'' on Jan. 31 at 1 P.M. at the New York State Theater.
The company will perform ''Symphony in C'' and ''The Four Temperaments,'' both by George Balanchine, and ''Brahms/ Handel,'' a collaboration by Jerome Robbins and Twyla Tharp.
During intermissions, company members will be on hand to answer questions and demonstrate such activities as the preparation of toe shoes, pre-performance warm-ups and applying stage makeup.


Hart Finds You Can Go Home Again
LEAD: Some of Gary Hart's old friends did not turn out to see him this weekend when he came back to his hometown.


BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 18, 1988
LEAD:  The Economy


Independent Taiwan: Risky Idea May Be Gaining
LEAD: As Tsai Yo-chuan and Hsu Tsao-teh saw it, all they had done was to exercise free speech when they organized a political group with a charter calling for Taiwan's independence from China.
But to the Government, what they did constituted an act of sedition, and this weekend Mr.
Tsai and Mr.
Hsu were sentenced to up to 11 years in prison.


GOVERNMENT LAGS ON PHONE CHANGES
LEAD: A $25 billion plan to overhaul the Government's outdated telephone system has fallen almost a year behind schedule and could experience substantial additional delays because of a bidding dispute that has led to several criminal investigations.


Mexican Candidate Ties Repayment Of Foreign Debt to Economic Growth
LEAD: In an interview here today, the man almost certain to become Mexico's President later this year said repayment of his country's $105 billion foreign debt must be linked to the achievement of ''sustainable economic growth'' and urged the United States to seek a more ''dignified'' and realistic relationship with Mexico.


The U.N. Today; Security Council
LEAD:  Meets on southern Lebanon at 11:30 A.M.
Economic and Social Council  COMMISSION ON INTERGOVERNMENTAL STRUCTURE AND FUNCTIONS IN ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL FIELDS - 10 A.M.


In Philosophy's Turf Wars, They Hurl Syllogisms; Journey of the Mind
LEAD: To the Editor:


Shevardnadze in Bonn; He Hails 'New Era'
LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, arrived in Bonn today for a three-day visit, the first by a senior Soviet official under Mikhail S. Gorbachev.


Being There
LEAD: For some firefighters in Engine Company No. 45 on Tremont Avenue in the Bronx, the daily routine provides enough excitement.
The firehouse has been among the busiest in the city for years.


Artificial Heart Patient, 60
LEAD: Walton Jones, the oldest person ever given a temporary artificial heart, died today of an infection, doctors said.
He was 60 years old.
Mr.
Jones' heart was replaced by the Jarvik-7 pump on Dec. 4 by Dr.
William DeVries, the surgeon who has done four of the five permanent mechanical heart operations.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Diplomatic Gaffe
LEAD: A playbill issued by the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts contains a passage that conflicts with the frequently-declared policy toward Yugoslavia of the center's sponsor, the United States Government.


Companies Match Worker Donations to Give Lift to Neediest
LEAD: Donald G. Fiordelisi of Princeton, N.J., contributed $100 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in honor of his father, Peter, who died on Thanksgiving Day.


Hanoi Seeks New Image, U.S. Lawmakers Report
LEAD: A Congressional delegation has returned from Vietnam convinced that Hanoi is embarking on a campaign to regain some of the international understanding it lost by invading and occupying Cambodia nine years ago.


Rail System Plan Backed by Houston Voters
LEAD: Voters here approved a $2.57 billion transit improvement program Saturday that includes a 20-mile rail system to connect downtown with other business areas.


Governor of Arizona to Face Impeachment Hearings Soon
LEAD: The Arizona House will begin impeachment hearings this week against Gov.
Evan Mecham, the House Speaker said today.


Bias Lawsuit May Have Wide Impact
LEAD: When Clara Watson dropped by Fort Worth Bank and Trust in 1973 to pick up an application for a job as a teller, she said, the chilly reception almost ended her dream of working at the bank.


Slowdown In Housing Expected
LEAD: After four years of robust demand that kept construction of new homes at annual levels of more than 1.7 million units, the housing industry has entered a slower period that is likely to extend into the mid-1990's.


Promotions At Times Co.
LEAD: Arthur M. Hettich, editor in chief of Family Circle magazine, has been named senior vice president, magazine development, of The New York Times Company Magazine Group.


In Iowa, Tarnish on Reagan Rubs Off on Bush
LEAD: Bill Southwick is George Bush's nightmare.


Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a sen-tence in an article by Kosta Tsipis on Jan. 11 implied that canceling further production of the MX missile and the Trident submarine would save $2 bil-lion.
It should have said ''as much as $2 billion per submarine.''


Dr. King Is Honored at Riverside Church
LEAD: The Rev.
Calvin O. Butts 3d, executive minister of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, delivering his sermon yesterday at Riverside Church during a service honoring the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)


More Gains Foreseen for Bonds
LEAD: Long-simmering hopes that interest rates will decline boiled over Friday after Government statistics showed a large drop in the nation's trade deficit and lower-than-expected inflation.


1988: The Process
LEAD:  Efforts to improve how America elects a President have had unexpected side effects such as Michigan's confusing caucus process.
First article of a series, page A12.
Mexican Debt Condition  The man almost certain to be Mexico's next President said foreign debt repayments must be linked to ''sustainable economic growth.


Dollar Jumps In Tokyo
LEAD: The dollar rose sharply in trading in Tokyo this morning, on the heels of an improvement in United States trade figures announced Friday.
Stock prices also rallied, traders said.


Neoax Raises Offer for IU
LEAD: Neoax Inc. said yesterday that it had increased its tender offer for the IU Corporation by $1.50 a share, to $19, or about $589 million.


Thief Must Pay Aged Victim
LEAD: A circuit judge has ordered a 17-year-old robber to pay $100 a month for the next five years to a 102-year-old man he attacked outside a grocery store.
Judge Frank Eppes issued the order to Darrel Burrel in sentencing him to 10 years in prison, suspended to probation for five years.


India's Clandestine Market in Gold
LEAD: It is the wedding season in this wealthy and powerful city - as in many other parts of India -and ballrooms and community centers are booked for months.


Washington Talk: Congress; . . . as Tiny U.S. Agency Takes on Japan Bashers
LEAD: While some legislators and others in the Government vilify Japan over economic issues, one tiny Federal agency struggles on to bring the two countries closer together.


Social Security Issue Stirs Debate
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson, left, talking with Senator Albert Gore Jr. before the Democratic Presidential candidates appeared on ABC News's ''This Week.''


Venezuela's Oil Dealings Abroad
LEAD: After Venezuela nationalized 14 American and other foreign oil companies in 1976, it came to recognize that much of the industry - the business of refining and marketing oil abroad - was in fact still in foreign hands.


Cross-Ownership Rule Driving Newspapers Out of Business
LEAD: To the Editor:


Bank of America Fined
LEAD: The Commerce Department said Friday that it had fined the Bank of America $220,000 for 22 purported violations of blacklist laws.
The Commerce Department said the bank had paid an American beneficiary based on a letter of credit that required him to refuse to do business with certain blacklisted nations.


Super Teams: Denver and Washington
LEAD: Ricky Nattiel of the Broncos after scoring during Denver's 38-33 victory over the Browns.
At right, the Vikings' Wade Wilson being sacked by Dave Butz and Dexter Manley (72) of the Redskins.
Washington won, 17-10.
Super Bowl is Jan. 31.
SportsMonday, page C1. (AP)


Denver Defense Rewrites the Script
LEAD: The Cleveland Browns were going to score.
The orange-clad fans stacked to the top of Mile High Stadium were going to have to endure an overtime period with a spot in the Super Bowl resting on the outcome.
The script said so, and the Denver Broncos thought so.


High Stakes In Nicaragua
LEAD: The Nicaraguan Government's last-minute offer Saturday to suspend its state of emergency and begin direct talks with the rebels opens a volatile period of political maneuvering, with high stakes that could determine the future course of not only the Sandinista revolution but also of Central America.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Just an 'Intimate' Party
LEAD: Several weeks ago, the finance chairmen of the Democratic National Committee sent out invitations to a $500-per-person ''intimate birthday dinner'' honoring Paul G. Kirk Jr., the national chairman, on Jan. 20, two days after his official 50th birthday.


A New Effort In Securities Fraud Cases
LEAD: Concerned that insider trading and other crimes are going unpunished, the Justice Department and several regulatory agencies are planning a task force that will seek out securities fraud cases across the country, concentrating on several large cities outside New York.


Rock: The Music of the 60's From the Dinosaurs
LEAD: PSYCHEDELIC-ERA nostalgia arrived Friday when the Dinosaurs, a group of San Francisco rockers with a 1960's pedigree, headlined an evening of music, lights and reminiscences.
It was the first Psychedelic Daze Revue at the Saint, the discotheque that replaced the Fillmore East Auditorium at 105 Second Avenue, at Sixth Street; the next revue, with the Chambers Brothers, is scheduled for Jan.


Coliseum as Shelter
LEAD: To the Editor:


Argentine Troops Move on Rebel Soldiers at Base
LEAD: Troops loyal to the civilian Government encircled a northern army compound today after a rebel officer and about 100 sympathizers had seized control of the compound's regimental headquarters.


Business and the Law; Expectations In Cigarette Case
LEAD: HALFWAY through a trial in Lexington, Miss., lawyers representing the survivors of a cigarette smoker are convinced that they have made the strongest case yet against the tobacco industry.


AN 'ANGEL' SAVES ROCKET DEVELOPER
LEAD: The American Rocket Company has always been a fun kind of place.

Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption in some editions on Jan. 7 about a hockey game between the Rangers and the Canucks misidentified the Rangers' defenseman.
He was David Shaw.


Painting Brings $6.6 Million
LEAD: Jan Davidsz de Heem's depiction of a banquet table from 1642 - the largest and most lavish still life ever painted by this artist - brought $6.6 million Friday in a sale at Christie's.
The price was the highest ever paid at auction in the United States for an Old Master painting.
The previous record was set Thursday at Sotheby's, with the sale of another


The Lie That Wasn't Shot Down
LEAD: On Aug. 31, 1983, the Soviet Union shot down a Boeing 747 with the loss of 269 lives, having failed to identify it as a civilian airliner.
Moscow deserved the universal obloquy it incurred.
But the Reagan Administration added a savage twist, sometimes implying and sometimes saying outright that the Soviet Union knew it was attacking a civilian plane.


Dance: Carol Fonda's 'Pieces of Glass'
LEAD: THE scenery dances along with the human performers in Carol Fonda's ''Pieces of Glass,'' thereby creating much of the magic of the two-act work that Carol Fonda and Company presented Friday night at the Triplex Theater of Borough of Manhattan Community College.


Pretoria's Frozen Debt
LEAD: South Africa said Friday that foreign creditors who were owed $13 billion in frozen debt could use the money to buy equity or property in the country.
Pretoria froze repayments of the debt in 1985 after foreign banks, worried by anti-Government actions, cut credit lines.


At Pan Am, Tensions Beneath a Surface Calm
LEAD: On the surface, the daily routine at the Manhattan headquarters of the Pan Am Corporation looks like business as usual.


Mixed View of G.M. Sales
LEAD: Officials of the General Motors Corporation's Pontiac, Buick and Oldsmobile divisions gave a mixed view Friday of auto sales for 1988.


ISRAELIS MAINTAIN WIDE ARAB CURFEW
LEAD: The Israeli Army kept more than 250,000 Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip sealed up in their refugee centers today in what is emerging as the Government's major tactic against the rioting in which at least 38 Palestinians have been shot dead.


Greta Bernard Is Married To R.S. Brown in Michigan
LEAD: Greta Bernard, a rabbinical student at the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York, and Robert S. Brown, a student at the New York University School of Law, were married yesterday at Congregation Beth Shalom in Southfield, Mich.
Rabbis Robert Abramson and Robert Nelson officiated.


New Zealand Inflation
LEAD: New Zealand's inflation rate has dropped below 10 percent for the first time in more than 14 years, according to figures released today by the Government.
The consumer price index rose 9.6 percent in 1987, down from 18.2 percent in 1986.
The annual rate was slightly lower than that forecast by the Labor Party Government.


Guinness Fights Ruling
LEAD: Guinness P.L.C. today challenged a ruling by the British Takeover Panel that the brewer acted unfairly during its acquisition of the Distillers Company.


TUESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1988   ; International
LEAD: Investment and growth have contracted in debtor countries since the global debt crisis began in 1982, and living standards have slumped badly, the World Bank said.
Prospects for any near-term improvements are bleak, the bank said in a report that is the most pessimistic it has ever issued on the debt crisis.

Retirement Set At Federated
LEAD: Donald J. Stone will retire Jan. 31 as a vice chairman of Federated Department Stores Inc. and will be succeeded by Allen I. Questrom, chairman of the company's Bullock's division in Los Angeles and a corporate executive vice president, Federated announced.


Music: Shostakovich 14th
LEAD: THE 14th Symphony of Dmitri Shostakovich, played at the 92d Street Y Sunday afternoon by the New York Chamber Symphony under the composer's son, Maxim, is a cycle of 11 songs on the subject of death.
The texts are by Lorca, Apollinaire, Kuchelbecher and Rilke, set for soprano and bass soloists.
It is an important, difficult work, and any performance of it is a significant event.

CRIME DATA SHOW LOW JAILING RATE
LEAD: Barely one-third of the people arrested on felony charges in 11 states went to jail, and only a third of those convicted of violent crimes were sentenced to more than a year, a Justice Department survey found.

Digital Repurchase

Mark Michtom, Toy Executive, 59
LEAD: Mark Michtom, a former executive of the Ideal Toy Company, died of bladder cancer Saturday at St.
Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center.
He was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Andrija Artukovic, 88, Nazi Ally Deported to Yugoslavia, Is Dead
LEAD: Andrija Artukovic, a former leader of the Nazi puppet state of Croatia who was extradited from the United States to Yugoslavia, died Saturday in a prison hospital in Zagreb, where he had been condemned to death for mass murder, the Yugoslav press agency announced yesterday.
He was 88 years old and had won a stay of execution on the ground of poor health.

LEAD: China's General Internal Combustion Engine Factory in Beijing has agreed to buy a second-hand assembly line from the General Motors Corporation for $16.5 million, the official New China News Agency said today.
The engine-making line, which was closed in 1984 after two years of operation, is to start running in Beijing in 1990.

Filipinos Vote in Local Elections
LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino voting at her family's estate yesterday in Tarlac.
About 80 percent of the nation's 27 million voters took part in the balloting for 16,000 provincial and local posts.
A gubernatorial candidate, Roy Padilla, was murdered hours before the polls opened and a campaign worker was killed during the voting which followed a violent campaign in which 87 people were reported killed.


108 Killed as Turboprop Plane Crashes in China
LEAD: A domestic airliner crashed in southwestern China, killing all 108 people aboard, the official New China News Agency reported today.

Harvard Names Head Of Renaissance Center
LEAD: A Harvard professor of English and comparative literature has been appointed director of the university's Center for Italian Renaissance Studies in Florence, Italy.


Rabin Vows to Quell Palestinian Unrest
LEAD: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that the disturbances in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip were the most difficult and widespread that Israel had yet faced, but he vowed to bring the unrest to a ''manageable'' level.


Sports People; Mahorn Is Punished
LEAD: Rick Mahorn, the Detroit Pistons' power forward, was suspended without pay for one game and fined $5,000 yesterday for committing a foul that started a fight during the Saturday night game in which the Bulls defeated the Pistons.
Rod Thorn, the National Basketball Association's vice president for operations, who levied the fine on Mahorn, also fined Charles Oakley, the Bulls' power forward, $2,000, and Doug Collins, the Bulls' coach, $1,500.

LEAD: The army-dominated Government defended Sunday's presidential election today as ''beautifully'' done, but several candidates charged widespread fraud and opposition leaders said irregularities and a lack of voter participation robbed the elections of credibility.

Rig Count Falls Again
LEAD: The number of rigs drilling for oil and gas in the United States dropped again last week, falling by 48, to 1,054, Baker Hughes Inc. said today.
A year ago, the rig count was 886.
The Houston-based oil tool maker tallies only the number of rigs exploring for oil.
The count is a widely watched barometer of drilling activity.


New Research Yields Clues in Fight Against Autoimmune Diseases
LEAD: WITH a newly detailed picture of molecules on the surfaces of cells, scientists are hopeful that they can finally devise strategies against the 40 or more diseases that result when the immune system mistakenly turns against the body.


Drug Prevention Project Enlists Girls' Peers
LEAD: The Girls Clubs of America is undertaking a nationwide program to prevent drug and alcohol abuse among girls 10 to 14 years old.
The goal of the Government-financed program is to reach at least 35,000 girls in the next five years.

Protests, Politics and Deep Emotion Mix as New York Honors Dr. King
LEAD: From Brooklyn to the World Trade Center, from Harlem to City Hall, protesters, politicians, worshipers and workers honored the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr. yesterday.
They did so with warmth, with criticism, with anger and with politics, in ways that the slain civil rights leader might have understood and in ways that he might not have appreciated.

It's Just Unshrinkable
LEAD: Ronald Reagan's pledge to reduce the size of the Government was a cornerstone of his Presidential campaign.
He asserted, in his first Inaugural address in 1981, that ''it is time to check and reverse the growth of government, which shows signs of having grown beyond the consent of the governed.''


San Juan Journal; Violence Turns Don Juan Tale Ugly
LEAD: His name is Antonio Garcia Lopez but in the rugged Central Cordillera he is better known as Tono Bicicleta - Tony Bicycle.
Police helicopters this week circled over the mountains' green ridges, dense and wet, probing into the shadowy pockets where he might be hiding.


Fruehauf Unit Sale
LEAD: The Fruehauf Corporation has completed the sale of its 91 percent stake in Fruehauf Canada, a truck and trailer servicing operation, to FRH Acquisitions, an affiliate of the Trailmobile Group of Companies of Brantford, Ontario.
The sale totaled about $96 million (Canadian), equal to $74.5 million (American), or about $30.20 (American) a share.

DRUG TESTS RISING AS WAY TO REDUCE PRISON CROWDING
LEAD: As prison and jail populations swell beyond capacity, cities and states are increasingly using drug tests to identify the worst criminal offenders, and using treatment of drug abuse to alter their criminal behavior.


Rates Little Changed Overseas
LEAD: Interest rates were little changed in overseas trading while speculators and investors waited for the resumption of full-scale trading in the United States after yesterday's holiday.

State House Detente
LEAD: It's been years since New York State had a governor and lieutenant governor who get along as well as Mario Cuomo and Stan Lundine.
Their rapport ought to inspire the Legislature to change the destructive rule that prevents a governor from choosing his own running mate.


Give Help Instead
LEAD: To the Editor:


Australian Open; Lendl Advances Easily to Semifinals
LEAD: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl moved into the semifinals of the Australian Open championships today, defeating the last surviving American in the men's singles, Todd Witsken, 6-2, 6-1, 7-6.


Carbide Files India Appeal
LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation today appealed a court decision that ordered it to pay $270 million in interim relief to victims of the 1984 gas leak that killed more than 2,800 people.


Advertising; A Women's Magazine Called Cameo Arrives
LEAD: There is still another women's beauty publication on the scene.
It is called Cameo magazine; it is very big (11 by 15 inches), very slick and distributed only through beauty salons.
You remember the late Cornelius Donovan's Girl Talk, and a barbershop magazine called Dare?


Flately Still Out Sports People
LEAD: Patrick Flatley of the Islanders underwent tests yesterday to determine the extent of damage to his right knee, which he injured Sunday night at Buffalo when he was checked into the boards by Mike Ramsey.
Ari Haanpaa was summoned from Springfield, Mass., on emergency recall to replace Flatley tonight against Pittsburgh.


White of Illinois Resigns
LEAD: Mike White, the head football coach at the University of Illinois, resigned today following an investigation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association into purported recruiting violations, a university spokeswoman said.


Corrections
LEAD: The Our Towns column on Dec. 29 misstated the frequency of volunteers' meetings with recovering mental patients in the Compeer program operated by the Mental Health Association of Nassau County.
They meet once a week for one year.

He was 82 years old.

Argentine Troops Storm Garrison And Put Down Colonel's Mutiny
LEAD: About 2,000 soldiers loyal to the civilian Government stormed an army compound today and forced the surrender of a rebellious colonel who had held the camp for three days with the support of about 100 followers, officials said.


Officers Ask Themselves Troubling Questions
LEAD: For two days the military officers at the National Defense University here grappled with ethical issues of loyalty and obedience, just and unjust wars, political responsibilities and pacifism.

LEAD: Ten years later, Bretons remember the catastrophe they call La Maree Noire, the Black Tide, with the intensity with which Americans recall the moment President Kennedy was shot.

3d World's Prospects Called Poor
LEAD: Investment and economic growth have contracted in debtor countries since the global debt crisis began in 1982, and living standards have staggered, the World Bank said today.


Snow, High Winds and Heavy Surf Batter the West
LEAD: A storm left up to two feet of snow in the mountains of the West yesterday after hammering California's coast with 12-foot waves that destroyed a restaurant, washed away part of a hotel and damaged beach homes.


Kidnapping in Colombia
LEAD: Leftist guerrillas kidnapped the leading candidate for mayor of Bogota today, the police said.
Andres Pastrana, the 34-year-old son of former President Misael Pastrana, was reported abducted at gunpoint from his campaign headquarters.
President Virgilio Barco Vargas called an emergency meeting of his Cabinet and Mayor Julio Cesar Sanchez of Bogota said a huge search had been mounted.


More Lyme Disease Reported in Connecticut
LEAD: The incidence of Lyme disease, the nation's most commonly reported tick-carried illness, has risen 163 percent in nine years in parts of Connecticut, the state where it was first discovered, Federal researchers have reported.


Concert: Philadelphia Group
LEAD: THE Concerto Soloists of Philadelphia played a concert at Town Hall on Sunday afternoon that was notable for its three strong 18th-century pieces.
The nicest discovery was Francesco Rosetti's G minor Symphony.
He was a Bohemian despite the Italian pen name, and his music here is terse and forceful - touched by the Sturm und Drang movement but with the tenseness smoothed over by the composer's elegance.


David W. C. Clark, Lawyer, 38; Was Convicted in Stock Scandal
LEAD: David W. C. Clark, a New York lawyer implicated in the insider trading scandal that involved a columnist for The Wall Street Journal, died Saturday at his mother's home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
He was 38 years old.

Dollar Moves Down in U.S. While Gold Closes Stronger
LEAD: The dollar drifted mostly lower in light domestic trading yesterday as worries about international trade suddenly arose again in the currency markets.


Stronger Yen Is Predicted
LEAD: In the coming year the yen will strengthen against the dollar, Japan's growth rate will taper off and the big trade imbalance between the United States and Japan will remain near its present level, a Japanese economist predicted today.


Stocks Up by 7.79 in Quiet Trading
LEAD: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in quiet holiday trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 7.79 points, to 1,963.86, after rising by 39.96 points on Friday.

Gas Supplies Are Restored
LEAD: Helped by a warming trend and fewer supply disruptions than expected, the nation's largest natural gas utility restored shipments today to 850 corporate customers in Southern California.
The service had been cut off two weeks ago to avert a shortage to residential customers.
The Southern California

LEAD: Politicians generally like to open campaigns before crowds of cheering supporters.
But Acting Mayor Eugene Sawyer, whose public appearances sometimes elicit jeers as well as cheers, chose to announce his bid in a radio studio.

4th Generation of Fords on Way Up
LEAD: The fourth generation of the founding family moved closer to power today as Edsel B. Ford 2d and William Clay Ford Jr. were elected to the board of the Ford Motor Company.


How Nature May Draw Stone Circles
LEAD: THE ''sorted circles of Spitsbergen,'' mysterious rings of stone found in a cold Norwegian landscape, have long stood as evidence that nature does not always need human architects to pick up rocks and arrange them in harmonious patterns.


Component Of Blood Also Found In Plants
LEAD: NO one can get blood from a turnip, but it might prove possible to find the blood substance hemoglobin in one.

Contributors Give Steadily To Neediest
LEAD: Uta Hagen, who celebrated her 50th anniversary in the theater last year, is a faithful contributor to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.


The Dance: New Works By 6 Choreographers
LEAD: DANCE CHANCE, a producing organization directed by Patricia Tarr, celebrated its fifth anniversary with two selections of new dance at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.
The previously reviewed first program and the second program, seen on Saturday night, suggested both the adventurousness and soundness of Dance Chance's plan.


Fair Price for Integrity
LEAD: Seeking public office in New York City has traditionally meant paying obeisance to real estate developers, brokerage houses and others who offer big contributions in hopes that the favor will be repaid once the beneficiary takes office.


Sales Slip in Britain
LEAD: Britain's consumer boom appeared to taper off at the end of last year, with retail sales falling a seasonally adjusted 1.1 percent in December after rising 1.05 percent in November, the Government said today.
The Department of Trade and Industry said sales rose more than 1 percent in the October-December period from the previous quarter, and were 5.5 percent higher than in the 1986 period.

LEAD: To the Editor:


The Debate Over Dinosaur Extinctions Takes an Unusually Rancorous Turn
LEAD: THE impact of a large comet may or may not have killed off the dinosaurs 65 million years ago.
But as the debate over dinosaur extinction rages on, personal rancor is increasingly clouding scientific issues.

LEAD: In response to what the authorities say they believe is a growing militancy among the most radical elements of the animal rights movement, the Federal authorities have begun to investigate, under anti-terrorism statutes, several arson cases involving research laboratories and meat companies.

Lawmakers on the Tube
LEAD: C-SPAN, the cable television network that brings Senate and House floor sessions live into your living room, has 43 percent more viewers than it did three years ago.
The public affairs network reports that a national poll by the Maryland Survey Research Center, taken in the final three months of 1987, showed 10.9 million households or a potential audience of 27.3 million people watching C-SPAN, an increase of 43 percent from the 1984 estimates of 7.6 million households and 19 million people.

LEAD: New Yorkers say they believe relations between blacks and whites are ''generally bad'' in the city and have worsened in the last year, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll.

Advertising; A Meredith Publisher In AIDS Fund Drive
LEAD: Stephen R. Burzon, publisher of Meredith's Metropolitan Home magazine, announced plans yesterday for a major fund-raising effort in behalf of the fight against AIDS.
He hopes to be able to donate at least $300,000 to the Design Industries' Foundation for AIDS.
During Designers Saturday Week in early October the magazine will have a show house on the East Side with its various rooms being done by some of the biggest names in interior decoration.

Dr. King Honored in Observances Around the Nation
LEAD: Martin Luther King 3d laying a wreath at the tomb of his father yesterday in Atlanta on the observance of Dr.
King's 59th birthday.
With him were, from left, Dr.
King's sister, Christine Ferris; Senator Sam Nunn; Mayor Andrew Young, and Coretta Scott King, Dr.
King's widow.
Articles, pages B1 and B3.


Prices of Copper Are Higher On Worry About Inventory
LEAD: Copper futures prices advanced yesterday as concern deepened on the Commodity Exchange in New York and the London Metal Exchange about dwindling inventories of the metal.
As usual, the low level of copper stocks has raised questions about how good the metal that remains in exchange warehouses is.

Sports People; 2 Steelers Retire
LEAD: John Stallworth, a wide receiver, and Donnie Shell, a safety, are retiring after 14 seasons with the Pittsburgh Steelers.
A team spokesman said yesterday that the Steelers will announce plans on Friday to honor the 35-year-old veterans of Pittsburgh's Super Bowl victories in 1975, 1976, 1979 and 1980.

Careers; Drug Testing Common for Job Seekers
LEAD: DRUG testing of prospective employees has become almost routine at many major companies, according to results of a new survey issued by the Interface Group, a Washington recruiting concern.
Meanwhile, a survey made by the University of Michigan finds that the use of cocaine among young adults has declined, perhaps partly because of fears about testing by employers.

LEAD: Earle Palmer Brown's Atlanta office, Burton-Campbell/EPB, has been renamed Earle Palmer Brown/ Atlanta.


Brand-New Net Sparks a Victory
LEAD: Things were different for the Nets tonight in many respects.
They had two new players on the roster.
They had a new starting center.
They had three players score more than 20 points each.
And they won.

China's Car Output Up
LEAD: China produced 445,000 cars in 1987, up more than 20 percent from 369,000 in 1986, the New China News Agency said today.
Domestic sales in the first nine months of 1987 came to 319,000 vehicles, up 40 percent over the 1986 period, the agency said.

Trust Their Peace Plan
LEAD: Central America's five presidents made a bold decision last weekend.
Their plan called for Nicaragua and the United States to take simultaneous steps toward peace - steps neither side liked.
With the plan's fate hanging in the balance, the presidents leaned hard on the Sandinistas to go first.
The strategy seems to have succeeded.


STUDY AFFIRMS LINK OF PERSONALITY TO ILLNESS
LEAD: A MAJOR new study links personality traits with illness on such a broad scale that some psychologists depict being neurotic as a key factor in susceptibility to disease.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Thursday about automobile sales for early January misstated the daily selling rate of Honda of America.


TV Review; 'Things My Mother Told Me'
LEAD: OFTEN dabbling in sensitive subjects, the kind that fit easily into tidy object lessons, programs for younger viewers can occasionally topple over into heavy-handed theatrics.
Take for instance ''Things My Mother Told Me,'' tomorrow's ''Afterschool Special'' on ABC at 4 o'clock.
Eager to insure that viewers don't miss the point, the little drama is exaggerated to the point of possibly inducing hives.


Insurer's Head Faces $4.2 Billion Decision
LEAD: Leo E. Denlea Jr.'s career in finance has meant managing money for companies including the Mobil Oil Corporation and the International Basic Economy Corporation, a Nelson Rockefeller venture.


Walter L. Strauss, Author and Expert On Old Masters Art
LEAD: Walter L. Strauss, a writer, publisher and authority on Old Master drawings and prints, died of a heart attack last Thursday at Madison Avenue and 56th Street.
He was 65 years old and lived in Scarborough, N.Y.

Vote on Contra Aid Thrown Into Turmoil
LEAD: Nicaragua's professed willingness to suspend its state of emergency and begin direct talks with the rebels could make it harder for the Reagan Administration to get them more military aid, Democratic and Republican lawmakers and key Congressional aides say.


Quotations of the Day
LEAD:  ''I wasted 12 weeks of my life in the hospital.
I was not insane when they picked me up - I was homeless.''  - Joyce Brown, about to be released from forced hospitalization.  [ A1:6. ] ''The lawyers won, and the patient lost.''  - Maureen McLeod, a city attorney.


Homeless Woman to Be Released After Being Forcibly Hospitalized
LEAD: Joyce Brown, the homeless woman who challenged a Koch administration program to forcibly hospitalize mentally ill street people, will be released this week, city officials said yesterday, 12 weeks after she was picked up on an East Side sidewalk.


In Human Rights Court, Honduras Is First to Face Death Squad Trial
LEAD: In the first case ever tried by the Inter-American Court on Human Rights in which a Government has been put on trial, Honduras is being accused here of maintaining army death squads that caused the ''disappearance'' of civilians suspected of being leftists.

Steel Output Up 3.8%
LEAD: Steel production rose to about 1.86 million tons in the week ended Saturday, an increase of 3.8 percent from the previous week's 1.79 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 86.6 percent of capacity, compared with 83.4 percent in the previous week.


Knicks Outgun Hawks, 110-102
LEAD: Dominique Wilkins of the Atlanta Hawks scored 45 points yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden, but it was not enough.
The Knicks used 28 points from Gerald Wilkins, Dominique's younger brother, 20 from Patrick Ewing, a first triple-double from Mark Jackson and a trapping, harassing defense in the second half to win, 110-102.


Sportswear Stays Up Later and Becomes Dressier
LEAD: Sportswear isn't sportswear any more.
Instead of navy blazers, tailored shirts and gray flannel pants, it's plunging necklines, chiffon skirts and lace T-shirts.
This indigenous branch of American fashion is changing its nature.
Instead of sportswear's traditional sturdy, casual look, the clothes are flirty, feminine and infinitely dressier.


First Chicago Posts $96.5 Million Loss in Quarter
LEAD: The First Chicago Corporation reported a $96.5 million fourth-quarter loss yesterday, largely because of a $240 million reserve against its loans to third-world nations.

Bork Not Expected to Return To Full-Time Teaching Post
LEAD: Judge Robert H. Bork, who failed to win Senate confirmation to the United States Supreme Court, probably will not return to teaching full time at Yale University after he steps down from the bench, the dean of the Yale Law School said today.


Iron From Exploding Star
LEAD: Observations made by astronomers aboard a high-flying airplane have found an extremely unusual form of iron in the debris ejected by an exploding star.
The existence of this type of iron, scientists say, implies that the temperature of the explosion must have been even higher than previously suspected.

Murdoch Raises Stake in Pearson
LEAD: The News Corporation, owned by Rupert Murdoch, has increased its stake in the Pearson Group P.L.C., a diversified British company that publishes The Financial Times, to 20.4 percent, from 19.8 percent.
The Australian media company and its subsidiaries now hold 44.20 million Pearson shares, Pearson said.


NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1988
LEAD:  International A2-10


Amendment Made To Carteret Offer
LEAD: The Home Group Inc., a New York insurance company, and Carteret Bancorp Inc., which owns the Carteret Savings Bank of Morristown, N.J., said they had amended the takeover agreement that was reached last August.
Under the revised deal, Home Group's offer price was reduced to $19 a share in cash, or about $232 million, from $22.50 a share, or about $320 million.


Bethlehem Sets Price Increases
LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation will increase its prices from $20 and $30 a ton on certain steel products.
The steelmaker increased its base price for carbon and other brands of its steel plates by $20 a ton, or 4.5 percent, to $465 a ton, Gary Graham, a spokesman for the nation's third-largest steel producer, said.


Recital: Mitsuko Shirai Sings
LEAD: MITSUKO SHIRAI, accompanied by her husband, Hartmut Holl, brought to Alice Tully Hall Sunday night a lieder program invested with unusual care and thoughtfulness.
First there was the music itself - mostly from familiar composers but chosen with an ear for freshness.

The budget is $5 million.
Initially, the competition included Motorola's former agency, Young &amp; Rubicam, which had had the account since 1978.
By October, however, the list came down to Lintas:New York, J.

Rights for the Aged, Long Overdue
LEAD: For most Americans, ''home'' means familiar faces, familiar furniture and a measure of control over one's own life.
For 1.3 million older adults, however, it means a space in a nursing home facility - and a loss of freedom and comfort.


CBS Says People Meter Errors Cause Big Losses
LEAD: The new ''people meter'' system of measuring television audiences, meant to be a revolutionary breakthrough in determining who is watching which programs, has already cost the three major networks $40 million to $50 million in lost advertising revenues because of errors in the system, according to several executives at one of the networks.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Pan Am Corporation contained a reference that incorrectly stated the position of the Independent Union of Flight Attendants on one of the company's top executives.
The union is seeking the ouster of the current management, including Martin R. Shugrue Jr., vice chairman; it has not sent a letter to the board in his support.

Yields Changed In Bond Tables
LEAD: The calculation of the yields of some United States Treasury bonds has been changed in tables distributed by The Associated Press.

Standoff Goes On at Polygamist's Utah Compound
LEAD: More than 150 officers wearing fatigues and armed with automatic weapons ringed the compound of a slain polygamist today as 14 relatives, including a suspect in a church bombing, remained inside for a third day awaiting his ''resurrection.''


French Pupil Ordered Home
LEAD: A foreign exchange student has been ordered to return to France because she visited her homeland for Christmas week instead of staying to watch Americans celebrate the holidays.


'Izzy, Did You Ask a Good Question Today?'
LEAD: To the Editor:


By Design: Elegant Pearls
LEAD: A pearl necklace has always been one of the luxuries women aspire to and many have obtained.
Because pearls run the gamut from fake to fabulous, a strand can range in price from $10 to $1 million.


Doing the Impossible
LEAD: IN WORLD War II, the Army Air Forces boasted, ''The difficult we do at once; the impossible takes a little longer.'' Dr.
Richard R. Green, New York City's newly appointed Schools Chancellor, has paraphrased that confident slogan: ''No task will be evaded merely because it is impossible.''


Candelaria Joins Yanks as No. 3 Starter
LEAD: The Yankees may have bolstered their corps of starting pitchers yesterday by adding John Candelaria to their staff.
General Manager Lou Piniella immediately pronounced Candelaria the team's third starter, but questions existed over how effective the left-hander might be.


S.A.S. to Buy 9 Boeing Jets
LEAD: The Boeing Company won a $660 million contract today from the Scandinavian Airlines System for nine twin-engined 767 jets, wresting a major sale from Airbus Industrie, the European consortium, and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

Radioactive Powder Leaks
LEAD: About 200 pounds of a low-level radioactive powder leaked early today from a rooftop vent at a federally owned uranium-processing plant, officials said.
Contamination from the uranium powder appeared limited to the immediate area and no trace was detected outside the 1,050-acre plant site, said Pete Kelley of the Westinghouse Materials Company of Ohio.


Law Bars Sale of a Jet Used by Congressmen
LEAD: A House committee chairman has quietly prevented the Army Corps of Engineers from selling an executive jet that has been used by members of Congress and called wasteful by the Army's auditors.


The U.N. Today
LEAD:  General Assembly


IN RETIRING, REP. LUJAN PUTS NEW MEXICO IN TURMULT
LEAD: Ever since Manuel Lujan Jr., the Republican Representative from New Mexico's First Congressional District, announced that he would not seek an 11th term, the state's political life has been in turmoil.

Theory on Earth's Core
LEAD: A geologist from the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute has challenged a fundamental belief about conditions on the Earth when it formed 4.5 billion years ago.
He says the young planet was hot at its center rather than cold.


Dyncorp Board Meets on New Bid
LEAD: Directors of Dyncorp, a diversified technology company based in McLean, Va., have met to consider dropping one merger agreement for a sweeter rival proposal.
A company spokesman said a decision was expected to be announced today.


Hoffman Lifts Sterling Bid; Suitors Seen
LEAD: Hoffmann-La Roche &amp; Company announced last night that it was raising its hostile takeover offer for Sterling Drug Inc. to nearly $4.4 billion, hours after Sterling rejected its initial $4.2 billion bid.

Theater Owner In Venture Talks
LEAD: AMC Entertainment Inc., one of the nation's largest movie theater chains, said it had been negotiating to form a venture to run the theaters it now operates in a major Northeastern metropolitan area.
AMC said only that the company with which it was negotiating was a major entertainment company.


Sports People; Howe Is Dismissed
LEAD: Steve Howe is out of a major league pitching job again.
After a struggle with drug abuse, alcohol was the problem this time, Howe's attorney said Sunday.


Gephardt's Iowa Campaign Resurges
LEAD: Representative Richard A. Gephardt has chalked up his 118th day of Presidential campaigning in Iowa, hoping to translate a recent upswing in his popularity into solid support at Iowa's Democratic caucuses on Feb. 8.

Belgian Giant Sought By Italian-Led Group
LEAD: In what Belgians view as an assault on their nation, a Paris-based investment group headed by Carlo de Benedetti, the Italian financier, said today that it was starting a bid for control of Societe Generale de Belgique, a holding company that is synonymous with Belgium.


Concert: St. Luke's and Samuel Ramey
LEAD: AT Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening, the Orchestra of St.
Luke's furthered its assertion to a place at the center of this city's concert life.
It is a virtuoso ensemble, though not in the high-tech sense we tend to associate with top American orchestras, and all the more welcome for providing a contrast to them.


Norway-China Oil Talks
LEAD: Norway's state oil company, Statoil, said today that it was close to reaching an agreement with China to lead a search for oil in the South China Sea.
Haakon Lavik, a spokesman for Statoil, said the agreement would make Statoil the main operator in a 1,450-square-mile tract south of Hainan island.


Executive Changes
LEAD: Central and South West Corp., Dallas, a holding company engaged in electricity, elected as a director James M. Moroney Jr., chairman of the executive committee at A. H. Belo Corp., Dallas, a newspaper publishing and broadcasting concern.


New TV Meter Blamed for Loss
LEAD: The new ''people meter'' system of measuring television audiences has cost the three major networks $40 million to $50 million in lost advertising revenues because of system errors, according to CBS executives.

Results Plus; Skiing
LEAD: Swiss Woman First: Brigitte Oertli of Switzerland won a special slalom yesterday in Saas Fee, Switzerland, for her first World Cup victory.
Oertli, third after the first heat, had a superb second run and finished with a combined time of 1 minute 26.57 seconds.
Vreni Schneider of Switzerland, the giant slalom world champion, went from eighth to second in the second run, finishing 23-hundredths of a second behind.

The Devotion of Judge Weinfeld
LEAD: Edward Weinfeld, who died Sunday at the age of 86, was the most admired judge on the Federal bench.
His sense of fairness, earnestness and commitment to doing justice were conspicuous.
His deep study and conscientious preparation won the respect and affection of lawyers - and inspired them to try to meet his standards.

Eating Well
LEAD: FOLLOWING in the footsteps of other celebrities, Elizabeth Taylor has written a weight-loss book.
Unlike many other authors - including Victoria Principal, Jane Fonda and Bess Myerson - Miss Taylor gained and lost her weight in full public view.


Missile Test Is Successful
LEAD: An unarmed Minuteman missile was launched Monday night after several days of delays in a successful test, an Air Force spokesman said today.
Lieut.
Col.
Richard Hill, who observed the test, said the test rocket reached its destination at Kwajalein Atoll in the Pacific Ocean, about 4,200 miles from here, in about 30 minutes.

LEAD: Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert will meet in the semifinals of the Australian Open, the 76th time they will face each other.


Bidder Held Below 25% Of Belgique
LEAD: The Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti acceded to a request by the Belgian Government today to keep his stake in Societe Generale de Belgique below 25 percent of the outstanding shares.

LEAD: A commuter airliner with 16 people aboard crashed near here tonight, and officials said there were at least 12 people seriously injured.
There was no word on fatalities.

LEAD: It is Christmas in January for Hollywood this week.
Fueled by the blockbuster opening of ''Good Morning, Vietnam'' and the unstoppable ''Three Men and a Baby,'' both movies from Walt Disney Pictures, the box office went wild last weekend.


Canadian Inflation Rate
LEAD: Canada's annual inflation rate held steady at 4.2 percent in December, unchanged from the annual rate in the previous month, the Government statistical agency reported today.


Humpback Whale Washes Ashore on Long Island
LEAD: A female humpback whale, 50 feet long and weighing about 100,000 pounds, was the first to wash ashore on Long Island, but the 16th humpback to have washed ashore in the last four weeks in the Northeast, according to a research director from the Okeanos Ocean Research Foundation.
He said he believed the Long Island whale died from paralytic fish poisoning, which killed the other 15 whales, which were found in Cape Cod.

G.M. Plans to Drop Two Small Autos
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it planned to discontinue two cars at the end of the current model year.
The Cadillac Division will discontinue the Cimarron, a compact car introduced in 1981.
The Oldsmobile Division will retire the Firenza subcompact, which was introduced in 1982.
Sales of both cars have declined.

LEAD: They finished with the American Conference's best record after playing most of the season without their top rusher, and they won the title game in an aerial shootout as their leading receiver watched from the hospital.


Di Giorgio Plans To Buy Back Stock
LEAD: The Di Giorgio Corporation said its board had approved a restructuring and a stock repurchase program.
The company plans to buy up to 1.5 million of its approximately 8.5 million common shares at a price of $21 a share.
The company's stock closed today at $19.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, down 87.5 cents.

LEAD: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union left Bonn today after a three-day visit in which he assured the West Germans that Moscow was in favor of eliminating short-range nuclear arms and chemical weapons, and of a ''radical reduction'' in conventional forces.

LEAD: The New York City Ballet has announced the election of Theodore C. Rogers as chairman of its board, succeeding Orville H. Schell Jr., who died last June.
Mr.
Rogers, a former president and chairman of the board of NL Industries Inc., has served on the New York City Ballet board and was formerly a director of the Houston Ballet.

Minkow was indicted last week by a Federal grand jury.

Components Expected For I.B.M. PS/2 Clones
LEAD: A group of small computer companies will announce Wednesday that they have succeeded in making chips and software that will allow computers to be built that are compatible with the new PS/2 line of personal computers from the International Business Machines Corporation.


Dukakis, in Annual Address, Looks to New Hampshire and Beyond
LEAD: Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis, making what he hopes is his last State of the State Address, said tonight that running for the Democratic Presidential nomination had been ''an extraordinary experience'' and that he had tried his best ''to make you proud of me and of what this commonwealth represents.''


Viola Re-signs
LEAD: Frank Viola, the Minnesota Twins' ace left-hander who was voted the most valuable player in the World Series, will remain with the Twins at least through 1989.
He signed a two-year contract Monday worth $2.9 million.


British Phone Booths Saved
LEAD: Britain has designated 1,000 telephone booths as national landmarks, the Environment Department announced today.
The traditional red boxes have been a familiar sight since 1936.
But British Telecom, in a modernization drive, has so far replaced 20,000 of 50,000 with a new design.


New York's Presidential Booby Traps
LEAD: Just to get on the ballot, candidates in New York must overcome pointless legal obstacles that stud the state's 300-page election law.
The rules encourage the nitpicking that has marred countless campaigns for local office.
Now those same legal nits could taint the Presidential races in New York's April 19 primary.


Trade Coalition Formed to Urge The Recycling of Plastic Bottles
LEAD: A newly formed coalition of chemical and packaging companies announced today that it was joining in a campaign to encourage the recycling of plastic bottles to help stem the nation's growing surfeit of garbage.

A Visiting Dissident
LEAD: Milovan Djilas, the venerable Yugoslav Communist dissident, is due to visit Washington next month on his first trip to the United States in almost 20 years.

Australian Trade Deficit
LEAD: Australia's current account deficit, the measure of exports of goods and services, fell to $467 million in December, from $590 million in November, according to official statistics released today.
If the present trend continues, the country could end the financial year in June with a current account shortfall of more than $8.5 billion, analysts said.

LEAD: Hanoi rejected as inadequate today the Reagan Administration's plan to make it easier for private organizations to give humanitarian aid to Vietnam.


Study Says Quitting Smoking Reduces Risk of Stroke by 50%
LEAD: Cigarette smokers who give up the habit cut their risk of stroke by about 50 percent, and even longtime smokers benefit from quitting, a new study indicates.

Jazz: Hamiet Bluiett
LEAD: THE baritone saxophonist Hamiet Bluiett brought a jubilantly noisy nine-piece big band to Carlos 1 (432 Avenue of the Americas, below 10th Street) Monday for the beginning of an indefinite stay of Monday nights.
Mr.
Bluiett, one quarter of the World Saxophone Quartet, has been leading a big band off and on for the last decade, and has ideas about what he wants from his orchestra.


An 'Active Partnership' That Spurs Learning
LEAD: In the early 1980's, Columbia Park Elementary School in Landover, Md., was in trouble.
On the average, its students, most of them black and from low-income families, could not crack the 50th percentile, or upper half, on national or local standardized tests.
Discipline was so weak that officials suspended 20 to 30 students a year for five consecutive years.

Swiss Trade Deficit Up
LEAD: Switzerland's trade deficit widened in 1987 as a rising tide of imports swamped a small increase in exports, the Federal Customs Office said today.
The trade deficit totaled 7.69 billion Swiss francs, or about $5.63 billion, compared with a gap of 6.51 billion francs in 1986.
A strong domestic economy drew 6.9 percent more imports into Switzerland on an inflation-adjusted basis, but exports grew by only 1.1 percent.

Chemical Bank
LEAD: The Chemical Bank said it had sold its Chicago-based merchant processing business to the Electro Data Corporation of Denver.
Terms were not disclosed.
Chemical announced in November that it would discontinue the service as part of its program to streamline its operations.

LEAD: About one of every three Americans inherits a tendency to produce a form of cholesterol that appears to be linked with an unusually high risk of heart disease, research released today shows.

Will Riot Role Blunt Israelis' Warrior Spirit?
LEAD: Since early December, the Israel Defense Force, envied among armies of the world for courage and performance, has been playing an unaccustomed role as policemen in trying to put down Palestinian riots in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
It is hardly a role that the combat-oriented army relishes.

LEAD: The Franklin Savings Association is offering $150 million of 20-year bonds with an interest rate that will be adjusted quarterly at 3 percent above the increase in consumer prices.

MCI to Reduce Its Phone Rates
LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation said it would reduce its long-distance telephone rates by about 3.5 percent on March 1, matching rate reductions announced earlier by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.


The Homeless Find a Haven At Residence
LEAD: There is nothing fancy about the corniced, four-story, red-brick building on West 40th Street into which Joyce Brown moved last night.


New Jet Coaches
LEAD: The Jets have named Wally Chambers as new defensive line coach and Mike Faulkiner as the coach of their defensive backs.
Chambers played for the Chicago Bears and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and then was defensive line coach at Temple.
Ray Callahan moved from defensive line coach to special assistant to Coach Joe Walton.


Gene Deal for Beckman
LEAD: Beckman Instruments Inc. has signed an agreement with British Bio-technology Ltd. to distribute the British company's line of synthetic genes.
The synthetic genes, sold under the trademark Designer Genes, produce proteins used in research, the company said.
Until now, researchers have had to grow their own genes for medical research.


Sugar Prices at 4-Year High On Philippine Storm News
LEAD: The price of world sugar futures soared to more than 10 cents a pound yesterday for the first time in more than four years.
Analysts cited fears that a storm had further damaged the Philippines' already battered sugar cane crop.


Trust and a Fortune Cookie: Blind Date Is Back in Fashion
LEAD: It was a blind date.
They decided to meet by the Dumpster in front of Jeremy's Ale House, a popular hangout at South Street Seaport.
Expectations were low.

The Pop Life; Hall of Fame Inductees
LEAD: The Beach Boys, the Beatles, the Drifters, Bob Dylan and the Supremes will be inducted into the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame this evening during the organization's third annual dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Three other artists -Woody Guthrie, Leadbelly and Les Paul -will also be inducted as early influences on rock music.


Safety Panel Urges More Controls On Connecticut Building Projects
LEAD: Stricter controls on construction projects in Connecticut were proposed today by a gubernatorial advisory committee appointed after the collapse last April of an apartment complex in Bridgeport that killed 28 construction workers.


Electoral Math
LEAD: To the Editor:


Joyce Brown, Hopeful, Savors Her New World
LEAD: Joyce Brown, the first person picked up under a New York City program to remove mentally ill homeless people from the streets, walked out of Bellevue Hospital Center yesterday after being forcibly hospitalized for 84 days.


The Interpublic Group Seeks Phillips-Ramsey
LEAD: The Interpublic Group of Companies Inc., which had the acquisition craze before the Saatchis appeared, has just announced a plan to buy Phillips-Ramsey of San Diego and Phoenix.
It will be its first acquisition since its deal for the United States arm of Geers Gross Advertising was completed earlier this month.


Nordic Skier Is Barred
LEAD: Kerry Lynch of Denver, the Nordic Combined specialist, was barred from international competition at least until the end of 1988 after acknowledging he practiced blood doping at the last world championship.
The International Ski Federation announced the ban yesterday in Bern, Switzerland.
The exact length of the suspension will be determined later, but it includes next month's Winter Olympics.

LEAD: The State Department issued a carefully understated rejection today of the legitimacy of the elections Sunday in Haiti, but said that the United States would deal with whatever government emerges.


Japanese Trade Report Shows Mixed Picture
LEAD: Japan said today that its trade surplus with the United States rose in December and for all of last year, although its global trade surplus declined in 1987 for the first time in five years.

LEAD: Without support from Federal and state governments, minority participation in higher education will steadily decrease, experts said here today at the 70th annual meeting of the American Council on Education.

Boyd F. Morgan, Stuntman, 72
LEAD: Boyd F. (Red) Morgan, a stuntman who doubled for John Wayne in dozens of Westerns and boasted of falling off 2,000 horses in front of cameras without injury, died of heart failure Jan. 8.
He was 72 years old.
Mr.
Morgan, who was born in Waurika, Okla., served in the Navy during World War II and coached high school football before becoming a stuntman in 1948.


Icahn Raises Texaco Stake
LEAD: The financier Carl C. Icahn said today that he had increased his stake in Texaco Inc. to 14.5 percent, from 13.3 percent.
The stock purchases cost him about $110 million.

Philadelphia Journal; On the Amtrak 7:30 to New York: Adventures of Commuting 2 Hours
