A Powder For Testing Conductivity
LEAD: ONE of high tech's current buzzwords is ''superconductivity,'' the capacity for a material to conduct electricity without friction if the material is cooled to low enough temperatures.
The discovery that some substances become superconducting at much higher temperatures than previously thought electrified scientists last year, leading to speculation about superconductivity uses ranging from high-speed trains to superfast electronic components.

A New Weapon Is Seen in Cancer Fight
LEAD: SUBSTANCES that undergo a chemical reaction when exposed to light are likely to become a new weapon in the treatment of cancer.
Known as porphyrins, they are given to patients intravenously and concentrate in cancer tumors.
When exposed to light, they give off energy that kills the cancer cells.

LEAD: Firefighters battling a five-alarm fire that destroyed a row of stores along Gramatan Avenue in Mount Vernon early yesterday.

Concert: The Philomusica
LEAD: HAYDN, Mozart and a light, tart Neo-Classical homage to them made up the New York Philomusica's program Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.
The Haydn was a curio: a pair of trios for violin, viola and cello cobbled by the composer out of his own piano sonatas.
It was profitable in those days to publish music in multiple versions for home consumption, which remains the best use for these arrangements; playing them in a concert is certainly not objectionable but not particularly enlightening either.

Jordan Offers to Pay
LEAD: For their roles in a brawl involving Rick Mahorn on Saturday night that cost the Detroit Piston power forward $5,000 and a one-game suspension, four members of the Chicago Bulls were assessed fines totaling $3,500 by the National Basketball Association.
Yesterday, Michael Jordan, who was knocked to the floor by Mahorn - the action that caused the brawl - offered to pay the fines for the Chicago players.


Dollar Declines on Report Of Bigger Japanese Surplus
LEAD: Japan's report of a growing trade surplus with the United States helped push the dollar lower against the yen yesterday.


Cheryl Pierson Leaves L.I. Jail
LEAD: After serving 3 1/2 months in jail for arranging her father's murder, 18-year-old Cheryl Pierson was released today and celebrated by riding in a limousine and feasting on a diner breakfast and later on a belated Christmas dinner.

Dr.
Martin Luther King included an erroneous identification provided by police officials and Mayor Koch's office for a woman who protested Mr.
Koch's appearance at the Convent Avenue Baptist Church.
She was not Beverly Weston.

Ban Greed? No: Harness It.
LEAD: Program trading . . . index arbitrage . . . portfolio insurance . . .
While regulators struggle to understand the implications of new ''derivative securities,'' it's a fair bet that most small investors have come to a simple conclusion.
These all sound like tools for hustlers.
They make it possible for speculators like Gordon Gekko, the villain in the movie ''Wall Street,'' to profit at the expense of honest investors.


Two Homeless Men Set Afire by Youths At a Bus Terminal
LEAD: Two homeless men were set on fire while they slept early yesterday in an isolated area of the Port Authority Bus Terminal, the police said, and two teen-agers were arrested shortly afterward when witnesses spotted them near Times Square.


Food Notes; A French Staple That's Made in America
LEAD: SOME American cheese makers are now producing fromage blanc, long a staple in France.
Fromage blanc is like an extremely smooth cottage cheese made from whole or skimmed milk.
It is eaten either spiced or sweetened, often with fruit, and is also used in cooking.

Lacroix will introduce his eagerly awaited second couture collection in Paris.

LEAD: The Senate Judiciary Committee has scheduled a vote for Jan. 27 on Judge Anthony Kennedy's nomination to the Supreme Court, a committee spokesman said today.
The nomination of Judge Kennedy, a 51-year-old Federal appellate court judge from California, is expected to be approved by the committee and sent to the full Senate for final confirmation.

He was 83 years old.

LEAD: The Los Angeles Raiders have called a news conference for today amid speculation that Tom Flores will step down as coach.

It was March 12.

LEAD: The New York State Comptroller yesterday asserted that the real-estate department of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has made ''inconsistent and questionable'' decisions in awarding leases, and said he has referred the matter to the United States Attorney in Manhattan.


The Medium Goes Elite
LEAD: Glued to Sunday's televised football, I was astonished by the high volume of commercials for goods and services which are of little or no use to most football fans.


Stage: 'The Last Resort' And a Geriatric Revolt
LEAD: IN ''The Last Resort'' six people make life at a Long Island nursing home more lively than their keepers or relatives can stand.
This place may be the last resort of the families that sent their elders to it, but to its inmates the last resort is escape, and even if the plotting of their breakout is hilariously inept, you keep hoping they will make it.


Tornadoes Hit Mississippi Valley, Killing 5 in Western Tennessee
LEAD: Tornadoes and thunderstorms swept over the lower Mississippi Valley yesterday, killing at least five people in western Tennessee, while blowing snow and drifts up to 14 feet high in the Plains stranded hundreds of travelers.


Hearings on G.O.P. Are Delayed
LEAD: Confronted with Republican challenges of its jurisdiction, the State Commission on Integrity in Government today postponed what were to be its first major hearings.


RESULTS
LEAD:  Skiing  Tomba Gains 7th Cup Victory: Alberto Tomba of Italy yesterday won his seventh World Cup race of the season in a giant slalom at Saas Fee, Switzerland, widening his lead over the defending champion, Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland, in the overall standing.
Tomba skied the two fastest heats to finish with a total time of 2 minutes 33.42 seconds.


Dole Urges Caution Toward Soviet Union and Distrust of Gorbachev
LEAD: Senator Bob Dole said tonight that if elected President he would he would shape a relationship with the Soviet Union marked by ''caution'' and essential distrust for the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev.


Coke Unit Faces Layoffs
LEAD: Citing fewer soft-drink bottlers in the United States, the Coca-Cola Company said today that it would lay off about 8 percent of the management workers in its domestic bottling operations.
About 200 of the 2,500 employees of the Coca-Cola U.S.A. division will be laid off ''over the next several weeks,'' said Randy Donaldson, a company spokesman.


Key Unilever Executive Plays Down New Role
LEAD: If the past is any precedent, Morris Tabaksblat's promotion to become Unilever's regional director for North America bodes well for his career.

Stage: 'Woza Albert!' Performed at City College
LEAD: WHEN ''Woza Albert!,'' the acclaimed two-man South African play, was first presented in New York several years ago, high-powered political South African ''township'' theater was a something of a novelty.
Since then, Lincoln Center's Woza Africa Theater Festival and its production of ''Sarafina!'' have familiarized us with an emotionally charged genre of spare, confrontational theater that transfuses political anger into ritualistic communal affirmation.

Children's Haircuts Without the Tears
LEAD: Having her hair cut was not Sydney Blumstein's idea, but her mother's.
Sydney, who is 3 years old, thought her long dark hair was just fine the way it was, until the video screen before her in a midtown hair salon lit up with a cartoon tape starring Mickey Mouse.


Record Profit for Volvo
LEAD: Volvo, the Swedish auto maker, today reported record pretax profits for 1987 of 9 billion crowns, or about $1.5 billion, substantially better than some analysts had expected.
Most had said the company would do well to match its 1986 profits of 7.5 billion crowns.
The 1987 figure included October's 1.15 billion crown sale of Volvo's 49.6 percent stake in the Hamilton Oil Corporation, a Denver-based oil and gas company.

Brazil's Trade Surplus
LEAD: Brazil had a trade surplus of $11.15 billion in 1987, with exports totaling $26.21 billion, the second highest ever, the Government said today.
Imports came to $15.06 billion.
The surplus was 33.8 percent higher than the 1986 figure of $8.33 billion.


Bankers Trust Net Soars; Irving Has Loss in Quarter
LEAD: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation, corporate parent of the Bankers Trust Company, yesterday reported extraordinarily high net income for the fourth quarter - nearly triple its earnings a year ago - mainly because of huge profits from its foreign-exchange and bond-trading activities.


An Umbrella of Fog, but the Rain Came Through Anyway
LEAD: Haze obscured the top of the Manhattan skyline as seen from the Brooklyn Promenade on a day that featured rain, rain and more rain.
Today is expected to be drier, with decreasing cloudiness and a high of about 48 degrees.
Tomorrow should be sunny and colder. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr)


HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: REPAIRING large holes in wallboard - larger than four inches across - requires some ingenuity and moderate experience with some basic tools.
Unlike patches for small holes, which were discussed in last week's column, these patches must be braced from behind.
The bracing, or backing, creates a surface to which the patch can be fastened.


No Emergency Seen in East Jerusalem
LEAD: The Minister of Police said today that he had no immediate plans to use emergency powers to impose curfews in Arab East Jerusalem or order striking shops there to open.


Results Plus
LEAD:  N.H.L.


REAGAN WILL LIMIT AID FOR ABORTIONS
LEAD: Despite the certainty of a legal challenge, President Reagan will soon announce rules prohibiting abortions and abortion counseling by family planning programs that receive Federal funds, White House officials said today.

Advertising; Shaffer Clarke Signs With a New Agency
LEAD: Roman &amp; Tannenholz has become the agency for Shaffer Clarke &amp; Company, a subsidiary of Britain's U. B. Holdings P.L.C.
The budget should be around $1.5 million, according to the agency.
And that is more than has been spent recently through Maged &amp; Behar.


Bristol-Myers Net Up 14.8%
LEAD: The Bristol-Myers Company, citing a strong rise in profit and in domestic and international sales, reported yesterday that it fourth-quarter earnings rose 14.8 percent on a 13.3 percent increase in sales.


Market Place; Analysts Term Rorer Attractive
LEAD: WHEN the A. H. Robins Company agreed Tuesday afternoon to be acquired by the American Home Products Corporation, there was a notable difference in how Robins's two other suitors took the news.


Music: Chamber Society
LEAD: THE novelty on this week's program of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, heard Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall, is a bristling, scherzo-like essay for clarinet, horn, piano and string trio by Peter Lieberson.
The title is ''Ziji,'' a Tibetan term associated by Mr.
Lieberson with the ''the energy of confidence,'' according to the program notes.


Al Hall, Jazz Bassist, Dies at 72; Broke Color Barrier on Broadway
LEAD: Al Hall, a jazz bassist believed to be the first black musician in a Broadway theater orchestra, died of lung cancer Monday at Roosevelt Hospital.
He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: ''The first priority is to use force, might, beatings.'' That is the message from the man in charge of Israel's response to the Palestinian protests, Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin.

Iowa, or the Smoke-Filled Room?
LEAD: Why is everybody paying so much attention to Iowa?
Things are looking up for Babbitt in Iowa . . .
Dole's lead in the Iowa polls is widening . . .
Hart looked rattled on TV in Iowa.
Who made Iowa the national barometer?
Why should we care what happens in the Iowa precinct caucuses on Feb. 8?
Let's go back to the old way and let the political professionals pick the candidates.


Dole Critizices Kemp Leaflet On Social Security Measures
LEAD: Senator Bob Dole accused Representative Jack F. Kemp today of trying to scare elderly voters by sending out a brochure that criticizes Mr.
Dole's votes on Social Security.

LEAD: ''Personally, I worry that if we ease up too much, the contras will take advantage.

Metro Matters; Today's Outrage May Inspire Tomorrow's Vote
LEAD: Two demonstrations are planned in New York City today - one to register outrage through civil disobedience and another to persuade outraged people to register to vote.


Cuomo and Moynihan Fighting Over Who Lost Big U.S. Project
LEAD: New York's highest officials, among them Governor Cuomo and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, are caught up in a bitter political dispute over who is to blame for what is widely viewed as the state's embarrassing fumbling in efforts to attract a $4.4 billion Federal project.

Dance: Jazzdance Troupe, With Danny Buraczeski
LEAD: DANNY BURACZESKI has hit the jackpot with the new choreography his jazz dance company will be presenting this week.
There is a haunting piece of interplay between Willie Ruff, the master French horn player, and Mr.
Buraczeski; a surprisingly effective work about victims of Argentina's recent military dictatorship; and an abstract bluesy piece with a sophisticated commissioned score.

Drug Use Blamed in Rail Crash
LEAD: A Federal safety agency said today that impairment from drug use and a failure to require automatic braking devices on freight trains were responsible for a fatal collision between an Amtrak passenger train and a string of freight locomotives last year.


White House Berates the Foes of Contra Aid
LEAD: The White House attacked Congressional opponents of renewed aid to the contras today, saying their criticisms of the Administration's Central America policy were ''outrageous'' and tantamount to ''surrender.''


Congressmen Claim an Accord With Hanoi to Resettle Amerasians
LEAD: Vietnam and the United States have agreed to move thousands of children of American servicemen and the children's immediate relatives to America within two years, two Congressmen said here today.


A.T.&amp;T. Plant Will Be Closed
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it would close a manufacturing plant employing 3,300 workers in this central North Carolina city, where it has had operations for more than 40 years.
The factory - part of


Housing Plan Approved In Yonkers Council Vote
LEAD: The City Council took a step tonight that it had long avoided, voting to approve a plan for construction of 200 units of low-income housing in the largely white neighborhoods of east and north Yonkers.


Head of New Division At CPC International
LEAD: CPC International Inc., which makes such household foods as Skippy peanut butter, Knorr soups and Hellman's mayonnaise, announced yesterday that it had established a worldwide consumer foods group and named Richard W. Siebrasse as its president.

The Editorial Notebook; Close Sweatshops, Open Jobs
LEAD: Mass production of ready-made clothes started a century ago in New York City's old tenement ''sweatshops.'' In the wake of tragic fires, business shifted to fireproof elevator factories shoehorned into mid-Manhattan.
Now, suddenly, sweatshops are reappearing in apartment basements all over the city.

INSIDE
LEAD:  Report on Bomber Crash


9 Survive Plane Crash in Colorado Mountains
LEAD: Investigators at the scene of a commuter plane crash yesterday.
The plane, carrying 15 passengers and two crew members, crashed in a mountainous area 10 miles east of Durango.
A survivor, Peter Schauer, walked about one and a half miles through snow four feet deep to a house for help.
Two people, including a 23-month-old girl, were treated and released, five were in good condition, and one was critically injured.


If a Doll Wears an Eye Patch, I Can Too
LEAD: IN 1981, when her 3-year-old son underwent surgery at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, Gail Zayka noticed that pediatric nurses, using teddy bears and medical jargon, often failed to address the real misconceptions and fears of their young patients.

Pop: Daniel Ponce Ensemble
LEAD: LATE last year, Daniel Ponce, a Cuban conga drummer, released ''Arawe,'' one of the most ambitious Latin albums of the decade.
On ''Arawe,'' Mr.
Ponce's band pulls together rhythms and melodic ideas from traditional and pop music all around the Americas: Cuban rumbas, New York jazz and funk, Brazilian samba, Dominican merengue, Puerto Rican bomba and plena, and Yoruba rhythms that look back to West Africa.


U.N. Chief Asks Panel For Mideast Peace Plan
LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar will ask the five permanent members of the Security Council to begin a new Middle East peace initiative modeled on their efforts to end the Iran-Iraq war, according to senior United Nations officials.


Music: Mahler's 9th, by the Philadelphia
LEAD: MAHLER did not believe in moderation as a way of making his musical point.
As an artist, he lived a life of unquiet desperation, both victimized and motivated by a nameless dread.
However, at times in his last completed symphony, the turbulent and emotionally searing No. 9, he seems to be desperately searching for even more immoderate ways to express himself.


Dollar Continues to Tumble And Gold Moves Lower
LEAD: The dollar slipped further in foreign-exchange trading yesterday as worries persisted about the United States trade gap with Japan.


Nets Lose on a Disputed Shot
LEAD: The Golden State Warriors came into Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight with the worst record in the league, including a franchise-record 17 consecutive road losses.
They left with a 103-101 victory, compliments of a fourth-quarter collapse by the Nets, who have the second-worst record in the league.


Cambodia Negotiators Dispute Hanoi's Role
LEAD: A second round of talks on Cambodia began near here today and ran into trouble as both sides insisted on tough conditions to settle the war that has raged in that country since 1978.

Heriditary Link Studied As Colon Cancer Cause
LEAD: Scientists in Japan have found evidence that hereditary predisposition to cancer of the colon and rectum may be a result of a highly complex process involving loss of protective genes on any of several different chromosomes.


Owner of Crane in Collapse Was Fined for '84 Accident
LEAD: The company that owned the crane that collapsed at a construction site at Seton Hall University, killing two workers, was fined for a fatal crane accident in 1984, a Federal inspector said today.


ARTIST DISCOVERS HIS MURAL, REDONE
LEAD: RECENTLY, on his way to a party, the muralist Richard Haas rounded a corner at South Street and Peck Slip in lower Manhattan, and was startled to see that a mural he had painted in 1978 on a Con Edison substation had been changed.


THE DESIGNING PROCESS
LEAD: THE thin line separating design and fashion becomes thinner in April when the American version of Elle, sister of the French fashion magazine, inaugurates a series of features on design and architecture.
The same month, Esquire magazine will also start a design feature, ''Living Quarters.''


Sanofi Drops Bid For A.H. Robins
LEAD: Sanofi S.A. said it was dropping out of the race for the A. H. Robins Company, which made the Dalkon Shield birth control device.


Foreign Trawlers Accused of Violating U.S. Zone
LEAD: Federal officials meeting in Anchorage today began investigating evidence that foreign trawlers may have been fishing illegally in rich American waters off the Aleutian Islands in Alaska.

Some Yields A Bit Lower
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were unchanged to slightly lower for the week ended yesterday.


Report on Adviser to Meese Describes Investment Fraud
LEAD: The investment adviser to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d transmitted ''over $1 million in apparently ill-gotten gains'' from some of his clients to Hong Kong accounts from 1985 to 1987, according to an affidavit by a Federal investigator looking into Mr.
Meese's affairs.

Crazy Eddie Reports a Loss
LEAD: Crazy Eddie Inc., a financially troubled retailer of electronics products, said yesterday that it had lost $73 million in its third quarter that ended Nov. 29.
In the quarter a year earlier, Crazy Eddie posted net income of $3.7 million.

Ethics Unit Investigating Elections Board
LEAD: The New York State Commission on Government Integrity disclosed yesterday that it is investigating the State Board of Elections as part of its inquiry into campaign contributions to Poughkeepsie Town Board candidates by a shopping mall developer.

Advertising; New Fashion Magazine Fills Its Editor Post
LEAD: Gay Bryant, former editor of Family Circle, is now editor of Model, a fashion and beauty magazine for a younger crowd that will make its debut in June as a joint venture between Family Media and Times Mirror Magazines, with Family Media managing the show.


Two Fords Discuss Goals
LEAD: Edsel B. Ford and William Clay Ford Jr. say they want to be treated like any other mid-level executives at the Ford Motor Company.


Japanese Cut 'Last Emperor'
LEAD: When Bernardo Bertolucci's epic ''The Last Emperor'' opens in Japan on Saturday it will not be quite the same film that audiences in the United States and Europe got to see.


Soviet Official Says Press Harms Army
LEAD: The Soviet Defense Minister, in a rare television appearance, has sharply criticized the Soviet press for undermining public respect for the Soviet Army.


George D. Clahr, 53, A Contact Lens Expert
LEAD: George D. Clahr, a New York City ophthalmologist and expert in the use of soft contact lenses, died of cancer of the colon yesterday at his home in New Milford, Conn.
He was 53 years old.


OLD CRAFTS, NEW LAMPS
LEAD: JACK CUNNINGHAM makes early-American lamps the way craftsmen made things 150 years ago.
He uses many of the tools used in the 19th century to trim the metal and fold the pieces together, and hand-solders each joint -as many as 75 in one lamp.


Final Seconds in a B-1's Cockpit Are Pieced Together by Air Force
LEAD: It took less than three minutes for a new B-1 bomber to crash into the Colorado desert last September after it struck a bird the size of a turkey that ripped through electrical, hydraulic and fuel lines to ignite a catastrophic fire.


College Basketball; Kentucky Shocked By Florida, 58-56
LEAD: Vernon Maxwell scored 19 points and Dwayne Schintzius added 18 tonight as Florida, despite going scoreless over the final 3 minutes 24 seconds, upset Kentucky, 58-56, in a Southeastern Conference game.


Illegal Contributiaons to Hart Reported
LEAD: Gary Hart faced new allegations today about the finances of his 1984 and 1988 Presidential campaigns but asserted he had no knowledge of any possible wrongdoing.

Assassinated Leaders
LEAD: To the Editor:


World Soybean Output
LEAD: The world output of soybeans in 1987-88 is smaller than had been forecast, according to an Agriculture Department report on Tuesday.
World production was estimated at 101 million metric tons, down 1.4 million tons from last month's forecast.


BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JANUARY 21, 1988
LEAD:  Markets


Washington Talk: Football and the Gourmet; Some Hot Recipes From Red Hot 'Skins
LEAD: A newly published Washington cookbook gives top billing to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d for 12 recipes submitted by his wife, Ursula, who admits her husband is no whiz in the kitchen.


Zimbabwe Share Prices
LEAD: Industrial share prices hit record levels on the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange this week, passing an index figure not seen since the country's first year of independence.
The index measuring price movements for shares of the 50 industrial companies listed on the exchange hit 487.2 Monday, its highest level in seven years, then rose further Tuesday to 488.5.

George F. McGrath, 70, Is Dead; Ex-Correction Chief in New York
LEAD: George F. McGrath, New York City Commissioner of Correction in the Linday administration and an authority on penology, died yesterday at his home in Boston.
He was 70 years old.


Advertising; A Captive Audience for Magazine
LEAD: COPIES of Harrowsmith magazine will suddenly appear in waiting rooms of doctors, dentists and even some veterinarians across the country next month under the sponsorship of General Foods.


Eurobond Deal By G.M.A.C.
LEAD: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering $200 million of 8 3/4 percent noncallable Eurobonds due 1991 at 101 1/8 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley International.


The Greatest Tragedy
LEAD: It couldn't have happened at a more appropriate time than the eve of the Martin Luther King birthday observances: Jimmy Snyder, a sports tipster known also as The Greek, was fired from his television job for a number of remarks claiming that blacks had been bred since the Civil War to be better athletes than whites.

STARTS IN HOUSING TUMBLE BY 16.2%, WORST IN 3 YEARS
LEAD: Housing starts plunged an unexpectedly steep 16.2 percent in December, the sharpest monthly decline in more than three years, the Commerce Department said yesterday.


EXCHANGE STUDIES SUSPENDING TRADE IN VOLATILE STOCKS
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange will consider a proposal to halt trading temporarily in individual stocks if their prices rise or fall by a certain amount, the exchange's chairman, John J. Phelan Jr., said in an interview yesterday.


10 Killed in Taiwan Crash
LEAD: Ten people died when a Taiwan Airlines commuter plane crashed into a mountain on Orchard Island, 170 miles southeast of Taipei, the Government said today.
One man survived.
The British-built Britten-Norman 2, a propeller-driven plane, had taken off Tuesday morning from the fishing port of Taitung, 160 miles south of Taipei, for a 20-minute flight to Orchid Island.

LEAD: ONE thing that fascinated this sympathetic neophyte on a recent three-week dash through Southeast Asia was the varied ways in which traditional performing arts are being preserved and offered to the public.

AFTER SPACE MARATHON, SOVIET ASTRONAUT LAUDS EXERCISE PLAN
LEAD: A strict and ''very monotonous'' new exercise regimen by a Soviet astronaut paid off in a smooth and relatively quick readjustment to Earth's gravity after 326 days in space, the astronaut, Col.
Yuri V. Romanenko, said today.

LEAD: Janice Raskin, a singer who performed on radio programs, died of colon cancer yesterday at a nursing home in Del Mar, Calif.
She was 77 years old.


The Stage: Alaskan Myth, 'Summer Face Woman'
LEAD: ''THE Summer Face Woman,'' Dave Hunsaker's meditation on Aleut history and mythology, begins with a nifty nugget of musical humor, as six of its cast members gather to sing a rock-and-roll version of Johnny Horton's 1960 hit, ''North to Alaska.'' The sight of a group of actor-singers who include several Alaska natives joining together in a tune that celebrates Alaskan territory as a new American frontier ripe for conquest, sets us up for a bracing indictment of marauding exploitation.

The American Family Is Adjusting To Teen-Agers' Work-Spend Ethic
LEAD: LaDONNIA FULLMER, a 17-year-old high school senior in Los Altos, Calif., works 25 hours a week and earns $500 a month doing housework and baby-sitting.
She has an A average. ''My parents can't afford to pay for me to buy the clothes I want or to go out with friends,'' she said. ''I wouldn't have to work if I didn't want any of those things.


Film: 'Half of Heaven,' From Spain
LEAD: ''HALF OF HEAVEN,'' the appealing Spanish movie that begins a run at the Lincoln Plaza Cinema today, is a quiet comedy, a low-temperature romance, a matter-of-fact fantasy.
It's all about Rosa, a cheerful, affectionate, diligent girl who works her way up from the family farmhouse to running Madrid's most fashionable restaurant.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. There are cracks in a ceiling of our 1867 house.
One contractor says the plaster has separated from the lath and recommends that the entire ceiling be taken down and replastered.
A second contractor says that the plaster may have separated only in some areas, and that if he tapes the cracks, smooths out the plaster and inserts long screws into the beams, the ceiling will hold.

Children Cited In Donations To Neediest
LEAD: Emma Myers, 4 years old, of Brooklyn saw homeless people every day and wanted to do something for poor children.
Her mother, Susan B. Myers, told her about The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, and they sent a gift of $10.


New Envoy: Native Son For Vienna
LEAD: A new American Ambassador, Henry Anatole Grunwald, presented his credentials today to President Kurt Waldheim.


New York Area Costs in '87 Up 5.9%
LEAD: Consumer prices for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose slightly in December, ending 1987 on a ''welcome quiet note'' after a 12-month increase of 5.9 percent, the largest in six years, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of labor statistics, said yesterday.


Washington Talk: Foreign Press Corps; Lively Beat Keeps Visitors on Toes
LEAD: While some merchants of doom see the United States as a waning power in the world, up against mounting economic and political competition from Asia and Europe, there are those who find the daily happenings of this capital city of ever more interest.

LEAD: ''The Lost Lennon Tapes,'' a yearlong weekly radio series, begins this week on stations associated with the Westwood One Radio Network.
Culled from more than 300 hours of John Lennon's taped archives, the series includes interviews, unreleased recordings (including an acoustic-guitar version of ''Strawberry Fields''), songs in various stages of development, jam sessions and other material - some of it dating back to the Quarrymen, Lennon's band before the Beatles - that was made available by Yoko Ono,

Rosewood Buys 6% Stake in Cronus
LEAD: Rosewood Financial Inc., an investment concern controlled by the Texas investor Caroline Rose Hunt, has purchased a 6 percent stake in Cronus Industries' 5.38 million shares outstanding.


Relief Convoy Ambushed
LEAD: Rebels ambushed a convoy in northern Ethiopia last Friday and burned seven trucks carrying food for famine victims, relief officials said today.
Guerrillas of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front attacked a column of trucks on the road from the port of Massawa to Asmara, the capital of Eritrea Province, the officials said.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Too Good a Cleanup?
LEAD: When new Presidents move into the White House, they invariably denude it of any reminders of their predecessors, Stuart E. Eizenstat, the former Presidential aide to Jimmy Carter, was saying yesterday.


Rockwell Picks 2 in Shuffle
LEAD: The Rockwell International Corporation said today that it would combine its aerospace and space operations and realign the responsibilities of two executives, adjustments that reflect the conclusion of B-1 bomber production.

LEAD: Denis Potvin, the Islander defenseman, was among 13 players added to the Wales Conference all-star team by Coach Mike Keenan of Philadelphia yesterday.

'Top Gun and Beyond,' on Pilots
LEAD: ''NOVA'' flies in fighter jets tonight: ''Top Gun'' with a sense of purpose.
In fact, the program is called ''Top Gun and Beyond.'' What happens when air technology becomes so complex it exceeds a pilot's ability to use it? ''Nova,'' on Channel 13 at 10 P.M., says there are problems; it also says that jets need pilots.

LEAD: The Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame moved into rock's second generation last night.
The Beatles, Bob Dylan, the Beach Boys, the Supremes and four members of the Drifters were inducted at the third annual hall of fame ceremony, a black-tie dinner at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel's Grand Ballroom, with speeches, tributes and a closing jam session.

Sports People; Olympic Director Quits
LEAD: In an unexpected move, Harvey Schiller resigned yesterday as executive director of the United States Olympic Committee, less than three weeks after he succeeded George Miller in the position.

Grounded Ship Stalls Carter and Hundreds
LEAD: Former President Jimmy Carter and nearly 2,000 fellow passengers finally left on a Caribbean cruise today after being delayed nearly 24 hours by a grounded freighter that trapped their cruise liner in San Juan Harbor.


Icahn Goes to Court To Pitch Texaco Plan
LEAD: Carl C. Icahn, the largest shareholder of Texaco Inc., came to Federal Bankruptcy Court here today to try to persuade a judge to allow his bankruptcy reorganization proposal to go to the company's shareholders for consideration.


Pacemaker Use Questioned
LEAD: One in five of all the pacemakers implanted in patients by doctors in one city were clearly not needed and about a third of them were of uncertain value, according to a review of medical records from 1983.

LEAD: The Rev.
Al Sharpton, a Brooklyn minister who has organized civil disobedience demonstrations and has frequently criticized the city's predominantly white political leadership, assisted law-enforcement officials in at least one recent criminal investigation of black community groups, Government sources said.


Role of Child's Sex In Divorce
LEAD: Sexism plays a role even in divorces, with the parents of sons less likely to separate than the parents of daughters, according to a new study.

LEAD: A jury has fined three former directors of the defunct First Maryland Savings and Loan $100 million each for mismanagement and fraud that contributed to the thrift institution's collapse in 1985.

LEAD: Delegates from the make-believe world of the theater and a real-life former delegate from the world of nuclear arms negotiations faced each other in an unusual encounter a few mornings ago during a rehearsal of ''A Walk in the Woods.'' Alan Patricof Sets Deal to Sell Details
LEAD: Advance Publications, the magazine company that owns The New Yorker, has agreed to acquire Details, the avant-garde fashion magazine, from Alan Patricof, head of Alan Patricof Associates, which is a venture capital group, and a group of investors.
S.
I.
Newhouse Jr., whose family owns Conde Nast Publications Inc., is chairman of Advance.


Abdul Ghaffar Khan, 98, a Follower of Gandhi
LEAD: Abdul Ghaffar Khan, a Moslem disciple of Mohandas K. Gandhi who opposed British rule in India and partition of the subcontinent, died yesterday in a hospital in Peshawar, Pakistan.
He was 98 years old and had suffered a stroke six months ago.


Child Molester Attacks 15th Victim, Girl, 9
LEAD: A child molester with a mustache and pock-marked face who preys on Queens schoolgirls attacked his 15th victim on Tuesday, the police said yesterday.


A Haitian Opposition Leader Is Seized After Tour Abroad
LEAD: With Haitians awaiting an announcement on the results of the flawed presidential election three days ago, the authorities detained a prominent opposition leader today as he returned home from an anti-Government campaign abroad.


AN UPDATE ON 'THE COSBY SHOW'
LEAD: IS he running out of steam?
Has he peaked?
How far can a megastar slip before he becomes an ordinary superstar again?
The subject is, of course, William H. Cosby Jr., comedian, actor, writer, producer and, according to some estimates, the top money-earning performer in these United States.
But suddenly the Bill Cosby media machine is showing signs of strain.


Dance: City Ballet Performs Robbins's 'Fanfare'
LEAD: JEROME ROBBINS is at his brightest and most goofily amusing in ''Fanfare.'' And the ballet received a correspondingly bright and funny performance on Tuesday, when the New York City Ballet presented it at the New York State Theater.

LEAD: CHITA RIVERA, the dancer and singer, is opening a new restaurant today at 444 West 42d Street that looks like a Broadway set of a New York restaurant: vivid, spirited, capable of delivering a slightly heightened experience along with grilled steak.

Pop: Houserockers, Blues
LEAD: THE ghosts of the blues guitarists Magic Sam and Freddie King swirled around the room Tuesday for the Abilene Houserockers, a blues trio.
At their first set at Mondo Cane, 205 Thompson Street, where they play regularly, the Houserockers worked their way through Texas-styled guitar instrumentals, and blues and soul standards, including Magic Sam's ''All of Your Love'' and Little Willie John's ''Fever.


Ex-CBS Chairman Tells of Takeover
LEAD: Thomas H. Wyman, the former chairman of CBS Inc., said yesterday that the 1986 assumption of management control by Laurence A. Tisch was a brilliantly plotted and executed takeover at bargain prices, and not the friendly management change it was depicted to be.


Old-Fashioned Dance
LEAD: Dennis O'Connor and Ann Papoulis will present ''Leonard and Cinciana,'' which they describe as a ''retro comedia de la danza,'' on Jan. 28 at 8:30 at At the World, 254 East Second Street.
The piece, conceived and performed by Mr.
O'Connor, a member of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, and Ms.
Papoulis, the choreographer, has a score by John King that will be performed live and a set by Cis Bierinckx.


Youths Finding Success Elusive Without College
LEAD: American youths who do not go to college are as eager to succeed in the work force as their college-bound peers, but they are facing increasing difficulties in finding good jobs, according to a report released today.

LEAD: Senator Jesse Helms, a leading opponent of the recently signed treaty eliminating American and Soviet medium-range missiles, asserted today that it must be amended before it can be approved by the Senate.

Knicks Can't Elude Another Roadblock
LEAD: Xavier McDaniel produced career-highs of 41 points and 18 rebounds in leading the Seattle SuperSonics to their 16th straight home victory, a 108-96 triumph over the Knicks tonight.


Redmen Shoot Down Hoyas
LEAD: St.
John's needed big performances from its top three guns tonight, and this is how they responded: Michael Porter scored and soared for a game-high 21 points; Shelton Jones added 16 points with 14 rebounds; and Boo Harvey scored 9 points and guided the Redmen offense through Georgetown's vaunted press.


Flores Steps Down As Raider Coach
LEAD: Tom Flores stepped down today as head coach of the Los Angeles Raiders after nine seasons, and speculation over a successor flared up immediately.


HIGH COURT BARS EXPELLING DISTURBED PUPILS
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled today that public schools may not expel or remove disruptive, emotionally disturbed students from their classrooms for more than 10 days, even to protect others from physical assault, without the permission of the parents or a judge.

LEAD:  General Assembly


In Sandinista Wall, Cracks Revealed
LEAD: Nicaragua's effort to comply with the Central American peace accord has accentuated differences within the Sandinista leadership, according to diplomats and Sandinista officials.

FRENCH NAVY AIDS A FOREIGN TANKER
LEAD: France appears to have altered its rules of military engagement in the Persian Gulf, announcing today that one of its warships intervened to stop an Iranian attack on a non-French tanker flying a Liberian flag last weekend.


Israelis Said to Kill 3 Guerrillas
LEAD: Israeli troops killed three Palestinian guerrillas early today, moments after the guerrillas cut a security fence on the northern border and slipped into Israel, apparently to mount an attack.


Change Seen In Limits on Soviet Trade
LEAD: The Western allies and Japan are expected to agree next week to fewer but more rigorously enforced curbs on exports to the Soviet Union, American and European officials said today.


Sports People; Comings and Goings
LEAD: Now that Bob Horner has signed with the St.
Louis Cardinals after playing one season with the Yakult Swallows of the Central League in Japan, the Swallows have responded by signing Doug DeCinces, a 37-year-old third baseman who batted .234 last year with California and St.
Louis, and Terry Harper, a 32-year-old outfielder who hit .246 with Detroit and Pittsburgh in 1987.


Kennedy Backs Extension in Sale of The Post if Deal Emerges
LEAD: Senator Edward M. Kennedy said yesterday that he ''would have no objection'' to extending Rupert Murdoch's March 6 deadline on selling The New York Post if such an extension is needed ''to complete the sale.''


Consumer Prices Rose 4.4% in 1987
LEAD: Consumer prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent in December, a modest finish to a year in which inflation at the retail level climbed 4.4 percent, the fastest pace in six years, the Labor Department reported today.


'Password' Winner's Logic
LEAD: Kerry Ketchem, the 36-year-old former Air Force airman who was arrested on mail fraud charges after trying to collect $58,600 in prize money he won on the television show ''Super Password,'' sent a Mailgram to the show's producer yesterday saying he deserved the money and had provided the show with ''priceless free publicity.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A picture on Jan. 2 with a review of the New York Philharmonic's Dec. 31 concert was published in error.
The picture, distributed by the orchestra last month, showed the New Year's Eve concert of 1984.
It was reissued to publicize Zubin Mehta and Kathleen Battle, who were once again appearing with the orchestra on the holiday, but it was imprecisely labeled.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column in Business Day yesterday described the appointment of J. Charles Taney Jr. incorrectly.
He is president of FCB/Leber Katz


FRANK GEHRY REALLY LOVES FISH
LEAD: THE question seems to come up at dinners among architects just when the fish course is being served: can the Los Angeles architect Frank Gehry really be designing a high-rise office tower in the shape of a fish to be built on the present Madison Square Garden site?


Legal Limits on Young Workers
LEAD: FEDERAL and state laws restrict the kinds of jobs that teen-agers may hold and the number of hours they may work.
But enforcement is ''virtually nil,'' according to Dorianne Beyer, general counsel for the National Child Labor Committee, a nonprofit agency that examines youth-employment policy.


Personal Health
LEAD: The lineup of dental products in drugstores is becoming as dazzling as the cereal aisle in a supermarket.
Fifty dentrifices, a score of mouth rinses and dozens of mechanical devices greet the shopper eager to have sweet-smelling breath, no cavities and, above all, no tartar or plaque.


PRESIDENT PRAISES ENRICHED SCHOOL PROGRAM
LEAD: President Reagan traveled today to a suburban Washington school that has the kind of program he favors to achieve school integration.
He praised the plan and announced that he would ask Congress for more money for such programs.


Black vs. Black in South Africa
LEAD: High in the hillside cemetery of Sinathingi, his name on a roughhewn cross, lies the freshly dug grave of Arron Mabuza.
Nearby, in jumbled rows of still newer graves, lie at least three other blacks, perhaps as many as eight or nine, who were killed as they made their way to Mr.
Mabuza's burial shortly before the New Year.


Sports People; Coe's U.S. Indoor Debut
LEAD: Sebastian Coe of Britain, the 1980 and 1984 Olympic 1,500-meter champion, will make his American indoor debut on Feb. 13 in the Vitalis Olympic Invitational meet in East Rutherford, N.J.
Coe will run in the 3,000 meters against Doug Padilla, who is the best American in that event, and Frank O'Mara and Paul Donovan of Ireland, who finished first and second, respectively, last March in the first world indoor championships.


United Technologies' Profit
LEAD: The United Technologies Corporation, led by a strong performance in its power group and in its automotive and wire and cable operations, reported yesterday that it had fourth-quarter earnings of $172.5 million, or $1.32 a share, in contrast to a deficit of $228 million in the corresponding quarter last year.


Tour Presses Family Issues in Campaign
LEAD: A doctor, a television producer and a United States Representative are touring the country to promote what they think should be a central issue in the Presidential election: the status of the family.

Hartford Insurance
LEAD: The Hartford Insurance Group has laid off 400 people and indicated that more cuts might be necessary as the company tries to reduce its costs.
Hartford Insurance employs 9,000 people in Connecticut and 20,000 nationwide.
Donald R. Frahm, its president, said he hoped attrition might offset the need for future layoffs.

LEAD: Pressing for increased airline safety, the Federal Aviation Administration urged today that two ''relatively inexperienced'' pilots not be assigned to the same flight, and it also ordered a tightening of maintenance rules.


Orion Stake Raised
LEAD: Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman of Viacom International Inc., has increased his stake in the Orion Pictures Corporation to 26.1 percent from 25.1 percent.
Analysts said Mr.
Redstone was interested in acquiring Orion's motion picture and television production operations to augment Viacom's cable and movie theater businesses.

Marvin F. Camillo, 51, Is Dead; Started Ex-Convicts' Stage Group
LEAD: Marvin Felix Camillo, the founder and director of the Family, a theater group composed primarily of former prison inmates, died last Saturday in La Rochelle, France, where he had been hospitalized since being injured in an automobile accident this month.
He was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan.

16 Million Layoffs Foreseen By Soviet in Next 12 Years
LEAD: About 16 million workers will be laid off by the year 2000 under Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan for restructuring the Soviet economy, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today.


Administration Lowers Goals on Contra Aid
LEAD: The Reagan Administration, acknowledging that Congressional opposition is intense and growing stronger, is planning to ask for significantly less aid for the Nicaraguan rebels than President Reagan had wanted.

LEAD: Baaron Pittenger has returned to the post of acting executive director of the United States Olympic Committee while a search is begun for a replacement for Harvey Schiller.
Schiller, 48 years old, became executive director less than three weeks ago, but then resigned to return to his job as commissioner of the Southeastern Conference.


Joseph H. Ream, 84, A Former CBS Director
LEAD: Joseph H. Ream, a former executive vice president and director of the Columbia Broadcasting System, died of neurological complications from an aneurysm at the Mobile (Ala.) Infirmary Wednesday.
He was 84 years old and lived in Fairhope, Ala.

Stop and Shop To Study Offer
LEAD: The Stop and Shop Companies, responding to an $834 million cash offer from the Dart Group Corporation, was noncommittal yesterday but said it would review the proposal.
The Haft family of Landover, Md., which controls Dart, has long been rumored to be interested in acquiring Stop and Shop, and the Boston-based retailer has taken defensive measures.

LEAD: Treasury bond prices rose nearly a point yesterday in response to a report that the Bank of Japan was considering a large increase in its buying of longer-term Treasury issues.

LEAD: Lawyers and legal scholars said the convening of Federal district judges in Brooklyn in an ''en banc,'' or ''entire bench,'' panel yesterday was exceptionally unusual.

America, Shadowed by Death Squads
LEAD: In an unusual trial under way in Costa Rica, Honduras stands accused of maintaining an army death squad responsible for murdering four people in 1981.
That a special court set up by the Organization of American States is hearing the case sets a powerful precedent - so much so that two key witnesses have now been killed.

Cellular Makes Bid
LEAD: Cellular Communications Inc., based in New York, has begun an unsolicited tender offer for a majority holding in the American Cellular Network Corporation for $15.50 cash a share, or a total of $69.75 million.
The bid was disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
American Cellular builds and owns cellular telephone systems in the Middle Atlantic region from its headquarters in Pleasantville, N.J.


Opera: 'Luisa Miller,' Season's First at Met
LEAD: EXPECT nothing and you will never be disappointed.
That bit of folk wisdom has been the safest shield to carry to the Metropolitan Opera on most evenings this season and certainly it fortified one in advance for the return to the repertory of ''Luisa Miller'' on Wednesday night.

Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr., young women were still doing their darnedest to look like Jacqueline Kennedy and glue-sniffing was an acceptable way to attain a high.

U.S. IS CONSIDERING A NEW INITIATIVE FOR MIDEAST PEACE
LEAD: As a result of the continuing violence in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, the Reagan Administration is conducting internal deliberations on whether the United States should take a more active and visible role in pursuing peace efforts in the Middle East, American officials said today.


ENVISIONING THE SHOW'S HEAVY ARTILLERY
LEAD: IT so happens that I live down the block from the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 66th Street.
For much of the year, I am aware of it as a thickset and bloodshot presence somewhere over my left shoulder.
In my dreams, ensigns straight out of Walt Whitman and sharpshooters straight out of Winslow Homer troop in and out of it.


Nobel Laureates Agree to Meet Again in 1990
LEAD: At the end of four days of deliberations, 75 Nobel laureates decided today to hold another meeting in two years and to create an emergency committee to intervene with moral authority in crises around the world.

LEAD: Facing heavy pressure from officially sanctioned trade unions, the Government said today that it would triple cash payments promised to workers this year to offset planned consumer price increases.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Jan. 6 about sweet potatoes incorrectly described the conversion of beta carotene to vitamin A. It is converted within the body, not in cooking.

Data General Profits Up
LEAD: The Data General Corporation said today that its profits had soared in its fiscal first quarter as shipments rose and cost-cutting efforts took hold.

Surcharge Set For Car Owners In New Jersey
LEAD: To prevent the collapse of the agency that insures more than half of New Jersey's 4 million motorists, all drivers will have to pay a surcharge averaging $66 for each car they own when they renew their insurance policies, the state's Insurance Commissioner said today.


STUDY TRACES AIDS IN AFRICA CHILDREN
LEAD: Nearly one in 15 Central African children receiving blood transfusions to combat malaria-related anemia may become infected with the AIDS virus as a result, a new study has found.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Consumer's World page last Saturday about radar detectors incorrectly described some applications issued by Geico.
Those distributed with mail solicitations specify that Geico does not insure vehicles equipped with radar detectors; all other applications do not.


Zimbabwe Emergency Stays
LEAD: The Government extended its 13-year-old state of emergency for six months today, saying it needed to deal with threats from rebels.
Parliament was told that South African-backed Mozambique National Resistance rebels were responsible for 101 incidents from July 12 to Jan. 4, including murders, abductions and the burning and ransacking of villages.

CRIME STUDY FINDS RECENT DRUG USE IN MOST ARRESTED
LEAD: Half to three-fourths of the men arrested for serious crimes in 12 major cities tested positive for the recent use of illicit drugs, according to a study by the Justice Department.


DIC Deal Opposed
LEAD: Two shareholders of Computer Memories Inc. said they opposed a proposed merger between the computer equipment maker and the cartoon maker DIC Animation City Inc. of Burbank, Calif., and intended to seek control of the company.
Paul and Natalie Koether of Far Hills, N.J., said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that they had increased their interest to 9.7 percent of Computer Memories, based in Chatsworth, Calif.


Genscher Urges Arms Cuts
LEAD: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany urged President Reagan today to press for the elimination of chemical weapons and for reductions of battlefield nuclear weapons in Europe.
Administration officials said that cuts in battlefield nuclear weapons with ranges under 300 miles was a low arms-control priority and that there would be little progress on the chemical arms issue until the United States can verify the destruction of the weapons.


Editors' Note
LEAD: An article from Washington on Wednesday cited a study showing that Pat Robertson's Presidential campaign paid more than $4 million to three consulting companies in the first nine months of 1987.
The article noted that under Federal law, consultants in turn can hire subcontractors in a way that lets a candidate avoid disclosing precisely how the money is spent.

Reinhardt's Hot Club Back in Style
LEAD: FEW jazz legends have a more exotic mystique than Django Reinhardt, the Belgian-born gypsy guitarist and banjo player who led the legendary Parisian ensemble known as the Quintet of the Hot Club of France in the 1930's and 40's.
By the time of his death in 1953, at age 43, he was recognized as one of the three or four most important jazz guitarists in history, and his influence has reverberated from Les Paul, one of his great champions in the 1940's, to Willie Nelson in his nostalgic mode.


Hartford Director Plans O'Neill Play in Moscow
LEAD: Mark Lamos, artistic director of the Hartford Stage Company, will direct Eugene O'Neill's ''Desire Under the Elms'' in Russian at the Pushkin Theater in Moscow.
Rehearsals begin there on Feb. 18.

LEAD: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that its earnings climbed 18.9 percent in the fourth quarter of 1987, buoyed by stronger performances from nearly all of its core businesses.

Market Place; Profit Jump Seen In Paper Industry
LEAD: BUSINESS is booming in the paper industry, particularly for commodity-oriented companies that produce such basic materials as linerboard, bleached board and market pulp.
Price increases are going into effect; production is humming at capacity levels, and the weak dollar has made American producers exceedingly competitive in world markets.

Sports of The Times; Holmes, Ali and Tyson
LEAD: EVER since Larry Holmes agreed to take $3.1 million for taking Mike Tyson's punches, he has been a different Larry Holmes, a hermit in a stylish sweatsuit.
He trained in his own quiet gym in Easton, Pa.
He hardly talked to sportswriters.
He didn't arrive in Atlantic City until 48 hours before he will try to dethrone Tyson as the world heavyweight champion.

City Ballet: 'Jewels'
LEAD: LOOKED at one way, George Balanchine's ''Jewels'' could be called a three-act abstract ballet in which each act evokes qualities associated with a particular jewel.
Looked at another way, it could be argued that ''Jewels'' is not a three-act ballet at all, but three one-act ballets, for each of its parts is self-contained and has music by a different composer.

Record British Spending
LEAD: British consumers spent a record amount in 1987, estimated at $:170.7 billion, or about $305.5 billion, but the boom slowed almost to a halt after the stock market collapse, the Government said today.
The Central Statistical Office said that in the last quarter of 1987, consumers spent only a little more than they did in the third quarter, despite the Christmas shopping.

LEAD: In a carefully choreographed and controlled rally that highlighted the growing frustration among blacks over drugs, almost 500 demonstrators marched yesterday along a circuitous route through some of Brooklyn's most drug- and crime-ridden communties.


TV Weekend; 'Murder of Mary Phagan,' on NBC
LEAD: PERHAPS it's just coincidence, but the subject of anti-Semitism is unusally prominent in television movies these days.
A couple of weeks ago, ABC's ''Evil in Clear River'' dealt with the fact-based story of a neo-Nazi in rural Canada.
On Home Box Office, ''Into the Homeland'' takes a look at white-supremacist hate groups in this country.


Bad Finishes Sink Islanders and Devils; Red Wings 3, Devils 2
LEAD: Sam St.
Laurent, a goaltender the Devils traded to Detroit two summers ago, helped drop New Jersey below the .500 mark for the first time this season as he made 27 saves tonight for the Red Wings, who beat the Devils, 3-2.
Brent Ashton's second goal of the game, scored 3 minutes 37 seconds into overtime, was the difference.


Music: Joshua Ensemble
LEAD: WHATEVER idea was behind the Joshua Chamber Orchestra's evening at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday, it was not a good one.
Two young performers from South Korea - Jeong Soo Kim and Hae Kyung Lee - were its stars, and the music was Prokofiev's ''Classical'' Symphony, Mozart's ''Jupiter'' and the Beethoven Piano Concerto in G.

LEAD: Roy Nathanson on saxophones and Curtis Fowlkes on trombone will lead the Jazz Passengers, tonight at 9 and 11 at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055).
Admission is $6.

Garbage Barge Sinks, Spilling Tons of Trash Into the East River
LEAD: A cleanup crew laying a containment barrier to trap floating debris from a city-owned barge that sank as workers tried to secure it to a pier in the Bronx.
The barge, carrying 703 tons of garbage, was one of four being pushed by a tugboat when it was struck by an empty tanker near Rikers Island.
Authorities said they expected to recover most of the trash.

Stage: 'Sally,' by Kern
LEAD: JEROME KERN'S ''Sally'' was a major musical success in 1920, running for almost two seasons and establishing Marilyn Miller as one of Broadway's most popular stars.
In contrast to other Kern hits, the show is seldom revived.
For that reason, one might suppose that the New Amsterdam Theater Company is performing a service by presenting the quasi-concert version that began a five-performance engagement Wednesday at the New Academy Theater.


Surge in AIDS Cases in Congo Could Be an Omen for africa
LEAD: Jean-Marie Matsiona, a 38-year-old oil tanker navigator, is one of the one million Africans expected to die of AIDS in the next decade.


Jazz Premiere Highlight Of Festival At Juilliard
LEAD: The New York premiere of a work by the jazz saxophonist Ornette Coleman is to highlight the first concert in the Juilliard School's ''Focus!
Festival'' that begins tonight at 8 at Alice Tully Hall.
Five concerts in all are to be presented during the festival, which is free and runs through next Friday.

A JAZZ-DANCE AMALGAM
LEAD: AMERICAN dance has been formed and shaped by choreographers who broke from tradition to follow their own lights.
In the case of Danny Buraczeski, whose jazz dance pieces are being performed by his company this weekend at the Joyce Theater, the break was twofold.
Mr.
Buraczeski, who began dancing as a Japanese major at Bucknell University and went on to Broadway show-dancing, chose to devote himself to choreographing jazz dance, a form that has seldom been taken so seriously.


Fordham Tops Iona With 28 by Parrotta
LEAD: In recent years, whenever Fordham and Iona clashed on the basketball court, two things were virtually guaranteed: an intense atmosphere and an Iona victory.


Jimmy Witherspoon
LEAD: Jimmy Witherspoon, the blues and jazz singer, will perform tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260).
Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

Science Talent Search Names 13 Winners From New York
LEAD: Thirteen students from 6 New York City high schools were among the 40 national winners of this year's Westinghouse Science Talent Search announced yesterday.


Righetti Ready to Sign
LEAD: The Yankees and Dave Righetti have resolved their dispute over the timing of a physical examination, and Righetti is expected to sign his three-year, $4.3 million agreement in New York today, Bill Goodstein, the pitcher's agent, said yesterday.


Pan Am, in a Union Deal, Ousts 2 Top Executives
LEAD: Bending to the pressure of a union coalition, the board of the Pan Am Corporation forced the resignation yesterday of its top two officers and three subordinates.


Horse Racing Notebook; Lottery Could Help Tracks
LEAD: Officials from Florida's horse racing tracks held a news conference in Miami today under the funereal banner of ''Florida Horse Racing Is Facing Extinction.'' There is no such imminent threat, but the officials effectively painted a gloomy picture.


Good Trade Neighbors
LEAD: To the Editor:


Film: 'The Grand Highway,' Childhood in France
LEAD: IN ''The Grand Highway,'' the French director Jean-Loup Hubert gives us his romance with childhood innocence.
The autobiographical story, set in a pretty peasant village in 1958, has the makings of a nostalgic glance backward, full of easy charm and sentimentality.
Louis, an adorable 9-year-old, is sent from Paris to the country for three weeks while his mother has a baby.

Drug Therapy for Professor
LEAD: A municipal judge ordered Glenn C. Loury, a professor at John F. Kennedy School of Government of Harvard University who was charged with posssessing drugs, to continue a program for drug treatment that he has entered since his arrest and to pay $115 in court costs and other fines.

LEAD: Palestinian children returning from their school at the Shatila refugee district yesterday in south Beirut.
On Wednesday, detachments of the Shiite Amal militia and the Sixth Brigade of the Lebanese Army ended a three-year siege.
Syrian troops moved in immediately afterward. (Agence France-Presse)

27 Pit Bulls Are Put to Death
LEAD: Twenty-seven pit bull dogs seized in a raid last month were put to death today after a judge ruled they had been trained for violence.
The dogs belonged to a couple who face cocaine-trafficking charges.
Judge William Green said he issued the order because ''these animals have been bred and trained for no purpose other than to viciously attack other animals.


Film: 'Family,' From Scola
LEAD: ''THE FAMILY,'' directed by the usually perceptive Ettore Scola, recalls 80 years in the life of a large, loving upper-middle-class Roman family.
It begins in 1906 at the baptism of the baby Carlo, lying in the arms of his patrician grandfather (Vittorio Gassman) as the members of the family gather for a group photograph.

Our Towns; Thin Mint Alert: Super Girl Scout Is On the Loose
LEAD: It's that time of year in the suburbs.
The doorbell rings.
You answer.
At first you don't see anything.
You look down and it's a lovely little girl with a million-dollar smile and maybe a ponytail to break your heart.
You smile back - relieved it's not a religious pamphleteer, or even worse, a guy selling meat out of his trunk - and already you have made the fatal mistake.

NBC News Explores Problem of the Homeless
LEAD: Who are the homeless, and why are they on the streets? ''Home Street Home,'' an NBC News special, on Channel 4 at 10 o'clock tonight, offers a number of answers.
That turns out to be its weakness.
Drugs, alcohol, mental illness, post-Vietnam stress, a failing farm economy and an uncaring society are rolled up as one.


Rep. Latta Is Retiring
LEAD: United States Representative Delbert L. Latta said today that he would not run for re-election this November.
Mr.
Latta, a 67-year-old Republican who has been in the House since 1959 and who is a key White House ally on budget matters, said he was retiring to spend more time with his family.


Super Bowl XXII; Monk Works Out With the Redskins
LEAD: Art Monk practiced with the Washington Redskins today for the first time in more than six weeks as the team began preparations for the Super Bowl.

LEAD: Nothing irritates investment bankers more than losing a shot at the huge fees they can earn for arranging major corporate deals.

LEAD: The Ameritech Corporation said yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1987 rose 16.1 percent, to $322.2 million, compared with $277.4 million in the 1986 fourth quarter.

Yevgeny Mravinsky, Conductor, 81
LEAD: Yevgeny Mravinsky, who became the chief conductor of the Leningrad Philharmonic Orchestra in 1938, has died of a heart attack, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.
He was 81 years old.
Tass did not say when or where he died.

Art: Works by 7 Women, 'Aspects of Abstraction'
LEAD: IN ''Aspects of Abstraction,'' the Holly Solomon Gallery has put together the kind of exhibition with which it has not been identified.
All seven artists are women.
All are abstract painters for whom touch and process are important.
All the paintings have an unapologetic, take-it-or-leave-it quality.


Haiti Jails Opposition Leader on Disorder Charge
LEAD: A prominent opposition leader was charged today with inciting public disorder and taken back to jail after a hearing in the Palace of Justice, his lawyer said.

LEAD: From September to December every year, the United Nations stages its annual extravaganza at Turtle Bay.


Profit at Recovering BankAmerica
LEAD: In a further sign that it is recovering from several years of losses caused mainly by bad loans, the BankAmerica Corporation today reported a fourth-quarter net income of $60 million, or 27 cents a share.


Soviet Looks at Lenin's Executed Comrades
LEAD: Soviet publications and films used the anniversary of Lenin's death today to call attention to his contemporaries who were executed under Stalin.


Grumman Appoints New Chief Executive
LEAD: The Grumman Corporation yesterday named John O'Brien, the aerospace company's president since mid-1986, to be its new chief executive.


Big Drop in Jobs in New York City Is Predicted by Its Budget Director
LEAD: New York City will lose more jobs this year - 39,000 - than at any time since its fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's, the city's Budget Director said in a report yesterday.

LEAD: With a winning smile and a friendly wave to her admirers, the Duchess of York, known to most of the world as ''Fergie,'' made her first official visit to New York City last night for a fund-raising performance of Andrew Lloyd Weber's ''The Phantom of the Opera'' benefitting three charities.

LEAD: The first of two concerts featuring Bach cantatas is to be presented by an ensemble with choir and soloists on Sunday at 4 P.M. at the Church of St.
Ann and the Holy Trinity, 157 Montague Street, Brooklyn Heights.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 414 money market mutual funds increased $2.05 billion, to $273.55 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 113 institutional funds increased $616.8 million, to $79.76 billion.
Assets of the 206 general purpose funds were up $79.2 million, to $81.09 billion.


G.S.A. Said to Try to Deflect Inquiry
LEAD: The General Services Administration is attempting to shift the focus of an investigation into possible corruption in the awarding of telephone contracts to the BellSouth Corporation and away from top agency officials, three people familiar with the inquiry said last night.

LEAD: After less than a year's absence the National Dairy Board is returning its Children's Milk Promotion program to McCann-Erickson in San Francisco, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
Billings are about $6.5 million.

LEAD: Judge Anthony Kennedy sailed through his Supreme Court confirmation hearings last month in almost total triumph, and he deserved it.

LEAD: Leland C. Wyman, a scholar in physiology and anthropology who was a leading authority on the culture and history of the Navajo Indians, died here Jan. 13.
He was 90 years old and lived in Brookline, Mass.

LEAD: The cargo of a commercial convoy attacked by rebel forces in northern Ethiopia last week included 176 tons of relief food being sent to drought victims, the State Department said today.

LEAD: A woman convicted in connection with her daughter's suicide was sentenced today to a year in jail, two years of community control and three years of probation.

Werner Nachmann, German Jewish Leader, 62
LEAD: Werner Nachmann, president of the Jewish Council of West Germany, died Thursday of a heart attack.
He was 62 years old.
Mr.
Nachmann, who was born here, fled the Nazi regime for France in 1938 and returned to West Germany in 1945 to rebuild his family's business.

LEAD: The Brown-Forman Corporation, the Louisville, Ky., liquor producer with annual sales of more than $1.4 billion, said that it had agreed to sell its Artcarved jewelry division to the SGI Acquisition Corporation for about $120 million.
Artcarved, which makes diamond engagement rings, wedding rings and scholastic class rings, has operations in New York, Austin, Tex., and P.R.

15 Hindus Killed in Punjab
LEAD: Gunmen believed to be Sikh terrorists killed at least 15 Hindus today in the northern state of Punjab, including Khushi Ram Sharma, vice president of the opposition National Peoples Party, the police said.
The killings came two days after the state's top police official, Julio F. Ribeiro, declared that his troops had captured or killed about 300 Sikh terrorists.

Oslo's Insider Inquiry
LEAD: The Oslo stock exchange said today that it would investigate trading in the shares of Norway's biggest bank to be sure no insider dealing occurred before the bank announced a huge loss.
Insider dealing is a criminal offense in Norway.
The exchange said it would check with dealers, including those at Den Norske Creditbank, because its shares fell sharply on Wednesday just before the bank disclosed that it had a 1987 loss of 1.5 billion kroner, or about $236 million.

LEAD: Throughout December, Shirley Bernard's sixth graders at the Tenafly (N.J.) Middle School gave up desserts, candy, gum, baseball cards and other luxuries.
The pocket money saved from these sacrifices amounted to $37, which was sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Bridge: Overbidders Are Legendary, Unlike Their Quiet Partners

Muslims Start Patrol to Fight Crack in Brooklyn
LEAD: Muslims with walkie-talkies and solemn stares, some of them armed off-duty correction and police officers, have started to patrol part of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn in another initiative to rid the community of crime and drugs, particularly crack.


Back on the Slope
LEAD: Sidelined since Nov. 9 when she suffered a broken leg in a training accident, Tamara McKinney will resume racing at the United States Alpine championships Feb. 4-8, according to a spokesman for the United States Ski Team in Denver.
McKinney, a World Cup skier and the best hope of the United States for an alpine medal at the Winter Olympics in Calgary, will skip the remaining World Cup races in January.

LTU-Boeing Deal
LEAD: A West German charter airline, Lufttransport-Unternehmen, or LTU, ordered three Boeing 767-300 jetliners, for a total of $205 million.
Deliveries to the Dusseldorf-based carrier are to begin in January 1989.
LTU's order was for 767-300ER aircraft, which are a high-gross-weight version of the extended-range airliners that first entered commercial service in October 1986.

How Public Art Is Changing New York City
LEAD: It's a show of art, a show of architecture and a show of urban design.
Most of all, it's a show that vividly portrays and explains the role New York City is playing in what many people say is the largest nationwide public art movement since the Works Progress Administration of the 1930's: ''Percent for Art'' programs in cities, counties and states throughout the United States.

Philharmonic: Haydn's 'Seasons'
LEAD: In terms of sheer creative struggle, ''The Seasons'' is perhaps even more a triumph than Haydn's other great oratorio, ''The Creation.'' The latter was built on a text in which he believed; ''The Seasons'' - with its romantic depictions of peasant labors, loves, hardships and celebrations -was more or less forced on the composer, who remarked to a friend that though he was an industrious man, it seemed strange to be setting industry to music.


Detectives Arrest a Fugitive Diamond Thief
LEAD: A multilingual con man who disappeared from a midtown Manhattan office with $3 million in diamonds two years ago emerged yesterday when investigators caught him trying to repeat the scheme and arrested him, the police said.

NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JANUARY 23, 1988
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL 3-6, 28  Israelis are beating Palestinians under a new army policy.
The policy is designed to end the wave of protests in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip that began in early December.
Page 1  A curfew on an Arab neighborhood in East Jerusalem was imposed by the Israeli police, who invoked emergency powers in the city for the first time since East Jerusalem was annexed in 1967.

Rushing to N.F.L.?
LEAD: Craig Heyward, Pitt's all-America tailback, has not attended classes this semester and has told friends he wants to play in the National Football League next season, according to published reports.

Fine Print and the Cost of Car Rental
LEAD: Renting a car in the New York City area for a week costs $49 to $145 above the advertised or quoted price, according to a review of the car-rental industry by the Better Business Bureau.


Correction
LEAD: A picture caption in The Living Section on Jan. 6 about Les Chefs de France, a restaurant at Epcot Center in Orlando, Fla., misidentified the Disney character greeting visitors.
It was Pluto.


SPORTS PEOPLE;
LEAD: The Philadelphia Phillies signed Lance Parrish to a one-year contract yesterday for $1 million plus incentives.
Last spring, Parrish signed an $800,000 contract that provided an additional $200,000 if he played the first half of the season without going on the disabled list.
The Phillies guarded against a recurrence of a back problem that caused Parrish to miss the last half of the 1986 season with the Detroit Tigers.


McDonnell to Pay U.S. In Overcharging Case
LEAD: A division of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation yesterday agreed to pay the Goverment $1.6 million to settle allegations that it overcharged on Air Force contracts.

Newspaper Merger Planned
LEAD: The Columbia Record, the afternoon newspaper in South Carolina's capital city, will cease publication after the April 1 issue and its staff will be merged into its sister morning newspaper, The State, the newspapers' publisher announced Wednesday.
The publisher, Ben R. Morris, told the newspapers' 650 employees that no layoffs were planned.

LEAD: ''What should be obvious to everyone here is that racism breeds hatred and hatred breeds racism and it is a vicious circle.'' - Justice Thomas A. Demakos of State Supreme Court in Queens.  [ 1:4. ]


Prices Set for Eagle Cars
LEAD: The Chrysler Motors Corporation has announced firm prices for its Premier four-door sedans, the first models to be sold under the No. 3 auto maker's new Eagle nameplate.
The manufacturer's suggested retail price for the 1988 Eagle Premier LX is $12,274, and for the Eagle Premier ES, $14,079, Chrysler said.

Firefighters Strike in Dublin
LEAD: Firefighters went on strike here today for the first time in 20 years, and 300 soldiers trained for firefighting and emergency services handled emergency calls.
Talks between the 800 firefighters and the city broke down early today.
The dispute is over staffing, training and what the firefighters' unions say are breaches of wage agreements.


Devils Frustrated And Penalized, 7-3
LEAD: The Devils fell behind by two goals in the first period tonight and never recovered, losing their fourth consecutive game, a 7-3 decision to the Buffalo Sabres.

Center Is Suspended
LEAD: The Minnesota North Stars' Dennis Maruk, a center, was suspended by the National Hockey League for cross-checking Wendel Clark of Toronto in the forehead on Jan. 13.
A cut on Clark's forehead required seven stitches.
Maruk, who has 6 goals and 3 assists in 15 games, will begin his suspension tonight with Minnesota's game at Hartford.


Parker W. Fennelly Dies at 96; Was Actor in Radio, Film and TV
LEAD: Parker W. Fennelly, who played Titus Moody, the cryptic New Englander, on the Fred Allen radio program in the 1940's and early 1950's, and who was later the television spokesman for Pepperidge Farm products, died yesterday at his home in Peekskill, N.Y.
He was 96 years old.
Mr.
Fennelly, who retired at 85, was known especially for his portrayals of old Yankee characters, whose accent he knew well; he was born and raised in Northeast Harbor on Mount Desert Island,


Contain AIDS by Treating Addicts
LEAD: New York City has long had to cope with crimes committed by its 200,000 heroin addicts to finance drug purchases.
Now the addicts pose a new danger.
By sharing the needles they use to shoot up, they spread AIDS.
Mayor Koch deserves praise for recognizing the need to increase the city's drug treatment capacity.


Unwanted Lottery Ticket Brings Holder $10 Million
LEAD: A bartender won $10 million in the Illinois lottery after hitting the wrong button on a computer and dispensing $50 worth of unwanted tickets that she had to buy herself.

Sermon at the Coal Pits: A Britain for Workers
LEAD: By 9 P.M. on Thursday, the Arthur Scargill gospel hour had begun at the Maltby Miners Welfare Club in this south Yorkshire coal-mining town.


15 Killed at Afghan Rites for Pathan Leader
LEAD: Two bombs exploded today during the funeral of Abdul Ghaffar Khan, the Pathan leader who preached nonviolent resistance to British rule in India and opposed the partition of the subcontinent.
The United News of India reported 15 people were killed and witnesses said 25 were wounded.

LEAD: An estimated 50,000 people demonstrated here today against abortion on the 15th anniversary of the Supreme Court decision legalizing it.

LEAD: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation today reported a fourth-quarter profit of nearly $113.7 million, or 72 cents a share, up from a steep loss posted in the period a year earlier.

LEAD: To preserve the millions of crumbling books, newspapers and maps that are slowly disintegrating because of the high-acid content of their paper, the New York Public Library has established a new state-of-the art laboratory in the cellar of the central research library on Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

LEAD: Men in George Balanchine's ballets often yearn after mysterious women.
So it was no surprise that Bart Cook yearned after Maria Calegari in Balanchine's ''Variations Pour une Porte et un Soupir,'' which the New York City Ballet presented Thursday night at the New York State Theater.


Security-Blanket Surrogates
LEAD: If urban life seems more crowded these days, one reason may be the Big Pack - that 4-by-4-foot, 20-pound pouch swinging from just about every other shoulder in downtown America.
Big Packs, riding high on crowded buses or trains, broadside fellow travelers, jam automatic doors, crush ribs.


Icahn Plan For Texaco Ruled Out
LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge ruled yesterday that Carl C. Icahn, Texaco's largest shareholder, cannot send his version of a bankruptcy reorganization plan for Texaco to other shareholders for their consideration.

LEAD: Pueblo International Inc., an operator of supermarkets in Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands and Florida, said that it had entered into a definitive agreement for a leveraged buyout by a company consisting of a subsidiary of First Boston and members of Pueblo's management.
