U.S. Cites Aid to Manila
LEAD: The United States is committed to helping the Philippine economic recovery by stepping up investments, keeping its doors open to imports and maintaining aid flows, United States Ambassador Nicholas Platt said today.
He told a meeting of American business executives that the Philippines had a trade surplus of $640 million with the United States in 1987 compared with a surplus of $461 million in 1986.


Chrysler in Europe
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation's return to Europe after nine years' absence will begin in March with a program to sell cars in five nations, a spokesman said in Paris.
Alexander Demuth said that Chrysler was initially planning to sell in West Germany, which is Europe's largest car market; Belgium; Switzerland; the Netherlands, and Austria.


A Bad Judgment on a Good Law
LEAD: A divided Federal appeals court panel has ruled that there can be no special Federal prosecutor independent of the executive branch.
This country is in trouble if the judgment stands.

LEAD: Paul Azinger, who won three PGA Tour events last year and was the runner-up in the British Open, birdied six holes on the back nine at Indian Wells today and shot a seven-under-par 65.
That gave him a 200, 16 shots under par, for a share of the lead after three rounds of the 90-hole Bob Hope Chrysler


Belgian Dispute to Court
LEAD: Societe Generale de Belgique S.A., the subject of a takeover bid by the Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti, said today that it had initiated court proceedings to counter Mr. de Benedetti.
Rene Lamy, governor of Societe Generale, Belgium's largest holding company, refused to elaborate on the nature of the proceedings before the Brussels commercial court.

CORRECTION
LEAD: An Article on Jan. 2 about the expiration of British copyrights to ''Peter Pan'' incompletely described the status of the United States copyrights to J. M. Barrie's work.
The novel ''Peter Pan'' entered the public domain in the United States in 1986.
The play ''Peter Pan'' is still protected under copyright in the United States.


Music: Concordia Opens Its Fourth Season
LEAD: Concordia: A Chamber Symphony, a group of freelance orchestral musicians founded by the conductor Marin Alsop, opened its fourth season Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall.
Concordia has shown a penchant for interesting programming and has been generally well received.
But Thursday's concert was not very successful.


Flying for Less: The Search for a Seat at the Best Possible Fare
LEAD: The lowest air fare between Los Angeles and San Antonio was about $125 last fall.
So when Diana Homer's supermarket in Northridge, Calif., offered shoppers $89 coupons for use on any domestic Continental Airlines flight, she bought four coupons for the family's Christmas trip to San Antonio.

Parliament in Vienna Bars a Waldheim Talk
LEAD: Parliament decided today that President Kurt Waldheim will not deliver an address on the 50th anniversary of Hitler's takeover of Austria, but a Government commission decided to ask him to address another assembly.


Bond Yields Continue to Decline
LEAD: Prices of fixed-income securities continued to rise and their yields declined further yesterday, despite some brief flurries of pre-weekend profit taking.
While prices of Treasury coupon issues finished below the best levels of the day, the gains for the session and week were impressive.

LEAD: A Federal judge declared a mistrial yesterday in the nine-month-old racketeering and drug trial of Gene Gotti and nine co-defendants.

Guidepost; Lighting Homes
LEAD: There are new ways to light homes during the long, dark days of winter, including low-wattage bulbs that use less electricity, and incandescent and halogen bulbs that last longer.
Halogen bulbs are more efficient because their quartz cases allow the tungsten filaments to burn at a higher temperature.

Stake in Orion Up
LEAD: For the second time in less than a week, John W. Kluge, the chairman of the Metromedia Corporaiton, has increased his stake in the Orion Pictures Corporation.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr.
Kluge said he had raised his stake in Orion to 23 percent from 21.9 percent, purchasing 176,200 additional Orion shares in the open market for prices ranging from $12.125 to $12.875 a share.

Kodak Agrees to Buy Sterling for $5.1 Billion
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Sterling Drug Inc. for about $5.1 billion, forcing an end to a competing hostile offer from Hoffmann-La Roche &amp; Company.


Europe's Inflation Rate
LEAD: Consumer prices in the 12 member countries of the European Community edged up a tenth of a percent in December to an average of 3.2 percent for 1987, Eurostat, the community's statistical service, reported today.


U.S. CHOOSES MARTIN MARIETTA FOR SIMULATION OF 'STAR WARS'
LEAD: The Martin Marietta Corporation won a contract yesterday to take the lead in developing a billion-dollar ''Star Wars'' computer complex.
The complex would be able to simulate strategic defense systems and evaluate whether it is technically possible to repel a nuclear attack.


Mary Brosnan Kratschmer, Mannequin Designer,81
LEAD: Mary Brosnan Kratschmer, a former designer and manufacturer of mannequins, died of cancer of the spine Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital.
She was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Caracas Journal; A President, a Liaison and a Lot of Political Clout
LEAD: When President Jaime Lusinchi took office in early 1984, his longtime liaison with his private secretary, Blanca Ibanez, seemed nothing out of the ordinary for a country where the extramarital relationships of prominent politicians have traditionally been heralded as signs of virility.


Paris and Bonn Set Up Military Link
LEAD: France and West Germany marked the 25th anniversary of their friendship treaty today by creating a joint military council and the legal basis for a French-German brigade.
The leaders of the two nations also announced the formation of an advisory council to coordinate their economic policies.

Tricentrol Fight
LEAD: The British oil group Tricentrol P.L.C. said it might seek the aid of a friendly company to fight a hostile bid by the French oil giant Elf Aquitaine.
But Tricentrol's chairman, James Longcroft, who has urged shareholders to reject Elf's offer of $:134.7 million, or about $240 million, said a friendly suitor was not now under consideration.

LEAD: In following through today on its announced plans to make a hostile tender offer for E-II Holdings Inc., American Brands Inc. appears to be hoping that it can dissuade E-II from making its threatened bid for American Brands.


Viola Honored
LEAD: As a sophomore at East Meadow High School he played first base and hit .288.
As a junior he hit .333, and after switching to pitching at midseason, went 5-0.
As a senior he boosted his batting average to .413 and turned in a 10-1 record.
Those were pretty good statistics, but when he was graduated in 1978, nobody thought about retiring his jersey number.

Volvo Expansion
LEAD: The Swedish car maker A.B.
Volvo, which has just reported record profits, says it will be on the lookout in 1988 for companies to buy in North America and Europe. ''Volvo is seeking companies in the United States and Europe, and is particularly keen to crack the West German market in terms of sales,'' Volvo's finance director, Lennart Jeansson, said in an interview.

Zev Vilnay, Geographer, 87
LEAD: Zev Vilnay, a geographer and author of an authoritative guidebook to Israel, died Thursday.
He was 87 years old.
His ''Israel Guide,'' published in 1955, went through 24 editions and was translated into many languages.


BellSouth May Give Up Federal Phone Contract
LEAD: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that it had offered to give up a Government telephone contract because its employees might have used secret bid information belonging to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to win the contract.

WADING RIVER TRIES TO RETAIN TRANQUIL PACE
LEAD: FOR more than 300 years, since the first eight families settled here, residents of Wading River, a community that depends on others for government, have enjoyed the rural flavor of farm stands, a local general store, open fields and country roads.
But a spurt of growth in the last decade is threatening to change the bucolic character of this waterfront community, and is generating a good deal of concern.

OUR TOWNS AND CHANGE
LEAD: Sharlene A. McEvoy asked what happened to ''Our Town'' as it appeared in Thornton Wilder's 1938 play.
Her answer was that it was ''ravaged by hordes of greedy developers'' and changed to ''their town.'' My answer is a little different.
It is 50 years later and ''our town'' has changed quite a bit.

LEAD: THE Museum of Cartoon Art's castle was already cracking when this reviewer first saw it almost a decade ago.
Now, the concrete edifice, which is on Comly Avenue in Rye Brook, has plastic protecting part of an outside wall and wood beams shoring up its curving colonnade.
These and other temporary measures cost $30,000, said the museum's curator, Sherman Krisher, who added that ''the building is collapsing faster than we can raise money for the radical surgery that it needs.

I wanted to get everybody's ear.
I had in mind a book for people familiar with America, with the technique and history of the novel - a book that audience could appreciate and applaud and relate to the Great Traditions, if there really are such things.

Southwestern Breakfasts
LEAD: BREAKFAST MAY BE THE FIRST meal of the day, but lately it has seemed last in our affections.
The crackle and spatter of eggs, bacon and sausage on the griddle have become a casualty of hectic schedules and the latest diet plan.
Breakfast seems to have lost its esthetic and psychological properties - warm, sustaining food shared by the family early in the day's labor - to become, at best, an injection of nutrients.

LEAD: The Army, in a move that could drive up expenses for the other armed services, has reportedly decided it will not buy a combat aircraft designed to take off and land like a helicopter but fly like an airplane.


CORRECTION
LEAD: A caption on Jan. 10 incorrectly attributed the lithograph ''Elfriede Mahler, Dance.'' The artist was Marguerite Doernbach.


UNMOVED BY TAX CUTS: Underground Economy Is Not Rising To the Bait
LEAD: LOWER tax rates, the Reagan Adminstration long maintained, would not only encourage people to work harder but would also make them more honest.
If less was taken by various tax collectors, the argument ran, fewer people would risk evasion, and significant numbers of moonlighters, barterers and other members of the ''underground'' economy would be lured into fiscal rectitude.


Unethical Lawyers Are Target of Bar Unit
LEAD: The Connecticut Bar Association adopted measures this week intended to protect clients from unscrupulous lawyers.


A Mayan Past, A Latin Present In Guatemala
LEAD: ARRIVING in Antigua, Guatemala, is like falling into a time warp and ending up in 16th- or 17th-century Spain.
Colonial-style mansions line the landscape, shrouded by eight-foot walls that hide pools, gardens brimming with multitudes of flowers and, beyond, elaborate hand-carved woodwork.


ADJUSTING TO THE TRANSITIONS OF LIFE
LEAD: THE other day, I took my wife's car to the garage for a periodic checkup.
Six hours later and $436.61 poorer, I had the ransomed car back home.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  RESCUE: The Exodus of the Ethiopian Jews.
By Ruth Gruber. (Atheneum, $19.95.) ''For the first time in history, white people were transporting black men and women and children out of Africa not to be sold but to be saved,'' writes Ruth Gruber, the author of 12 previous books and the only foreign correspondent permitted to witness the secret mission that the world came to know as Operation Moses.


HARVEY'S OVERTIME PAYS OFF
LEAD: For the last three days, Connecticut players studied the scouting report that focused on how to contain Greg (Boo) Harvey and Michael Porter, St.
John's stunning backcourt combination.
The secret: cut off the drive, keep them out of the paint, give them the outside shot and encourage the 3-point shot.

LEAD: The Democratic Presidential candidates, searching for ways of moving a still highly volatile and uncertain Iowa electorate, stepped up their attacks on one another today in a series of forums held just 16 days before the state's Presidential caucuses.

Stories Make a Family
LEAD: IN THE BEGINNING, AS FAR back in my family as anyone could go, was my great-grandmother, and her name was Annunziata.
In the next generation, it would be my grandmother's name, in the generation after that (in its Anglicized form, Nancy) it would be my aunt's first name and my mother's middle name, and in the generation after that, my sister's middle name as well.

A Town in California Where Waste Isn't Wasted
LEAD: Public restrooms in this coastal city are called ''pre-treatment facilities.'' An office in City Hall is decorated with a poster of a toilet headlined ''The Origin.'' And every September, thousands of people are drawn to this city's foggy shoreline for the ''Flush With Pride'' festival.


Agrippa and the Hamburger
LEAD: THE name, in two-foot-high bronze letters, on the portico of the Pantheon is that of Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa.
He was the general, admiral and son-in-law of Augustus, the emperor who in 27 B.C. built the complex of baths, water gardens - and the temple that has survived.
The name newly inscribed in black and gold on the 18th-century house facing the Pantheon is Burghy.


NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JANUARY 24, 1988
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL/3-19


ASSESSING THE RISKY JOB OF RISK ASSESSMENT
LEAD: EARLY this century, the principal insecticide used on fruits and vegetables went by the elegant appellation ''Paris green.'' Today's chemists have a less appetizing name for the toxin - lead arsenate.


PETERS SEEKS OPTIONS ON SENTENCES
LEAD: JUDGES need more options when they impose sentences on criminals, according to Chief Justice Ellen A. Peters of the Connecticut Supreme Court.
The options now, she said, are generally limited to probation and incarceration.


New Canaan Offices: Another Story
LEAD: When downtown zoning in New Canaan, Conn., allowed for three-story structures, most builders limited themselves to one.
But that was when the Fairfield County town was still manufacturing shoes.
Now, with a growing docksider population and new, two-story zoning, many of those buildings are getting an extra floor.


About Men; A Brother's Dreams
LEAD: EACH TIME I GO home to see my parents at their house near Poughkeepsie, N.Y., my brother, a schizophrenic for almost nine years now, comes to visit from the halfway house where he lives nearby.
He owns a car that my parents help him to maintain, and his food and washing are taken care of by the halfway house.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs.
Neil Smith of Greensboro, N.C., of the engagement of their daughter Lisa Karen Smith to Warren Seth Waters, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Paul Waters of Clifton, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla.
A May wedding is planned.
The future bride is a senior at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro.


Fresh Winds Blow Through French Museums
LEAD: IN PARIS, THERE HAS LATELY BEEN more good art than almost anyone can keep up with.
Momentarily, there will be much more.
To those who remember how long and slow was the recovery of the great city from the effects of World War II, there is an element of wild exhilaration about the current exhibition schedule.


Millesgarden
LEAD: To the Editor: Re the article on Carl Milles: a quibble.
Milles did not bring a forest of antique sculptures filling his living room to Cranbrook in order to use them as teaching aids for his students.
When I was in his home with a group of students in 1944, Milles told us, ''These are my resource books, my library.

LEAD: On Friday they had a meeting to articulate the soul-searching that went on during the silent bus ride home from Thursday's loss, their third in a row.
Tonight, they skipped their morning practice, regrouped at game time, and plowed their way to a 3-2 victory against Edmonton.


The Opera: Pavarotti and Freni in 'La Boheme'
LEAD: CARLOS KLEIBER, who made his Metropolitan Opera debut on Friday evening as conductor of the season's eighth ''La Boheme,'' arrived on a wave of excited expectation that had to make one wary.
Before he even lifted the baton, the 57-year-old German musician was treated to the kind of heady ovation that many conductors do not receive after their finest performances.

Cabaret: Julienne Scanlon Sings
LEAD: JULIENNE MARIE SCANLON, who was known only as Julienne Marie when she played leads in musicals on Broadway in the 1960's and early 70's, has renewed her singing career after a 10-year retirement with an act made up of songs that were sung in musicals by ''the other woman,'' the second female leads.


Suriname's Civilian Leaders to Be Sworn in Tomorrow
LEAD: Henck Arron, who is to be the Vice President and Prime Minister of Suriname, speaking at a news conference Friday in Paramaribo.
With him was Ramsewak Shankar, the President-elect.
Their inauguration tomorrow will return the South American country to civilian rule after eight years of military rule.

New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:  THE LOCKED ROOM: The New York Trilogy, Volume Three, by Paul Auster. (Penguin, $5.95.) In the latest of Paul Auster's self-reflexive, metafictional whodunits, a biographer turns detective and sets out to solve the literary and linguistic mysteries surrounding the disappearance of a friend.
Last year our reviewer, Stephen Schiff, said he had found the author's previous two novels annoyingly austere, but added that in ''The Locked Room,'' his ''philosophical asides now sound heartfelt instead of stentorian and his descents into semiological Angst feel genuinely anguished and near.


Actresses And the Oscar Race
LEAD: ''WHO IS PEARL HARBOR?'' SALLY White asks in Woody Allen's ''Radio Days.'' Sally's big break as a radio actress has been abruptly terminated by the announcement that the Japanese have attacked the United States naval base on Oahu.
One minute before air time, Sally's debut performance has been canceled to make way for a special news broadcast.

Restaurants
LEAD: To the Editor: This past fall we spent an enjoyable two weeks in Paris.
We particularly delighted in the quality of the French cuisine; not only the subtleties and nuances of fragrance and taste but also its beauty of presentation, the elegance of restaurant decor and the impeccable service.
However, into the midst of this culinary splendor, our privacy and senses were assaulted on numerous occasions by smokers, often seated in close proximity.


RELIGIOUS SCHOOLS GET U.S. AID ABROAD
LEAD: The United States has funneled tens of millions of dollars to religious-affiliated schools and hospitals around the world under a little-known program administered by the Agency for International Development, The program, American Schools and Hospitals Abroad, has since 1971 quietly financed Jewish, Catholic and Protestant schools and hospitals in Africa, Latin America, Asia and the Middle East.


CHICAGO'S GRUMPY GURU
LEAD: James Atlas describes well the Chicago I knew as an undergraduate (''Chicago's Grumpy Guru: Best-Selling Professor Allan Bloom,'' Jan. 3).
I studied with Allan Bloom and other members of the Committee on Social Thought.
It was an invigorating education that continuously forced us to consider what it means to be a human being and a member of civil society.


Comedy: Jeffrey Essmann
LEAD: JEFFREY ESSMANN, a character comedian whose fine-tuned sensibility places him in the tradition of Ruth Draper, Lily Tomlin and Danitra Vance, is a performer whose pursuit of comic truth embraces all ages and freely crosses sexual boundaries.
Mr.
Essmann is also something of a literary daredevil, for his most ambitious pieces assume some historical knowledge and steer away from pat comic formulas.


Jazz Refreshes Itself With a Dash of Brazil
LEAD: MUSICIANS, LIKE MOST FOLK, love to travel.
Unlike other tourists who bring home clothing and carvings or other such bric-a-brac, musicians pick up odd-sounding rhythms, exotic melodies, new ways of turning a phrase.
Sometimes what they accomplish amounts to colonialist plunder.
But at times their wanderlust produces unexpected insights.

LEAD: IN the good old summertime of 1984, the most popular song on the charts was ''The Star-Spangled Banner.'' Now, it's the winter of 1988, and by the close of the Olympic Games next month, the national anthem may seem like a golden oldie.

LEAD: IT isn't often that the same game gets both a brilliancy prize and a prize for excellence in the end game, but Michael Rohde showed, in the 1987 United States Championship, that such a feat is not impossible.


A Mixed Harvest Of 1987 Statistics
LEAD: The harvest of statistics from 1987 continued.
A steep, 16.2 percent plunge in housing starts in December got the most attention.
That put housing construction for all of 1987 at 1.62 million units, the lowest since 1982 and down 10 percent from 1986.
Much of the December decline was in apartment construction, which has lagged since tax laws changed last year.

SNOWTHROWERS: CARE AND FEEDING
LEAD: TO those who own or use a snowthrower, happiness is trouble-free operation.
Although knowing how to operate a snowthrower safely and skillfully is important, smooth sailing throughout the snow season depends largely on performing manufacturer-recommended maintenance thoroughly and on time.
Complete maintenance information is usually printed in the owner's manual furnished with the snowthrower or available from the manufacturer.

FICTION
LEAD:  BLOOD HUNT.
By Neil M. Gunn. (Walker, $15.95.) Though this book, first published in Britain in 1952, includes a murderer on the run, a wronged woman and a revenge-obsessed policeman, it is not really a mystery or a thriller.
It is, rather, a charming, old-fashioned novel of life in a remote section of the Scottish Highlands right after World War II.

Streetscapes: 13th Regiment Armory; A Brooklyn Fortress Yields to the Changing Times
LEAD: NEW YORK CITY'S armories are generally elaborate structures, often with 200-foot-wide drill halls and unusual architectural character.

Research Findings
LEAD: CHECK indoor plant collection for presence of mealybugs, white flies, aphids and spider mites; control if found.
Use water-soluble fertilizer sparingly; indoor plants are semi-dormant during the winter months since light levels are low.
Keep up with seed and nursery catalogue orders; plan the garden for this spring and summer.

IRAN DEAL HAUNTING THE BUSH CAMPAIGN
LEAD: GEORGE BUSH'S role in the Iran-contra affair has come back to haunt him at a critical juncture in his Presidential campaign.
The problem isn't so much what Mr.
Bush has said he knew about the affair as what he has said he didn't know: that it was an arms-for-hostages swap, from which funds were diverted to the contras.

SNOWTHROWERS: CARE AND FEEDING
LEAD: TO those who own or use a snowthrower, happiness is trouble-free operation.
Although knowing how to operate a snowthrower safely and skillfully is important, smooth sailing throughout the snow season depends largely on performing manufacturer-recommended maintenance thoroughly and on time.
Complete maintenance information is usually printed in the owner's manual furnished with the snowthrower or available from the manufacturer.

OUR TOWNS AND CHANGE
LEAD: ''Whose Town Is It, Anyway?'' was interesting and many of Sharlene A. McEvoy's statements were right on the money.
The problem seems obvious to me in her statement that ''we have watched our beloved small towns being ravaged.'' Hers is a plea for political action, for when one ''watches,'' the inevitable happens: the course of least resistance results in results not always to the liking of the watcher.

Practical Traveler; Bypassing Waiver Fees
LEAD: THE year has begun with a tug-of-war over auto rental companies' coverage for collision damage.
On New Year's Day, the Hertz Corporation placed a greater burden on those choosing not to pay Hertz for this coverage.
Within days, a large insurance organization responded, saying that it was insuring holders of certain credit cards against this and any other new risks the auto rental companies might hold the customer responsible for.

In ''Song of Lawino,'' which opened Thursday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, the three women have joined Valeria Vasilevski, the experimentalist director and writer, for an evening of incomparably rich and powerful theater.

LEAD: To the Editor:


TOKYO QUARTET TO PLAY AT PURCHASE
LEAD: MANY ensembles take on the complete cycle of Beethoven Quartets as an early challenge in their collective careers, but not so the Tokyo String Quartet.
It took well more than 15 years of international concertizing before the Tokyo felt ready to tackle this most demanding of musical enterprises.
That was in the summer of 1986, and since then the quartet has repeated the cycle a number of times, always to great critical and audience acclaim.

Beauty; BODY LANGUAGE
LEAD: JUST AS SKIRT lengths and shapes go in and out of style, so too do body types.
When the reedy, angular physique of models in the 1960's and 70's was replaced by a more curvaceous ideal, many fashion pundits declared that, at last, womanly women were attractive again.
But the new ideal, shown off in the tight and skimpy spring clothes that crowded the runways late last fall, seems even more demanding than the old one.


Looking Back on A Cavalcade of TV
LEAD: IT WAS NOT THE AMERICANS BUT the British who largely invented television, as the new public-TV series ''Television'' makes clear.
And so, there may be a certain poetic justice in the fact that this eight-part retrospective of the medium, which makes its hourlong debut tomorrow night at 8 on Channel 13, is based on a British series that ran three years ago in England but was never shown in this country.

ART VIEW
LEAD: WHEN FORTUNE MAGAZINE hired Charles Sheeler to paint a series of pictures for its December, 1940, issue celebrating the glories of American technology they found just the man for the job.
Sheeler had by then become known for his paintings and photographs of cities and machines.
For Fortune, the artist created steely, crisp images of an airplane propeller, a steam locomotive's wheels, a turbine engine, an electric transmission tower - pictures that treated the bits and pieces of technology as if they were icons of a new, bracing religion.

LEAD: ITEM: Just a few weeks after Richard D. Bernard learned that his job as manager of merchandise marketing at NBC would be eliminated last May, he was given a shot at another position in the company.
Mr.
Bernard chose instead to take his chances as an unemployed job hunter. ''I wasn't so sure that being a survivor was any better than being let go with a severance package,'' he said.

WHAT'S NEW IN THE SUPERCONDUCTIVITY BUSINESS
LEAD: UNTIL 1986, most people had never heard of superconductivity.
But for 75 years scientists have known that certain materials lose all resistance in conducting electricity under conditions of extreme cold.
Such temperatures can be achieved only by cooling with liquid helium, which is quite expensive and difficult to use.

As the Palestinian protests entered their seventh week, soldiers were carrying out a new policy of force in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
Palestinians and foreign relief workers said hundreds of people were brutally beaten, some in street clashes and some in house-to-house searches, as the Army tried to break a general strike.

THE QUANDARY OF AIDS AND INSURANCE
LEAD: SINCE AIDS began its cruel assault, the insurance industry and homosexual rights advocates have been locked in a rancorous debate over the testing of insurance applicants for antibodies to the disease.
But the groups are finding common ground on two issues: regulatory AIDS guidelines designed to keep discrimination out of the underwriting business, and health insurance pools for so-called uninsurable people, such as those who test positive for the virus.

LEAD: A GROWING number of teen-age runaways in Westchester are in reality homeless youths who are abandoning bleak motel rooms and trying to return to their own communities, according to the county Youth Board.

LEAD: DR.
OTIS R. BOWEN, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and other top officials in the department want Congress to repeal a law that limits most elderly people's earnings to $8,400 a year.
For those 65 to 69 years old, the law reduces benefits by $1 for every $2 of earnings above that amount, until, when earnings top $20,000, no benefit is paid at all.

WELL DREAMT AND SPLENDILY WOVEN
LEAD: ''When a Maya woman puts on her huipil she emerges through the neckhole symbolically in the axis of the world.
The designs of the universe radiate from her head extending over the sleeves and bodice,'' Walter F. Morris Jr. writes in LIVING MAYA (Abrams, $40).
During 14 years of research, this American anthropologist found parallels between the diamond patterning woven into intricately brocaded blouses of contemporary Mayas in Chiapas, Mexico, and the fabric designs depicted 1,200 years ago in the art of their ancestors, the Classic Mayas.

DOES PRO GOLF NEED A NEW STAR TO SUCCEED?
LEAD: The PGA may have to liberalize its rules to permit more foreign players to compete more frequently in the United States.
A Seve Ballesteros, a Greg Norman, an Ian Woosnam radiate a charisma now missing among American players.
The college education and PGA training process seems to have bleached the color out of our current crop of leading money-winning pros.

LEAD: A cargo craft carrying food, fuel and mail docked today with the Mir space station, according to Tass, the official Soviet press agency.

Comstock Group Inc., Danbury, Conn., an engineering and construction company, elected Joseph G. Munisteri president, chief executive and a director.


Playground Clearance
LEAD: Luke Holland had plenty of room to spare as he deftly kept his balance and guided his bicycle over an obstacle, in this case another bicycle, during a jump in the playground at Washington Square Park. (NYT/Vic DeLucia)


Mental Health on the Street
LEAD: It remains to be seen whether Joyce Brown's release from the hospital to a residential program puts a happy ending to the story of a homeless woman's fight against involuntary psychiatric treatment.
Beyond law, her case dramatizes the failure of a policy - deinstitutionalization, the emptying of state mental hospitals during the 1970's.


Seemingly Endless War Is Strangling Mozambique
LEAD: This desperately poor nation on the southeastern coast of Africa is playing out a tragic drama whose chapters are scrawled in blood.
A 12-year-old conflict is strangling Mozambique.


NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1988
LEAD:  International A2-14


Lacroix in High Spirits for Spring
LEAD: For the second successive season, Christian Lacroix has opened the couture showings here on an exuberant note.
He is always high-spirited and his clothes always merry.
Because the season at hand is spring and summer, usually a lighthearted time for fashion, he has been inspired to new heights of gaiety.


HAWAIIANS CONCLUDE YEARLONG CELEBRATION
LEAD: With the sounding of conch shells, revelers wrapped up a yearlong celebration of Hawaii's 1,000-year-old native culture.


Far-Away Home Court
LEAD: When Billy Ray Bates was signed by the Portland Trail Blazers out of the Continental Basketball Association in 1980, his acrobatic slam dunks and spinning moves to the basket made him an instant crowd favorite and earned him a nickname: The Great Legend of the Northwest.


London Marchers Call For Stepped-Up Fight Against AIDS
LEAD: Demonstrators marching yesterday from Hyde Park to the Queen Elizabeth II Conference Center in Westminster, where an international conference on AIDS is scheduled to begin tomorrow.
The marchers called for more spending on AIDS research and care, anti-discrimination laws and free AIDS drugs. (AP)


Poll Puts 3 Democrats Neck and Neck in Iowa
LEAD: Three Democratic Presidential candidates are running almost even with two weeks left until Iowa's precinct caucuses, according to a poll published yesterday in The Des Moines Sunday Register.


Name Game: Who's Who
LEAD: A cast of larger-than-life characters that makes grown people go ''Oink'' and others shout ''Ole!'' is invading San Diego.


Sri Lanka Leader Going to India
LEAD: President J. R. Jayewardene is to travel to New Delhi Monday to discuss the possibilities of a mutual-assistance treaty between Sri Lanka and India and the phased withdrawal of 38,000 Indian troops who were sent to support a plan for ending the Tamil insurgency here.


Oak Park Journal; No Welcome Mat for Black Church
LEAD: Officials in this predominantly white Chicago suburb have been wrangling in recent days over a black church's efforts to move into town.


Haas Wins Hope Golf By 2 Shots
LEAD: Jay Haas, one of the consistent but not spectacular players on the PGA Tour for the last dozen years, played just that way today - managing steady but not spectacular golf - to win the 29th annual Bob Hope Chrysler Classic by two shots over David Edwards.


Boeing Losing Chairman As It Adds 2 Jet Models
LEAD: Tonight, Thornton A. Wilson, who is 66, intends to ''have fun'' at his retirement party at a Seattle hotel where he will be toasted by 500 friends and international business associates.
They are flying in to celebrate his 17 years of guiding the Boeing Company out of the ''Boeing Bust'' of 1970 to its position today as the world's largest aerospace company, with revenues of $16.3 billion in 1986.

LEAD: The Abu Nidal terrorist network for at least four years maintained an important financial operation in Warsaw that traded arms and consumer goods to raise funds for terrorist acts, according to a classified State Department report on the group's operations.

LEAD: Orders for American-made machine tools surged 76.7 percent in December from the previous month, to $242.5 million, according to a report scheduled to be released today by the industry's trade association.

LEAD: The Dallas Ballet, which is $1.8 million in debt, has canceled its spring program and laid off its 33 dancers and most staff members.

LEAD: Until the Eastman Kodak Company agreed Friday to spend $5.1 billion to acquire Sterling Drug Inc., it had been pursuing a diversification strategy that could best be described as busy but dainty.

LEAD: Dominique Wilkins scored 31 points but the Atlanta Hawks had to withstand a fourth-quarter rally to defeat the New Jersey Nets, 118-111, today.

LEAD: Roy Blount Jr. has rafted down the Amazon River, taking a brief swim that ended abruptly when he realized piranhas had wiggled into his bathing suit and were nibbling at his upper thigh - an unpleasant experience that nonetheless enabled him to write an account of the trip that began with the lead of a lifetime: ''Wild fish tore my flesh.

LEAD: West Germany's economy is expected to grow between 1.5 percent and 2 percent this year, compared with 1.7 percent growth in 1987, the Economics Minister, Martin Bangemann, said today.

LEAD: ''The Last Emperor,'' a panoramic history of modern China, won four Golden Globe Awards, including best dramatic motion picture, on Saturday night while Sally Kirkland, who played an emigre actress in ''Anna,'' and Michael Douglas, a ruthless trader in ''Wall Street,'' took top honors for actors in dramas.

LEAD: Iran has informed Lebanon that all foreign hostages held by extremists loyal to Teheran will be released once the war in the Persian Gulf ends, Lebanese Government officials said this week.

A small girl hands him flowers.
A hand holding a gun suddenly appears, horrifying the man's supporters.

Concert: Montreal Symphony
LEAD: SOMEONE once said of of Gabriel Faure's music that it behaved like a cat - discreet, graceful, with a sense of great adventure but at the end, always landing on its feet no matter how high or dangerous the fall.
His chaste little Pavane - as performed by the orchestra and singers of the Montreal Symphony on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall - was an instructive microcosm of Faure's quiet risk-taking.


Stage: Brook's 'Cherry Orchard'
LEAD: IT is not until the final act of ''The Cherry Orchard'' that the malevolent thud of an ax signals the destruction of a family's ancestral estate and, with it, the traumatic uprooting of a dozen late-19th-century Russian lives.
But in Peter Brook's production of Chekhov's play, the landscape seems to have been cleared before Act I begins.

BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1988
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL REPORT  Unemployment in Western Europe is expected to get worse as a result of the dollar's drop, which has made American goods more competitive with European products.
The situation is already grim, with Europe's jobless rate at 11 percent.
No net new jobs have been created in Europe since 1980.

LEAD: A DC-6 cargo plane on a supply mission to contra guerrillas crashed inside Nicaragua Saturday night, apparently killing 11 Nicaraguan crewmen and cargo handlers.

LEAD: Warning that the price of failure will be a suspension of its debt payments abroad, Argentina has begun searching for new loans to help cover this year's interest payments on its $54 billion foreign debt, the third largest in Latin America after Brazil and Mexico.

LEAD: Nearly a month after the expiration of a state-imposed deadline, a small company in New York City has yet to comply with an order to empty its plant of an enormous inventory of radium-226, a dangerously radioactive material that was once widely used in treating cancer.

Saudi Phone Fees Rise
LEAD: Saudi Arabia, in a move to help reduce its budget deficit, has raised telephone charges for the first time in 14 years.
Fouad Abu Mansour, the deputy minister for posts, said in an interview reported today by the Saudi press agency that the move was taken to keep pace with rates in neighboring countries.


Music: Fine Arts Quartet At Alice Tully Hall
LEAD: THE Fine Arts Quartet is an American ensemble with a decided Central European tint.
In its program at Alice Tully Hall Saturday night, one heard a rounded rather than a finely cut edge to phrasing and timbre.
At its worst, the Fine Arts sounds fuzzy to the point of imprecision; yet there is a depth to the group's sound and a relaxed, welcoming quality to the music itself.


Hoyas Surprise Syracuse
LEAD: Georgetown limped into Syracuse this afternoon without a victory in its last three games, punchless on offense and close to falling hopelessly behind in the Big East race.

LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company and New York State, trying to put the stalemate on the Shoreham nuclear power plant behind them, have intensified negotiations that could close Shoreham but allow Lilco to remain an independent, investor-owned utility.

Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a Washington article on Saturday about illegal aliens misstated the status of a proposal to extend a May 4 deadline for applying for legal status.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service is considering, but has not formally announced, action that would allow aliens who have made known their intention to apply by May 4 to submit the necessary documentation later; they could do so as long as they could show that the delay was caused by reasons beyond their control.


Fitness; It May Not Be Exciting, But You'll Perform Best With a Balanced Diet
LEAD: ONE of the enduring myths of athletics is that eating protein will enhance one's performance.
Since protein is composed of amino acids, some advocates take the notion one step further: loading up on certain amino acids will improve strength, promote muscle building and increase performance.

LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has told the General Services Administration that a $25 billion project to replace the Government's antiquated telephone system has been compromised by a growing contract controversy.

LEAD: European Community ministers today resumed their struggle to agree on strict curbs on farm spending that could clear the way for a revamping of the near-bankrupt group's finances.
Diplomats said differences remained unresolved after three days of talks last week and a session that lasted more than 10 hours on Saturday.

Since then, the 48-year-old Mr.
Portale helped Tiffany &amp; Company put out a one-shot magazine marking its 150th anniversary.

Apple's Products
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. has introduced two new software products designed to improve communications between its Macintosh personal computers and the larger computer systems offered by such vendors as the Digital Equipment Corporation.

Japan Chip Imports Slip
LEAD: Japanese imports of foreign microchips appear to have tapered off after reaching a peak in the second quarter of 1987, an official with the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.
The United States has charged that Japan has failed to open its market to foreign semiconductor makers.


Nissan Raises Prices
LEAD: The Nissan Motor Corporation said today that it had raised the suggested retail price of its cars and light trucks by an average of 1.9 percent, or $224 a vehicle, effective immediately.
The company attributed the increase to the depreciation of the dollar against the yen.
The price increase will not apply to its standard Sentra model or it Pulsar NX model, the company said.

LEAD: Most of the Denver Broncos and the Washington Redskins will join Saturday in a prayer meeting that is believed to be the first to bring together National Football League players from opposing teams on the eve of any game - much less a Super Bowl.

Computervision In Merger Talks
LEAD: The Computervision Corporation has begun negotiations with Prime Computer Inc. about a possible acquisition by Prime, but the companies warned that no agreement might be reached.
Computervision officials said the company was still urging its stockholders not to tender shares to Prime under its offer of $443.5 million, or $15 a share.

LEAD: A second assailant pleaded guilty yesterday in the fatal beating and stabbing of a 20-year-old Brooklyn man who was riding a bicycle when he was attacked in Coney Island in May 1986, officials said.


Actors Studio, Long in Turmoil, Seeks a New Artistic Director
LEAD: After months of internal turmoil and financial stress at the Actors Studio, a search is under way to find a replacement for the artistic director, Ellen Burstyn.
At the same time, the institution - for more than 40 years the major American training ground for Method acting - is broadening its program to emphasize the development of writers along with actors and directors.


Sandinistas Begin Talks With Indian Rebels
LEAD: The Sandinista Government opened formal peace talks today with Miskito Indian leaders who have been waging a sporadic anti-Sandinista war for seven years.

LEAD: The Long Beach Opera is interesting to sociologists of the operatic scene as a point of entry in this country for the school of deconstructionist stage direction that has flourished in Europe over the past decade or so, especially in Germany.
The dominant artistic presence here in recent years has been that of the brothers Christopher and David Alden, both directors.

LEAD: Three days after Kirk Gibson and six other players were awarded a second shot at becoming free agents because of collusion among the club owners, the Yankees announced yesterday that they would not pursue Gibson in the open market.

Shock Torturing Of Drug Suspect Charged at Trial
LEAD: A Queens prosecutor charged in court yesterday that a police sergeant had tortured a drug suspect with an electronic stun gun after beating the man with the help of two other officers.


Freddie Mac Plans Purchase Of Convertible Mortgages
LEAD: The growing popularity of adjustable-rate mortgages convertible to a fixed interest rate led the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation to announce yesterday that it would issue participation certificates in exchange for those mortgages, or else buy the mortgages for cash.

LEAD:  International A2-11, B6


Corning Net Surges 72%
LEAD: Corning Glass Works today reported a 72 percent rise in profits in the fourth quarter and a record profit for 1987, thanks to one-time gains in the tax and accounting areas and the addition of an extra week into the financial figuring.


Merrill Shows Profit for Quarter
LEAD: Capping a tumultuous year, Merrill Lynch &amp; Company, the parent of the nation's largest stock brokerage, yesterday reported a small fourth-quarter profit, surprising analysts who had expected it to post a small loss.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Dusty Baker, who hit 242 home runs during his 14-year career, has been named first-base coach for the San Francisco Giants. . . .
Sean Green, a freshman forward, has transferred from North Carolina State to Iona and will be eligible to play for the Gaels next December. . . .
Billy Martin, the Yankee manager, was married in Danville, Calif., yesterday to Jill Uann Guiver, a freelance photographer.

Number of Homeless Far Below Shelter Forecasts
LEAD: After years of steady increases, the number of homeless people in New York City shelters and welfare hotels has remained far below levels forecast by the city this winter, leaving city planners and advocates for the homeless puzzling over the unexpected development.


Nascar Drug Testing
LEAD: While saying ''we don't think we have a problem at this time,'' Bill France Jr., the president of Nascar, announced yesterday a drug testing program for Winston Cup Series stock car racing drivers.
The policy, which goes into effect immediately, would incorporate ''reasonable suspicion'' as the basis for testing drivers, mechanics, crew members and Nascar officials.


By Design; French Chic
LEAD: Whatever you call it - chic, cachet or ''chien,'' that odd French expression - it is something Frenchwomen just seem to have.
It's an indefinable quality, a knack for putting oneself together, that results in an enviably stylish look.


Family Opens Home to 63 After Storm Closes Road
LEAD: A couple who saw a line of stranded motorists near their home invited them in for the night and ended up serving breakfast today to 63 new friends, including a missionary from Japan and a couple from England, ''It's been quite fun - it's a lovely group of people,'' said Nickie Jones, 23 years old, of London.

LEAD: As the spring and summer couture openings take off in earnest after the lively prologue by Christian Lacroix on Sunday, it is clear that the freewheeling Lacroix spirit has left its mark.

LEAD: George Frederick Howe, a historian, author and teacher whose career spanned six decades, died of cancer Jan. 18 at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington.
He was 86 years old and lived in Harrisville, N.H., and Washington.

LEAD: American wine producers have reached a voluntary agreement to reduce levels of urethane in table and dessert wines, the Food and Drug Administration announced today.

The Basic Speech; There's No Challenge That 'the American Mind Collectively Cannot Solve'
LEAD: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns.
Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way.
But more often the candidate uses a basic speech.
It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.

The Lessons of '68 for Liberals in '88
LEAD: Before we are inundated by the inevitable flood of articles and television specials commemorating the tumultuous events of 20 years ago, any Americans who still call themselves liberals would do well to remember that 1968 was a year of unmitigated disaster for their cause.
It marked the end of New Deal, Fair Deal, New Frontier and Great Society liberalism.

He was 59 years old and lived in Newton, Mass.


TV Reviews; The Rev. Jim Bakker And the Government
LEAD: WHAT did the Rev.
Jim Bakker do, and how did he do it?
Forget the sexual scandal. ''Frontline'' is exploring a more important area: Mr.
Bakker and the Government.
Did some agencies look the other way when the television preacher was piling up money? ''Frontline,'' on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, suggests they did.


Blast Kills 10 in a Mexican Mine
LEAD: An explosion and fire trapped more than 125 men in a coal mine in northern Mexico today, and authorities said at least 10 had died.

LEAD: Not long ago, when hundreds defied the law and grew marijuana openly in this region's remote valleys, cash flowed easily along the town's Main Street, spurring one of the biggest bonanzas in the history of a rawboned town whose economic story has been one long chronicle of boom and bust.


Lights at Wrigley Field?
LEAD: The chairman of the Cubs told a Chicago City Council hearing yesterday that the club would consider leaving Chicago if the city did not allow night baseball games at Wrigley Field.
The chairman, John Madigan, appeared before the council's committee on energy and environmental protection.
The panel is considering a proposal to install lights at Wrigley Field.


Violin: Hanna Lachert Plays
LEAD: HANNA LACHERT is a violinist whose education began in Poland and continued in a gradual westward direction, including a stay at the Royal Conservatory of Brussels.
Ms.
Lachert joined the New York Philharmonic in 1972, settled into the American musical life and has still worked at keeping her status as a solo recitalist.


Ozone Study In Arctic
LEAD: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration scientists who earlier studied the loss of ozone over the South Pole are now turning their attention to the North Pole, the Federal agency announced today.


Bus Strike Jams Golden Gate
LEAD: Cars jammed the Golden Gate Bridge today as a strike by bus drivers who normally haul 27,000 passengers a day forced commuters to form car pools, ride ferries and seek other ways of getting to work.
About 300 Golden Gate Transit drivers and telephone operators walked off the job early Saturday after negotiators remained deadlocked beyond a Friday midnight strike deadline.


Pacific Telesis Profit Declines
LEAD: The Pacific Telesis Group today reported a 37 percent drop in its fourth-quarter earnings.
A restructuring program, early-retirement incentives and an adverse rate ruling were cited.

Advertising; Pitney Bowes Switches to Hill, Holliday
LEAD: HILL, HOLLIDAY, CONNORS, COSMOPULOS of Boston has won Pitney Bowes Inc.'s account, which includes the corporate advertising and most of work for the company's business systems.
Billings will be between $7 million and $10 million.
This is the first new account of 1988 for Hill, Holliday, which last year increased its billings 23 percent, to $320 million.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Green Is 5 Million Point Man: Rickey Green, a Jazz reserve, took a shot at National Basketball Association history last night and made it during Utah's 119-96 home victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.
His 3-point basket at the end of the third quarter pushed the league 1 point over the 5,000,000 mark since play began in 1946.


Heyward Decides He Will Turn Pro
LEAD: Craig Heyward, Pitt's all-America running back, said today that he would forgo his final season of college football eligibility in the hope of playing in the National Football League next season.


No Crimp in Her Style
LEAD: Joan Benoit Samuelson, the Olympic gold medalist and two-time Boston Marathon winner, said that recent motherhood isn't putting a crimp in her running style.
In a 10-kilometer race at Wilton Manors, Fla., on Sunday, she finished first in the women's division in 34 minutes 12 seconds and 11th over all in a field of 560.


Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Rule Witnesses May Be Barred by Judge
LEAD: In a 5-to-3 decision, the Supreme Court ruled today that criminal trial judges may bar defense witnesses from testifying in order to punish attorneys for failing to disclose the witnesses' identities soon enough.
The Court said the judges could take the action regardless of whether the defendants were at fault.


Dollar Rises in a Quiet Day And Gold Declines Sharply
LEAD: The dollar strengthened yesterday against all major currencies except the Canadian dollar in generally quiet worldwide trading.


Soviet Space Contract
LEAD: A West German concern has signed an agreement with the Soviet Union to use Russian satellites for space experiments.
The company, Kayser Threde, is to conduct three experiments on board the Soviet Foton spacecraft between 1989 and 1992, according to the Soviet news agency Tass.
The news agency gave no details, but said the company was developing a laser device to measure environmental pollution from space.


Few Israelis Dispute Army Tactics in Unrest
LEAD: ''They've risen on us, we didn't rise on them,'' Yehuda Genyan, a tailor, was saying today of the Palestinian protesters. ''They walk around here like kings, but a Jew goes to pray at the wall and he gets stabbed.''


Jews Must Not Break Bones
LEAD: There is a gift that foreign supporters of Israel, particularly Jews, can now give to the country.
And there is a gift that a particular leader of Israel, who has fought for her in war after war, can give.
It would be a gift of great cost to himself, but would burnish his name and that of his perpetually embattled nation.


Former Aide Says He Can Detail Noriega's Corruption
LEAD: A former top adviser to the Panamanian military ruler, Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, said yesterday that he would provide details on the general's involvement in drug and arms smuggling, corruption and money laundering, unless the general removed himself from politics.


Federated's Fading Profitability
LEAD: When Howard Goldfeder became chairman of Federated Department Stores Inc. in 1981, he vowed to improve the profitability of a company that had long been one of the nation's most respected retailers.
But Mr.
Goldfeder's failure thus far to accomplish that goal, according to analysts, is a major reason why he now finds himself having to fight off an unwanted $4.2 billion bid from Robert Campeau, the Toronto-based real estate developer.


Lab Dispute Delays Chambers Trial
LEAD: Lawyers and scientists continued to squabble yesterday at a hearing over whether a laboratory test that has apparently never been used in a criminal case in the United States could be used in the trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr.
The test, using a laboratory-engineered antibody, showed a high level of an enzyme found in saliva on a stained denim jacket that investigators discovered in August 1986 with Jennifer Levin's body in Central Park.


Poor Policy to Forgive The Mexican Debt
LEAD: To the Editor:


'Chemical Clamps' May Eliminate Some Surgery
LEAD: MEDICAL researchers have begun experimenting with synthetic hormones that effectively block harmful body secretions, an approach they hope will lead to the better treatments for many common diseases.
In the case of some cancers, the new approach may even eliminate the need for surgery.


Music: Morocco's Gnawa
LEAD: IN Marrakesh, and elsewhere in southern Morocco, Gnawa musicians play for all-night, outdoor rituals with dancing, singing and spirit possession.
A young master Gnawa musician, Hassan Hakmoun, brought a solo version of the music to the Ethnic Folk Arts Center (179 Varick Street) on Sunday, as part of its Music Around the Mediterranean series.


2 Nordiques Suspended
LEAD: Coach Ron Lapointe of the Quebec Nordiques and Terry Carkner, a defenseman for the club, were suspended for five and 10 games, respectively, for leaving the bench during a third-period fight in a game against the Montreal Canadiens on Sunday night.
Lapointe also was fined $1,000 and the team was fined $10,000.


Chess: Gelfand Wins Junior Event With Two Queen Sacrifices
LEAD: Two Soviet players captured the top places in the 1988 European Junior Championship in Arnhem, the Netherlands.
Boris Gelfand won the gold medal with an 11 1/2-1 1/2 score, a half-point ahead of the silver medalist, Vassily Ivanchuk, an international master who was last year's winner.

LEAD: A former Queens Democratic Party official convicted on corruption charges, Richard L. Rubin, has secretly been cooperating with a state agency investigating political corruption and patronage in the Queens judiciary, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

LEAD: Bennett E. Bidwell and Robert A. Lutz have both gained the title of president, along with some added responsibilities, at the Chrysler Corporation's Chrysler Motors subsidiary.
Their job changes followed the resignation last week of Harold K. Sperlich, the unit's president since 1985.

But beyond this world of doorways, benches and trash can fires in the night are thousands of homeless people who have never lived on the streets of New York.

Oil Rig Count Declining
LEAD: The number of oil and gas drilling rigs working in the United States fell again last week, by 28, to 1,026, Baker Hughes said today.
The count had dropped by 48 the previous week, to 1,054.
A year ago it was 837.
The count peaked at 4,500 in December 1981 and reached its low of 663 in mid-1986.


Union Carbide Posts a Profit
LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation yesterday reported fourth-quarter net income of $23 million, or 17 cents a share.
In the period a year earlier, the giant chemical company reported a net loss of $495 million, reflecting an after-tax charge of $473 million from the company's repurchase of shares during a takeover battle with the GAF


Boeing Profit Declines 26%
LEAD: The Boeing Company today reported fourth-quarter earnings of $141 million, or 92 cents a share, down 26.2 percent from $191 million, or $1.23 a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.

Gulf Lull: An Iran Offensive on Hold
LEAD: Iran is hesitating to mount a long-forecast winter offensive against Iraq in the seven-year-old Persian Gulf war, Western and Iraqi officials say, and apparently is concentrating instead on diplomatic efforts to break up a broad coalition of pro-Iraqi Arab nations.


Specialist Gives Up Stock
LEAD: M. J. Meehan &amp; Company, one of Wall Street's largest specialist firms, said yesterday that it had resigned as a market maker in the stock of Gould Inc. after an investigation by the New York Stock Exchange of the way Meehan handled Gould's stock during the week of Oct. 19.

Elton John to Sell Artworks
LEAD: Elton John is selling a major portion of his collection of paintings, personal memorabilia and 20th-century decorative arts - at auction in the early fall at his home near Windsor, Berkshire, a Sotheby's spokesman, Fiona James, said yesterday by telephone from London.


CUBANS WRONGED, MIAMI BISHOP SAYS
LEAD: Auxiliary Bishop Agustin A. Roman of Miami, the Cuban-born prelate who played a major role in the peaceful ending of two prison riots by Cuban inmates, charged today that the Justice Department had not lived up to the spirit of the agreement that brought about the solution to the uprisings.

Federated Stock Soars After Bid
LEAD: A battle between two major department-store operators opened yesterday as the Campeau Corporation of Canada, owner of Jordan Marsh and Brooks Brothers, began its hostile tender offer to buy Federated Department Stores, which owns Bloomingdale's, Bullock's, Rich's and Filene's.


Victim of a Fatal Plunge At Met Seemed Depressed
LEAD: The 82-year-old opera fan who fell to his death Saturday from an upper balcony of the Metropolitan Opera House during an intermission of Verdi's ''Macbeth'' had indicated that he was severely depressed or contemplating suicide.


Corrections
LEAD: A graph in Business Day last Tuesday, with an article about businesses' reluctance to build new factories, bore an incorrect label.
It represented gross spending on machinery and factories.


A 25-Year Term Given in Killing Of a Policeman
LEAD: As more than 50 police officers watched, a man described as a low-level drug dealer was sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life in prison for the murder of a rookie police officer in a gun battle in Queens.


Catfish Slime's Healing Agents
LEAD: CATFISH slime, a gel-like substance secreted by the fish, has remarkable properties that help heal wounds, a team of American and Kuwaiti scientists has discovered.


Japanese Imposing Sanctions on North Korea
LEAD: Japan imposed diplomatic sanctions on North Korea today, saying it was convinced that ''organized terrorism from North Korea'' was responsible for the bombing of a South Korean airliner two months ago.


Providence Suffers A Shattering Loss
LEAD: Jerome Lane had 17 points and 17 rebounds, and halted the game for a half-hour with a backboard-shattering slam dunk tonight as Pittsburgh routed Providence, 90-56, in a Big East Conference game.

LEAD: Rowntree-Mackintosh P.L.C., a confectionery company, said it wanted to sell its British and American snack-food units for at least the $:155 million, or $277 million in United States currency, it paid for them.
The company said that both the Tom's Foods Inc. unit in the United States and the Rowntree Snack Foods Ltd.


Costly Federal Fix for Local Tolls
LEAD: Hard facts now prove the folly of a Federal law that ordered one-way tolls on the bridge over New York harbor.
Local tolls are none of Congress's business, and the consequences were predictable -lost revenues, clogged traffic and polluted air.


Bureau Provides List Of Magazine Ad Pages
LEAD: The Publishers Information Bureau, a sister organization of the Magazine Publishers of America, has released its annual list of its members along with the ad page count and estimated ad revenues for 1987.

Washington Talk: Briefing; A Candidate's Foibles
LEAD: The American electorate may still be divided over the extent to which a politician's personal foibles should be considered in judging his fitness to hold office.
But in the Soviet Union a vote has been taken on the subject.


'87 Gas Use Up in West
LEAD: Europe and North America used 3.7 percent more natural gas last year than in 1986, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.
The increase was higher in Europe, at 4.8 percent, than in North America, where the United States and Canada each registered a 2 percent gain.
Natural gas production in Europe, the United States and Canada rose 2.1 percent.


For the Adventurous
LEAD: IT really is a nightmare.
You wake up in a shower stall in a dilapidated building, your head throbbing, your right hand caked with dried blood that is apparently not your own, and a pain under your left forearm where someone may have injected you with - something.
As if that weren't enough, you haven't the faintest idea who you are.


Court Blocks Florida Execution in Cause Celebre
LEAD: The United States Supreme Court today blocked the execution of a Florida prisoner whose innocence has been proclaimed by opponents of capital punishment in this country and abraod.

COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Adler &amp; Shaykin Inc. said it accepted for payment about 7.8 million shares, or about 92 percent, of the outstanding common stock of Wherehouse Entertainment Inc., Torrance, Calif., at $14 a share in cash.


Colleen Moore, Star of 'Flapper' Films, Dies at 85
LEAD: Colleen Moore, the star of the silent screen who personified the ''flapper'' of the 1920's, died of cancer yesterday at her ranch near Paso Robles, Calif.
She was 85 years old.
Miss Moore appeared in about 100 films beginning in 1917 and ending with one of her comparatively few talking pictures, ''The Scarlet Letter,'' in 1937.


Mecham-Recall Forces Have Names to Spare
LEAD: State officials today certified that more than 300,000 Arizonans had signed petitions demanding Gov.
Evan Mecham's recall.
The Governor will be told officially Tuesday that he has five days to resign or agree to run in an election to recall him from office.

LEAD: Is the promise of money to attend college enough to keep students from becoming high school dropouts?

LEAD: The Soviet Union's aversion to Black-tie events here appears to be crumbling, Washington socialites report.


Drexel Sees No Quick Resolution
LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the investment house that for more than a year has been the subject of two extensive Federal investigations, said yesterday that it did not expect any issues arising from those investigations to be resolved for several months.


Back to High School
LEAD: Emory Bellard, who coached football teams at Texas A&amp;M and Mississippi State - some of them ranked among the nation's top 20 - from 1972 to 1985, was named head coach yesterday at Westfield High School in Spring, Tex., a suburb of Houston.
While at Texas A&amp;M, Bellard compiled a 48-27 record that included three bowl appearances.

LEAD: The State Department announced today that Secretary of State George P. Stage: Robert Moresco's 'Half Deserted Streets'
LEAD: SET on the mean streets of Hell's Kitchen, Robert Moresco's ''Half Deserted Streets'' belongs to a ''kitchen sink'' school of drama that has become so familiar it is almost incapable of delivering any surprises.
Among many other ingredients from the past, this version of the recipe calls for a smidgen of ''Dead End,'' a teaspoon of ''On the Waterfont,'' a dollop of ''Cuba and His Teddy Bear,'' and a dash of ''A View From the Bridge.

NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 27, 1988
LEAD:  International A2-10


Houston Discovers the Diner
LEAD: Diners, the old-fashioned stainless-steel and tile kind, don't blend with the landscape here as they do on the Jersey Shore or the roadsides of Long Island.
That's probably because, until recently, there were no diners to speak of in Houston.
But if restaurateurs here missed out on the diner business the first time around, they seem determined to cash in now that diners are the nostalgic rage.


Cotton and Soybeans Drop; Crude Oil Is Slightly Higher
LEAD: Cotton futures prices plunged nearly 2 cents a pound yesterday in a selloff that accelerated after the price for March delivery broke through a level last seen in mid-December, analysts said.


Carteret Bancorp's Merger Agreement
LEAD: Home Group Inc. said that, despite its merger agreement with Carteret Bancorp, it would allow the Delaware-based savings and loan holding company to look for a new merger partner until mid-February.


Why the Fairness Doctrine Should Be Restored
LEAD: To the Editor:


From Here On, Reagan May Have More Power Outside U.S.
LEAD: While President Reagan retains enormous influence in foreign affairs, his ability to control the domestic agenda has diminished considerably as he begins his final year in office, analysts in the White House and on Capitol Hill said today.


State of Union: Bewitched by Pageant
LEAD: When the British rebuilt the bomb-damaged House of Commons after World War II, Winston Churchill insisted that it contain many fewer seats than members.
This was to guarantee standing-room-only crowds for major events, just to impart an appropriate sense of drama.


Paradise Valley Journal; Town Hires Robot to Curb Speeders
LEAD: Howard Schwartz, a Maricopa County deputy attorney, was driving his Corvette along a cactus-lined street of this Phoenix suburb recently when he saw a burst of light.
A few days later he received a notice in the mail from the City of Paradise Valley charging him with speeding and summoning him to traffic court.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.H.L.
Jets 3, Capitals 2: Dale Hawerchuk and Iain Duncan scored second-period goals to lift Winnipeg to victory at Landover, Md. last night.
Hawerchuck snapped a 1-1 tie with an unassisted goal at 10:04 of the period.
Duncan made it 3-1 when he knocked in a rebound from out of the air for his 14th goal of the season six minutes later.(AP)

Smooth Flow on Golden Gate
LEAD: A mass traffic tieup that was predicted on the Golden Gate Bridge Monday failed to materialize as commuters used ferries and automobile pools and stayed late in the office in an effort to avoid delays that were expected to be caused by a strike of bus drivers.
The morning rush hour was marked by a peaceful demonstration at the bridge by representatives of the 300 bus drivers of the Golden Gate Transit District.

BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 27, 1988
LEAD:  Markets


Life in the 30's
LEAD: MY friend's voice was as plaintive as a bird's song at night. ''Do you know what I really want to do?'' she asked.


Airplanes Lead Surge In Orders for Durables
LEAD: Orders for big-ticket durable goods, bolstered by demand for aircraft, shot up 6.7 percent in December, the largest increase in 15 months, the Commerce Department reported today.


BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances; Junk Food That's Lean And Healthy?
LEAD: THE strategic thinkers at food companies have long coveted the potentially enormous markets that would be created if a low-cholesterol, low-calorie fat substitute could be developed for use in such things as ice cream, french fries, chocolate doughnuts and potato chips.


Navajos Suing U.S. to Block Arizona Relocation of 6,000
LEAD: Representatives of 45 Navajo Indians filed a lawsuit today against the Federal Government to block the relocation of approximately 6,000 Navajos from part of a reservation in northern Arizona.


BABBITT REVIEWING IOWA DEAL
LEAD: Bruce Babbitt's Presidential campaign said Monday that it would send $10,000 to the Iowa Democratic Party after questions were raised about whether the campaign broke the law in the way it obtained a list of caucus participants from the party.


Canadian Imperial
LEAD: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce said it had agreed in principle to acquire 60 percent of the Wood Gundy Inc. securities firm for $110 million (Canadian), or about $86 million (United States).
The bank said a minimum of 75 percent of that amount would be paid in Canadian Imperial stock, with the balance in cash.


At Age 200, Australia Makes Merry
LEAD: Hundreds of boats filled the sparkling harbor, fighter aircraft roared overhead and huge crowds packed the rocky shoreline today to celebrate the landing here 200 years ago of the English convicts who were Australia's first white settlers.


In Boston, Pilgrims' Food (With a Touch of Paris)
LEAD: MOST serious students of the American culinary scene still think of New England cooking - the boiled dinners, codfish cakes and baked beans - as quaint at best, and as heavy, tasteless and overcooked at worst.
Even many Bostonians don't have a high opinion of the food with which they are inextricably linked.


And in This Corner . . .
LEAD: Negotiations for a Mike Tyson-Michael Spinks fight have taken a new turn.
Shelly Finkel, a fight manager and close friend of Tyson's co-manager, Jim Jacobs, has entered the acrimonious negotiations in an attempt to smooth out the differences between the Tyson and Spinks camps.
Talks broke off over the weekend in Atlantic City, ostensibly because of differences on the money to be paid to the fighters.


Chevron Posts a Profit; Amoco Earnings Soar
LEAD: The Chevron Corporation yesterday reported a fourth-quarter profit, in contrast to a loss a year earlier.
The Amoco Corporation said its quarterly earnings more than doubled for the period.

LEAD: M&amp;M Mars Inc., whose account melted in the hands of the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, in December, has decided to give the business to Backer Spielvogel Bates in New York and D'Arcy Masius Benton &amp; Bowles in St.
Louis and New York.

The Franco Zeffirelli production of Puccini's ''Turandot,'' ridiculed by many critics but cheered by audiences who made it one of New York's hottest tickets, is being telecast at 8 o'clock this evening on Channel 13.

LEAD: Vietnam intends to turn over to the United States the remains of five Americans missing in the Vietnam War and has information about 18 other missing Americans, the State Department said today.
The department spokesman, Charles E. Redman, said Vietnam made its pledge in a three-day meeting of Vietnamese Government representatives and United States experts that ended Monday in Hanoi.

Xtra Plans to Sell Container Business
LEAD: The Xtra Corporation said it would sell its marine cargo container operations in two separate transactions worth a total of about $180 million.
The larger acquisition is by the Itel Corporation of Chicago, which will pay $130 million for 80,000 steel containers and leases on some of the containers.


2 Cargo Companies Accused of Illegal Flights
LEAD: Two overnight cargo-delivery companies, involved in four fatal plane crashes in the last five years, were accused by the Federal Government yesterday of operating thousands of illegal cargo flights since 1983.


Hollings Defends His Sponsorship Of Legislation Affecting Murdoch
LEAD: Senator Ernest F. Hollings took to the floor of the Senate today to defend his role in passing legislation that could force Rupert Murdoch to sell The New York Post, insisting that he had not tried to sneak it past his Senate colleagues or the public.


Ulster Police Trial Dropped by Britain
LEAD: The British Government has announced that it will not prosecute Northern Ireland police officers who interfered with an investigation of shootings by the police.

One More Time: The Reagan Hymn
LEAD: If ours were a parliamentary system, the Reagan Government would have fallen 14 months ago.
When the Democrats recaptured the Senate in 1986, it reflected a surprising loss of confidence.
Then, almost immediately, came the Iran-contra bombshells.
President Reagan's popularity sank like a stone, from 67 percent to 46 percent in a month, and it's barely more than that today.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: The Question and Answer column in Science Times on Tuesday incorrectly described Dr.
J.
E.
Jelinek's explanation of hair loss after high fevers, pregnancy, anesthesia and other conditions.
Dr.
Jelinek said hair loss results when many more hairs than normal enter a resting phase.

LEAD: Nearly a quarter of all American children now live with just one parent, and the Census Bureau estimates that more than half will, at some time before they reach adulthood, live in single-parent households.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: Abie Grossfeld of Southern Connecticut State University has been named head coach of the United States men's gymnastics team for the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea.
It will be the second time in succession and the third time over all that Grossfeld will coach the team.
Grossfeld, who competed in the Olympics in 1956 in Melbourne and in 1960 at Rome, was chosen by the United States Gymnastics Federation and the United States Olympic Committee's executive board.

LEAD: President Reagan began an intensive Administration lobbying effort today to win more than $36.25 million in aid for the Nicaraguan rebels.
But he provoked some lawmakers by apparently rejecting suggestions that Congress play a role in deciding whether to release $3.6 million in military aid that would be held in escrow.


Topics of The Times; Colombia Fights Back
LEAD: The powerful drug mafia that profits from Colombia's huge cocaine trade declared war on the nation's Government Monday when it gunned down Attorney General Carlos Hoyos.
A day later, President Virgilio Barco picked up the gauntlet.
Challenging guerrillas as well as drug lords, he sent troops into the streets, created new police and judicial positions and closed legal loopholes.

An Opening for Democracy in Panama
LEAD: Chances grow for Panama to be rid of its corrupt strongman and move toward democracy, without much more pain.
The Reagan Administration rightly seems to understand that the present military Government undermines rather than underpins Panama's stability.
Even Gen.
Manuel Noriega, the Panamanian dictator, seemed a few weeks ago to realize that he had to go.


Soviet Scraps a New Atomic Plant In Face of Protest Over Chernobyl
LEAD: The Soviet authorities have abandoned construction of a nuclear power plant near the Black Sea in the face of public opposition generated by the 1986 accident at the Chernobyl atomic power station, a Soviet newspaper reported today.

Corrections
LEAD: The Home Improvement column in The Home Section last Thursday misidentified a substance used in patching wallboard.
The substance - less effective than joint compound for the perimeter of a large patch - is not putty but spackling putty.

BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JANUARY 28, 1988
LEAD:  The Economy


Engineer to Get Award For Warning on Shuttle
LEAD: An engineer who warned that it was dangerous to launch the space shuttle Challenger in cold weather only hours before the craft exploded has been named a winner of the Scientific Freedom and Responsibility Award from the American Association for the Advancement of Science.


The Real Target
LEAD: Opponents of the treaty eliminating shorter- and medium-range nuclear missiles really have a more important target in mind - the pact being negotiated by Moscow and the Reagan Administration to reduce superpower nuclear arsenals by 50 percent across the board.


Old-Style Roses Are Tough as Well as Sweet
LEAD: SINCE the first hybrid tea roses were bred early in this century, they have loomed ever larger in the consciousness of the American gardener as well as in the commercial horticultural economy.
They appear early every spring in huge numbers at almost every neighborhood garden center, as familiar a sight as bales of peat moss or bags of fertilizer.


Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL


Bid for Singer Extended
LEAD: The investor Paul A. Bilzerian has extended his $50-a-share offer for the Singer Company until next Monday amid talks with Singer's banks about the company's credit status after the $1.06 billion proposed takeover.
He also said Tuesday that almost 15.7 million of the 21.1 million shares had been tendered.
