Regret, No Rancor as Carpenter Departs
LEAD: A day after his dismissal as coach of the Devils, Doug Carpenter said it was inevitable that he would be blamed for the team's recent slide, but added that the team was on the right road.


New York's Home Health-Care System Facing a Labor Crisis
LEAD: New York's home health-care system, because of low pay and difficult working conditions, is having problems attracting and keeping workers, according to health and labor experts and officials of agencies that provide the care.


Senate Panel Approves Judge Kennedy
LEAD: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted unanimously today to recommend confirmation of Judge Anthony M. Kennedy to the Supreme Court.
The vote by the full Senate is likely to come next week, enabling Judge Kennedy to take his seat well in advance of the Court's return from its recess on Feb. 22.


Currents; 'Swaying' Palm Trees Need No Breezes
LEAD: THE sheet-metal palm trees that seem to lean with the wind at the Pink Cadillac Cafe in Los Angeles are witty and useful, too.


W. Hawkins Ferry, Patron of Arts And Architecture Historian,
LEAD: W. Hawkins Ferry, an architectural historian and a well-known collector and patron of 20th-century art, died of cardiac arrest yesterday at his home in Grosse Pointe Shores, a suburb of Detroit.
He was 74 years old, and had for some time suffered from a neurological disorder.


BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Avery Inc., New Brunswick, N.J., said its board had agreed to sell the company's Uniroyal Chemical subsidiary.


Syracuse Triumphs With Late Spurt
LEAD: The Syracuse Orangemen mastered tonight what might be their biggest problem.
In last season's national championship final, they shot poorly from the free-throw line and lost to Indiana.
They shot 50.7 percent from the line during their first six Big East Conference games this season, and lost three.


It's Lights, Camera, Recess for Crew At Studio in Ozone Park Junior High
LEAD: Since completing her solo, around-the-world voyage Nov. 7, Tania Aebi has appeared on television about 15 times, the usual network news and talk programs -''ABC News Night Line,'' David Letterman, etc., - and at stations in Washington, Philadelphia, Seattle, Toronto and elsewhere.


Cabinetry Worth Fixing
LEAD: WHAT do you do if the gooseneck ornament of your English clock snaps off during a move?
Or if a piece of inlay disappears from your game table?
Perhaps you want to remove those cherubs from the Victorian headboard you inherited.

30-Year Bonds Yield 9.42% At Financing Corporation
LEAD: The Financing Corporation yesterday offered $650 million of 9.40 percent 30-year bonds at a price of 99.24, to yield 9.42 percent.


Topics of The Times; Renovated Rhythms
LEAD: Gentrification means new sights: gleaming restaurants, cookie stores, video shops and repaved sidewalks.
But there's more than meets the eye to the changes that turn neglected neighborhoods into fashionable places to live.
Some are heard, not seen.

LEAD: General Assembly


Carlos Rangel, Author, Dies in Venezuela at 58
LEAD: Carlos Rangel, an author and journalist and one of Latin America's most articulate conservative intellectuals, has died at age 58.


Savings Unit Posts Big loss
LEAD: The Financial Corporation of America, the parent of the nation's largest savings and loan institution, said today that it had lost $224.6 million in the fourth quarter after adding $235.5 million to its reserves for bad loans.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Old Idea Flies Again
LEAD: It was evident enough in the State of the Union Message that at the White House, these are times for reheating old ideas, and the Council of Economic Advisers will soon join in with a ringing defense of airline deregulation.


Music: Neikrug Concerto By Cleveland Orchestra
LEAD: THE Cleveland Orchestra opened a six-concert series in the New York area Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall (four of the concerts will be there, tonight's will be at Avery Fisher Hall, and the sixth at C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University, in Greenvale).
There were only two pieces on this first program, a blockbuster preceded by a shorter New York premiere.


The Art in Ordinary African Objects
LEAD: ''Suppose you had a slightly mad and creative gas station attendant,'' Susan Vogel said the other day. ''Now suppose he had a huge pile of spare tires, and he said, 'I could make something with those,' and he threw them into a big pile.
Is it a work of art?
If the same pile of tires is shown in front of the Whitney Museum, does it then become art?


Daily Aspirin and Strokes
LEAD: Aspirin appears to decrease the risk of one kind of stroke but may increase the risk of another, a finding that troubles experts.


Principals' Accord to Extend Probation Period to 5 Years
LEAD: The Board of Education and the principals' union announced a tentative three-year contract yesterday that extends the probationary period for all school supervisors, to five years from three.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q.My split-level apartment is on the top floor.
Some minor roof leaks left little water spots here and there, but in January dark spots appeared over every nail in the ceiling and deep down in each wall.
Since it is unlikely there is a major leak from one ceiling to another one at a different level, what could cause these dark spots and what steps must be taken before repainting?

Some Gray Hairs and a Bare Foot
LEAD: HE'S only 27 years old, but atop Ali Haji-Sheikh's stylish black mop, occasional long gray hairs betray his burden.
At a quick glance, the Washington Redskins' kicker appears to have sprouted one for each of the 35 field-goal attempts he has missed in his five seasons.
As he awaits a Super Bowl XXII duel with Rich Karlis, the Denver Broncos' barefooted kicker, the Sheikh has missed five of his last eight attempts.


Restoring Fanciful British Pavilions
LEAD: In 1721, the poet Alexander Pope helped his friend Lord Bathurst design Alfred's Hall, a curious little castle for the garden of Cirencester Park, Bathurst's estate in Cirencester, Gloucestershire.
With ivy-covered turrets and stained-glass windows, it resembled a Gothic ruin and promptly set a fashion for similar fanciful structures in large English gardens.

North Stars Score Twice in Final 4:26
LEAD: Herb Brooks, the Minnesota coach, hadn't expected to have anything to beam about after this game.
For the longest time, his players trailed the Islanders by a 1-0 margin, but then, with half of the final period elapsed, it was the North Stars who skated dangerously close to the New York goal, tied the game, and then won it in the final second left on the clock.


Steel Output Up in U.S.
LEAD: Steel production in the United States rose to 1.866 million tons in the week ended Saturday, up four-tenths of a percent from 1.859 million tons in the previous week, the American Iron and Steel Institute has reported.
The industry's output amounted to 86.9 percent of capacity for the week, compared with 86.6 percent in the previous week.


Medical Guardians; Aspirin Report Illustrates the Control of New England Journal on Data Flow
LEAD: For weeks the results of a major new study on aspirin's ability to prevent heart disease were known by many scientists, government officials, business leaders and journalists.


WELDS DEFECTIVE IN RUPTURED TANK
LEAD: The Ashland Oil Company tank that ruptured and spilled more than a million gallons of diesel fuel into the Monongahela River contained defective welds that were reported to the company more than a year before, according to documents made available today.


City of Yonkers Votes to Back Housing Order
LEAD: After a raucous five-and-a-half hour meeting in which they were branded liars, wimps and masters of deceit by their former supporters, Yonkers City Council members voted 5 to 2 early this morning to begin building low-income housing in predominantly white neighborhoods.


Talking Deals; Advisers' Conflict In Merger Battles
LEAD: IN the wake of the recent spate of takeover battles, investment bankers, company directors and the courts are grappling with a controversy over loyalty between investment banking firms and their clients.


Bus Kills a Boy in Rockland
LEAD: A boy was killed this morning when he was struck by a school bus in this Rockland County community, the police said.
The boy, identified as Pincus Zisholtz of 11 Yale Drive, believed to be about 4 years old, was struck about 8:30 A.M., the police said.
They said the bus driver, David Ben-Zikry, 30, of Maple Avenue in Monsey.


Games Help Calgary Solve Hard Times
LEAD: The times were heady here, back at the dawn of the decade.
Oil prices were up.
Agricultural markets were strong.
Unemployment was virtually nonexistent.
New glassy buildings were creating a skyline.
So many people were moving here that city leaders were discouraging others from coming.

LEAD: The Northrop Corporation said it has been awarded a $2 billion contract for work on the advanced Stealth bomber, an unusual announcement that implied to analysts that full-scale production had begun.

X-Rated Computer Displays
LEAD: The personal computer your child got for Christmas may be more educational than you think.
Animated pictures of nudes, sex-related messages and files of dirty jokes are accessible to computers that have modems, devices that enable them to reach other computers by telephone.

LEAD: THE news announcement yesterday that an aspirin every other day may sharply reduce the risk of heart attacks in men is expected to have a far bigger impact on American consumers than investors.
The aspirin market is dominated by the Bristol-Myers Company, the American Home Products Corporation, and the Sterling Drug

Chef Sues in Attack by Goose
LEAD: A chef who says he was attacked by a goose at the restaurant where he worked is suing the restaurant for $1 million.
Richard Braue, a former chef at the Villa Victor in Syosset, said he was standing by a pond on the restaurant's property in June 1985 when he was charged by a Canada goose.
While trying to avoid the bird, he fell and broke his back, he said.


Azinger's First Defense
LEAD: Paul Azinger, who lost any chance to win the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic last Sunday after taking five putts on one green, will be defending the first championship of his career when the Phoenix Open begins Thursday at the Tournament Players Club of Scottsdale.
Azinger went on to win two more tournaments last year, finished second in the British Open and ended the year No.


Irving Protecting Its Pension Fund
LEAD: The board of directors of the Irving Bank Corporation has moved to make the assets of its employee pension plan invulnerable in the face of a hostile $1.08 million takeover offer by the Bank of New York Company.
Under amendments to the plans approved by Irving's board on Jan. 19, the bank's surplus pension assets ''can only be used to provide for existing medical and life insurance benefits of retirees and employees eligible to retire within five years of the change of control,'' acccording to company documents filed with the Securities and Exchange


Tom J. Maloney, 83; Published Magazines
LEAD: Tom Maloney, retired editor and publisher of U.S.
Camera Annual, died of a heart attack Jan. 18 at his home in Cranbury, N.J.
He was 83 years old.


Steel Shutters In West Bank: New Defiance
LEAD: Hefting their crowbars and their rifles in what is a now a daily ritual, the Israeli soldiers moved from store to store this morning, ordering the owners to open up their steel shutters or, if the owners were not around, breaking the locks.

Childhood Regained, on Film
LEAD: ''The movie camera is very close to the eye of a child,'' John Boorman said last week, as the British writer and director of ''Hope and Glory'' was heading off to collect several awards from the Los Angeles Film Critics Association, including one for best picture of the year.
Last Saturday, his gently humorous autobiographical film about a young boy's coming of age during World War II also won a Golden Globe Award.

Coast Guard Seeks More Money to Avert Cutbacks
LEAD: The Coast Guard began a campaign yesterday to rally public support behind its effort to fill a $100 million shortage in its 1988 budget, a gap that officials said would ''allow more drugs into this country.''


Sandinistas Feel Sting Of an Unshackled Press
LEAD: The opposition newspaper, La Prensa, has published articles recently saying that Nicaragua is in the midst of a ''wave of repression'' that includes the use of jails ''dreadful enough to recall Treblinka and other Nazi concentration camps.''


Score of 'Phantom': How Good Is It?
LEAD: What is the music of Andrew Lloyd Webber's ''Phantom of the Opera'' worth?
Some composers and performers for whom songfulness is serious business are responding this week.


Rallying Cry: Remember Last Time
LEAD: They are calling it the Deja Vu Super Bowl.


NASA Delays Flight of Shuttle Until August
LEAD: The space agency announced today that it had delayed by two months, until Aug. 4, its target date for launching the next space shuttle.
The delay was caused primarily by problems with the solid-fuel booster rockets, the agency said.


Dollar Is Broadly Lower; G.N.P. Data Called a Factor
LEAD: The dollar declined against nearly all major currencies yesterday, reflecting disappointment in a key Government report on economic growth.


Apartments Planned for the Homeless
LEAD: A partnership of government and education, religion and banking has developed a $7 million plan to create 101 apartment units for homeless young families and the elderly in a handsome old building on the Upper West Side.


U.S. Patient Found With 2d Variety of AIDS Virus
LEAD: For the first time, a patient diagnosed with AIDS while in the United States has been found to be infected with a second variety of AIDS virus that was previously found mainly in West Africa.


Vancouver Symphony, In Debt, Ends Activities
LEAD: The Vancouver Symphony Orchestra, Canada's third largest, suspended operations after Tuesday night's concert because of poor attendance and a debt of nearly $1.5 million.


Clean Up New York With a New Handbill Law
LEAD: To the Editor:


Philip Morris Profits Rise
LEAD: The Philip Morris Companies reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 28.8 percent, on a 7.8 percent gain in revenues.

Many Nursing Homes Are Overlooking Needs Of Younger Patients
LEAD: Amid all the recent concern about conditions in the nation's nursing homes, the problems faced by one group have been overlooked, experts say.
Younger patients, some of them disabled since birth and others cut down suddenly by accident or stroke, make up a small but significant share of the residents of the nation's nursing homes.

United Artists Set To Acquire Daniels
LEAD: United Artists Communications Inc. said it intended to merge with a smaller, rival cable television company, Daniels &amp; Associates Inc.
The deal calls for Daniels' shareholders to receive $108 million in cash and $82 million in convertible preferred stock.
The deal will increase United Artists' subscriber-base by 48 percent, to 1.2 million subscribers in 26 states.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Before Chernobyl, to have a nuclear power plant was profitable - and also prestigious.
In addition to providing self-dependency in energy, a nuclear power plant guaranteed increased attention toward the region, including jobs, housing and social and cultural amenities.
But then the entire world started talking about Chernobyl.


School-Tower Plan in Doubt
LEAD: An unusual combination of politics, public perception, mayoral miscalculation and the legacy of the New York corruption scandals has thrown a proposal for an office tower into the center of a battle.


Home Improvement
LEAD: EVERY building using commercial electric power has a safeguard system of circuit breakers or fuses incorporated into the wiring.
If an overload occurs - when, for instance, too many appliances make too large a power demand - these devices automatically interrupt the current, preventing an electrical fire.


Hovering German Train
LEAD: West Germany said today that it would press commercial development of a train that travels without touching the ground.
The Research and Technology Minister, Heinz Riesenhuber, told reporters that the Transrapid train carried passengers at 255.9 miles an hour in a test last week.
Using electromagnets, it moves along an elevated track while remaining about half an inch above the rails.

U.S. Agents Search For Drugs on QE2
LEAD: Drug-sniffing dogs were taken aboard the luxury liner Queen Elizabeth 2 when it docked here today and hundreds of passengers had to wait in line for hours for their luggage to be searched.


Boxing Awards
LEAD: Mike Tyson, the undisputed heavyweight champion, was named Fighter of the Year by the World Boxing Council at its annual awards luncheon in New York yesterday.
The Marvelous Marvin Hagler-Ray Leonard fight of last April 6 was named Fight of the Year and Leonard was awarded a special trophy for winning his third world title.


Negotiating the Arms Treaty: Verification Issue Proved Thorny
LEAD: On Dec. 6, two days before Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan were to sign a new missile accord in Washington, American and Soviet negotiators were still arguing in Geneva about a key treaty detail.


REVAMPED REDMEN WIN
LEAD: Just when they thought they had it all figured out, the Villanova Wildcats learned a hard lesson in the art of adjustment.
Three weeks ago, after a 69-62 victory over St.
John's at Alumni Hall, most of the Villanova players agreed that they had caught on to the Redmen's system and knew how to stop it.


Following the Account
LEAD: An interesting aspect of the ad agency business is the way certain people follow accounts from agency to agency.
A most stunning example of that is at the Los Angeles office of Batten, Barton, Durstine &amp; Osborn, whose new president and chief executive, Eugene F. Cameron, 42, followed the Apple Computer account in from Chiat/Day.

Judge Sets Limits On Child Aid Society
LEAD: The Westchester County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children has been ordered not to say it is a police agency or a state agency and has been forbidden to lock up suspects.


Margeottes/Fertitta Wins Business Week
LEAD: McGraw-Hill's Business Week magazine has assigned its trade advertising to Margeottes/Fertitta &amp; Weiss.
The account, which has a budget of $2 million, was formerly served by the Edwin Bird Willson agency.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a campaign appearance by Vice President Bush misstated the circumstances of a 1986 meeting he had in Israel.
It was held while the United States was selling arms to Iran, not before the sales began.


Restaurants
LEAD: ''ARE there any New Yorkers in this place?'' asked a fellow diner one evening as we sat in the Crystal Room at Tavern on the Green, Manhattan's gastronomic Xanadu where every day is a holiday and the Christmas lights never come down.

Art Show at Armory
LEAD: ''Art at the Armory,'' an exhibition of paintings, drawings, prints and sculpture from the late 19th century to the present, will continue through Sunday at the Lexington Avenue Armory, at 25th Street.
More than 50 galleries from the United States, Canada and Europe are to exhibit about 1,500 works, among them paintings by Picasso, Matisse, Renoir, Picasso, Dali and O'Keeffe.


Santa Fe Off $1.75 a Share
LEAD: Shares of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation fell $1.75, to $45.75, yesterday in the wake of Wednesday's announcement that the company would pay stockholders a dividend of $30 a share, or $4.7 billion.
The payout came a week after the Henley Group, which owns nearly 15 percent of Santa Fe, said it was considering a proxy fight.


Gains at Nynex, BellSouth
LEAD: The Nynex Corporation and the BellSouth Corporation yesterday reported modestly higher earnings for the fourth quarter and the full year.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about a fat substitute developed by the Nutrasweet Company misidentified Norman S. Singer.
Mr.
Singer is Nutrasweet's director of new product development.
The article also misstated the location of the Monsanto Company, which owns Nutrasweet.
It is in St.


THE LAW: AT THE BAR
LEAD: Lawyers are reluctant to ask judges to recuse themselves - to step down from a given case - and it's easy to understand why.
Such motions are rarely granted, and if one is denied, an attorney can find himself before a judge fuming over the implication that he's anything but even-handed and judicious.


Revised Curbs on East-Bloc Trade
LEAD: The United States and its principal allies reportedly agreed today to tighten controls on the export of high-technology goods to Warsaw Pact members while committing themselves to keep shortening the lists of items banned for sale to Communist nations.


Pentagon Asks No New Weapons In Return for Backing Arms Pact
LEAD: In a departure from their practice with previous arms control treaties, the Joint Chiefs of Staff are not demanding compensation in the form of new weapons as a condition for endorsing the new treaty governing missiles in Europe.

Elizabeth S. Kean, 90, Mother of Governor
LEAD: Elizabeth S. Kean, the mother of Governor Kean, died early today at her home in Livingston.
She was 90 years old and had been ill for a month.


Vatican and the AIDS Fight: Amid Worry, Papal Reticence
LEAD: Pope John Paul II, who has spoken out on many sensitive issues of sexual ethics, has not addressed the campaigns under way in many parts of the world to help prevent the spread of AIDS by promoting ''safe sex'' and specifically the use of condoms.

BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JANUARY 29, 1988
LEAD:  Companies


Volvo's Loan Plan
LEAD: Volvo Cars of North America said it would offer buyers 10-year car loans, more than double the period that is customary in the industry.
The company said that a survey had indicated that nearly half of its customers intended to keep their cars for at least 10 years.


Bush-Kemp Alliance Passes First Test in Michigan
LEAD: The new alliance between Vice President Bush and Representative Jack F. Kemp has passed its first test, a 12-hour session to settle credentials challenges for the Republican state convention that begins Friday.


MUSIC: VIOLIN AND CELLO DUO
LEAD: ENTHUSIASM - especially when it is supported by two strong techniques - is hard to resist in any musical format.
Laura Hamilton and Lanny Paykin gave us an unusual one on Wednesday night in Merkin Hall - a violin and cello duo augmented only in Beethoven's String Trio in G. Here Michael Ouzounian, Miss Hamilton's colleague in the Metropolitan Opera


Jackson to Skip Debate Among the Democrats
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson abruptly canceled all campaign appearances for Friday afternoon and Saturday and will skip a South Dakota Democratic debate because he needs some rest, a spokeswoman said today.


Investor Sells Stake
LEAD: A member of the investment group Ivanhoe Partners, which sought control of the Newmont Mining Corporation last fall, has withdrawn from the partnership and sold his stake in the New York-based energy and minerals company.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, John M. Harbert 3d, the owner of the Harbert Corporation of Birmingham, Ala., said he had sold 1.6 million Newmont shares for $34 a share.


NEW-MUSIC OFFERINGS FOR ADVENTUROUS EARS
LEAD: IN previous centuries, audiences expected new music; anything older than a decade or two was considered ''ancient'' or in desperate need of modernization, as with Mozart's reorchestration of Handel's ''Messiah.''

LEAD: The Rangers were outstanding tonight as they beat the first-place Philadelphia Flyers, 5-2, at the Spectrum and raised for Coach Michel Bergeron and the team's followers the following question:


Doles Team Up for Campaign Blitz Through New Hampshire
LEAD: It was shortly before 9 o'clock Wednesday night, and Senator Bob Dole was winding up his speech before a packed dinner of the town's Chamber of Commerce.
His wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole, sat beside him.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A table in Business Day yesterday with an article on the gross national product gave an incorrect number for the G.N.P. deflator.
The deflator, a measure of prices throughout the economy adjusted to reflect changes in the composition of the G.N.P., was 2.7 percent in the fourth quarter.


Ballet: Suzanne Farrell Returns, in 'Waltzes'
LEAD: SUZANNE FARRELL made a triumphant return to the New York City Ballet Wednesday night when she swept through George Balanchine's ''Vienna Waltzes'' at the New York State Theater.


Transactions
LEAD: BASEBALL  BOSTON (AL) - Agreed to terms with Spike Owen, shortstop; Brady Anderson, outfielder; Pat Dodson, first baseman; Dan Gabriele, pitcher, and Randy Kutcher, infielder.
CLEVELAND (AL) - Named Paul Olden radio announcer.
LOS ANGELES (NL) - Agreed to terms with Mike Marshall, outfielder, and Ken Howell, pitcher, on one-year contracts.


Allegis Posts Loss; Delta Off
LEAD: Two major airlines reported mixed results for the fourth quarter yesterday with the Allegis Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, reporting a large operating loss that it blamed on severe winter weather while Delta Air Lines Inc, showed an operating gain attributed to higher fares.


A Sonic Mix On the Lower East Side
LEAD: THE Lower East Side has often been treated as a neighborhood producing one sort of music, neatly categorizable and easily stuffed away with the dirty laundry.
But when historians of the Lower East Side reconsider the facts, the 1980's will be thought of as an immensely diverse, fecund era for music.


Federated Board Holds Meeting
LEAD: Directors of Federated Department Stores Inc. met yesterday for a regular meeting in the wake of Monday's $4.2 billion bid for the chain by the Campeau Corporation of Canada.
Federated declined to comment on the meeting, but the company said it would have a response by Feb. 5.


Art: Change of Fortune For Viollet-le-Duc
LEAD: ONE of the more astonishing among recent reversals of accepted opinion is summed up in an exhibition entitled ''Viollet-le-Duc: Architect, Artist, Master of Historic Preservation'' at the Grey Art Gallery.
Until quite lately, there were literally no limits to the unpopularity of Eugene Viollet-le-Duc (1814-1879), the architect who from 1840 onward was in charge of the preservation of historic buildings all over


A Narrow Escape
LEAD: Nella Domenici, daughter of Senator Pete V. Domenici, recently survived a fire in a Manhattan apartment building that claimed five lives.

LEAD: Representative Patricia Schroeder has a bone to pick with a Reagan Administration official over the size and role of Congressional staffs.


Horse Racing Notebook; Eclipse Award Election Needs Reform
LEAD: The system for electing thoroughbred racing's Horse of the Year clearly needs revamping - not because Ferdinand won by so narrow a margin when the results were announced Wednesday, but because only one vote kept him from unfairly losing the title.


Cuomo Broke Budget Surplus Agreement, G.O.P. Senators Charge
LEAD: State Senate Republicans said today that the state's budget surplus was almost $300 million higher than Governor Cuomo has estimated.
They accused the Governor of having spent most of the difference on routine state operating expenses instead of putting the money, as agreed, into a special capital fund for roads and housing.


HART CHALLENGES MOTIVES OF CRITICS
LEAD: Gary Hart fought back against his critics today, suggesting that he had become a special target of the press and of his party because ''my candidacy is different and it is the fact of that difference that threatens the defenders of the status quo.''


Slower Spending And Fed's Policy
LEAD: THE American economy grew faster in the final quarter of 1987 than most economists expected.
But since most of the gain was due to an unintended surge of inventories, a sharp slowdown in the economy appears to be in the works.
While it is not yet the general view, some economists think a 1988 recession may have begun.


Waning Days Cast New Glow Over White House
LEAD: Nancy Reagan, sitting in the Capitol Monday night watching her husband deliver his State of the Union Address, was touched by the moment.
This performance, so familiar after six re-runs, was making its final appearance on national television.

Citicorp to Buy Arizona Bank
LEAD: Citicorp announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the United Bank of Arizona in Phoenix and merge it into its existing subsidiary in the state, Citibank Arizona.

Jay Hoggard
LEAD: Jay Hoggard, a vibraphonist, is leading a group tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750).
Sets begin at 9, 10:30 P.M. and midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Sunday.
There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.
Tonight's first set will be broadcast by WKCR, 89.9 FM.

LEAD: In the television battle between Vice President Bush and Dan Rather, the CBS News anchor, Americans divided sharply along party lines, with Democrats backing Mr.
Rather and Republicans supporting Mr.

The Proper Study Of Economists
LEAD: To the Editor:


Opera Coach Died in His 'House of Worship'
LEAD: Until a few months ago, Bantcho Bantchevsky, the 82-year-old opera coach who plunged to his death at the Metropolitan Opera House last Saturday, was a gregarious man, rich in friendships and surrounded by music.


Bulgaria Parley Is Foretaste Of a Scaling Down of Change
LEAD: The Bulgarian Communist Party, which startled the rest of the Soviet camp last year by moving to change its Government, society and economy, opened a special conference today that signified a sharp scaling down of its initiatives.


Grand Plan for a Park Stalls in Miss Liberty's Shadow
LEAD: A $10 million private marina proposed for prime public waterfront at Liberty State Park has slowed the development of the park and jeopardized the organization managing it.
The 750-acre park has been extolled as potentially one of the grandest in the New York metropolitan region, with the Manhattan skyline and Statue of


Cab-Robbery Suspect Seized
LEAD: A 23-year-old suspect in a series of cab robberies in East Harlem was arrested last night at East 102d Street and Lexington Avenue, the police said.
The suspect, Erick Mourino, of 60 East 102d Street, was charged with one count of robbery.


Norway Joblessness Up
LEAD: Unemployment in Norway, which has one of the lowest levels of joblessness in the West, rose 25 percent in January, to 42,600 from 31,500.
The rate, however, is still at only 2 percent of the working population.


Perles Staying Put
LEAD: Even the possibility of someday earning a fifth Super Bowl ring could not break the loyalty of Coach George Perles to Michigan State University.
So the head coach of the Spartans, who earned about $200,000 for leading Michigan State to its first Rose Bowl victory in 22 years, has turned down an offer to coach the Green Bay Packers for five years for a reported $1.8 million.

Jewish Heritage Songs
LEAD: Nico Castel, a tenor with the Metropolitan and New York City Opera companies, will sing ''Songs From the Jewish Heritage,'' Sunday at 7 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.
He will be accompanied by Ann Lewin, pianist, and C. J. Everett, percussionist.
The program includes Russian-Jewish and Yiddish songs arranged by Rimsky-Korsakov, Glinka, Mussorgsky and Shostakovich; Sephardic songs and liturgical chants, and pieces by Gounod, Ravel and Castelnuovo-Tedesco.


Icahn Hints at Strategy
LEAD: Carl C. Icahn, the largest shareholder of Texaco Inc., told the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that he might join with a third party to buy more Texaco stock.


Raymond Williams, British Writer, 66, Dies
LEAD: Raymond Williams, a cultural historian and critic who championed the arts for the working class and taught at Cambridge and Oxford universities, died on Tuesday at his home here.
He was 66 years old.

Diner's Journal
LEAD: CONSIDERING the sizable demand for vegetarian fare in New York, there are few places around that make an effort to be distinctive in either ambiance or food.
A happy new exception is the Health Pub, a cheerful vegetarian cafe at 371 Second Avenue, at 21st Street.
The two large dining rooms are crisp and tidy, done in soft beige with butcher-block tables.


Vatican Leader Questions Some Bible Scholarship
LEAD: The Vatican's chief keeper of the faith raised some sharp questions Wednesday and yesterday about modern methods of studying the Bible, but at the same time he showed himself to be no friend to biblical fundamentalism.


Theater: 'Hedda Gabler'
LEAD: In his stage directions for ''Hedda Gabler,'' Ibsen calls for the Tesman drawing room to be decorated with bouquets of flowers, in celebration of Hedda's wedding.
For the opening scene of his production at the Hartford Stage Company, Mark Lamos festoons the stage with bouquets, not as a sign of beauty but of the airlessness that is pervasive, of the decay that has already begun to infect the marriage.


Israeli General Describes Charges Of Brutal Beatings as 'Just Stories'
LEAD: A top Israeli general said today that beatings of Palestinian civilians by troops were ''exceptions'' to Government policy and that many of the widespread complaints of brutality were rooted in ''imagination.''


Coca-Cola Unit To Buy Bottlers
LEAD: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., the bottling subsidiary created by the Coca-Cola Company in 1986, said it was buying several bottling operations from the large soft-drink manufacturer for $500 million.
Last week, the parent company said it would reorganize its American subsidiary, Coca-Cola U.S.A., to respond to changes in its bottling operations.


Film: 'Mammame,' Tribe of Dancers
LEAD: ''MAMMAME,'' which will be seen in its first New York screenings today and tomorrow at Film Forum 2, is the work of Raul Ruiz, the Chilean expatriate film director, and Jean-Claude Gallotta, the French experimentalist choreographer.
Mr.
Ruiz is a surrealist.
Mr.
Gallotta is a fabulist.
And the surprisingly immediate private worlds of these two enfants terribles of the arts are complementary here.


Gault on Bobsled Squad
LEAD: Willie Gault, the Chicago Bears wide receiver, was named today to the men's bobsled team that will compete for the United States in the Winter Olympics next month at Calgary.


Precedent for Lower Courts: Tyrant or Teacher?
LEAD: To say that judges of lower courts follow precedent has long been a maxim seemingly unworthy of debate in the American legal system.
But that unquestioned belief suddenly lies at the heart of the next round in the battle over the Federal judiciary.

Computervision-Prime Deal
LEAD: The Computervision Corporation has accepted a $434 million takeover offer from Prime Computer Inc., the two Massachusetts companies announced yesterday.


BRIEFS
LEAD:  Debt


An Officer Sues Hasidic Patrol In Assault Case
LEAD: A 49-year-old officer in the New York City housing police filed a $2 million lawsuit yesterday against a Hasidic community patrol in Brooklyn and five of its members, who he said beat him and tried to take his service revolver when he went to the aid of an elderly man they were kicking and pummeling.


Fear of Lending
LEAD: To the Editor:


Seattle Journal; Downtown Epidemic Of Growing Pains
LEAD: On a recent visit to Seattle, the New York humorist Fran Lebowitz was asked what she thought of the city. ''It's cute,'' she replied. ''Why are they tearing it down?''


Art: Works by Richard Artschwager
LEAD: THE Richard Artschwager retrospective, a survey of 25 years of art, looks wonderful installed in the big fourth-floor galleries of the Whitney Museum of American Art, and it also looks fresh and informative.
This is no mean feat for an artist of Mr.
Artschwager's popularity.
Throughout the 1960's, his idiosyncratic, multifaceted work hovered in the vicinity of Pop, Minimalism and Photo-Realism without ever requesting permission to land.


ARCO Purchases 14% Of Britain's Tricentrol
LEAD: ARCO said today that it had acquired an interest of 14.6 percent, or about $43.7 million, in Tricentrol P.L.C., an independent British oil company that is fighting an acquisition offer from Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, France's state-owned oil company.

Dollar Edges Up Slightly In Extremely Light Trading
LEAD: The dollar rose marginally against most of the leading currencies yesterday, but traders said there was very little activity.


BANKRUPTCY FILED BY LEADING UTILITY IN SEABROOK PLANT
LEAD: Beleaguered by the controversy surrounding the Seabrook nuclear power plant, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, the first major public utility to take that step since the Depression.

The 1935 'Mutiny'
LEAD: The 1935 film ''Mutiny on the Bounty,'' with Charles Laughton, Clark Gable and Franchot Tone, will be shown Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Fraunces Tavern Museum, 54 Pearl Street.
This version, directed by Frank Lloyd, features Clark Gable as Fletcher Christian and Charles Laughton as Captain Bligh.
The screening is part of the museum's film series, ''Love, Intrigue and Revolution: 1715-1830.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 415 money market mutual funds increased $1.22 billion, to $274.83 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 113 institutional funds increased $499.1 million, to $80.26 billion.
Assets of the 207 general-purpose funds were up $83.1 million, to $81.24 billion.


Poll Finds Support For Space Shuttle, But Doubts Persist
LEAD: Two-thirds of American adults say the space shuttle program is worth continuing, but as many also expect it not to be ''successful'' by the end of this year, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.


Klaus Fuchs, Physicist Who Gave Atom Secrets to Soviet, Dies at 76
LEAD: Klaus Fuchs, the German-born physicist who was imprisoned in the 1950's in Britain after being convicted of passing nuclear secrets to the Soviet Union, died yesterday, the East German press agency A.D.N. reported.
He was 76 years old.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article on Wednesday about Secretary of State George P. Shultz's plans to meet with two Palestinians, and a correction in this space yesterday, misidentified a speaker for an event to be held tomorrow at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in Manhattan.

Corrections
LEAD: The introduction yesterday to the text of the ''basic speech'' of Richard A. Gephardt, Democratic candidate for the Presidency, misstated his title.
He is a Representative from Missouri, not its former Governor.

LEAD: AT the age of 40, Klaus Drittemann, a writer and performer of protest songs, is given a one-way visa to leave East Germany for the West.

He's a bristly character and has been a merciless critic of the East German Government for failures to realize its


Perot, in an Article, Takes a Jab at G.M.
LEAD: H. Ross Perot, the Dallas billionaire not known to mince words or turn down a good platform for speaking them, audaciously tells ''How I Would Turn Around G.M.'' in the issue of Fortune magazine that comes out Monday.


Charles Tennant, 33, Zoning-Law Specialist
LEAD: Charles E. Tennant, a lawyer specializing in zoning and land-use issues, died of lymphoma yesterday at New York Hospital, according to a hospital spokesman, Jed Golden.
Mr.
Tennant was 33 years old and lived in Manhattan.


The 'March of Folly' in Further Contra Aid
LEAD: In her classic book ''The March of Folly,'' the historian Barbara Tuchman notes the compulsion of national leaders all through history to behave woodenheadedly - that is, to follow policies contrary to those indicated by good sense and enlightened self-interest.
Calling Philip II of Spain ''the surpassing woodenhead of all sovereigns,'' she observes, ''No experience of the failure of his policy could shake his belief in its essential excellence.


Viking Pact for Burns
LEAD: Mike Lynn, the general manager of the Minnesota Vikings, said yesterday that the Vikings had offered Coach Jerry Burns a two-year contract extension.
Lynn said he expected Burns to agree to the extension to the three-year contract he signed before the 1986 season. ''I don't think it's right for a coach to have one year left,'' Lynn said.

LEAD: The McDonald's Corporation said today that its profit for the fourth quarter of 1987 rose 14.1 percent over the period a year earlier.

White Plains Police Revise Report of Lawyer's Suicide
LEAD: The police said a former president of the Westchester County Bar Association who killed himself Monday did not fire the fatal shot while on the telephone as they originally reported.


Estimate Board Delays Vote on School Project
LEAD: The New York City Board of Estimate, lacking the votes to approve a Koch administration plan to have private developers renovate a landmark school in exchange for air rights to build a 48-story office tower next door, delayed acting on the plan yesterday.


Bonds Rise Again on Rate Hopes
LEAD: Bond prices continued to rise yesterday as investors and traders remained convinced that slower economic growth in coming months would keep inflation low and bring lower interest rates.


Opening Night Plans For U.S.-Soviet Festival
LEAD: Opening night of Making Music Together, a three-week arts festival to be staged here by American and Soviet performers starting March 11, is to feature Dzhansug Kakhidze, a Soviet conductor, and Maksim Vengerov, a violinist.


'Alto e Basso'
LEAD: ''Alto e Basso,'' a program of music for the lower strings, will be offered Sunday at 3 P.M. at St.
Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street.
The three musicians - Richard Spencer, violist; Lawrence Zoernig, cellist, and Joseph Russo, bassist - will play works by Rossini, Haydn and Beethoven.

LEAD: A burst of gunfire ended a 13-day standoff today between a polygamist clan and the police.

The Games We Play
LEAD: Are we all just a little mad?


Aircraft Maker Recounts Paying $25,000 to Nofziger for Lobbying
LEAD: Lyn Nofziger's lobbying firm received $25,000 from a military contractor a day before prosecutors say the former White House aide urged government officials to continue production of a warplane, according to testimony today at Mr.
Nofziger's trial.


Time Runs Out at Old Car Plant
LEAD: A sword has been hanging for years over the giant automobile factory here - the oldest operating auto-assembly plant in the country.
The sword fell Wednesday when the Chrysler Corporation announced plans to close most of its Kenosha operations by the end of the 1988 model year.


Bethlehem Profit Spurts
LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has reported that its income more than doubled in the fourth quarter, to $71.5 million, from $34.2 million a year earlier.


Rights Monitors at a Protest By Group of Jews in Moscow
LEAD: More than 100 Soviet Jews seeking exit visas demonstrated in Moscow today in a large and peaceful protest attended by members of an international human rights group.


Two Yale Unions Ratify 4-Year Pacts
LEAD: Two unions representing 3,600 Yale University employees yesterday approved a four-year contract with annual salary increases of six percent.


On Stage
LEAD:  Ibsen, via Bergman, in Brooklyn


Delaware Takeover Curb Near
LEAD: Delaware will soon have a new law that makes hostile takeovers of corporations more difficult.


Gretzky Expected Back
LEAD: Wayne Gretzky says he is ready to play again and expects to be in the Edmonton Oiler lineup for the game tonight against the first-place Calgary Flames.
Gretzky, who hasn't played since suffering a severely strained ligament in his right knee Dec. 30, said the knee was greatly improved. ''The knee feels strong, the range of motion is solid,'' he said.


Blood Banks Plan No Testing For 2d Variety of AIDS Virus
LEAD: The American Red Cross said today that it would not test blood donors for signs of infection with a second variety of AIDS virus that has just been detected in this country.

LEAD: Warner Books will publish Caspar Weinberger's first-hand account of his years as Secretary of Defense, from 1980 to 1987.
Mr.

AIDS TEST SOUGHT FOR U.S. COLLEGE
LEAD: American health officials hope to screen every student at a major university this spring to help determine the incidence of infection with the AIDS virus among young adults, C. Everett Koop, Surgeon General of the United States, said today.

LEAD: Clients at couture houses, where prices this season generally run to five figures, usually have a good collection of precious jewelry to complement their clothes.
Still, designers pay attention to the accessories they choose at their openings to carry out the mood of their clothes.
This season some of the accessories are memorable.


Income Up Only 1.2% Last Year
LEAD: Americans' after-tax incomes grew a sluggish 1.2 percent last year, the poorest showing since the last recession, while their savings rate in 1987 fell to a 40-year low, the Government reported today.

A Broad Decentralization at I.B.M.
LEAD: In a sweeping restructuring intended to reverse three years of disappointing performance, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday created five new, highly autonomous organizations that will be responsible for all of the company's innovation, design and manufacturing.


Art: 2 Gallery Shows On Marsden Hartley
LEAD: AMONG the early American modernists who were a part of Alfred Stieglitz's circle, Marsden Hartley has attracted an especially healthy dose of attention in recent years.
He was the subject of a major retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art in 1980 and of several smaller shows since, including two now.


CRONKITE TESTIFIES AT TRIAL
LEAD: Walter Cronkite, a retired anchor for CBS news, who is an avid yachtsman, testified today in the trial of an alleged leader of cocaine smuggling network that he was once shooed away from a Bahamiam island that prosecutors say was used as a way station by the smugglers.
He testified that he often visited Norman's Cay on his Christmas vacations.

Schering-Plough To Get Cooper Unit
LEAD: The Schering-Plough Corporation said it had signed a letter to acquire the worldwide contact lens operations of the Cooper Companies for about $150 million.
Cooper, based in Palo Alto, Calif., has received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing the first ultraviolet light-blocking contact lens in the United States.


Despite It All, Poland Rocks
LEAD: To the Editor:


Welfare 'Rights' vs. Children's Rights
LEAD: Supporters of welfare rights assail as ''punitive'' child support provisions in Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's constructive welfare reform bill.
The criticism is shortsighted.
The support provisions are essential to a plan that could put unemployed fathers to work and help repair broken families.


Music: The Cleveland
LEAD: AT age 74, Witold Lutoslawski remains the most consistently interesting of the band of avant-gardists who emerged from the social and political upheavals of Poland after World War II.
Like many composers of his generation from whatever country, he likes music made of angular lines, off-center rhythms, systematic atonality and structural formulas.

900 Age Cases Died Wrongly, Agency Chief Says
LEAD: The chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission admitted today that his agency deserves ''harsh criticism'' for allowing 900 age discrimination cases to expire before victims had a chance to gain relief.


2 Film Companies Set Stock Merger
LEAD: The New Century Entertainment Corporation, a publicly owned film company that had losses of $6 million in the first nine months of 1987, said it had agreed to a stock merger with New Vision Inc., a private, independent production company responsible for ''La Bamba'' and other films.


IU Rejects Bid; Offers Alternative
LEAD: The IU International Corporation has rejected as inadequate a hostile $520 million bid from Neoax Inc. and has offered shareholders an alternative restructuring plan.
IU, a trucking and waste management company, offered $14 in cash and a new share of its common stock for each of its 27.4 million common shares outstanding, or a total of about $383 million in cash.


Antonin Himl, Czechoslovak Politician, 54
LEAD: Sports Minister Antonin Himl, a member of the Communist Party Central Committee, died of a stroke in Beijing on Wednesday while visiting China with a sports delegation.
He was 54 years old.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: HORSE RACING  Nice Core Wins by a Neck: Nice Core raced near the leaders early, went to the front once into the stretch and held on gamely to win by a neck in the $31,000 allowance feature yesterday at Aqueduct.
Special Message, one of the outsiders in the field of 12, was the runner-up.
Nice Core carried 112 pounds under Carlos Correa for a mile and an eighth on the fast but dull racing strip in 1:54 to win his first race this year.


British Back Guilt of 6, Upsetting Irish
LEAD: After one of Britain's most politically sensitive judicial reviews, a three-judge court today upheld the convictions of six men for the murder of 21 people in the bombing of a Birmingham pub in 1974.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: Guy F. Atkinson Co., South San Francisco, Calif., which is involved in construction, steel fabrication and makes pumps and heavy machinery, appointed Robert D. Langford senior vice president, chief legal officer and corporate secretary.
Mr.
Langford succeeds Bryant K. Zimmerman, who becomes senior legal counsel, in anticipation of his retirement.


Merc-Comex Link Delayed
LEAD: The twisted route to a possible merger between New York's two largest futures exchanges took another turn yesterday, when the Commodity Exchange said it had been informed by the New York Mercantile Exchange that the Merc would be unable to respond to the merger proposal by Feb. 1, as previously agreed.


Film: 'Anguish,' Horror From Bigas Luna
LEAD: BIRDS fly around the room, and a little old lady with her hair in a bun croaks murderous orders at her son.
John always does what Mama says, so he leaves the house, kills a couple of people and gouges out their eyes.
He is, however, well raised enough to rinse off the eyeballs neatly in the victims' bathroom sinks.

Plan for Highway Through Amish Region Is Killed in Pennsylvania
LEAD: Declaring that the life and traditions of Pennsylvania's Amish ''should not be destroyed or dislocated or interrupted,'' Gov.
Robert P. Casey has killed a proposal to build a superhighway through the heart of the Amish country in Lancaster County.


Theater: Pearl Troupe In Sophocles' 'Electra'
LEAD: WHATEVER else one may say about the Pearl Theater Company, which has taken on the classics since its beginnings in 1984, it does not do things by halves.
This season, it has already come to grips with Shakespeare (''Macbeth''), Moliere (''The Imaginary Invalid'') and Shaw (''Candida'') and is readying itself for Chekhov (''Uncle Vanya'').

Mitchell House Given A Reprieve in Atlanta
LEAD: The stucco Victorian-style apartment building here where Margaret Mitchell began and finished the first draft of her novel ''Gone With the Wind'' has received a reprieve from the wrecker's ball, with Mayor Andrew Young turning down a developer's permit to demolish it.


Dr. John D. Lewis, 82, Teacher of Government
LEAD: Dr.
John D. Lewis, a professor of government at Oberlin College for 37 years, died of cardiac arrest Saturday at a nursing home in Oberlin, Ohio.
He was 82 years old.


Pop: Earth, Wind And Fire
LEAD: EARTH, WIND AND FIRE needs to work some bugs out of the elaborate show that opened a sold-out five-night stand Wednesday at Radio City Music Hall.
Reconstituted after a four-year hiatus, with seven sidemen bolstering five longtime band members, Earth, Wind and Fire had to force the buoyancy that made the band so popular a decade ago.


Strike Issues Still Unresolved
LEAD: Gene Upshaw, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association, said today that he was willing to resume negotiations at any time to achieve a new collective bargaining agreement.


Council Backs Housing Order In Yonkers
LEAD: After nearly five hours of being denounced by residents as wimps, liars, snakes and ''masters of deceit,'' the City Council voted early this morning to obey a Federal court order to build low-income housing in predominantly white neighborhoods.


New York's Three-Musician Limit For Clubs Is Held Unconstitutional
LEAD: A New York City law that sets a limit of three musicians on stage at a time in many of the city's clubs and cabarets is unconstitutional because it abridges the First Amendment rights of composers and performers, a judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday.

Unless he says more, voters are left to judge him by the known record.
It presents three possibilities, each disquieting - or worse.

Earnings Jump At Time Inc.
LEAD: Time Inc.'s net income more than quadrupled in the fourth quarter, to $52 million, or 88 cents a share, from $12 million, or 20 cents a share, a year earlier.
The company took a charge of $63 million, or 55 cents a share, in 1986's fourth quarter to cover the cost of staff cuts.
Revenues rose 9.7 percent, to $1.14 billion, from $1.03 billion a year earlier.


Simon Takes Off Gloves But Puts Them Back On
LEAD: Throughout last fall, after jumping to the front of the polls in Iowa and finding an unmistakable link with many of its voters, Senator Paul Simon of Illinois campaigned as the different politician.


Indictment in Asbestos Dumping
LEAD: A Staten Island construction company and one of its employees were indicted yesterday on charges that they used unsafe methods to remove asbestos from a Sanitation Department garage and dumped the debris outside a Bronx apartment house.


G.M. Rebate Plan
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it had added the Chevrolet Nova to its buyer-incentive programs by offering a $1,200 cash rebate to buyers who own an imported car and a $600 rebate to others.
The Nova is made by New United Motor Manufacturing Industries of Fremont, Calif., a G.M. venture with the Toyota Motor Corporation.

Stop and Shop Bid
LEAD: The Stop and Shop Companies said its board had rejected the Dart Group's $30-a-share takeover offer.
The board decided that it was in the best interest of the company to remain independent, Stop and Shop said.
The retailer's shares fell 37.5 cents today, to close at $31.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.


Albany Split as It Tries To Solve Garbage Crisis
LEAD: Stressing the need for quick action, the Governor, the State Assembly and the State Senate have each drawn up comprehensive legislation to deal with New York State's garbage crisis.
But the proposals indicate that so far the only point the three parties agree on is the urgency of the problem.

Col.
Oliver L. North's safe shows that participants in the White House-directed efforts to supply the contras sought to silence at least one witness who was helping Congress investigate the secret operation.


Don't Be Bullied by School Custodians
LEAD: New York City's public school custodians wield such excessive power that it warps administration of the whole school system.
The custodians have reigned unchallenged for so long that cutting them down to size won't be easy.
Yet that task remains essential to meaningful school reform.

GLENN CLOSE IN 'STONES FOR IBARRA'
LEAD: GENTLY and intelligently, ''Stones for Ibarra,'' the ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' presentation on CBS tonight at 9 o'clock, takes chances and ends up succeeding wonderfully.
There is an entrenched mechanism in television drama, with roots in the 19th-century novel, that forces writers into a naturalistic mode, a straighforward chronological unfolding of a story.

LEAD: The Detroit Tigers have offered Kirk Gibson a one-year contract extension with a no-trade clause, according to Greg Shea, a team spokesman, who refused to specify details of the offer.
Gibson, one of seven players declared a free agent until March 1 by an arbitrator last week, is being pursued by the Los Angeles Dodgers and is entering the final year of a contract with Detroit that will pay him $1.3 million in 1988.

He was 81 years old.

Nanne Quits Stars
LEAD: Citing the effects the continuing stress of working with the team may have on his health, Lou Nanne, the Minnesota North Stars' general manager, resigned yesterday after more than 20 years with the team as a player, coach and executive. ''I couldn't divorce myself during the game from the stress of winning and losing,'' said Nanne, who is 46 years old.

Film: 'You Can't Hurry Love'
''YOU Can't Hurry Love,'' opening today at the Gemini and other theaters, is a very dim comedy about how funny and peculiar sunny Los Angeles is supposed to be to a square young man from Akron.
It's the first feature written and directed by Richard Martini, who apparently has connections.
Appearing in throwaway cameos are Charles Grodin, Sally Kellerman and Kristy McNichol.

Peak Japan Jobless Rate
LEAD: The unemployment rate in Japan, seasonally adjusted, averaged 2.8 percent in 1987, the worst on record, the Statistics Bureau reported today.
In December, the rate stood at 2.6 percent of the labor force, down a tenth of a percentage point from November, the bureau said.

What's Behind Strange Tasaday Hoax Charges
LEAD: To the Editor:


Better Off Under Reagan? Mostly, No
LEAD: As we approach another Presidential election and in the aftermath of President Reagan's rosy State of the Union Message it is appropriate to revisit the question that Ronald Reagan used with such effect as a candidate in 1980: ''Are you better off now than you were when this Administration took office?


A MEMO TO MEESE SAID TO ASK CASH FOR ISRAELI PARTY
LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d was told in a 1985 memo from a close friend who wanted his help in arranging Government support for a billion-dollar Iraqi oil pipeline that the project would involve payments to the Israeli Labor Party, present and former United States Government officials said today.


CONSUMER'S WORLDCoping/With Restaurant Abuses
LEAD: Your party of four made a reservation for 8 P.M. at an expensive restaurant.
An hour later, you are seated without apology at a table near the kitchen in the path of rushing waiters.
You eventually order four steaks, rare; they eventually arrive, well done.
By that time it's 10:30.
The sentiment is a unanimous ''let's walk out.


Reagan Bars Mention of Abortion At Clinics Receiving U.S. Money
LEAD: In the first formal step of what promises to be a major legal battle, the Reagan Administration today prohibited most of the nation's family planning clinics from providing advice or other assistance that would help women obtain abortions.


Trying to Save Man, Woman Dies in Fire
LEAD: A Queens woman was killed yesterday afternoon after running back into her burning house to rescue an elderly invalid trapped by the flames in a second-story bedroom, the Fire Department said.
The invalid and another man also perished.


Comments on Paterno
LEAD: One person who seems unlikely to apply for membership in the Joe Paterno Fan Club is Darin Roberts, who in 1984 was a highly publicized and talented quarterback from Franklin High School in Somerset, N.J.
Roberts was heavily recruited, but he chose Paterno and Penn State because ''they told me I was going to play quarterback when they recruited me,'' he said.


Seats Are Sought On Ameron Board
LEAD: Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., which holds an 18.7 percent stake in Ameron Inc., has requested two seats on the company's board of directors.
In a letter Thursday to Ameron's board, Industrial Equity said its holdings in the contruction concern, based in Monterey Park, Calif., were ''nearly two times the next largest shareholder.


The Battle Against Fraudulent Ads
LEAD: ''Just take Dream Away before going to bed,'' said the advertisement printed in newspapers and shown on television last year. ''You will wake up the next morning slimmer, trimmer and looking better than you did before.''

Super Bowl Notebook; Humphries Expected to Start
LEAD: Stefan Humphries, the Denver starting offensive guard who was injured in practice Thursday, was reported feeling better today.
Coach Dan Reeves said he expected Humphries to start against the Washington Redskins Sunday in Super Bowl XXII.


U.S. Scales Back on Military Aid; Most to Latin Nations Is Dropped
LEAD: The Reagan Administration is cutting back sharply on security assistance to some key allies and is ending military grants to all of Latin America with the exception of three Central American countries, the State Department announced today.


AIDS and Headlong Headlines
LEAD: Much news about AIDS is grim, but the isolation of a new form of AIDS virus, known as HIV-2, from a woman in Newark is no particular reason for panic. ''New AIDS Bug Perils Blood Banks,'' gasped the hasty tabloid headline.
That's just what the virus doesn't do.


Prices Paid To Farmers Up by 2.4%
LEAD: The prices that farmers received for raw products this month rose an average 2.4 percent from last month's level and were 7.4 percent above prices last January, the Agriculture Department said today.


Britain and France Stay at Odds On Economic and Defense Policy
LEAD: The leaders of France and Britain failed to narrow their differences on economic and defense policy in talks here today, but they left the way open for further discussions on military cooperation.


Seabrook Filing Stirs Fears on Rates
LEAD: Who will set electricity rates for the customers of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire and whether the utility's assets will be sold emerged as major issues today following the utility's filing for bankruptcy protection.

LEAD: Nurses returned to work at hospitals in Los Angeles County today after a judge ordered an end to their strike, but pharmacists called in sick and doctors vowed to strike the county's largest medical center.

LEAD: West Germany and Japan posted record trade surpluses for 1987, according to reports released today.

Survey Finds Wide AIDS Ignorance
LEAD: A new survey has found widespread misinformation about AIDS, with 26 percent of the respondents thinking they would probably get the disease from giving blood and 36 percent believing they could get AIDS by eating at a restaurant where the cook has it.


U.S. and Brazil at Odds Over Arms for Libya
LEAD: American and Brazilian officials have been locked in a sharp dispute this week over Brazil's intention to sell a large quantity of arms to Libya.


Bush Prevails at G.O.P. Parley in Michigan
LEAD: Vice President Bush won the first prize of the 1988 Presidential campaign late tonight when he prevailed over Pat Robertson at a contentious Republican state convention here to capture the biggest share of Michigan's 77 national convention delegates.


Concert: Sinopoli Leads 2 Scriabin Symphonies
LEAD: A conductor who decides to conduct two Scriabin symphonies on one program is unquestionably a brave man, confident of his powers.
What can be questioned, however, is his good sense.
Scriabin's orchestral works, intended as mystical or philosophical revelations, are so much alike in their shapeless meanderings and overheated rhetoric that hearing two of them in an evening can be numbing.

South Korea Chief Says He Never Sought Power
LEAD: Although he seized control in a military coup eight years ago, President Chun Doo Hwan insists that he never actively sought power. ''The country was in peril,'' he said today. ''The job was thrust upon me.''

Investor Seeking A Chicken Chain
LEAD: Francis J. Spillman, a Dallas investor, has offered to purchase all of the shares of the Winners Corporation that he does not already control for $4.25 a share in cash, or about $15.4 million.
In a telephone interview, Mr.
Spillman said that he had had ''preliminary discussions with another chicken chain'' about the possible takeover of Winners.

Carteret Bancorp
LEAD: Alpine Associates, a limited partnership based in Cresskill, N.J., has purchased a 5.5 percent stake in Carteret Bancorp Inc.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Alpine said it had acquired the Carteret shares for investment purposes only.
Carteret, a bank holding company based in Morristown, N.J., has until mid-February to find a better offer than its $19 a share, or about $232 million, merger agreement with Home Group Inc.

Guidepost
LEAD:  Giving Gold  Valentine's Day is approaching, and gold jewelry remains a popular gift.
Beyond the choice of the item, decisions must be made about karats, color and texture.
Gold in its purest state is generally too soft for jewelry and so is mixed with copper, zinc, silver or nickel, which increases its hardness and modifies its color.

LEAD: They had a book-signing party the other night on West 46th Street in a narrow shop brimming with smoked sausages, meat pies, manioc flour, coffee beans, beer, books, cassettes and periodicals, among other items.
Nearly everyone spoke Portuguese, a silky language slipping off certain tongues.
The author, who is famous round the world but not so hot in this republic yet, is Brazilian.

LEAD: Senators will be sorely tempted to put their stamp on the treaty to eliminate medium- and shorter-range missiles.
The itch seemed irresistible as the hearings got under way this week.
But an array of political and military authorities told them the treaty was good for American security as is, and that other issues could be attended to elsewhere.

ARCO-Tricentrol
LEAD: ARCO slightly raised its stake in Tricentrol P.L.C. and indicated an intent to buy the entire company, an oil exploration and development concern.
ARCO, which swooped into the market Thursday and scooped up 14.6 percent of Tricentrol's shares, said its further purchases brought the total stake to 14.8 percent, or 13.8 million shares.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Angel Cordero, fully recovered from injuries to his chest and back suffered in a spill at Santa Anita Dec. 30, will resume riding at Aqueduct on Feb. 11.
His agent, Kevin Lyons, said Cordero's first stakes engagement would be aboard D. Wayne Lukas's Cougarized in the $75,000 added Whirlaway Stakes at Aqueduct Feb.


The Media Have Wronged Howard Beach
LEAD: Over the past year, ''Howard Beach'' has become the new catch-phrase for racism.

Desperate Financial Steps in '84 Come Back to Haunt Hart's '88 Campaign
LEAD: Out of cash and nearly out of hope, Gary Hart's insurgent 1984 Presidential campaign took desperate financial measures that are now dogging his already battered 1988 candidacy.


U.S. URGING ANGOLA ON CUBAN PULLOUT
LEAD: After seven years of intense but futile diplomatic efforts, the Reagan Administration is making a final attempt to reach an agreement on the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola and independence for South-West Africa.


ANSWERS TO QUIZ
LEAD: Questions appear on page 13.


CORRECTION
LEAD: An article and a drawing on the Health page on Thursday about strokes incorrectly described two arterial systems feeding the brain.
The vertebral-basilar system of arteries is parallel to the carotid arteries in the neck and behind them; the two systems join in the brain.


Brooklyn Navy Yard Thrives, but Not as Shipyard
LEAD: Workers for the American, French and Japanese joint venture called Nemko working on a train locomotive in a warehouse where battleships were once built. (The New York Times/Keith Meyers) Page 31.


City Ballet to Offer Bonus at Intermission
LEAD: Dancers from the New York City Ballet and the School of American Ballet will demonstrate the arts of makeup, costume and dance at the ''Family Matinee'' performance on at 1 P.M. tomorrow at the New York State Theater, Lincoln Center.


Guard Held in Gun Smuggling
LEAD: A New York City Correction officer was arrested yesterday in Brooklyn after law-enforcement officials said he had been videotaped receiving $3,000 for having smuggled a loaded pistol to a prisoner on Rikers Island.

Denise Stoklos
LEAD: ''Denise Stoklos Unearths Hamlet in Irati,'' a solo dramatic piece written and performed by Ms.
Stoklos, began performances this weekend at La Mama E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street.
Several issues are covered in the work, which is based on Shakespeare's ''Hamlet.'' In it, Ms.
Stoklos uses her childhood years in Brazil to examine the issue of independence for third-world countries.


Two Accused Of Extorting From Wedtech
LEAD: Two teamsters' union officials were charged yesterday with receiving at least $465,000 in illegal payoffs from the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor, in return for negotiating favorable union contracts and preventing labor unrest at the company's Bronx manufacturing plants.


Critic's Notebook; Unadorned but Complex Chekhov
LEAD: When Peter Brook first staged his production of ''The Cherry Orchard'' in Paris in 1981, he approached the play as, in his words, ''a theatrical movement purely played.'' The idea was ''to avoid sentimentality, a false Chekhovian manner that is not in the text.'' For him, ''The Cherry Orchard'' was not ''gloomy, romantic, long and slow,'' but ''a comic play about real life.


Student's-Eye View
LEAD: To the Editor:


Resurgence of Brooklyn Navy Yard Is Dealt Blow by Company's Rebuff
LEAD: When a ship repair company New York City officials hoped would help revitalize the Brooklyn Navy Yard pulled out of negotiations last week, it dealt a serious blow to plans to continue the yard's tradition as a major ship repair center.


Warner Books to Offer Trump in Paperback
LEAD: In an auction that ended Thursday night, Warner Books bought the paperback rights to ''Trump: The Art of the Deal'' by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz.

Greyhound Set To Drop Verex
LEAD: The Greyhound Corporation said today that it would get out of the mortgage insurance business.
As a result, the company will take an after-tax charge of $45 million in the fourth quarter of 1987 to reclassify its Verex Corporation mortgage insurance subsidiary as a discontinued operation.

Change at Apple Creates New Posts
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said it would restructure its research and development organization to encourage new products and emphasize products for networking and communications.
The action created positions for two new vice presidents who will report to Jean-Louis Gasse, senior vice president of research and development.

LEAD: The focus of Palestinian protest shifted to East Jerusalem today as relief workers charged that 50 Palestinians had to be treated for injuries after Israeli police officers swept through a refugee camp in a roundup of male residents.

Dance: At the World, 'Leonard and Cinciana'
LEAD: The theater was packed when Dennis O'Connor and Ann Papoulis presented ''Leonard and Cinciana'' at the World, at 254 East Second Street, on Thursday.
That was unsurprising, for Mr.
O'Connor is a gifted member of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company and Ms.
Papoulis is a performer of special resonance.


Driver Flees After Car Kills a Girl in Harlem
LEAD: A 9-year-old girl was killed and her two companions were seriously injured in Harlem yesterday when a car went out of control and struck them, the police said.
The driver fled.


SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.
Answers appear on page 50.


DEMOCRATS SPAR IN SOUTH DAKOTA
LEAD: The Democratic candidates for President brought their much-practiced road show to South Dakota tonight, jabbing at one another's weak spots and, along the way, debating issues from economics to Central America policy.


BULGARIAN REJECTS POLITICAL OPENING
LEAD: A top Communist Party official today defended Bulgaria's lack of eagerness to accompany its program of restructuring economic and administrative life with a parallel emphasis on greater openness.


Museum in Harlem Celebrates 3 Ways
LEAD: A major Harlem cultural institution, the Studio Museum, celebrated its 20th anniversary in decisive fashion recently by announcing a new executive director, opening two new exhibitions and becoming the nation's first black or Hispanic institution accredited by the American Association of Museums, the world's largest organization of museums.


REAGAN ON TV FOR CONTRA AID
LEAD: President Reagan will go on television Tuesday to press his plea to Congress to approve fresh aid for the rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government, the White House announced today.


Solti Set to Stay at Head of Chicago Symphony
LEAD: Sir Georg Solti said yesterday he would remain music director of the Chichago Symphony '' as long as my orchestra and board want me.''


Bankruptcy Judge Approves Texaco Financial Statement
LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge approved Texaco Inc.'s financial disclosure statement today, setting the stage for the oil giant's emergence from Chapter 11 bankruptcy.


A Wide Gap for Sandinistas and Rebels
LEAD: Sandinista and contra negotiators ended their first face-to-face talks here today with a decision to meet again in two weeks in Guatemala, but little other substantive agreement.

Europeans Assail Bill On Export Sanctions
LEAD: The European Community, in a note to the State Department, has protested a Senate-passed measure imposing sanctions against violators of allied export controls.
It threatened retaliation should European companies be hit by the legislation.


STUDY TURNS UP NO PROTECTION DUE TO ASPIRIN
LEAD: A six-year study involving more than 5,000 British doctors has found no strong evidence that regular use of aspirin reduces the risk of heart attack, but the authors say their data do not necessarily invalidate a similar but much larger American study that showed the rate of heart attacks was cut almost in half.

When the Census Is Precisely Wrong
LEAD: With the 1990 Census still 27 months away, the Commerce Department says it seeks ''the best census ever,'' including a reduction of the perennial undercount.
Yet it has decided, prematurely, that it won't consider adjustments that could smooth the undercount's uneven and unfair impact.
It's a mistake that could be costly for the cities and states that bear the undercount's burden.

'Tristan and Iseult,' By Boston Camerata
LEAD: ''Tristan and Iseult,'' a new production by the Boston Camerata, will have its New York premiere on Feb. 18 at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.
The drama, which is based on medieval musical scores and texts, chronicles the story of Tristan, Iseult and King Mark.

LEAD: Two film makers and a video artist are the recipients of this year's Maya Deren Awards, sponsored by the American Film Institute.
The three - Bruce Conner, Yvonne Rainer and Bill Viola - will each receive a $5,000 cash award.
J.
Hoberman, a film critic for The Village Voice, is to receive a citation from the institute for contributions to independent film and video.

B.P.'s Britoil Stake
LEAD: The British Petroleum Company has completed the purchase of the 24 percent stake in Britoil P.L.C. that had been held by ARCO and in the process gained a majority of the shares of the North Sea oil producer.
But B.P.'s control of the company's board still hinges on a Government decision.
The British Government said it was ready to meet Britoil and B.P.

South Africa Crash Kills 13
LEAD: A bus carrying black policemen on their way to give a gymnastics exhibition plunged off a mountain road today, killing 13 officers and injuring 71, the police said.
The crash occurred at Robinson Pass in Cape Province.

SMOKER'S LAWSUIT ENDS IN A MISTRIAL
LEAD: A mistrial was declared here today in a lawsuit against a tobacco company charged with causing a smoker's death by lung cancer.
The jury deadlocked in the case that had been widely viewed as having the best chance of succeeding of any brought by smokers who charged that their illnesses were brought on by cigarettes.


Out With the Bad Air: Dirt and Noise Fighters
LEAD: For city dwellers, winter can mean stuffy rooms and heating pipes that clank through the night.
Often an open window will only yield sooty, malodorous drafts and more noise.


Liggett &amp; Myers Told To Issue Smoking Data
LEAD: A Federal district judge, in a ruling that stemmed from a tobacco liability case, has ordered the release of secret studies on the dangers of cigarette smoking that were conducted for the Liggett &amp; Myers Tobacco Company over the course of 30 years.


U.S. Will Drop 4 Areas in Asia From Trade Aid
LEAD: In a hardening of its trade policy, the Reagan Administration announced today that it would end special trade preferences for four of the most powerful third-world economies: Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore.


PARTIES' ROLES REVERSED IN IOWA ADS
LEAD: The battle of the airwaves for the Iowa Presidential caucuses has produced a reversal of the usual party roles: Republicans are violating their own commandment against negative advertising while the Democrats are trying be inspirational without living up to their reputation for bloodying the television landscape.


'Highlights in Jazz' Concert
LEAD: A number of noted jazz musicians, including Tito Puente, Phil Woods, and Jon Faddis, will perform at a ''Highlights in Jazz'' concert on Thursday, at New York University, Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place.
The concert marks the 15th anniversary of the jazz series.
Also appearing will be John Pizzarelli Jr., Bob Mover, Tony Monte, Kenny Washington and James Williams.


Campeau Seeking Federated Talks
LEAD: Amid speculation that Federated Department Stores Inc. may be planning a restructuring offer that would be sweeter than its $47-a-share takeover bid, the Campeau Corporation said it was willing to negotiate the price with Federated.
In a statement, the Canadian real estate and department store company said it had sent a letter to Federated's chairman, Howard


Gibson Agrees to Sign With the Dodgers
LEAD: One week after a labor arbitrator made him a free agent, Kirk Gibson left the Detroit Tigers late last night and agreed to a three-year, $4.5-million contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers.


Beck Posts 63 For Lead
LEAD: After nine years of coming close, Charles Henry (Chip) Beck has more second-place finishes than any of the other nonwinners on the PGA Tour.

Five Firefighters Injured in Blaze
LEAD: Smoke and flames billowing from an apartment during a four-alarm fire in building at 360 East 72d Street.
Five firefighters were hurt, none seriously as more than 100 firefighters, using 25 pieces of equipment, fought the blaze for two hours before bringing it under control.
No residents were injured.

What's Do8ing in Cologne
LEAD: Cologne's age is disputed.
Peg its birthdate to 38 B.C., when it was established as a Roman garrison town by Marcus Vispanius Agrippa, the military genius who orchestrated Augustus Caesar's victory over Antony and Cleopatra, then it is 2,026.

THE WISE OLD GRANDMOTHER: FANTASY AND REALITY
LEAD: I USED to create fantasies of how I would be when I reached a certain age.
I even created the appropriate rocking chair and the porch where I would sit and view life passing by; where I would receive my children and tell tales of my past to numerous grandchildren, who would delight in my company; where friends would gather to reminisce happily about our long-ago adventures; where I would feel at peace - wise, loving and loved.
