GURNEY'S 'AMERICAN LIFE' REVIVED AT LONG WHARF
LEAD: WITH the current Long Wharf Theater revival of one of A. R. Gurney Jr.'s early works, the 1970 ''Scenes From American Life,'' and the opening Off Broadway of his latest produced play, ''Another Antigone,'' at Playwrights Horizons, chroniclers of Mr.
Gurney's career have a rare chance to see the playwright in perspective, and to contrast his past and present concerns.

THE AFTERSHOCKS OF AN ACCIDENT REPEAT A LESSON ABOUT SURVIVAL
LEAD: IN April my daughter and I were in a car accident.
We were driving to my parents' house in Pennyslvania; it was rush hour on a three-lane interstate highway.
I was in the right lane.
The 18-wheeler to my left didn't see me.
He pulled abruptly into my lane and hit my car, sending me spinning in front of him, where he hit me a second time.


Question Of the Week; WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL?
LEAD: Joe Gibbs is arguably the best coach in football.
John Elway is unquestionably the best quarterback in football.
This Super Bowl will be decided by these two men.
In the World Series, the on-field leadership of Don Baylor outmatched the off-field leadership of Whitey Herzog.
Super Bowls, like World Series, are won or lost on the field, not in the locker room.

LEAD: ON the Super Bowl sidelines, coaches have always projected a variety of images.
Vince Lombardi, as tough as his tombstone teeth.
Don Shula, as solid as his Mount Rushmore jaw.
Chuck Noll, as cool as his icy eyes.
Tom Landry, as unflappable as his snap-brim hat.
Bill Walsh, as organized as the game plan on his clipboard.

The Spell of the Rain Forest
LEAD: SO sudden is the change as one steps off the Tamborine Mountain Road (outside Brisbane, Australia) and into the pocket of subtropical rain forest that I feel like those children in ''The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe'' by C. S. Lewis; they stepped through a doorway in the back of a closet and abruptly entered a room that was another world.

The Editorial Notebook; Challenge to the Church on Race
LEAD: On a late summer Sunday in 1954, the pastor of the only Catholic church in Ashland, Ky., mounted the pulpit and made an important announcement to his parishioners.
That fall, he said, there would be a ''colored'' family in the parish for the first time - ''colored'' was the polite term for blacks in those days - and ''colored'' children in the parish school.

LEAD:  OUT ON THE RIM.

POSTINGS: Georgetown Conversion; Mixed-Use Complex in a Historic Mill
LEAD: When Georgetown, Conn., was placed on the National Register of Historic Places last March, it was recommended as ''a community which today resembles the rural industrial village of 19th-century Utopian ideology.'' The mill of the Gilbert and Bennett Company, founded in 1818, forms the center of the unincorporated village near Norwalk.

LEAD: THE state's new recycling law is a step in the right direction, but more needs to be done to reduce the amount of trash that is burned or buried in Connecticut, according to Russell C. Beisiegel, the First Selectman of Franklin.


Headliners; Ending in Colombia
LEAD: Drug traffickers in Colombia demonstrated a new level of ruthless audacity last week with the kidnapping and murder of Carlos Hoyos, Colombia's Attorney General.
American law-enforcement authorities considered Mr.
Hoyos an important ally in the campaign to prosecute the Colombian drug kingpins believed to be responsible for 80 percent of the cocaine entering the United States.


OUT ON A LIMB, SHOUTING
LEAD: Sinead O'Connor sings sweetly on her debut album, ''The Lion and the Cobra'' (Chrysalis 41612; LP, cassette and CD).
But not very often.
She's more likely to howl or snarl, to make her voice rasp or crack, to summon the gnarled embellishments of Celtic songs or the open-throated wail of arena-rock.


Marbled Paper
LEAD: To the Editor: Readers interested in Susan Lumsden's article ''Marbled Paper From Florence'' (Travel, Dec. 13) have an opportunity to learn of the process as applied to another material - slate.
The first exhibit dealing with this process as used on slate is on view at the Vermont Historical Society Museum in Montpelier through April 30.


Opera: Bernstein's 'Trouble in Tahiti'
LEAD: LEONARD BERNSTEIN'S ''Trouble in Tahiti'' has raised its public profile the past few years, but encased within the composer's newer, altogether grimmer opera ''A Quiet Place.'' It was nice on Friday to see this lovely, touching, delicately put-together treatise on love in the suburbs (the original is from 1952) floating free of its more recently acquired burdens.

POSTINGS: Coming Attraction; 9 Bronx Stores
LEAD: A former RKO movie theater is being converted into nine storefronts on Broadway at 232d Street in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx.
The 14,500-square-foot building, which David Magier purchased last August for $1.4 million, was built in the 1920's and for the past 20 years has been used as a bingo parlor.

James Killian, 83, Science Adviser, Dies
LEAD: James R. Killian Jr., the first Presidential assistant for science and technology, an architect of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, and a president of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died Friday at his home in Cambridge, Mass.
He was 83 years old.


Defer the Contra Decision
LEAD: Yes or no: Continue aid to the contra rebels in Nicaragua, or finally cut them off?
For the last seven years, the Reagan Administration has by hook and, almost literally, crook, kept the aid flowing.
This week Congress will vote on the newest proposal, for $36 million in aid, including $3.6 million in military aid.

LEAD: Q. I have a chair whose frame is made of white plastic that has discolored to an uneven beige.
Yet a painted metal brace is still white.
Is there any way to clean or bleach the plastic, or is there a white paint I can apply?

Nelson A. Rockefeller for 15 years.
Surprisingly, Mr.
Wilson's advice was exactly the opposite of what Mr.
Lundine had hoped for.

Wilderness Caesars and Their Wives
LEAD: To the Editor:


PREPAID PROGRAMS FOR HEALTH CARE ENCOUNTER SNAGS
LEAD: After 15 years of spectacular growth in which health maintenance organizations have enrolled nearly 30 million Americans, there are signs that consumers are losing their enthusiasm for the plans, which offer comprehensive medical care for a set fee.


Death Sentence Imposed for '73 Georgia Killings
LEAD: A jury today sentenced Carl Isaacs to die in the electric chair for the 1973 murders of six members of a family.


PROSPECTS
LEAD:  Investment Boom?


Key Matchups For Redskins
LEAD: Darrell Green, Redskins' cornerback, vs.
Ricky Nattiel, Broncos' wide receiver - Green is one of the two or three best cornerbacks in the league, with exceptional speed and an ability to be physical despite his small size.
Nattiel, a 5-foot-9-inch, 180-pound rookie, caught 31 passes for an average 20.3 yards during the season.


Cable TV
LEAD: Definitely a notch above the norm are the two films making their cable debut this week - the 1986 box-office smash ''Crocodile Dundee'' and the 1987 thriller ''Black Widow.''


INTELLECTUAL SEDUCTION
LEAD: I am an admirer of Joyce Carol Oates and of Henry A. Kissinger, and also of Mikhail Baryshnikov, Alexander Solzhenitsyn, Yevgeny Yevtushenko.
Imagine if an American leader and spouse were to give a dinner in the Soviet Union for their favorite Russian intellectuals.
The Soviet Government would have to pull many of them from Gorky, from Siberia, from phony psychiatric facilities, from exile, from defection.


L.I. SOUND NEIGHBORS FORM A COALITION
LEAD: REACHING beyond the political and geographic boundaries that divide them, government leaders of the areas bordering Long Island Sound have agreed to form a coalition to resolve environmental problems. ''We've got a lot of clout down here,'' Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin, a Democrat, said.


WHAT THEY'RE WEARING
LEAD: NOW, THE PAPARAZZI'S cameras catch them, though at the turn of the century it would have been the brush of a portrait painter.


Theater
LEAD: Last winter, Artificial Intelligence, an audaciously imaginative 22-member troupe of comic actors led by Nancy Cassaro, invaded the Ballroom, a normally staid Chelsea cabaret to put on a mock TV special, ''Vicki's Valentine Thing,'' which satirically recreated the sound and style of a 1967 family variety show.


U.S. PROMISE TO STUDY THE SOUND WAS RELUCTANT
LEAD: THE spending bill Congress passed last month included $2.2 million to continue environmental studies of Long Island Sound and the surrounding shoreline.


Reservoir Bursts in Soviet
LEAD: A sewage reservoir burst in Soviet Kazakhstan on Friday, releasing a towering wave of stagnant water and gravel that destroyed two bridges and caused deaths, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today.
Without giving a casualty toll, Pravda said people were killed when the mud slide destroyed a bridge on the road between Kapchagai and Alma-Ata, capital of the Soviet republic in Central Asia.


Kean to Propose a $11.8 Billion Budget
LEAD: Governor Kean will recommend a state budget of $11.8 billion Tuesday that includes money to raise minimum starting salaries of teachers and to create a new state division to deal with AIDS.


Breaking the Stalemate
LEAD: President Mubarak of Egypt has been here this week urging the Reagan Administration to get actively involved in the search for Arab-Israeli peace.
He had a central message, delivered with passion.

Bavarian Premier Assailed for South Africa Visit
LEAD: Premier Franz Josef Strauss of Bavaria said today that the South African Government promised to free 14 jailed blacks within a week and review the cases of more than 100 more.


This One Might Truly Be Super
LEAD: Year after year, Super Bowl football games have been anything but super.
In the last five years, in order, the Washington Redskins have won by 10 points, the Los Angeles Raiders by 29, the San Francisco 49ers by 22, the Chicago Bears by 36 and the Giants by 19.

NEW CYCLE BEGINS AT ST. JAMES
LEAD: A SERIES of concerts organized last winter at the historic St.
James Episcopal Church in North Salem drew such an enthusiastic response that a new cycle of ''Music at St.
James'' has been arranged for the final Sundays of January, February and March - with the first concert beginning this afternoon.


Islanders Cannot Keep Rolling
LEAD: All the repairs the Islanders made Friday were conspicuous by their absence tonight.
The team seemed to suddenly lose its sense of direction, and found itself humbled, 6-2, by the Montreal Canadiens.


Oral Record of a Loquacious Mayor Strains Storage Space
LEAD: In a high-ceilinged room in a 110-year-old building near City Hall, the ubiquitous sight and sound of Edward I. Koch is filling file cabinets at the rate of more than a drawer a month.


Settling Suits
LEAD: To the Editor:


Correction
LEAD: Because of a transcription error, a review of Primo Levi's book ''The Drowned and the Saved'' on Jan. 10 misstated the year in which Levi joined a group of anti-Fascist Italian partisans.
It was 1943.


NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JANUARY 31, 1988
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL/3-19


SUPER BOWL XXII
LEAD:  That Game Is Today


LOVE POSTS 66 TO REGAIN LEAD IN PHOENIX
LEAD: Fred Couples opened today's third round of the Phoenix Open with an eagle 2 on the first hole, then sank a 40-foot birdie putt on the second.
That was a strong enough start to get the attention of Davis Love 3d.


MUMBLING TO THE COMPUTER
LEAD: I would like to add to William Safire's collection of ''summative dribble-offs'' such as et cetera, blah, blah, blah and whatever (On Language: ''I am Appalled,'' Dec. 20).
Among folks who work in computer science, artificial intelligence and cognitive science, the term mumble has become a mildly self-deprecatory way to terminate a thought that has gotten beyond the control of its thinker.


Industry and River Form a Gulf Between 2 States
LEAD: As the Pigeon River winds through the Great Smoky Mountains in North Carolina, its waters are clear and filled with bass and trout.
But about 40 miles before crossing into Tennessee, the river turns the color of coffee, and the only fish found in it are bottom dwellers like carp and bullhead.


In Hot Pursuit of a Wonder Drug
LEAD: Over lunch at Danny's Restaurant here six years ago, a brilliant medical researcher from Johns Hopkins University and two brash New York brothers who fancied themselves company founders batted around ideas for creating a drug company.


DON'T CAST SHADOW ON ANIMAL SHELTER
LEAD: It was with great delight that I read your article on the progress of the plans to open a new Central Westchester Humane Society shelter  [ Westchester Journal, Dec. 6 ] .
It was with great disgust that I read Nancy Johnson's letter  [ Letters to the Westchester Editor, Jan. 10 ]  faulting the spending of monies for the shelter instead of for the human homeless and the use of an architectural firm for the planning.


MISS MATHESON WEDS W. H. SAWYER 3D
LEAD: At the Cathedral of St.
John the Divine in New York, Marie Matheson, a daughter of Gladys May Matheson of Townsville, Queensland, Australia, and the late Donald Duncan Matheson, was married yesterday to Willits Herbert Sawyer 3d of New York and New Haven.
He is the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Edward Case Sawyer of Zanesville, Ohio.

Correction
LEAD: A Travel Advisory report on Jan. 3 reversed the dimensions of the screen at the Max-Linder movie theater in Paris.
It is about 28 feet high and 54 feet wide.


New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:  THE STARS AT NOON, by Denis Johnson. (Vintage, $5.95.) A young American woman seeking ''the exact dimensions of Hell'' goes to Nicaragua in this story by the author of ''Fiskadoro.'' ''It is daring, this political novel that disdains politics, this philosophical work that rejects all philosophies,'' Caryn James said here in 1986.

EVELYN H. SEELER, LAWYER, TO WED
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs.
Richard W. Seeler of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Evelyn Harrison Seeler to John F. McKay 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
McKay Jr. of Hempstead, L.I.
The wedding is to be in September.
Miss Seeler, an associate in the New York law firm of Rosenberg &amp; Estis, graduated from the Kew-Forest School and cum laude from the University of Richmond.


GARDEN OF HIS OWN
LEAD: Jim Davidson is looking forward to cultivating his own garden this summer.
Mr.
Davidson, the president of Handleman's Garden Center, a White Plains landmark, has been selling plants and telling customers how to grow them for 32 years.


Correction
LEAD: A chart on page 9 of the Travel section today about airports around the nation locates Kennedy International Airport incorrectly.
It is southeast of midtown Manhattan, not southwest.


U.S. Envoy in Austria Would 'Set Aside' Rift
LEAD: The new United States Ambassador to Austria, Henry Anatole Grunwald, says it would be in the best interest of both Washington and Vienna to set aside the Waldheim affair, a magazine reported today.


TALKING: Home Office; The New Outlook On Taxes
LEAD: PEOPLE who run an office out of a home may no longer find it worthwhile to take allowable deductions on the office when preparing income tax returns this spring.


ALEXIS EFTHIMIOU TO WED IN APRIL
LEAD: The engagement of Alexis Efthimiou to Scott Livington Probasco 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Probasco Jr. of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs.
George B. Efthimiou of Garden City, L.I.
An April wedding is planned.


Where Dance Is Heading
LEAD: Is the party over?
Has American dance, re-cently perceived as the pride of American creativity, actually become estranged from the culture around it?


Gretzky Returns
LEAD: IT was his first day back at work after the longest layoff of his career, and for Wayne Gretzky it was a busy, if ultimately unsatisfying, night Friday in Edmonton.
He set up all four Oiler goals in a game against Calgary, but the Flames got five, spoiling Gretzky's return after a 13-game absence.


A California Inn for Romance
LEAD: DRIVING north from San Francisco toward Little River, (a three-hour ride on Route 101, six hours on Route 1) you can get so involved in the spectacular scenery along California's northern coastline with its rocky promontories, green hills and awesome vistas of the Pacific that you can easily miss the sign for the turnoff for Heritage House.


A WINTER'S TALE OF FIRE ISLAND, BETWEEN ICE AND OPEN OCEAN
LEAD: IT'S cold, and it's going to be a rough day on the beach.
I can tell as soon as I look out the window.
The snow is blowing so hard that I can scarcely see the crest of the dunes, 100 yards away.
A lone deer walks stiffly through the beach grass, and a marsh hawk fights the winds.
Nine mourning doves line up on my porch railing; with feathers fluffed up to trap air and preserve heat, they look like tiny hens.


JANE PENZINER TO WED DANIEL DAUSCH IN JULY
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs.
Michael L. Penziner of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter Jane Laura Penziner to Daniel George Dausch, a son of Kathryn Dausch and George Edward Dausch, both of Easthampton, Mass.
A July wedding is planned.


A Million Taiwanese Mourn as Leader is Buried
LEAD: Weeping women, in traditional mourning robes, kneeling along the funeral route of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo.
The body of the 77-year-old leader, who died on Jan. 13, was taken to his country estate outside Taipei.
The remains of his father, Gen.
Chaing Kai-shek, are in a mausoleum nearby.

FOOTBALL FANTASIA COMES TO POWER TOWN
LEAD: THERE will be a curfew in Washington this evening.
It is self-imposed and will begin at approximately 5 P.M.
The streets will be deserted, the delicatessen shelves emptied and most restaurants, drugstore and supermarket chains shuttered early.

Australia
LEAD: To the Editor: One thing travel agents and travel articles fail to mention is that the Alice Springs and Ayers Rock areas in central Australia are ''the fly capitals of the world.'' Seeking moisture, they attack the mouth and eyes.


MISS STERN WEDS MARTIN R. KRAVET
LEAD: Susan Leslie Stern, the publicity director for Saks Fifth Avenue in New York, and Martin Ross Kravet, the vice president of the Royal Abstract Corporation, a New York title insurance agency, were married last night at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens.
Rabbi Joseph Potasnik officiated.


THE MANY WAYS OF USING VERSATILE NUTS
LEAD: RECORD crops of nuts, especially walnuts and almonds, were harvested this fall in California, according to the Department of Agriculture.
This volume is good news for consumers.
Wholesale prices for walnuts are below last year's levels and almond production was more than double last year with prices also lower.


THE ANATOMY OF KNOWING
LEAD:  How do we know what we know?
In THE RING OF TRUTH: An Inquiry Into How We Know What We Know (Random House, $24.95), an immensely pretty book crafted as a companion volume to a public television series of that name on scientific inquiry, Philip and Phylis Morrison, master teachers both - he at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, she in classrooms for all ages - go a long way toward telling us.

Is there any way to clean or bleach the plastic, or is there a white paint I can apply?

AN AMERICAN HABIT: SHUNNING THE BALLOT BOX
LEAD: ONLY the very brave or the very foolish are making predictions about the voters' choices this year.
But one prediction can be made with confidence: Of Americans eligible to go to the polls, the largest group will shun all the candidates.
They will not vote.

Rethinking Needs Some Thought
LEAD: I recall reading in an old book that the world was rushed into production in six days, after which a complete rest was felt to be necessary.
Presumably, the work was considered perfect at the time.
Or maybe the result fell so short of expectation that the whole show was simply allowed to stand, flaws and all, to be rethought another day.

Dance: Balanchine's 'Stravinsky Violin Concerto'
LEAD: THE program note for George Balanchine's ballet ''Stravinsky Violin Concerto'' remarks that the choreographer used the same score in 1941 for an earlier ballet, ''under the title 'Balustrade,' with beautiful costumes and scenery by the late Pavel Tchelitchev.''

LEAD: Jade Hunter benefited from an uncontested early lead and an 11-pound swing in the weights to hold off Cryptoclearance by a length and win the $200,000 Donn Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.


No Clear Favorite, According to Poll
LEAD: Americans are almost evenly split over whom they want to win the Super Bowl, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
But even more say they don't care or don't know whom they want to win.

Maryland Politician Convicted
LEAD: A jury in Federal District Court on Friday found Clarence Mitchell 3d, a former State Senator, guilty of conspiracy and obstructing a grand jury investigation into his connection with a convicted Baltimore drug dealer.


POSTINGS: Five-Story Rehab; 21 New Co-ops In Fort Greene
LEAD: The five-story building at 147 South Oxford Street in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn cost Louis Perlman $700,000.
To that he added a $1.3 million gut rehab, and dividing his investment by the 21,000 square feet of space he created among 21 cooperative apartments, he found that he had developed unsubsidized housing for under $100 a square foot.

LEAD: LUKAS FOSS's now 15-year-old Meet the Moderns series is changing.
In recent years offered in pairs of programs, one at the Brooklyn Philharmonic's home base of the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the other at Cooper Union, the series - this season, at least - has abandoned Brooklyn and now consists of five single concerts in Manhattan, three at Cooper Union, one at Town Hall and one at Merkin Concert

Minority Students Still Lag, A Survey of Schools Shows
LEAD: Minority students were more likely than whites to be suspended or placed in classes for the handicapped and were less likely to graduate from the public schools in the 1986-87 school year, according to a survey whose results were issued Friday by the Department of Education.

Rebel Threats in Philippines
LEAD: A rebel band based here warned today that it may try to kill the United States Ambassador and other foreigners said to be supporting the Government's war against Communist guerrillas.
A rebel spokesman told an Australian journalist that guerrillas were considering an assassination attempt against the Ambassador, Nicholas Platt.


FOSTER PARENTING AND AIDS
LEAD: STEVE, 10 months old, pushed Emily, 14 months old, across the living-room floor on her three-wheeler.
Ricky, 9 months old, played with a hat.
Their foster mother sat on the floor, occasionally reaching out to hug or pat one of the children. ''A house full of kids - just what I always wanted,'' she said, laughing as Ricky hid behind the hat.

SHAPELY SKIRTS
LEAD: POUFS ARE FAST BECOMING passe for evening, but the bouncy or puffed skirt is beginning to be big news for day.
Some of the most forward of the new spring styles, while fairly simple above the waist, wind up in skirts that look as though a passing breeze could tilt them this way and that.
Sometimes, the effect is achieved with a petticoat or two propping up a fullish skirt.

Glittering Crystal From Portugal
LEAD: LIKE some ancient ritual fire dance, shadowy figures dart hither and yon, bearing blazing torches.
One man jabs the air with a great glob of fire; another rolls a flaming mass in rapid swirls; still others breathe life into their burning bubbles.

LEAD:  The Dog in the Poet

The lifting of his spirits prompted some almost hysterically enthusiastic love letters, like this one from ''Rilke and Benvenuta: An Intimate Correspondence'' (Fromm).

MOTHER'S NETWORK: FEMINISM AT AGE 40
LEAD: IN my small suburban town, a group of children are shared freely by a group of mothers who happen to be friends.
The friendships began with the children, but they have grown more quickly than the toddlers who used to crawl on our laps and upset coffee cups when we were full-time mothers.
All of us have jobs outside our homes now, with a variety of titles, hours, responsibilities and pressures.

LEAD: I LIKED TV even before it became trendy.
For a long time this meant guilt.
I was reared on Praire Public Television in Fargo, N.D., as a sort of intellectual irrigation -without it, cultural death - and was disdainful of commercial entertainment.

LEAD:  DOMESTIC REVOLUTIONS  A Social History of American Family Life.
By Steven Mintz and Susan Kellogg.
Illustrated. 316 pp.
New York: The Free Press. $22.50.


Strategies for Harried Air Travelers
LEAD: WHILE storm clouds and spare parts still cause most flight delays, a growing number of late planes are the result of crowded airports.
Yet avoiding airport congestion can be as simple as bypassing congested airports.
Most major American cities have mid-sized airports in and around them that are served by major airlines but are less busy than the city's main facility.


Music
LEAD: Increasingly, classical music lovers are finding some of their deepest satisfactions before and after the ''standard repertory,'' which means mostly music composed between the late 18th and early 20th centuries.
This week, there are piquant events both old and new to be heard.

THE BEAUTY - AND MYSTERY - OF GLASS
LEAD: A WHILE ago, a friend at odds with his colleagues told of a dream in which they were feeding him glass.
This writer, at an offbeat exhibition recently, recalled her visceral reaction to his story when she confronted a pile of broken glass contained within a circular rim.
Glass at its rawest -jagged, brittle, uncivilized by shaping and capable of hurting - rarely shows up in galleries where glass is the theme.

Recalling Tet, the Attack That Began the End
LEAD: Col.
Do Tan Phong remembers Jan. 31, 1968, in vivid detail.

Classical Music: What Next?
LEAD: The date is Jan 31, 2038.
At 8 o'clock tonight, Carnegie Hall will be the scene of a special concert of rediscovered music - music that has not been played for three decades.
There will, however, be no orchestra - not enough people play the violin, or the cello, or the oboe, anymore.
All of the instruments will be played on a new computer, programmed for the occasion: the Bach 9000, which sounds more like an old-fashioned symphony orchestra than the real thing.


Racism in Sports
LEAD: To the Editor:


Marbled Paper
LEAD: To the Editor: Miss Lumsden asserts that ''marbled paper-making survives today almost exclusively in Florence.'' This is most certainly not true.
Neither can Italy, nor France, whose firm of Michel Duval is referred to in the article, be said to be the only Western countries in which the marbling tradition continues.

Fossilization Evolves Into a Modern Metaphor
LEAD: One of the stranger and more revealing aspects of art this season has been the number of works suggesting fossilization.
In some sculptures, human beings and plants seem embedded in earth or frozen in stone.
In others, industrial objects resembling plants and bones lie on the floor like prize findings of a dig.

LEAD: WINTER vacation: a time for family to sit together by the fire.
My 63-year-old husband wants to learn to ski.
I want to do some cross-country skiing.
My stepson-in-law wants to ski.
My stepdaughter, four months pregnant, wants to ski; the obstetrician says don't go down hill.
My 17-year-old wants to ski.

LEAD: TAKE a walk down Main Street of any town born a century or more ago and you will find evidence of the fascination for house plants during the Victorian era.

AS THE ROOM TURNS
LEAD: THE HISTORY OF A ROOM IS A scrapbook of lives; the evolution of its decor, a record of evolving tastes and fashions.
The room shown here was originally the newspaper publisher Joseph Pulitzer's bedroom.
Tucked away on the upper floor of an old New York house, Pulitzer's private quarters were grand, his bedroom measuring 32 by 36 feet, with 16-foot-high ceilings.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Skiing  Nierlich Leads Austrian Sweep: Rudi Nierlich, a 21-year-old from Austria, scored his first World Cup victory yesterday and led Austria to a sweep of the top four places in a World Cup giant slalom at Schladming, Austria.
Nierlich was timed in 2 minutes 45.54 seconds for the two runs down the course which dropped 396 meters and had 57 gates.

A Lyrical Pianist Who Had Everything
LEAD: Benno Moiseiwitsch (1890-1963) started recording in 1916, and thus he lived through several revolutions in the recording industry, from acoustic to electric, to LP, to stereo.
He was, along with Paderewski, Schnabel, Friedman, Gabrilowitsch and many other headliners of the day, a pupil of Theodor Leschetizky, who produced as many great pianists as Liszt.

When Bonds Lose Their Convertibility
LEAD: WHILE takeovers and restructurings may enrich common stockholders, owners of corporate bonds in many cases are left reeling from losses.
That has been particularly true in recent months for holders of debt convertible into corporate shares.
These bonds are generally sold at lower than prevailing interest rates because investors get a kicker: a chance to share in any appreciation of the common stock.

But CPC itself?
It seemed to have made a high science of keeping a low profile.

A HARDY SHRUB FOR WINTERTIME
LEAD: RECENT ice/wind storms may have broken limbs or branches; check yews, hemlocks, rhododendrons, junipers, birches, dogwoods and magnolias; if damage is found, saw or prune back to main trunk or strong wood.
If trees and shrubs are not broken, but bent over, they should right themselves naturally in time.

Governments loved them, and in a time of relative inactivity in the museum world the public often loved them, too.

SICK THINKING
LEAD: It is an excellent idea to take your spouse or another person to the doctor with you, especially if surgery is on the agenda.
The subtle mental dysfunction discussed in Morton Hunt's article must not cloud what lawyers and physicians recognize as informed consent to undergo a surgical procedure.
Relevant questions should be asked and note should be made of the risks of the intervention, possible complications and the expected benefits.

Riding A Ghost Train To New York
LEAD: THE Montrealer was a classic train.


Hints of Weakness In Growth Report
LEAD: The economy's growth rate for the final quarter of 1987 was deceptively robust.
Gross national product rose at an annual rate of 4.2 percent during the quarter, but most of the increased output piled up as unsold inventory, which is likely to be a drag on the economy in the immediate future.
The economy grew at an inflation-adjusted rate of 3.7 percent for all of 1987, the fifth year of expansion.

LEAD: ''I wouldn't be surprised to see negative growth in this quarter and even in the second quarter.''


Jury Awards Are Too Big
LEAD: IN too many cases, the American legal system treats civil violations as if they were criminal.
There are fundamental differences between criminal and civil offenses, and there are large costs from confounding them.


PERSPECTIVES: Assessments on Offices; A Heavier Load for the 'Second Tier'
LEAD: IN the past, there was a type of investment property that the city's assessors called ''sleepers.'' These were the buildings that the were suspected of being underassessed.
But since there was no recent sale with which to confirm market value, and no income and expense data unless owners cared to protest an assessment they considered too high, assessors could greatly underestimate their true value.

New Yorkers, etc.

Taking Off From Tucson
LEAD: SOUTHERN ARIZONA.
To an Easterner who had never traveled to this corner of the United States before, the image Tucson and its vicinity brought to mind was of vast, dusty plains, an expanse broken only by the profile of a straggly cactus.
But, in fact, the natural beauty of this section of the Grand Canyon State is startlingly diverse; day trips from Tucson will take the traveler from the lush coolness of a mountain canyon to the raw beauty of a forest of saguaro cactuses.

Music: Ives's 'Holidays Symphony,' in Focus Series
LEAD: THE Juilliard School ended its weeklong ''Focus'' series, devoted to interactions between American vernacular music and the art music we call ''classical,'' with Charles Ives's ''Holidays Symphony'' Friday evening at Alice Tully Hall.
The performance, under Paul Zukofsky, was worthwhile: a reminder that there is broad music of deep feeling woven throughout this piece, which has been played rather infrequently since its overexposure in the years of the Ives centennial and the nation's bicentennial.

TOBIAS 'SCULPTURAL PAINTINGS' IN RUTGERS ZIMMERLI SHOW
LEAD: ABRAHAM Joel Tobias hasn't had a show since the mid-1930's, but he has made several murals.
The earliest, done for the post office in Clarendon, Ark., is dated 1942; the most recent is a fresco, ''History of Science,'' that the artist worked on from 1960 to 1975 but for some reason left incomplete.


FICTION
LEAD:  TITCH.
By Chaim Bermant. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) Chaim Bermant's brief eighth novel closely resembles the oft-told tale of the American Jew who comes of age during World War II, discovering in wartime his Americanness as well as his ambivalence about his Jewish identity.
The differences in ''Titch'' are that its bookish Jewish youth, the repository of his immigrant family's ambitions, is British; that the locale is neither the Bronx, Brooklyn nor Newark but Manchester; and that the forbidden fruits are rashers and the granddaughters of baronets.

Car Stereo: A Turn for the Better
LEAD: Music keeps chang-ing venue.
From church and palace, it moved to the public concert hall as its chief abode.
Then the parlor piano and later the phonograph and radio brought music into the living room.
And now it seems that music is on the move again, in more than one way.
These days, much of it is heard in cars.

New York State Harvests: A Mixed Picture
LEAD: New York farmers grew more apples, grapes, sour cherries, cabbage and sweet corn in 1987 than the year before, but fewer pears, sweet cherries and onions, according to a series of year-end farm reports issued this week, They also received less money for their fruit and vegetable crops last year, $308 million, compared with $324 million in 1986, a drop of 5 percent, the State Agricultural Statistics Service said.


TESTING THE POWERS OF SPECIAL PROSECUTORS
LEAD: THE challenge by the Reagan Administration and others to the constitutionality of court-appointed special prosecutors will soon come before the Supreme Court.
The Watergate-inspired law provides for independent counsels to investigate possible crimes by high-level officials.
Many conservatives assail the statute as a flagrant invasion of the President's authority to enforce the laws.


Does Rock Merit Subsidy?
LEAD: An article tucked away in a recent Billboard magazine and filed for future reference reports that Australia, which already provided a modest sum (slightly more than $50,000) in such support in 1985, is considering a significant expansion in public subsidies for rock music.
The debate in that country apparently revolves around such questions as who should administer the funds, whether they are better provided for international touring bands or for mid- or entry-level groups, and so forth.


Bearing Witness
LEAD: THREE YEARS ago, when I suggested an article to the editors of this magazine on ''the human cost of AIDS,'' most reporting on the epidemic was scientific in nature and people with AIDS were often portrayed as faceless victims.
By profiling a man with AIDS and his volunteer counselor from Gay Men's Health Crisis, I proposed to show the devastating impact AIDS was having on a few individual lives.


CHERNOBYL LEGACY: RUSSIANS WARY, TOO
LEAD: DESPITE the Chernobyl accident in 1986, in which 31 people died after a reactor exploded, the Soviet Union has clung to its ambitious plans for developing nuclear power.
By the turn of the century, Soviet officials hope to double - to more than 20 percent - the percentage of electricity generated by nuclear reactors.

LEAD: TWO decades ago bridge was a recreation of the capitalist countries, spurned by the communist world as a bourgeois pursuit that promotes gambling.

The 3,500-acre park is home to about 50 to 60 wild 20-pound turkeys, although, as a New York State park ranger, Gary Lawton, said, ''These turkeys aren't really so wild - they're somewhat tame because they're so used to seeing people in the park.

CANDIDATES HAVE BECOME A DEBATING SOCIETY
LEAD: In the midst of an exhausting string of debates, the Presidential candidates are wondering whether they are worth it.


Antiques; French Empire Rules at the Armory
LEAD: Period French chairs and commodes are more visible than they have been for many years at the Winter Antiques Show, which continues through today at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street.
There is, however, a dramatic difference.
For the first time at the nation's most prestigious antiques show, now in its 34th year, 19th-century styles - Empire through Art Nouveau - upstage those of the 18th century at most of the 11 dealers' booths where


Headliners; Postponing in Florida
LEAD: For the sixth time, Willie Jasper Darden has broken a date with death.
The United States Supreme Court last week blocked the execution of the Florida prison inmate, who was scheduled to be electrocuted this week for the 1973 murder of a Lakeland merchant, pending his latest appeal, which will be heard after the Court reconvenes next month.


New York Says Thanks To 'Ultimate Volunteer'
LEAD: His lyric tenor filling the room, Bishop Joseph M. Sullivan of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn offered a ballad about love.


Iowa Tactic: Shake the Hand That Shook the Hand of . . .
LEAD: Representative Marvin Leath of Texas seemed disappointed.
Here he had come all the way from Waco to persuade Charlie Gross, an Iowa farmer, to support Representative Richard A. Gephardt in next month's Democratic caucus, and Mr.
Gross confessed he was still leaning to Senator Paul Simon.


Tarte Flambee From Alsace
LEAD: IN the dialect spoken in Alsace, flammekueche means ''cooked in the flames''; the French flambee has a similar meaning.
Whatever it's called, tarte flambee is to northern Alsace what pizza is to southern Italy.


GERONIMO AND PRINCESS ALICE AND A WRITER'S CAREER
LEAD: DURING the summer of 1904, my parents, my little brother and I lived in St.
Louis, in one large room, of which we had only the privacy of curtained-off corners.


PIPELINE DEAL: INTRIQUE IN HIGH PLACES
LEAD: Shortly after Rear Adm.
John M. Poindexter became national security adviser in December 1985, a predecessor in the job offered him sober advice about a billion dollar Iraqi oil pipeline project that was supported by the National Security Council and by President Reagan.


Hutton's End
LEAD: To the Editor:


DURABLE STRATEGIES HAND ON DESPITE FAILURE
LEAD: PUT a strategy into the mind of the chessplayer and it stays there, embedded, forever.
It may fail miserably, yet that's not enough to expel it.
There are always myriad tactics to explain why the plan failed.
If the idea enjoyed one meager triumph, it might just as well have been hammered into Mount Sinai.


Bistate Team to Help Homeless Is Proposed
LEAD: A bistate crisis team should be formed to deal with the needs of homeless people who have established almost permanent homes in public transportation centers, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.

LEAD:  A TIME FOR GIANTS: Politics of the American High Command in World War II.
By D. Clayton James with Anne Sharp Wells. (Franklin Watts, $19.95.) A distinguished historian and the author of the well-received three-volume biography ''The Years of MacArthur'' here focuses attention on the careers of 18 top American military leaders.

LEAD: A Concert, a Tea, a Cruise  Black History Awards  Feb. 1 - The Associated Black Charities, comprising 59 health and service groups, is holding a Black History Makers Award and Benefit Concert to honor Marian Anderson and other leading figures.
The event opens with a cocktail party from 6 to 7:30 P.M.

LEAD: ''From our point of view, there were five main targets.
The American Embassy was one of them.''
Col. Do Tan Phong,  a Vietcong commander  in the Tet offensive in 1968.  [ 1:2. ]

Miss Minnesota-U.S.A. Held On a Charge of Shoplifting
LEAD: Miss Minnesota-U.S.A. was arrested on a gross misdemeanor theft charge after a security guard at a department store here told police she was shoplifting, City Attorney Marsh Halberg said today.


KNICKS ROAD WOES GROW IN OVERTIME
LEAD: Sedale Threatt's basket from the right of the key with 55 seconds remaining in overtime tonight enabled the Chicago Bulls to defeat the Knicks, 97-95.
The loss extended the Knicks' road-game losing streak to 15; they have lost 20 of the last 21 on the road.

Tensions Grow When the Prize Is the Next Presidency
LEAD: As he briefed reporters before the State of the Union address last Monday night, Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, insisted that President Reagan ''is very mindful of the fact that he was elected for eight years, not seven years.''


NONFICTION
LEAD:  COVENANT HOUSE: Lifeline to the Street.
By Bruce Ritter. (Doubleday, $16.95.) This book is a selection of epistles - monthly newsletters-cum-fundraising appeals - issued from Times Square.
The Rev.
Bruce Ritter is a remarkable Roman Catholic missionary to the runaway, castoff and abused street kids drawn into drugs and prostitution.

On New Issues
LEAD: To the Editor:


Correction
LEAD: Because of incorrect information provided by WNET, a picture on the first page of The Guide for Jan. 17 misidentified a performer in Benjamin Britten's ''Turn of the Screw.'' The woman pictured is Magdalena Vasaroya, who plays the role of the governess; the character's singing voice is that of Helen Donas.


PUTTING A CONSERVATION PLAN TO WORK
LEAD: THE National Fish and Wildlife Foundation is helping to implement the North American Waterfowl Management Plan, an ambitious and much-needed cooperative agreement that this country and Canada signed in 1986 but for which no funds were allocated.


Key Matchups For Broncos
LEAD: Dave Studdard, Broncos' offensive tackle, versus Dexter Manley, Redskins' defensive end - Manley is coming on after a sluggish season during which he had 8 1/2 sacks.
However, if he keeps his composure, he is the quickest and most dangerous pass rusher in this game, and he can disrupt an offense.
Studdard is not as skilled as Manley.


Bulgaria Planning Value Tax
LEAD: Bulgaria plans to introduce a Western-style value-added tax to accompany major increases in prices, a leading Communist Party official said today.
But the official, Emil Christov, a Central Committee Secretary, promised that wages would keep pace with the price rises.


SMALL-TOWN BENEFITS OF NEIGHBORS OUTWEIGH INCONVENIENCES
LEAD: THE bell rang as I was preparing dinner, and I wiped my hands on my apron and opened the door.
A golden-haired moppet of about 7 piped sweetly, ''Would you like to buy cookies for my Brownie troop?''


CHRISTIE WILLIAMS PLANS TO BE WED TO CATE MOFFETT
LEAD: The engagement of Mary Catherine Moffett to Christie Max Williams, a son of Ann L. Williams of Los Angeles and Robert C. Williams of Spencerville, Ontario, has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs.
William W. Moffett of Mystic, Conn.
A May wedding is planned.


Food Inspection Results
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 32 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

Balsamic Vinegar
LEAD: To the Editor: The article on Balsamic vinegar by Anne Marshall Zwack (Travel, Jan. 3) left out an important bit of information for your readers.


THE MANY WAYS OF USING VERSATILE NUTS
LEAD: RECORD crops of nuts, especially walnuts and almonds, were harvested this fall in California, according to the Department of Agriculture.
This volume is good news for consumers.
Wholesale prices for walnuts are below last year's levels and almond production was more than double last year with prices also lower.


Reagan Presses Case for Aid to Nicaragua Rebels
LEAD: President Reagan said today that while the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua had made limited concessions toward greater democracy, continued military pressure by the contras was necessary to continue that progress.


Noah's Ark: The Sequel
LEAD: IT MAY SEEM WILDLY FUTURISTIC, but the whole idea actually recalls Noah's Ark.
Biosphere II, a completely enclosed, 2.25-acre, self-supporting ecosystem designed to accommodate plant, animal and human life, has been in the works since 1984 near Tucson, Ariz.
Supporters see the project as a hedge against the eventual extinction of life on Earth (aka, Biosphere I), as well as a step toward colonization of the Moon and Mars.

Dubious Tactics: F.B.I. Again Called Lax On Liberties
LEAD: As they pored over newly declassified documents last week, members of civil liberties groups wondered how much of the spirit of J. Edgar Hoover - a spirit that several successors have tried to exorcise since he died in 1972 - survives at the Federal Bureau of Investigation.


IT'S NEVER TOO EARLY TO PROTECT THE SHORE
LEAD: BETWEEN winter storm warnings and people wondering whether they can get one more season out of the brown overcoat, thoughts of the Jersey Shore are scarce.
Except in the State House.


Bernice Franklin; Nursing Supervisor, 79
LEAD: Bernice Franklin, a retired supervisor of pediatric nursing at New York Hospital, died of complications arising from Alzheimer's disease Tuesday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 79 years old.
Mrs.
Franklin was associated with New York Hospital for four years, retiring in 1940.
Earlier, she worked for the Nursery and Child's Hospital, which has since closed, on the West Side of


On Language; Grovel, Grovel, Grovel
LEAD: FIRST OFF, I OWE AN apology to Mikhail Gorbachev, author of ''Perestroika,'' whose book tour recently included a stop in Washington. (Why first off? Why not just first? Because I am being determinedly colloquial, and it's better than the awkward firstly.) With a loud ''Ah-hah!'', I quoted an anonymous refusenik catching the Soviet General Secretary using a Russian word that was kind of an insult to President Reagan.


ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. I have a chair whose frame is made of white plastic that has discolored to an uneven beige.
Yet a painted metal brace is still white.
Is there any way to clean or bleach the plastic, or is there a white paint I can apply?


Sports of The Times; The Fabric of the Old-Boy Network
LEAD: SOME in the so-called news media have come to refer to Pete Rozelle's annual Super Bowl news conference - No.
XXII was held here on Friday - as a state of the union address.
That's the last thing it is.
It is, in fact, a state of management address.


SATELLITE MAP CENTER PLANNED
LEAD: RUTGERS UNIVERSITY'S department of environmental resources, which makes maps from satellite photographs for the state, has received a $10 million grant from the university's board of governors and plans to build a state-of-the-art center here on the campus.


WHY WE MUST INTEGRATE OUR SCHOOLS
LEAD: I WOULD like to summarize several points about the State Department of Education report on racial integration in our public schools that was presented to the State Board of Education earlier this month.
The report raises fundamental issues about excellence and equity in education, and a review of the facts helps brings the report and its goals into clear focus.


TRAVEL ADVISORY
LEAD: Fare Tactics For Visitors To Australia


Question Of the Week; WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL?
LEAD: The Washington Redskins will triumph.
The tremendous dependence of the Bronco team on John Elway will allow the Redskin defense to focus chiefly on his activities.
This will result in the sharpening of the Redskin play as the game winds down, culminating in an exciting final two minutes, in which the Redskin defense will frustrate the Bronco offense.


At the Trade Talks, America Must Lead
LEAD: NEXT month, the 95 members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade will reconvene in their Geneva headquarters to begin the second year of negotiations on revisions of world trade rules.
Watched with a good deal of fanfare in the fall of 1986 in Punta del Este, Uruguay, these negotiations are scheduled to end in 1990.

CELEBRITY MATCHMAKER: Marty Blackman Marrying Athletes and Endorsements
LEAD: The advertising agency executive, Marty Blackman recalled, was frantic.
He had just heard a rumor that a former football star serving as a spokesman for his client, a major soft drink company, was gay.
He wanted Mr.
Blackman to find out whether it was true.

PUTTING THE SHELTER INTO PERSPECTIVE
LEAD: In response to ''Homeless Should Live Such a Dog's Life,''  [ Letters to the Westchester Editor, Jan. 10 ] , it is clear to see that the writer is a self-proclaimed animal lover but not a lover of animals.


Going On in the Northeast
LEAD:  FRONTIER ARTISTS


Killings Laid to India Rebels
LEAD: Tribal rebels were blamed for the shooting deaths of 30 people in four attacks in northeastern Tripura state, the United News of India said today.
The authorities said the Tribal National Volunteers, an outlawed group seeking a separate state, was responsible for the killings Friday, the Government-run news agency said.

LEAD:  THE BOOK AND THE BROTHERHOOD  By Iris Murdoch. 607 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.


RANGERS EXTEND ROAD STREAK TO 3
LEAD: Playing again with minimum mistakes, the Rangers beat the Bruins, 4-2, today at the Boston Garden where the Bruins had compiled a .640 winning percentage this season.


A HOME AUDIO SYSTEM FINDS BUYERS AT $50,000
LEAD: ''GO ahead and turn the knob all the way to the right, then all the way back,'' said Mark Levinson, as he twirled a burnished aluminum dial.
The soprano voice coming from two sets of stereo speakers shot to singularly clear high-range notes.
He adjusted five other knobs, muting some sounds and bringing life to others.


CHALK UP ANOTHER ONE FOR THE BRITISH
LEAD: THE current fascination with all things British has certainly left its mark on well-dressed Americans.
Take the chalk-striped suit, for instance.
While it has never exactly disappeared from wardrobes on this side of the Atlantic, these days it seems to be asserting itself with a vengeance.
